Amiodarone-Induced Myxoedema Coma: A Case with Favorable Outcome. A 62-year-old male developed bradycardia, hypothermia, and respiratory failure three weeks following amiodarone initiation for atrial fibrillation. Laboratory tests revealed a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 168 uIU/mL (normal range: 0.3-5 uIU/mL) and free thyroxine (FT4) <0.2 ng/dL (normal range: 0.8-1.8 ng/dL). The patient received intravenous fluids, vasopressor support, stress-dose steroids, was intubated, and admitted to the intensive care unit. Intravenous levothyroxine was administered as 500 ug initially over 18 hours, followed by 150 ug daily. Within 48 hours, hemodynamic stability and full mental status recovery were observed. Twelve hours into therapy, FT4 reached 0.96 ng/dL. Maintenance involved oral levothyroxine 175 ug daily. Thyroid ultrasound demonstrated diffuse heterogeneity, and 24-hour iodine excretion was 3657 mcg (normal: 25-756 mcg). Previous literature documents only two cases of amiodarone-induced myxoedema coma, both resulting in patient demise despite treatment. This report details the most extensively investigated instance of amiodarone-induced myxoedema coma, notably occurring in a patient with a history of subclinical thyroid dysfunction.

Amiodarone-Induced Myxoedema Coma: Clinical Presentation and Successful Outcome. We report the case of a 62-year-old man who presented with bradycardia, hypothermia, and respiratory failure three weeks after starting amiodarone for atrial fibrillation. Diagnostic evaluation revealed significantly elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) at 168 uIU/mL (reference: 0.3-5 uIU/mL) and markedly suppressed free thyroxine (FT4) at <0.2 ng/dL (reference: 0.8-1.8 ng/dL). Management included aggressive supportive care with intravenous fluids, vasopressors, and stress-dose steroids, necessitating intubation and ICU admission. Thyroid hormone replacement commenced with 500 ug intravenous levothyroxine over the initial 18 hours, followed by 150 ug intravenously daily. A rapid clinical response was observed, with hemodynamic stability and complete restoration of mental status within 48 hours. Twelve hours after initiating therapy, FT4 levels rose to 0.96 ng/dL. The patient was subsequently maintained on 175 ug oral levothyroxine daily. Further workup included a thyroid ultrasound showing diffuse heterogeneity and a 24-hour urinary iodine excretion of 3657 mcg (normal: 25-756 mcg). This extensively documented case of amiodarone-induced myxoedema coma, occurring in a patient with pre-existing subclinical thyroid disease, is notable as the prior two reported cases in literature both resulted in mortality despite intervention.

Comprehensive Investigation and Survival in Amiodarone-Induced Myxoedema Coma. This case distinguishes itself as the most thoroughly investigated instance of amiodarone-induced myxoedema coma, particularly given the patient's history of subclinical thyroid disease, and stands in contrast to the two prior literature reports, both of which described patient mortality despite therapeutic efforts.

Amiodarone-Induced Myxoedema Coma: A Thoroughly Documented Recovery. This report details the most extensively investigated case of amiodarone-induced myxoedema coma, distinguishing it from the only two previously documented cases, both of which reported patient death despite similar supportive and thyroid hormone replacement therapies. The patients history of subclinical thyroid disease is a notable contributing factor.

Dexmedetomidine's Cardiac Protective Effects in Non-Cardiac Surgery: A Meta-Analysis of Randomised Controlled Trials. This systematic review investigated the impact of dexmedetomidine on cardiac endpoints following non-cardiac surgical procedures. We selected prospective, randomised peri-operative studies that reported on patient mortality, cardiac morbidity, or adverse drug reactions. Searches were performed on PubMed Central and EMBASE up to July 2007, supplemented by examining reference lists of relevant articles. Out of 425 identified studies, 20 trials involving 840 patients were incorporated into the meta-analysis. Dexmedetomidine demonstrated a tendency towards better cardiac outcomes, specifically for all-cause mortality (OR 0.27, 95% CI 0.01-7.13, p = 0.44), non-fatal myocardial infarction (OR 0.26, 95% CI 0.04-1.60, p = 0.14), and myocardial ischaemia (OR 0.65, 95% CI 0.26-1.63, p = 0.36). Conversely, peri-operative hypotension (26%, OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.91-7.54, p = 0.0001) and bradycardia (17%, OR 5.45, 95% CI 2.98-9.95, p < 0.00001) were significantly more frequent. Administration of an anticholinergic did not mitigate the incidence of bradycardia (p = 0.43). The findings suggest the need for a randomised placebo-controlled trial of dexmedetomidine.

The Impact of Dexmedetomidine on Cardiac Protection During Non-Cardiac Surgery: A Meta-Analysis of Randomised Controlled Trials. We systematically reviewed the influence of dexmedetomidine on cardiac outcomes after non-cardiac surgery. Prospective, randomised peri-operative studies were included if they reported mortality, cardiac morbidity, or adverse drug events. An extensive search on PubMed Central and EMBASE, active until July 2007, was conducted, with further trials identified from reference lists. From 425 initial studies, 20 were selected for meta-analysis, encompassing 840 patients. Dexmedetomidine showed a trend of improving cardiac outcomes, specifically for all-cause mortality (OR 0.27, 95% CI 0.01-7.13, p = 0.44), non-fatal myocardial infarction (OR 0.26, 95% CI 0.04-1.60, p = 0.14), and myocardial ischaemia (OR 0.65, 95% CI 0.26-1.63, p = 0.36). However, peri-operative hypotension (26%, OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.91-7.54, p = 0.0001) and bradycardia (17%, OR 5.45, 95% CI 2.98-9.95, p < 0.00001) significantly increased. An anticholinergic agent did not diminish the occurrence of bradycardia (p = 0.43). A new randomised placebo-controlled trial of dexmedetomidine is thus warranted.

Cardiac Protection with Dexmedetomidine in Non-Cardiac Surgery: A Meta-Analysis of Randomised Controlled Trials. Conversely, peri-operative hypotension (26%, OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.91-7.54, p = 0.0001) and bradycardia (17%, OR 5.45, 95% CI 2.98-9.95, p < 0.00001) were significantly elevated. An anticholinergic failed to reduce the incidence of bradycardia (p = 0.43). Consequently, a randomised placebo-controlled trial for dexmedetomidine is justified.

However, peri-operative hypotension (26%, OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.91-7.54, p = 0.0001) and bradycardia (17%, OR 5.45, 95% CI 2.98-9.95, p < 0.00001) were significantly augmented. The administration of an anticholinergic did not decrease the frequency of bradycardia (p = 0.43). Therefore, a randomised placebo-controlled investigation of dexmedetomidine is advisable.

Severe adverse drug reactions from concurrent beta-blocker and verapamil administration: three case reports. In three patients diagnosed with ischaemic heart disease, severe cardiac failure, hypotension, and bradycardia manifested during concurrent therapeutic regimens of verapamil and beta-adrenergic blocking agents. Complete resolution of these clinical symptoms occurred upon discontinuation of the combined treatment. Baseline left ventricular function, evaluated via cardiac catheterisation or nuclear angiography, was preserved in two individuals and only slightly impaired in the third. The simultaneous prescription of beta-adrenergic blocking drugs and verapamil has the potential to induce significant adverse interactions and, therefore, mandates extreme caution in its application.

Serious cardiovascular complications associated with concomitant beta-blocker and verapamil therapy: three case presentations. Three individuals with ischaemic heart disease experienced severe cardiac decompensation, low blood pressure, and slow heart rate while receiving concomitant therapy involving verapamil and beta-adrenergic blocking drugs. The complete resolution of these symptoms was observed following the cessation of the combined drug regimen. Baseline assessments of left ventricular function, performed using cardiac catheterisation or nuclear angiography, showed normality in two patients and only minor impairment in one. The simultaneous administration of beta-adrenergic blocking drugs and verapamil carries a risk of inducing serious adverse interactions and should thus be managed with considerable prudence.

Hazardous interactions of combined beta-adrenergic blockers and verapamil: a three-case series. Profound cardiac failure, hypotension, and bradycardia developed in three patients with ischaemic heart disease receiving a combined therapeutic approach of verapamil and beta-adrenergic blocking agents. Discontinuation of this combined therapy led to a complete reversal of the clinical manifestations. Baseline left ventricular function, determined through cardiac catheterisation or nuclear angiography, was found to be normal in two patients and mildly diminished in one. The combined use of beta-adrenergic blocking drugs and verapamil has the potential for severe adverse interactions and necessitates extreme circumspection during administration.

Cardiac adverse events with dual beta-adrenergic blocker and verapamil therapy: three case examples. These severe clinical signs completely resolved upon the cessation of the dual therapy. Assessment of baseline left ventricular function, conducted via cardiac catheterisation or nuclear angiography, revealed normal function in two patients and only a slight reduction in the third. Concurrent administration of beta-adrenergic blocking drugs and verapamil may precipitate significant adverse events and must therefore be approached with utmost caution.

Pentamidine-Induced Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: A Case Series and Comprehensive Review. Pentamidine isethionate has been linked to ventricular tachyarrhythmias, notably torsade de pointes. This article presents two instances of this complication and summarizes all previously documented cases to date. The development of pentamidine-induced torsade de pointes may correlate with serum magnesium concentrations, with hypomagnesemia potentially acting synergistically. Torsade de pointes manifested following an average of ten days of pentamidine therapy. These patients experienced no other acute adverse effects attributable to pentamidine. Prompt recognition of torsade de pointes allows for effective treatment, potentially without discontinuing the medication. When QTc interval prolongation is detected, early magnesium supplementation is recommended.

Pentamidine and Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: Updating the Clinical Evidence. Ventricular tachyarrhythmias, including torsade de pointes, are known associations of pentamidine isethionate. Two instances of this complication are documented here, alongside a review of all historical case reports. A potential link between pentamidine-induced torsade de pointes and serum magnesium levels exists, with hypomagnesemia possibly acting as a synergistic factor. The onset of torsade de pointes typically occurred after approximately 10 days of pentamidine administration. These specific patients did not exhibit other acute adverse reactions to pentamidine. Early detection of torsade de pointes enables successful intervention, conceivably without halting pentamidine treatment. In cases where QTc interval prolongation is observed, proactive magnesium supplementation is advised.

The occurrence of pentamidine-elicited torsade de pointes may be linked to serum magnesium concentrations, with hypomagnesemia potentially exacerbating the risk. On average, torsade de pointes developed after 10 days of pentamidine therapy. No other acute side effects of pentamidine were noted in these individuals. Prompt identification of torsade de pointes facilitates its management, potentially without discontinuation of pentamidine. If QTc interval prolongation is observed, early magnesium supplementation is strongly recommended.

Insights into Pentamidine-Induced Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: A Case Series and Clinical Summary. This article presents two novel instances of this complication and compiles an analysis of all prior reported cases. The etiology of pentamidine-induced torsade de pointes may involve serum magnesium levels, with hypomagnesemia potentially contributing synergistically to its induction. Torsade de pointes manifested, on average, after a 10-day course of pentamidine treatment. Notably, no other acute adverse reactions to pentamidine were observed in these patients. Timely recognition of torsade de pointes allows for effective therapeutic intervention, potentially obviating the need to cease pentamidine. The recommendation is for early magnesium supplementation upon detection of QTc interval prolongation.

A Family Investigation of Complement Factor 2 Deficiency: Clinical and Serological Findings. Inherited deficiencies in the complement system are frequently associated with various connective tissue disorders. This report details a family with an inherited complement factor 2 (C2) deficiency, where two homozygous individuals presented with cutaneous vasculitis and sicca syndrome. The heterozygous family members were uniformly found to possess the HLA-A25, B18, DR2(w15) haplotype. The mother, a heterozygote, was diagnosed with seropositive rheumatoid arthritis. Subsequent investigations revealed the presence of cryoglobulins, anti-endothelial cell antibodies, and anticardiolipin antibodies.

Other family members, presenting with heterozygous C2 deficiency, each exhibited the HLA-A25, B18, DR2(w15) haplotype. Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis was observed in the mother. Further analyses demonstrated the existence of cryoglobulins, antibodies targeting endothelial cells, and anticardiolipin antibodies.

Assessment of side effects associated with apraclonidine hydrochloride ophthalmic solution. This prospective study evaluated apraclonidine's adverse reactions in 20 healthy volunteers. A single 1% apraclonidine drop was instilled into their right eyes. Parameters including blood pressure, pulse rate, conjunctiva, cornea, intraocular pressure (IOP), pupil diameter, basal tear secretion, and eyelid margin reflex distance were measured before and at 1, 3, 5, and 7 hours post-instillation. Statistically significant ocular hypotensive effects were observed in treated eyes throughout the study and in contralateral eyes from three hours post-topical administration. A statistically, but not clinically, significant decrease in systolic blood pressure occurred. Diastolic blood pressure, pulse rate, and basal tear secretion showed no significant changes. Conjunctival blanching and mydriasis were common findings, as was frequent upper lid retraction. While most subjects experienced upper lid elevation of less than 2 mm without noticeable cosmetic changes, one individual developed mechanical entropion and severe corneal abrasion three hours after drug administration. This specific observation may be particularly relevant in individuals of Asian ethnicity.

Safety profile of apraclonidine hydrochloride ophthalmic solution: Adverse event analysis. We conducted a prospective analysis to determine the adverse events of apraclonidine. Twenty normal volunteers received a single 1% apraclonidine drop in their right eye. Examinations, including assessments of blood pressure, pulse rate, conjunctiva, cornea, intraocular pressure (IOP), pupil diameter, basal tear secretion, and the margin reflex distance of both upper and lower eyelids, were performed at baseline and at 1, 3, 5, and 7 hours after instillation. Significant ocular hypotensive effects were consistently noted in apraclonidine-treated eyes, and also in contralateral eyes starting three hours after topical application of 1% apraclonidine. Systolic blood pressure reductions were statistically significant, yet lacked clinical significance. No significant alterations were detected in diastolic blood pressure, pulse rate, or basal tear secretion. Conjunctival blanching and mydriasis were frequently observed. Upper lid retraction was also a common finding. Although upper eyelid margin elevations in most participants did not exceed 2 mm and did not noticeably alter appearance, one participant experienced mechanical entropion and substantial corneal abrasion 3 hours post-instillation. This finding may hold particular significance for Asian populations.

While upper lid margin elevations were generally minor (not exceeding 2 mm) and did not noticeably affect appearance in most subjects, one subject developed mechanical entropion and severe corneal abrasion three hours post-medication instillation. This specific observation may be especially pertinent to individuals of Asian descent.

Direct Cardiac HCN Pacemaker Channel Inhibition by Clonidine. BACKGROUND: Inhibiting cardiac sympathetic activity is a vital strategy for managing cardiovascular conditions such as arrhythmias, coronary heart disease, and chronic heart failure. While clonidine, an antisympathetic agent, is primarily understood to act via presynaptic alpha2-adrenoceptor activation, the involvement of other target proteins in its in vivo effects has been proposed. METHODS AND RESULTS: To investigate clonidine's pharmacological effects independently of alpha2-adrenoceptors, we developed mice with a targeted deletion of all three alpha2-adrenoceptor subtypes (alpha2ABC-/-). Although alpha2ABC-/- mice were entirely unresponsive to clonidine's analgesic and hypnotic properties, clonidine significantly lowered their heart rate by up to 150 bpm. The clonidine-induced bradycardia in conscious alpha2ABC-/- mice represented 32.3% (at 10 microg/kg) and 26.6% (at 100 microg/kg) of the effect observed in wild-type mice. A similar bradycardic response to clonidine was observed in isolated, spontaneously beating right atria from both alpha2ABC-knockout and wild-type animals. Clonidine also inhibited the native pacemaker current (I(f)) in isolated sinoatrial node pacemaker cells, as well as the I(f)-generating hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) 2 and HCN4 channels in transfected HEK293 cells. Consequently, by blocking I(f), clonidine decreased the slope of diastolic depolarization and the frequency of pacemaker potentials in sinoatrial node cells from both wild-type and alpha2ABC-knockout mice. CONCLUSIONS: Direct inhibition of cardiac HCN pacemaker channels contributes to the bradycardic effects of clonidine in vivo in gene-targeted mice, suggesting clonidine-like compounds as potential novel structures for future HCN channel inhibitors.

Clonidine as a Direct Inhibitor of Cardiac Hyperpolarization-Activated Cyclic Nucleotide-Gated Pacemaker Channels. BACKGROUND: Suppressing cardiac sympathetic tone is a crucial therapeutic approach for cardiovascular ailments, including cardiac arrhythmias, coronary artery disease, and chronic heart failure. The primary mechanism attributed to the antisympathetic drug clonidine involves activating presynaptic alpha2-adrenoceptors; however, the contribution of other protein targets to clonidine's physiological actions has been hypothesized. METHODS AND RESULTS: To ascertain if clonidine exerts pharmacological effects independent of alpha2-adrenoceptors, mice lacking all three alpha2-adrenoceptor subtypes (alpha2ABC-/-) were engineered. While these alpha2ABC-/- mice showed no response to the analgesic and hypnotic effects of clonidine, the drug markedly reduced their heart rate, by as much as 150 bpm. In conscious alpha2ABC-/- mice, the clonidine-induced bradycardia accounted for 32.3% (10 microg/kg) and 26.6% (100 microg/kg) of the effect seen in wild-type counterparts. A comparable bradycardic action of clonidine was observed in spontaneously beating right atria isolated from both alpha2ABC-knockout and wild-type mice. Clonidine was found to inhibit the native pacemaker current (I(f)) in isolated sinoatrial node pacemaker cells and also the I(f)-producing hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) 2 and HCN4 channels when expressed in HEK293 cells. This I(f) blockade by clonidine subsequently led to a reduction in the slope of diastolic depolarization and the rate of pacemaker potentials in sinoatrial node cells from both wild-type and alpha2ABC-knockout mice. CONCLUSIONS: The direct inhibition of cardiac HCN pacemaker channels plays a role in the in vivo bradycardic effects of clonidine in gene-targeted mice, thereby identifying clonidine-like molecules as promising scaffolds for novel HCN channel inhibitors.

A similar clonidine-induced bradycardia was evident in isolated, spontaneously beating right atria from both alpha2ABC-knockout and wild-type animals. Furthermore, clonidine directly inhibited the native pacemaker current (I(f)) in isolated sinoatrial node pacemaker cells, as well as the I(f)-generating hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) 2 and HCN4 channels when expressed in transfected HEK293 cells. This I(f) blockade resulted in clonidine reducing the slope of the diastolic depolarization and the frequency of pacemaker potentials in sinoatrial node cells from both wild-type and alpha2ABC-knockout mice. CONCLUSIONS: The direct inhibition of cardiac HCN pacemaker channels significantly contributes to the in vivo bradycardic effects of clonidine in genetically modified mice, positioning clonidine-like compounds as new templates for future HCN channel inhibitors.

Clonidine Directly Inhibits Cardiac Hyperpolarization-Activated Cyclic Nucleotide-Gated Pacemaker Channels. BACKGROUND: Reducing cardiac sympathetic activity represents an important therapeutic approach for various cardiovascular conditions, including cardiac arrhythmias, coronary artery disease, and chronic heart failure. While the antisympathetic drug clonidine is primarily known to act by activating presynaptic alpha2-adrenoceptors, the involvement of other protein targets in its systemic effects has been hypothesized. METHODS AND RESULTS: To investigate whether clonidine exerts pharmacological effects without involving alpha2-adrenoceptors, we created mice with a targeted deletion of all three alpha2-adrenoceptor subtypes (alpha2ABC-/-). These alpha2ABC-/- mice displayed complete unresponsiveness to clonidine's analgesic and hypnotic effects; nevertheless, clonidine notably lowered their heart rate, achieving reductions of up to 150 bpm. In conscious alpha2ABC-/- mice, the clonidine-induced bradycardia represented 32.3% (at 10 microg/kg) and 26.6% (at 100 microg/kg) of the effect observed in wild-type animals. A comparable bradycardic effect of clonidine was also noted in isolated, spontaneously beating right atria derived from both alpha2ABC-knockout and wild-type mice. Clonidine was found to inhibit the native pacemaker current (I(f)) in isolated sinoatrial node pacemaker cells, and furthermore, it inhibited the I(f)-generating hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) 2 and HCN4 channels in transfected HEK293 cells. This block of I(f) by clonidine subsequently led to a decrease in the slope of the diastolic depolarization and the frequency of pacemaker potentials in sinoatrial node cells from both wild-type and alpha2ABC-knockout mice. CONCLUSIONS: The direct inhibition of cardiac HCN pacemaker channels substantially contributes to the in vivo bradycardic actions of clonidine in gene-targeted mice, suggesting clonidine and its analogs as promising candidates for novel HCN channel inhibitors.

The Impact of Intravenous Metoprolol, Alone or with Glucagon, on Dobutamine-Induced Myocardial Ischemia. This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, conducted in a community hospital, aimed to determine the effect of metoprolol on dobutamine stress testing, incorporating technetium-99m sestamibi single-photon emission computed tomography imaging and ST-segment monitoring, and to assess the influence of intravenous glucagon on metoprolol's actions. The study enrolled 22 patients with documented reversible perfusion defects. Standard dobutamine stress tests were performed. During the initial visit, no therapy was administered prior to dobutamine; for subsequent visits, patients were randomized to receive either intravenous metoprolol or intravenous metoprolol combined with 1 mg of glucagon. Metoprolol was titrated to achieve a resting predobutamine heart rate below 65 beats/minute or a total intravenous dose of 20 mg. Metoprolol alone significantly reduced maximum heart rate by 31%, summed stress scores by 29%, and summed difference scores by 43% compared to control. The combination of metoprolol and glucagon also decreased maximum heart rate by 29% versus control, but summed stress and summed difference scores, although 18% and 30% lower respectively than control, were not significantly reduced. No significant disparities were observed in any parameter between the metoprolol and metoprolol-glucagon groups. In conclusion, metoprolol attenuates or eliminates evidence of myocardial ischemia during dobutamine stress testing. Glucagon 1 mg, while demonstrating some effectiveness, does not correct this effect sufficiently for clinical administration.

Evaluation of Intravenous Metoprolol and Metoprolol-Glucagon in Mitigating Dobutamine-Induced Myocardial Ischemia. The primary objective of this study was to ascertain the effect of metoprolol on dobutamine stress testing, monitored by technetium-99m sestamibi single-photon emission computed tomography imaging and ST-segment changes, and to investigate the contribution of intravenous glucagon to metoprolol's observed effects. This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was carried out in a community hospital, involving 22 patients who had known reversible perfusion defects. Patients underwent dobutamine stress tests according to a standard protocol. No therapy was provided before dobutamine during the first visit, and patients were subsequently randomized to receive either metoprolol or metoprolol plus 1 mg glucagon intravenously. Metoprolol dosage aimed to achieve a resting predobutamine heart rate under 65 beats/minute or a maximum total intravenous dose of 20 mg. Main results revealed that metoprolol significantly lowered maximum heart rate by 31%, summed stress scores by 29%, and summed difference scores by 43% when contrasted with the control group. Metoprolol plus glucagon also reduced maximum heart rate by 29% compared to control, yet summed stress and summed difference scores, despite being 18% and 30% lower than control respectively, did not show statistically significant reductions. Furthermore, no significant differences were detected in any parameter between the metoprolol and metoprolol-glucagon interventions. Consequently, metoprolol attenuates or eliminates evidence of myocardial ischemia during dobutamine stress testing. Although 1 mg of glucagon proved somewhat effective, it fails to correct this effect to an extent suitable for clinical administration.

Anorexigen Use and Pulmonary Hypertension in North America: A Surveillance Study. BACKGROUND: The development of primary pulmonary hypertension (PPH) has been linked to appetite suppressant use in Europe. In the United States, fenfluramine appetite suppressants became widespread but were withdrawn in September 1997 due to safety concerns. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted a prospective surveillance study of patients diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension at 12 major North American referral centers. Data collected from September 1, 1996, to December 31, 1997, included the etiology and severity of pulmonary hypertension. Patients without an identifiable cause were classified as PPH. A history of drug exposure, specifically for antidepressants, anorexigens, and amphetamines, was also obtained. RESULTS: Of the 579 patients studied, 205 presented with PPH and 374 with secondary pulmonary hypertension (SPH). Anorexigen use was prevalent in both groups. However, among the surveyed medications, only fenfluramines demonstrated a significant preferential association with PPH compared to SPH (adjusted odds ratio for use exceeding 6 months, 7.5; 95% confidence interval, 1.7 to 32.4). The strength of this association increased with longer duration of use and was more pronounced in recent users. Furthermore, a notable 11.4% of SPH patients reported anorexigen use. CONCLUSION: The significant magnitude, duration-dependent increase, and fenfluramine-specific nature of this association with PPH are consistent with prior studies suggesting a causal link between fenfluramines and PPH. The high prevalence of anorexigen use in SPH patients additionally raises the possibility that these drugs may precipitate pulmonary hypertension in individuals with pre-existing conditions.

The Relationship Between Anorexigen Exposure and Pulmonary Hypertension: Insights from a US Surveillance Program. BACKGROUND: Appetite suppressant use in Europe has been associated with primary pulmonary hypertension (PPH). Fenfluramine appetite suppressants gained widespread use in the United States but were withdrawn in September 1997 due to concerns regarding adverse effects. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A prospective surveillance study was performed on patients diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension at 12 large referral centers across North America. Data collected between September 1, 1996, and December 31, 1997, encompassed the cause and severity of pulmonary hypertension. Patients with no identifiable cause were categorized as PPH. Information on drug exposure, particularly to antidepressants, anorexigens, and amphetamines, was also gathered. RESULTS: The study involved 579 patients, comprising 205 with PPH and 374 with secondary pulmonary hypertension (SPH). Anorexigen use was frequently observed in both cohorts. Nevertheless, among the medications investigated, only the fenfluramines showed a statistically significant preferential association with PPH versus SPH (adjusted odds ratio for use exceeding 6 months: 7.5; 95% confidence interval, 1.7 to 32.4). This association intensified with prolonged usage and was more evident in recent users than in remote users. Notably, 11.4% of SPH patients reported a history of anorexigen use. CONCLUSION: The observed strong association with PPH, its augmentation with increased duration of use, and its specificity for fenfluramines are consistent with previous research indicating a causal relationship between fenfluramines and PPH. The high prevalence of anorexigen use among patients with SPH also suggests these drugs may precipitate pulmonary hypertension in individuals with underlying predisposing conditions.

Drug-Induced Pulmonary Hypertension in the United States: A Surveillance of Anorexigen Use. BACKGROUND: Primary pulmonary hypertension has been associated with appetite suppressant use in Europe, leading to concerns in the US where fenfluramines were extensively used before their withdrawal in September 1997 due to safety issues. MATERIALS AND METHODS: A prospective surveillance study was conducted at 12 prominent North American referral centers. Patient data, including PH etiology and severity, were collected from September 1, 1996, to December 31, 1997. Cases of PH without an identifiable cause were classified as PPH. Detailed histories of exposure to drugs, particularly anorexigens, antidepressants, and amphetamines, were recorded. RESULTS: Of 579 patients analyzed, 205 had PPH and 374 had SPH. Anorexigen use was prevalent in both groups. However, among the medications assessed, only fenfluramines exhibited a statistically significant and preferential association with PPH compared to SPH (adjusted odds ratio for use exceeding 6 months: 7.5; 95% confidence interval, 1.7 to 32.4). This association intensified with prolonged usage and was more pronounced in recent users. Notably, 11.4% of SPH patients also reported anorexigen use. CONCLUSION: The substantial and duration-dependent association, along with the specificity to fenfluramines, corroborates prior research on the causal relationship between fenfluramines and PPH. The high incidence of anorexigen use among SPH patients also suggests these agents might contribute to PH development in individuals with predisposing underlying conditions.

Assessing Anorexigen-Related Pulmonary Hypertension Risk in the United States: North American Surveillance Findings. BACKGROUND: The link between European appetite suppressants and primary pulmonary hypertension (PPH) raised concerns, especially after fenfluramines saw widespread use and subsequent withdrawal in the United States in September 1997 due to adverse effect concerns. RESULTS: The study cohort comprised 579 patients: 205 with PPH and 374 with secondary pulmonary hypertension (SPH). This association was found to be stronger with increased duration of use and in more recent users. An unexpected 11.4% of SPH patients also reported anorexigen use. CONCLUSION: The strong magnitude, dose-response relationship, and fenfluramine specificity of the observed association with PPH are consistent with previous studies, reinforcing a causal link between fenfluramines and PPH. The considerable prevalence of anorexigen use in SPH patients further implies a potential for these drugs to precipitate pulmonary hypertension in individuals already possessing underlying conditions.

The Impact of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure on Pulmonary Shunt and Cardiovascular Parameters during Nitroprusside-Induced Hypotension. An investigation was conducted into the influence of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on cardiovascular dynamics and pulmonary shunt (QS/QT) in 12 canine subjects. Observations were made both prior to and during an infusion of sodium nitroprusside, which induced a 40-50 percent reduction in mean arterial blood pressure. Pre-nitroprusside, 5 cm H2O CPAP led to a statistically significant reduction (P < .05) in arterial blood pressure, but did not significantly modify heart rate, cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance, or QS/QT. Application of 10 cm H2O CPAP before nitroprusside infusion further diminished arterial blood pressure, while concurrently increasing heart rate and decreasing both cardiac output and QS/QT significantly. Nitroprusside alone resulted in significant decreases in arterial blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance, alongside increases in heart rate, yet cardiac output and QS/QT remained unchanged. During nitroprusside administration, 5 cm H2O CPAP caused no additional alterations to these variables. However, 10 cm H2O CPAP during nitroprusside decreased arterial blood pressure, cardiac output, and QS/QT. These findings indicate that nitroprusside infusion rates sufficient to reduce mean arterial blood pressure by 40-50 percent do not affect cardiac output or QS/QT. Furthermore, during nitroprusside, modest CPAP levels have minimal impact on cardiovascular dynamics, whereas elevated CPAP levels (10 cm H2O), while reducing QS/QT, cause substantial reductions in arterial blood pressure and cardiac output.

Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Shunt Responses to Continuous Positive Airway Pressure in Hypotensive States Induced by Nitroprusside. We examined the effects of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on cardiovascular dynamics and pulmonary shunt (QS/QT) in a cohort of 12 dogs. The study protocol involved observations before and during the infusion of sodium nitroprusside, which was titrated to reduce mean arterial blood pressure by 40-50 percent. Prior to nitroprusside administration, 5 cm H2O CPAP significantly lowered arterial blood pressure (P < .05), without causing significant changes in heart rate, cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance, or QS/QT. Subsequently, 10 cm H2O CPAP applied before nitroprusside produced an additional decline in arterial blood pressure, alongside a significant elevation in heart rate and reductions in both cardiac output and QS/QT. Nitroprusside infusion independently led to substantial decreases in arterial blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance, and increases in heart rate, but did not alter cardiac output or QS/QT. The application of 5 cm H2O CPAP concurrent with nitroprusside did not elicit further changes in any measured parameters. Conversely, 10 cm H2O CPAP during nitroprusside infusion resulted in decreased arterial blood pressure, cardiac output, and QS/QT. These results demonstrate that nitroprusside infusion rates, which achieve a 40-50 percent decrease in mean arterial blood pressure, do not modify cardiac output or QS/QT. Moreover, while under nitroprusside, low levels of CPAP do not profoundly affect cardiovascular dynamics, but higher levels of CPAP (10 cm H2O), despite reducing QS/QT, lead to pronounced decreases in arterial blood pressure and cardiac output.

It is further indicated that during nitroprusside, low CPAP levels do not substantially alter cardiovascular dynamics, while high CPAP levels (10 cm H2O), although reducing QS/QT, result in considerable decreases in arterial blood pressure and cardiac output.

Cardiotoxicity associated with lopinavir/ritonavir in preterm twin neonates. This report details twin neonates delivered prematurely at 32 weeks of gestation to an HIV-positive mother. One twin experienced complete heart block and dilated cardiomyopathy, attributed to lopinavir/ritonavir therapy, a boosted protease inhibitor. The co-twin exhibited mild bradycardia. A cautious approach to lopinavir/ritonavir administration in the immediate neonatal period is advised.

Lopinavir/ritonavir-induced cardiac toxicity in premature twin infants. We present a case of twin neonates, born prematurely at 32 weeks of gestation to an HIV-infected mother. Treatment with lopinavir/ritonavir, a boosted protease-inhibitor agent, led to the development of complete heart block and dilated cardiomyopathy in one twin. The other twin presented with mild bradycardia. We recommend careful consideration when using lopinavir/ritonavir in the immediate postnatal period.

Adverse cardiac events in preterm twin neonates treated with lopinavir/ritonavir. This report describes twin neonates born prematurely at 32 weeks of gestation to a mother with human immunodeficiency virus infection. Lopinavir/ritonavir therapy, a boosted protease-inhibitor agent, was associated with cardiac toxicity: one twin developed complete heart block and dilated cardiomyopathy, while the other twin experienced mild bradycardia. Caution is advised regarding the use of lopinavir/ritonavir during the immediate neonatal phase.

Amiodarone-Associated Torsade de Pointes during Bladder Irrigation: An Atypical Case Presentation. This report details an instance of torsade de pointes (TdP) occurring within four days of initiating oral amiodarone treatment. Similar to previous observations, this TdP episode was observed amidst several contributing factors, specifically hypokalemia and elevated digoxin levels. A brief QT interval prolongation during bladder irrigation directly preceded the TdP event. Given the established link between bradycardia and acquired TdP exacerbation, the authors hypothesize that heightened vagal tone, induced by the bladder irrigation maneuver, combined with amiodarone therapy, led to this amiodarone-triggered proarrhythmia. Crucially, a subsequent bladder irrigation performed without amiodarone, despite the presence of hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, did not precipitate TdP.

Uncommon Amiodarone-Induced Torsade de Pointes Presentation During Bladder Irrigation: A Case Study. We describe a case of early-onset (within 4 days) torsade de pointes (TdP) linked to oral amiodarone administration. Consistent with prior literature, this TdP incident was complicated by multiple predisposing conditions, including hypokalemia and digoxin toxicity. The TdP episode was specifically triggered by transient QT interval prolongation during bladder irrigation. It is recognized that acquired TdP is worsened by bradycardia. The authors propose that the elevated vagal tone associated with bladder irrigation, a known vagal maneuver, when concurrent with amiodarone therapy, resulted in amiodarone-mediated proarrhythmia. A subsequent bladder irrigation, performed without amiodarone but in the presence of hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, failed to induce TdP.

An Atypical Manifestation of Amiodarone-Related Torsade de Pointes Triggered by Bladder Irrigation: A Clinical Report. A clinical case is presented involving the rapid development (within four days) of torsade de pointes (TdP) following oral amiodarone initiation. This TdP event, aligning with other published reports, unfolded against a backdrop of several aggravating factors, such as hypokalemia and digoxin excess. Notably, transient QT interval prolongation observed during bladder irrigation served as the immediate precursor to the TdP episode. Acknowledging the known exacerbating effect of bradycardia on acquired TdP, the authors postulate that the increased vagal tone from bladder irrigationfunctioning as a vagal maneuverin conjunction with amiodarone treatment, culminated in an amiodarone-induced proarrhythmic effect. Significantly, a second bladder irrigation performed without amiodarone treatment did not elicit TdP, even though hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia were still present.

Atypical Onset of Amiodarone-Associated Torsade de Pointes During Bladder Irrigation: A Clinical Case Narrative. Reported herein is a case illustrating the early onset (within a four-day period) of torsade de pointes (TdP) in conjunction with oral amiodarone therapy. Similar to observations detailed in other publications, this particular instance of TdP was complicated by a confluence of exacerbating elements, specifically hypokalemia and an elevated digoxin concentration. The episode of TdP was directly precipitated by a temporary prolongation of the QT interval that occurred during bladder irrigation. Given the well-established role of bradycardia in exacerbating acquired TdP, the authors put forth the hypothesis that the enhanced vagal tone, a physiological response to bladder irrigation as a vagal maneuver, when combined with concurrent amiodarone administration, instigated the amiodarone-induced proarrhythmia. Furthermore, a subsequent bladder irrigation, conducted in the absence of amiodarone therapy, did not result in TdP despite the persistent presence of hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.

Continuous Ketamine Anesthesia in Resource-Limited Conflict and Tropical Surgical Settings. Successful application of a continuous intravenous ketamine anesthesia protocol was demonstrated during the Somalia civil war in 1994 and in northern Uganda in 1999. This technique facilitated 64 operations on 62 patients, ranging in age from 6 weeks to 70 years, for limb and abdominal procedures, including caesarian sections and neonatal interventions. Operations, some lasting up to 2 hours, were performed effectively without advanced equipment such as pulse oximeters or ventilators, with patients breathing spontaneously on air/oxygen. Following premedication with diazepam, glycopyrrolate, and local anesthesia, and standard ketamine induction, a maintenance infusion of 10-20 microg/kg/min of ketamine was found to be safe and efficacious. Bedside clinical monitoring, primarily heart rate, was emphasized. Diazepam, when not contraindicated, served as the essential adjunct to ketamine, mitigating its cardiovascular effects and reducing the incidence and severity of operative and postoperative hallucinations. Local anesthetic blocks proved beneficial for lowering postoperative analgesia needs. An antisialogue was generally not required for procedures up to 2 hours, with glycopyrrolate being the preferred agent due to its minimal psychotropic and chronotropic impact, particularly in hot climates. This experience suggests the potential utility of this technique in civilian emergency scenarios, such as outdoor life-saving surgery or mass casualty incidents requiring rapid procedures like amputation and extrication.

Racemic Ketamine for Continuous Intravenous Anesthesia in War and Tropical Surgical Contexts. Continuous intravenous ketamine anesthesia was successfully employed for 64 surgical procedures in 62 patients, aged from 6 weeks to 70 years, during the Somalia civil war in 1994 and in north Uganda in 1999. These interventions encompassed limb and abdominal surgeries, including caesarian sections and neonatal operations. The technique allowed operations, some extending up to 2 hours, to be conducted safely and effectively despite the absence of advanced medical devices like pulse oximeters or ventilators, with patients maintaining spontaneous ventilation on air/oxygen. After premedication with diazepam, glycopyrrolate, and local anesthesia, and a standard ketamine induction dose, a maintenance infusion of 10-20 microg/kg/min of ketamine proved both safe and effective. Clinical monitoring at the bedside, with a strong emphasis on heart rate, was crucial. Diazepam, unless medically contraindicated or risky, was identified as the sole essential complementary drug to ketamine, buffering its cardiovascular responses and diminishing the duration and intensity of both operative and postoperative hallucinations. Local anesthetic blocks were advantageous in reducing the necessity for postoperative analgesia. Antisialogues were typically unneeded for operations lasting up to 2 hours, with glycopyrrolate being the optimal choice due to its minimal psychotropic and chronotropic effects, especially relevant in hot conditions. This accumulated experience suggests the technique's applicability extends to civilian emergencies, such as field surgery or situations with mass casualties requiring procedures like amputation and rapid extrication.

Application and Efficacy of Continuous Intravenous Ketamine Anesthesia in War-Affected and Tropical Regions. In 1994 during the Somalia civil war and in 1999 in north Uganda, a continuous intravenous ketamine anesthesia technique was successfully utilized for 64 operations on 62 patients. This diverse patient cohort, aged from 6 weeks to 70 years, underwent limb and abdominal surgeries, including caesarian sections and procedures on neonates. Operations, which could last up to 2 hours, were performed effectively despite the lack of sophisticated equipment like pulse oximeters or ventilators, with patients maintaining spontaneous ventilation using only air/oxygen. Following premedication with diazepam, glycopyrrolate, and local anesthesia, and an initial standard dose of ketamine for induction, a maintenance dose of 10-20 microg/kg/min was found to be safe and effective. Clinical monitoring, performed at the bedside and heavily relying on heart rate, was a critical component of patient management. Diazepam emerged as the sole essential adjunct to ketamine, unless contraindicated, due to its ability to moderate cardiovascular responses and reduce the severity and duration of operative and postoperative hallucinations. Local anesthetic blocks were beneficial in minimizing the requirement for postoperative analgesia. For operations up to 2 hours, an antisialogue was generally not required, with glycopyrrolate being preferred for its minimal psychotropic and chronotropic actions, particularly relevant in hot climates. The experience gained in these challenging war and tropical settings indicates the potential utility of this technique in civilian contexts, such as urgent outdoor life-saving surgery or mass casualty events necessitating rapid interventions like amputation and extrication.

Practical Application of Continuous Intravenous Ketamine for Surgery in Austere War and Tropical Settings. During the Somalia civil war in 1994 and in north Uganda in 1999, a continuous intravenous ketamine anesthesia technique was successfully applied to 64 operations in 62 patients, spanning an age range from 6 weeks to 70 years. Surgical procedures included limb and abdominal interventions, caesarian sections, and operations on neonates. These operations, some lasting up to two hours, were conducted without access to sophisticated equipment such as pulse oximeters or ventilators, with patients breathing spontaneously on air/oxygen. After initial premedication with diazepam, glycopyrrolate, and local anesthesia, and a standard induction dose of ketamine, a maintenance infusion rate of 10-20 microg/kg/min proved both safe and effective. Close bedside clinical monitoring, with particular emphasis on heart rate, was paramount. Diazepam was identified as the only necessary complementary drug to ketamine, buffering its cardiovascular effects and decreasing the duration and intensity of both operative and postoperative hallucinations, provided no contraindications or risks existed. The use of local anesthetic blocks was advantageous for reducing the need for postoperative analgesia. Antisialogues were typically not needed for procedures up to two hours, with glycopyrrolate being the optimal choice due to its minimal psychotropic and chronotropic effects, especially in hot environments. This experience in war and tropical settings indicates that the technique holds promise for civilian applications, including outdoor life-saving emergency surgery or mass casualty situations where interventions like amputation and rapid extrication are required.

Postoperative Respiratory Outcomes: Intravenous Morphine Versus Extradural Block Analgesia. This study evaluated the incidence of postoperative respiratory apnoea in two patient cohorts. Five individuals received a continuous intravenous morphine infusion (average 73.6 mg), while another five patients were administered a continuous extradural infusion of 0.25% bupivacaine (average 192 mg) over the 24 hours subsequent to upper abdominal surgery. Monitoring involved airflow assessment via a carbon dioxide analyser, chest wall motion detection using pneumatic capsules, and continuous electrocardiographic recording with a Holter ambulatory monitor. Both obstructive (P < 0.05) and central apnoea (P < 0.05) manifested with greater frequency among patients receiving morphine. Furthermore, a higher occurrence of tachyarrhythmias (P < 0.05) and ventricular ectopic beats (P < 0.05) was observed in the morphine infusion cohort.

Respiratory and Cardiac Complications Associated with Intravenous Morphine Compared to Extradural Analgesia. The occurrence of postoperative respiratory apnoea was investigated in a comparison between two groups of five patients each. One group received a continuous intravenous morphine infusion (mean dose 73.6 mg), and the other received a continuous extradural infusion of 0.25% bupivacaine (mean dose 192 mg) during the 24-hour period following upper abdominal surgery. Monitoring techniques included airflow detection by a carbon dioxide analyser, chest wall movement monitoring via pneumatic capsules, and continuous electrocardiogram recording using a Holter ambulatory device. Significantly, both obstructive (P < 0.05) and central apnoea (P < 0.05) presented more frequently in the cohort treated with morphine. The morphine infusion group also demonstrated a heightened incidence of tachyarrhythmias (P < 0.05) and ventricular ectopic beats (P < 0.05).

Diagnostic Performance of Troponin I in Cocaine-Related Chest Pain Patients. Accurately diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) presents a challenge in individuals experiencing cocaine-induced chest pain, primarily due to baseline electrocardiogram anomalies and elevated biomarkers not indicative of myocardial necrosis. Troponin measurement could offer improved diagnostic value in this population. This study aimed to evaluate outcomes linked to troponin positivity in patients admitted for MI exclusion following cocaine-related chest pain. Outcomes were investigated in patients hospitalized for suspected MI after cocaine consumption. A rapid rule-in protocol was employed, involving serial measurements of creatine kinase (CK), CK-MB, and cardiac troponin I (cTnI) over an eight-hour period. Key outcomes included CK-MB MI (defined as CK-MB  8 ng/mL with a relative index [(CK-MB x 100)/total CK]  4), cardiac death, and substantial coronary artery disease (50% stenosis). Among the 246 admitted patients, 34 (14%) fulfilled the CK-MB criteria for MI, while 38 (16%) displayed cTnI elevations. Angiography was conducted on 29 of the 38 cTnI-positive patients, revealing significant disease in 25 (86%). Of the four cTnI-elevated patients without significant disease, three met CK-MB MI criteria, and the remaining patient had a peak CK-MB level of 13 ng/mL. Both CK-MB MI and cTnI demonstrated high sensitivities, specificities, and positive and negative likelihood ratios for predicting cardiac death or significant disease, with no statistically significant differences observed between them. In conclusion, the majority of patients with cTnI elevations also satisfy CK-MB criteria for MI and exhibit a high prevalence of significant underlying disease. Troponin appears to possess comparable diagnostic accuracy to CK-MB for detecting necrosis in patients with cocaine-associated chest pain and suspected MI.

Cardiac Troponin I for Myocardial Infarction Exclusion in Cocaine Users with Chest Pain. Troponin sampling may provide enhanced diagnostic utility in these individuals. Our objective was to assess patient outcomes based on troponin positivity among patients with cocaine-related chest pain admitted for MI rule-out. We examined outcomes in patients hospitalized for potential MI following cocaine ingestion. All participants underwent a rapid rule-in protocol incorporating serial measurements of creatine kinase (CK), CK-MB, and cardiac troponin I (cTnI) across an eight-hour window. Evaluated outcomes encompassed CK-MB MI (defined as CK-MB  8 ng/mL with a relative index [(CK-MB x 100)/total CK]  4), cardiac mortality, and significant coronary disease (stenosis  50%). From the 246 admitted patients, 34 (14%) fulfilled the CK-MB MI criteria, and 38 (16%) showed elevated cTnI levels. Angiography was performed in 29 of the 38 cTnI-positive patients, identifying significant disease in 25 (86%) cases. Among the four cTnI-elevated patients without significant disease, three met CK-MB MI criteria, and the fourth had a peak CK-MB concentration of 13 ng/mL. Sensitivities, specificities, and positive and negative likelihood ratios for predicting cardiac death or significant disease were high for both CK-MB MI and cTnI, and these metrics did not differ significantly. In conclusion, the majority of patients with cTnI elevations also satisfy CK-MB MI criteria and present with a high incidence of underlying significant disease. Troponin appears to offer diagnostic accuracy equivalent to CK-MB for detecting necrosis in patients experiencing cocaine-associated chest pain and suspected MI.

Amlodipine-Induced Dysgeusia: Assessment of its Rarity or Frequency. Dysgeusia is recognized as a highly infrequent adverse effect of amlodipine. Prior literature review revealed only a singular reported instance. We present a case detailing a female patient, undergoing treatment with amlodipine for essential hypertension, who developed a loss of taste sensation. Her condition showed moderate amelioration after the drug was discontinued for 25 days. Our findings suggest that amlodipine is capable of inducing dysgeusia. This report provides a description of the clinical manifestations and a review of the pertinent literature concerning amlodipine and dysgeusia.

Amlodipine-Induced Dysgeusia: An Evaluation of its Incidence. Her symptoms moderately improved 25 days after the medication was ceased. We conclude that amlodipine possesses the potential to cause dysgeusia. The clinical presentation of this case is detailed, and relevant scholarly articles on amlodipine and dysgeusia are reviewed.

Intracoronary Cocaine Infusion's Impact on Human Left Ventricular Systolic and Diastolic Performance. Previous research in canines demonstrated that substantial intravenous cocaine doses lead to significant impairment of left ventricular (LV) systolic function and an elevation in LV end-diastolic pressure. This investigation aimed to determine how a high intracoronary cocaine concentration affects LV systolic and diastolic function in human subjects. Twenty patients (14 males, 6 females; ages 39-72 years), undergoing cardiac catheterization for chest pain assessment, had their heart rate, systemic arterial pressure, LV pressure and its first derivative (dP/dt), and LV volumes and ejection fraction measured. Measurements were taken before and during the final 2-3 minutes of a 15-minute intracoronary infusion of either saline (n=10, controls) or 1 mg/min cocaine hydrochloride (n=10). No changes were observed with saline administration. For the cocaine group, the drug concentration in coronary sinus blood averaged 3.00.4 mg/L, a level comparable to that reported in fatalities from cocaine intoxication. Cocaine did not induce significant alterations in heart rate, LV dP/dt (positive or negative), or LV end-diastolic volume. However, it did lead to elevated systolic and mean arterial pressures, increased LV end-diastolic pressure, and an augmented LV end-systolic volume, concurrently with a reduced LV ejection fraction. These findings indicate that in humans, intracoronary cocaine infusion, at a dosage sufficient to achieve a high drug concentration in coronary sinus blood, results in compromised LV systolic and diastolic performance.

Human Left Ventricular Systolic and Diastolic Function: Response to Intracoronary Cocaine Administration. Prior studies in dogs revealed that substantial intravenous cocaine administration severely impairs left ventricular (LV) systolic function and elevates LV end-diastolic pressure. The objective of this study was to evaluate the impact of a significant intracoronary cocaine concentration on LV systolic and diastolic capabilities in human subjects. In 20 individuals (14 men, 6 women; 39 to 72 years old) undergoing cardiac catheterization for chest pain, heart rate, systemic arterial pressure, LV pressure and dP/dt, LV volumes, and ejection fraction were assessed. These measurements occurred before and during the conclusion of a 15-minute intracoronary infusion (the last 2 to 3 minutes) of either saline (n=10, controls) or cocaine hydrochloride at 1 mg/min (n=10). Saline infusion produced no changes in any measured variable. With cocaine, the mean ( SD) drug concentration in coronary sinus blood reached 3.00.4 mg/L, a magnitude akin to that observed in individuals who succumbed to cocaine intoxication. Cocaine did not significantly alter heart rate, LV dP/dt (positive or negative), or LV end-diastolic volume. Nevertheless, it prompted increases in systolic and mean arterial pressures, LV end-diastolic pressure, and LV end-systolic volume, alongside a reduction in LV ejection fraction. Consequently, in humans, an intracoronary cocaine infusion that achieves a high drug concentration in coronary sinus blood leads to a decline in LV systolic and diastolic function.

Ten patients received saline (controls), while the other ten received 1 mg/min cocaine hydrochloride. Saline administration yielded no changes in any parameter. In the cocaine cohort, coronary sinus blood samples exhibited a mean ( SD) cocaine concentration of 3.00.4 mg/L, a level comparable to that documented in fatal cocaine intoxications. While heart rate, LV dP/dt (positive or negative), and LV end-diastolic volume remained unaffected, cocaine administration resulted in elevated systolic and mean arterial pressures, an increased LV end-diastolic pressure, and an augmented LV end-systolic volume. Therefore, in human subjects, an intracoronary cocaine infusion that generates a high drug concentration in the coronary sinus culminates in a degradation of LV systolic and diastolic performance.

The Impact of Intracoronary Cocaine Infusion on Left Ventricular Systolic and Diastolic Function in Humans. Large doses of intravenous cocaine have previously been shown to cause profound left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction and elevated LV end-diastolic pressure in dogs. This investigation was conducted to determine the impact of a high intracoronary cocaine concentration on LV systolic and diastolic function in humans. Twenty patients (14 men, 6 women, aged 39 to 72 years) who presented for cardiac catheterization due to chest pain were studied. Heart rate, systemic arterial pressure, LV pressure and its first derivative (dP/dt), LV volumes, and ejection fraction were quantified both before and during the final 2 to 3 minutes of a 15-minute intracoronary infusion. Ten patients served as controls, receiving saline, while the other ten received cocaine hydrochloride at 1 mg/min. No variables changed with saline infusion. In the cocaine group, the drug concentration in blood from the coronary sinus was measured at 3.00.4 (meanSD) mg/L, a level of similar magnitude to that reported in cocaine abusers who died from intoxication. Cocaine did not induce significant changes in heart rate, LV dP/dt (positive or negative), or LV end-diastolic volume. However, it led to rises in systolic and mean arterial pressures, an increase in LV end-diastolic pressure, and an expansion of LV end-systolic volume, concurrently causing a reduction in LV ejection fraction. In conclusion, an intracoronary infusion of cocaine in humans, administered at a dose sufficient to achieve a high drug concentration within coronary sinus blood, precipitates a decline in LV systolic and diastolic performance.

Molecular Disparity of Homozygous Hypobetalipoproteinemia from Abetalipoproteinemia. An investigation of apoB DNA, RNA, and protein in two patients with homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) and normal controls was conducted. Southern blot analysis, employing ten distinct cDNA probes, showed a normal apoB gene devoid of significant insertions, deletions, or rearrangements. Northern and slot blot analyses of total liver mRNA from HBL subjects indicated normal-sized apoB mRNA, but its quantity was substantially diminished. Immunohistochemical methods revealed the presence of apoB protein within HBL hepatocytes, though its concentration was considerably lower than in control samples. Furthermore, plasma from HBL individuals showed no detectable apoB via ELISA. These findings strongly suggest a mutation within the coding region of the apoB gene in HBL patients, resulting in an atypical apoB protein and subsequent apoB mRNA instability. This molecular profile contrasts with abetalipoproteinemia, which previously exhibited elevated hepatic apoB mRNA levels and intracellular hepatic apoB protein accumulation.

Distinct Molecular Basis of Homozygous Hypobetalipoproteinemia Compared to Abetalipoproteinemia. The apoB DNA, RNA, and protein components from two individuals diagnosed with homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) underwent evaluation, with comparisons made against healthy subjects. Southern blotting, utilizing a panel of 10 cDNA probes, confirmed the integrity of the apoB gene, showing no evidence of major insertions, deletions, or structural rearrangements. Hepatic total mRNA from HBL patients, analyzed by Northern and slot blots, contained apoB mRNA of normal size, albeit in significantly reduced amounts. Intracellular apoB protein was identifiable within HBL hepatocytes via immunohistochemistry, yet its quantity was markedly diminished relative to control specimens. An ELISA assay confirmed the complete absence of apoB in the plasma of HBL patients. These observations are most consistent with a mutation occurring in the apoB gene's coding region in HBL patients, leading to an abnormal apoB protein and destabilized apoB mRNA. Such outcomes diverge from those documented in abetalipoproteinemia, characterized by increased levels of hepatic apoB mRNA and accumulation of intrahepatic apoB protein.

Homozygous Hypobetalipoproteinemia: A Molecularly Distinct Entity from Abetalipoproteinemia. Researchers investigated apoB DNA, RNA, and protein from two patients afflicted with homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) and contrasted these with normal individuals. Southern blot analysis, performed with 10 different cDNA probes, demonstrated an intact apoB gene, free of major insertions, deletions, or rearrangements. Assessment of total liver mRNA from HBL patients using Northern and slot blot techniques revealed normal-sized apoB mRNA, but its presence was substantially diminished. Within HBL hepatocytes, immunohistochemistry detected apoB protein, although in significantly reduced quantities compared to control samples. Plasma from HBL individuals contained no detectable apoB when assessed by an ELISA assay. These findings strongly support a mutation in the apoB gene's coding region in HBL patients, resulting in an anomalous apoB protein and subsequent apoB mRNA instability. This profile clearly differs from abetalipoproteinemia, which was previously shown to involve elevated hepatic apoB mRNA levels and intracellular hepatic apoB protein accumulation.

Genetic and Molecular Differentiation of Homozygous Hypobetalipoproteinemia from Abetalipoproteinemia. The apoB DNA, RNA, and protein constituents of two homozygous hypobetalipoproteinemia (HBL) patients were analyzed and compared against healthy subjects. Employing 10 distinct cDNA probes, Southern blot analysis confirmed an uncompromised apoB gene, exhibiting no substantial insertions, deletions, or structural alterations. Northern and slot blot methodologies applied to total liver mRNA from HBL patients revealed apoB mRNA of appropriate size but in markedly depleted quantities. Immunohistochemical staining identified apoB protein within HBL hepatocytes; however, its concentration was notably lower than that observed in control specimens. No apoB could be detected in the plasma of HBL patients using an ELISA protocol. These comprehensive data are most consistent with a mutational event within the coding sequence of the apoB gene in HBL patients, culminating in a dysfunctional apoB protein and instability of apoB mRNA. These results establish a clear divergence from prior observations in abetalipoproteinemia, which was characterized by heightened hepatic apoB mRNA levels and intracellular deposition of hepatic apoB protein.

Acute Renal Failure in AIDS Patients Receiving Concurrent Tenofovir and Prolonged Vancomycin for Osteomyelitis. Two patients on tenofovir disoproxil fumarate as part of an antiretroviral regimen experienced renal failure following extended vancomycin therapy. Clinicians should recognize that tenofovir may elevate the risk of renal failure during prolonged vancomycin treatment.

Amphotericin-induced Recurrent Reversible Acute Renal Failure. Initial Experience with Rapamycin Immunosuppression Conversion in Renal Transplant Recipients. This study aimed to assess the impact of converting to rapamycin (RAPA) in patients experiencing cyclosporine (CsA) or tacrolimus (Tac) toxicity. Twenty renal transplant recipients transitioned to a fixed 5 mg/day dose of RAPA between 0 and 204 months post-transplant. Initial dose adjustments did not involve drug monitoring. Indications for the switch included chronic CsA or Tac nephrotoxicity (12 cases), acute CsA or Tac toxicity (3), severe facial dysmorphism (2), PTLD in remission (2), and hepatotoxicity (1). Patients were followed for 7 to 24 months. Results showed a significant reduction in serum creatinine levels from 233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05) at 6 months in the 12 patients with chronic nephrotoxicity. Facial dysmorphism improved in two individuals, and no PTLD relapse occurred. However, five patients developed pneumonia (including two Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia and one infectious mononucleosis with polyclonal PTLD lung infiltrate), and two experienced bronchiolitis obliterans. No deaths were reported. RAPA was discontinued in four patients due to pneumonia (two), PTLD (one), and oral aphthous ulcers (one). High RAPA levels (>15 ng/ml) were found in 7 of 13 (54%) patients. In conclusion, RAPA conversion offers effective immunosuppression, allowing CsA withdrawal. However, drug levels must be monitored during conversion to prevent over-immunosuppression, and robust antiviral and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia prophylaxis is essential.

A Preliminary Evaluation of Rapamycin Immunosuppression Transition in Renal Transplant Recipients. The objective of this investigation was to evaluate the consequences of converting patients with cyclosporine (CsA) or tacrolimus (Tac) toxicity to rapamycin (RAPA). A cohort of twenty renal transplant recipients received a fixed daily dose of 5 mg rapamycin, with the switch occurring between 0 and 204 months post-transplant. Initially, therapeutic drug monitoring was not employed for dose titration. The rationale for conversion comprised chronic CsA or Tac nephrotoxicity in 12 cases, acute CsA or Tac toxicity in 3, severe facial dysmorphism in 2, post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) in remission in 2, and hepatotoxicity in 1 instance. The follow-up period extended from 7 to 24 months. Within the 12 patients converted due to chronic nephrotoxicity, a statistically significant decrease in serum creatinine was observed at 6 months [233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05)]. Facial dysmorphism alleviated in two patients, and no recurrence of PTLD was noted. Nevertheless, five patients contracted pneumonia (two cases of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, one of infectious mononucleosis with polyclonal PTLD lung infiltrate), and bronchiolitis obliterans affected two patients. No fatalities occurred. Four patients ceased RAPA treatment, attributed to pneumonia (two), PTLD (one), and oral aphthous ulcers (one). Elevated RAPA concentrations (>15 ng/ml) were detected in 7 of 13 (54%) patients. This study concludes that conversion to RAPA provides adequate immunosuppressive efficacy, facilitating CsA discontinuation. Nevertheless, drug levels should be assiduously monitored during conversion to preclude excessive immunosuppression, and comprehensive antiviral and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia prophylaxis is recommended.

The follow-up duration ranged from 7 to 24 months. A significant decrease in serum creatinine [from 233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05) at 6 months] was observed among the 12 patients converted due to chronic nephrotoxicity. Additionally, facial dysmorphism improved in two patients, and no PTLD relapse was recorded. However, five patients experienced pneumonia, including two cases of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia and one of infectious mononucleosis with polyclonal PTLD lung infiltrate, while two developed bronchiolitis obliterans. No deaths occurred. RAPA therapy was discontinued in four patients: two due to pneumonia, one due to PTLD, and one due to oral aphthous ulcers. Notably, 7 of 13 (54%) patients exhibited high RAPA levels (>15 ng/ml). In summary, RAPA conversion offers adequate immunosuppression, enabling CsA withdrawal. Nevertheless, consistent drug level monitoring is crucial during RAPA conversion to prevent over-immunosuppression, and appropriate antiviral and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia prophylaxis must be administered.

Renal Transplant Recipient Outcomes Following Rapamycin Immunosuppression Conversion: An Initial Study. This investigation sought to assess the impact of switching to rapamycin (RAPA) immunosuppression in patients experiencing cyclosporine (CsA) or tacrolimus (Tac) toxicity. We converted twenty renal transplant recipients to a fixed 5 mg/day dose of RAPA, ranging from 0 to 204 months post-transplant. Initially, drug monitoring did not guide dose adjustments. Twelve patients were switched due to chronic CsA or Tac nephrotoxicity; three, for acute CsA or Tac toxicity; two, for severe facial dysmorphism; two, for PTLD in remission; and one, for hepatotoxicity. We followed these patients for 7 to 24 months. In the 12 patients whose conversion addressed chronic nephrotoxicity, serum creatinine significantly decreased [from 233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05) at 6 months]. Facial dysmorphism lessened in two patients, and PTLD did not relapse. However, five patients contracted pneumonia (two Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, one infectious mononucleosis with polyclonal PTLD lung infiltrate), and two developed bronchiolitis obliterans. No patient fatalities were recorded. Four patients ceased RAPA treatment: two due to pneumonia, one due to PTLD, and one due to oral aphthous ulcers. Thirteen patients had their RAPA levels measured, and 7 of these (54%) showed concentrations exceeding 15 ng/ml. Our findings indicate that RAPA conversion provides sufficient immunosuppression to permit CsA withdrawal. Nevertheless, clinicians should monitor RAPA drug levels during conversion to avoid excessive immunosuppression and administer adequate antiviral and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia prophylaxis.
