Investigation of Hepatocellular Oxidant Stress Subsequent to Intestinal Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury. Acute hepatic dysfunction, evidenced by the release of hepatocellular enzymes into plasma, diminished bile flow, and hepatic neutrophil sequestration, arises from reperfusion of ischemic intestine. The precise mechanisms of this acute liver damage remain unclear. This investigation sought to ascertain the involvement of oxidants in this hepatic injury and to evaluate the comparative utility of various indirect in vivo oxidant exposure assessment techniques. A standardized intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury was induced in rats. Hepatic tissue samples were analyzed for lipid peroxidation byproducts and for the concentrations of oxidized and reduced glutathione. Total hepatic glutathione levels exhibited no alteration following intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury. A significant elevation in oxidized glutathione (GSSG) was observed after 30 and 60 minutes of reperfusion. Conversely, no increase in any lipid peroxidation products was associated with this injury. The observed rise in hepatic tissue GSSG during intestinal reperfusion indicates that hepatocytes are subjected to an oxidant stress. The absence of a substantial increase in lipid peroxidation products implies that the oxidant stress is not severe enough to induce irreversible damage to hepatocyte cell membranes. These findings further suggest that quantifying tissue GSSG might serve as a more sensitive biomarker for oxidant stress than measuring lipid peroxidation products.

Hepatic Oxidant Stress Response to Intestinal Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury. Acute liver dysfunction, marked by hepatocellular enzyme leakage into plasma, decreased bile production, and neutrophil accumulation within the liver, develops after reperfusing ischemic bowel. The underlying pathological mechanisms of this acute hepatic insult are not yet elucidated. This study aimed to determine if oxidants play a role in this liver injury and to assess the comparative efficacy of several indirect in vivo methods for detecting oxidant exposure. Rats were subjected to a standardized intestinal ischemia-reperfusion protocol. Hepatic tissue was subsequently analyzed for lipid peroxidation markers and for oxidized and reduced glutathione levels. No change in total hepatic glutathione was detected following intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury. However, oxidized glutathione (GSSG) levels significantly increased after 30 and 60 minutes of reperfusion. No concomitant increase in any lipid peroxidation products was observed. This increase in hepatic tissue GSSG during intestinal reperfusion points to the exposure of hepatocytes to oxidant stress. The lack of a significant rise in lipid peroxidation products suggests that the oxidant stress magnitude is insufficient to cause irreversible damage to hepatocyte membranes. Furthermore, these data propose that GSSG measurement in tissue could be a more sensitive indicator of oxidant stress compared to the quantification of lipid peroxidation products.

Elucidating Hepatocellular Oxidant Stress After Intestinal Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury. Acute dysfunction of the liver, characterized by the release of hepatocellular enzymes into the bloodstream, a reduced rate of bile flow, and the sequestration of neutrophils within the liver, occurs upon reperfusion of an ischemic intestine. The precise pathophysiology of this acute hepatic damage remains to be fully understood. This investigation was conducted to ascertain whether oxidants are involved in the hepatic injury and to determine the relative utility of various indirect approaches for assessing oxidant exposure in living organisms. A standardized intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury was induced in rats. Hepatic tissue was subsequently examined for lipid peroxidation products and for both oxidized and reduced glutathione. Total glutathione levels in hepatic tissue remained unchanged following the intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury. Oxidized glutathione (GSSG) exhibited a statistically significant elevation after 30 and 60 minutes of reperfusion. In contrast, no increase was observed in any products of lipid peroxidation in conjunction with this injury. The rise in GSSG within hepatic tissue during intestinal reperfusion implies that hepatocytes are subjected to an oxidant stress. The absence of a substantial increase in lipid peroxidation products suggests that the oxidant stress is not intense enough to lead to irreversible damage to hepatocyte cell membranes. These data also indicate that measuring tissue GSSG may offer a more sensitive assessment of oxidant stress than the measurement of lipid peroxidation products.

Characterization of Hepatocellular Oxidant Stress Following Intestinal Ischemia-Reperfusion. The reperfusion of ischemic intestine leads to acute liver dysfunction, manifesting as the release of hepatocellular enzymes into plasma, a decrease in bile flow rate, and the sequestration of neutrophils within the liver. The mechanisms underlying this acute hepatic injury are currently not fully understood. This study aimed to ascertain the role of oxidants in the hepatic injury and to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of several indirect methodologies for assessing in vivo oxidant exposure. Rats were subjected to a standardized model of intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury. Hepatic tissue was subsequently assayed for lipid peroxidation products, as well as for oxidized and reduced glutathione. No alteration was observed in total hepatic tissue glutathione following intestinal ischemia-reperfusion injury. A significant increase in oxidized glutathione (GSSG) was detected after 30 and 60 minutes of reperfusion. However, no elevation in any lipid peroxidation products was associated with this injury. The observed increase in GSSG within hepatic tissue during intestinal reperfusion indicates the exposure of hepatocytes to an oxidant stress. The absence of a notable increase in lipid peroxidation products suggests that the oxidant stress is of insufficient magnitude to cause irreversible damage to hepatocyte cell membranes. These findings further imply that the quantification of tissue GSSG may represent a more sensitive indicator of oxidant stress than the measurement of lipid peroxidation products.

5-Azacytidine's Enhancement of Carcinogen-Induced Initiation in Rat Liver. To investigate the hypothesis that DNA hypomethylation plays a significant role in the initiation of carcinogenesis, 5-azacytidine (5-AzC) at 10 mg/kg, a DNA methylation inhibitor, was administered to rats during the DNA repair synthesis phase elicited by three carcinogens: benzo[a]-pyrene (200 mg/kg), N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (60 mg/kg), and 1,2-dimethylhydrazine (1,2-DMH) (100 mg/kg). Initiated hepatocytes in the liver were quantified as gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT) positive foci following a 2-week selection regimen involving dietary 0.02% 2-acetylaminofluorene and a necrogenic dose of CCl4. The findings demonstrated that, with all three carcinogens, 5-AzC administration during repair synthesis increased the incidence of initiated hepatocytes, for instance, 10-20 foci/cm2 in rats treated with 5-AzC and a carcinogen, compared to 3-5 foci/cm2 in rats receiving only the carcinogen. Further, administration of [3H]-5-azadeoxycytidine during 1,2-DMH-induced repair synthesis indicated that 0.019 mol % of cytosine residues in DNA were substituted by the analogue, confirming 5-AzC incorporation during repair synthesis. In the absence of a carcinogen, 5-AzC administered after a two-thirds partial hepatectomy, when its incorporation would be maximal, failed to induce any gamma-GT positive foci. These results suggest that DNA hypomethylation alone may not be sufficient for initiation, perhaps necessitating two events: one caused by the carcinogen and a second involving DNA hypomethylation.

Augmentation of Carcinogen-Driven Hepatic Initiation by 5-Azacytidine-Mediated DNA Hypomethylation in Rats. This study investigated the premise that DNA hypomethylation is crucial for the initiation of the carcinogenic process. Rats received 5-azacytidine (5-AzC) (10 mg/kg), an inhibitor of DNA methylation, during the period of repair synthesis induced by benzo[a]-pyrene (200 mg/kg), N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (60 mg/kg), and 1,2-dimethylhydrazine (1,2-DMH) (100 mg/kg). Initiated hepatocytes were subsequently quantified in the liver as gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT) positive foci after a 2-week selection regimen comprising dietary 0.02% 2-acetylaminofluorene alongside a necrogenic CCl4 dose. The results indicated a significant increase in the incidence of initiated hepatocytes across all three carcinogen groups when 5-AzC was co-administered during repair synthesis; specifically, 10-20 foci/cm2 were observed in 5-AzC and carcinogen-treated rats compared to 3-5 foci/cm2 in those receiving only the carcinogen. The incorporation of 5-AzC during repair synthesis was further elucidated by administering [3H]-5-azadeoxycytidine during 1,2-DMH-induced repair synthesis, revealing that 0.019 mol % of DNA cytosine residues were replaced by the analogue. Notably, 5-AzC alone, administered after a two-thirds partial hepatectomy (when incorporation would be maximal), did not induce any gamma-GT positive foci in the absence of a carcinogen. These findings imply that DNA hypomethylation in isolation may be insufficient for initiation, suggesting that a two-step mechanism, involving a carcinogen-induced event followed by DNA hypomethylation, may be required.

5-Azacytidine-Mediated Hypomethylation Synergizes with Carcinogens to Promote Rat Hepatic Initiation. Crucially, in the absence of the carcinogen, 5-AzC given after a two-thirds partial hepatectomy (when its incorporation should be maximum) failed to induce any gamma-GT positive foci. These data suggest that DNA hypomethylation alone may not be sufficient for initiation, perhaps indicating that two distinct events are necessary: an initial event caused by the carcinogen and a subsequent event involving DNA hypomethylation.

An investigation into the contribution of p-aminophenol to acetaminophen-induced nephrotoxicity, examining bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate's impact on toxicity and metabolism in Fischer 344 rats. Acetaminophen (APAP) induces proximal tubular necrosis in Fischer 344 (F344) rats, with p-aminophenol (PAP), a known nephrotoxicant, identified as an APAP metabolite in this model. This study aimed to ascertain if PAP generation is essential for APAP-mediated nephrotoxicity. To achieve this, the influence of bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate (BNPP), an acylamidase inhibitor, on the nephrotoxicity and metabolic fate of both APAP and PAP was evaluated. BNPP, at concentrations from 1 to 8 mM, proportionally decreased APAP deacetylation and covalent binding within F344 renal cortical homogenates. Pre-administration of BNPP before APAP or PAP dosage led to a notable attenuation of APAP (900 mg/kg) nephrotoxicity, yet PAP nephrotoxicity remained unaffected. This outcome was not attributable to altered pharmacokinetics of APAP or its acetylated derivatives in plasma or renal/hepatic tissues. Rather, BNPP pretreatment decreased the proportion of APAP excreted as PAP by 64% and 75% following APAP doses of 750 mg/kg and 900 mg/kg, respectively. BNPP did not modify the excretion of APAP or its non-deacetylated metabolites, nor did it alter the excretion of PAP or its metabolites after PAP doses of 150 mg/kg and 300 mg/kg. Consequently, the observed reduction in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity by BNPP appears to stem from its inhibition of APAP deacetylation. It is concluded that in vivo PAP formation contributes, at least partially, to APAP-induced renal tubular necrosis.

Elucidating the contribution of p-aminophenol to acetaminophen-induced nephrotoxicity: modulation by bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate in Fischer 344 rats. Acetaminophen (APAP) elicits proximal tubular necrosis in Fischer 344 (F344) rats. Recent findings indicate that p-aminophenol (PAP), a potent nephrotoxic agent, is an APAP metabolite in these rats. The objective of this investigation was to determine whether PAP formation constitutes a prerequisite step in APAP-mediated renal damage. For this purpose, the impact of bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate (BNPP), an acylamidase inhibitor, on the nephrotoxic effects and metabolic processing of APAP and PAP was assessed. BNPP effectively reduced APAP deacetylation and covalent binding in F344 renal cortical homogenates in a concentration-dependent manner (1 to 8 mM). Administration of BNPP prior to APAP or PAP significantly diminished APAP (900 mg/kg) nephrotoxicity, but had no effect on PAP nephrotoxicity. This outcome was not due to altered systemic or tissue distribution of APAP or its acetylated metabolites. Instead, BNPP pretreatment reduced the percentage of APAP eliminated as PAP by 64% and 75% following APAP administrations of 750 mg/kg and 900 mg/kg. BNPP did not affect the excretion patterns of APAP or its non-deacetylated metabolites, nor did it alter PAP or its metabolite excretion after PAP doses of 150 mg/kg and 300 mg/kg. Therefore, the decrease in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity observed with BNPP appears to result from its capacity to inhibit APAP deacetylation. We conclude that the in vivo generation of PAP is at least partly responsible for APAP-induced renal tubular necrosis.

The causal link of p-aminophenol in acetaminophen nephrotoxicity: intervention with bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate on metabolism and toxicity in Fischer 344 rats. Proximal tubular necrosis in Fischer 344 (F344) rats is caused by acetaminophen (APAP). P-aminophenol (PAP), a known potent nephrotoxicant, has recently been identified as an APAP metabolite in F344 rats. This study sought to establish if PAP generation is an obligatory step in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity. Consequently, the effects of bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate (BNPP), an acylamidase inhibitor, on the nephrotoxicity and metabolism of APAP and PAP were evaluated. BNPP (1 to 8 mM) dose-dependently decreased APAP deacetylation and covalent binding in F344 renal cortical homogenates. Pretreatment of animals with BNPP before APAP or PAP administration led to a substantial reduction in APAP (900 mg/kg) nephrotoxicity, but not PAP nephrotoxicity. This finding was not attributable to changes in the disposition of APAP or acetylated metabolites in plasma or renal cortical and hepatic tissue. Instead, BNPP pretreatment lowered the proportion of APAP excreted as PAP by 64% and 75% after APAP doses of 750 and 900 mg/kg, respectively. BNPP did not alter the excretion of APAP or any non-deacetylated metabolites, nor did BNPP modify the excretion of PAP or its metabolites after PAP doses of 150 and 300 mg/kg. Hence, the BNPP-mediated reduction in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity appears to be due to its inhibition of APAP deacetylation. It is concluded that in vivo PAP formation accounts, at least partially, for APAP-induced renal tubular necrosis.

Assessing p-aminophenol as a determinant of acetaminophen-induced nephrotoxicity: the influence of bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate on toxicity and metabolic pathways in Fischer 344 rats. Acetaminophen (APAP) is responsible for proximal tubular necrosis in Fischer 344 (F344) rats. P-aminophenol (PAP), a well-established potent nephrotoxicant, has recently been identified as an APAP metabolite in F344 rats. The primary aim of this study was to determine whether the formation of PAP is a necessary component in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity. Therefore, the impact of bis(p-nitrophenyl) phosphate (BNPP), an acylamidase inhibitor, on the nephrotoxicity and metabolism of both APAP and PAP was investigated. Within F344 renal cortical homogenates, BNPP (at 1 to 8 mM concentrations) produced a concentration-dependent decrease in APAP deacetylation and covalent binding. Administering BNPP prior to either APAP or PAP resulted in a significant decrease in APAP (900 mg/kg) nephrotoxicity, while PAP nephrotoxicity remained unaffected. This result was not linked to altered distribution of APAP or its acetylated metabolites in plasma or renal cortical and hepatic tissue. Rather, BNPP pretreatment decreased the percentage of APAP excreted as PAP by 64% and 75% following APAP doses of 750 mg/kg and 900 mg/kg. BNPP did not modify the excretion of APAP or any of its non-deacetylated metabolites, nor did it alter the excretion of PAP or its metabolites after PAP doses of 150 mg/kg and 300 mg/kg. Consequently, the reduction in APAP-induced nephrotoxicity induced by BNPP is attributed to its inhibition of APAP deacetylation. We conclude that the in vivo formation of PAP is, at least to some extent, responsible for APAP-induced renal tubular necrosis.

A specific amino acid change implicated in phenylketonuria shows linkage disequilibrium with DNA haplotype 2. Phenylketonuria (PKU), an autosomal recessive human genetic disorder, arises from a deficiency of hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH, phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase, EC 1.14.16.1). This common inborn error of amino-acid metabolism affects Caucasian populations, with approximately 1 in 50 individuals being carriers of a PKU allele. To elucidate the molecular foundation of PKU, we analyzed twelve restriction fragment-length polymorphism (RFLP) haplotypes of the PAH locus within the Northern European population, observing that 90% of PKU alleles in this group are restricted to four prevalent RFLP haplotypes. Our prior work identified a splicing mutation in the PAH gene linked to RFLP haplotype 3, accounting for about 40% of mutant alleles. This study now details the molecular defect associated with the RFLP haplotype 2 mutant allele. This defect is a C-to-T transversion in exon 12, leading to an arginine-to-tryptophan (Arg to Trp) amino-acid substitution at PAH residue 408. Direct hybridization utilizing a specific oligonucleotide probe confirmed that this mutation is also in linkage disequilibrium with RFLP haplotype 2 alleles, which comprise approximately 20% of mutant PAH genes.

Linkage Disequilibrium Between a Phenylketonuria-Associated Amino-Acid Substitution and DNA Haplotype 2. Phenylketonuria (PKU), an autosomal recessive disorder, is characterized by hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH, phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase, EC 1.14.16.1) deficiency. This prevalent inborn error of amino-acid metabolism in Caucasian populations means about 1 in 50 individuals carry a PKU allele. Our investigation into PKU's molecular underpinnings involved characterizing twelve restriction fragment-length polymorphism (RFLP) haplotypes of the PAH locus in a Northern European cohort. We found that 90% of PKU alleles in this cohort reside within four major RFLP haplotypes. Previously, we documented a splicing mutation in the PAH gene linked to RFLP haplotype 3, representing approximately 40% of mutant alleles. We now present the molecular anomaly linked to the RFLP haplotype 2 mutant allele. This anomaly stems from a C-to-T transition in exon 12, resulting in an Arg408Trp amino-acid substitution in PAH. Oligonucleotide probe-based direct hybridization confirmed this mutation's linkage disequilibrium with RFLP haplotype 2 alleles, which constitute about 20% of mutant PAH genes.

Association of a Phenylketonuria-Related Amino-Acid Change with DNA Haplotype 2 in Linkage Disequilibrium. PKU represents a frequent inborn error of amino-acid metabolism among Caucasian populations, with approximately 1 in 50 individuals carrying a PKU allele. A Phenylketonuria-Causing Amino-Acid Substitution Demonstrates Linkage Disequilibrium with DNA Haplotype 2. Captopril's Ameliorative Effects on Pulmonary and Renal Dysfunction Induced by Intravascular Coagulation in Rats. Administering thrombin and tranexamic acid (AMCA) to rats induces intravascular coagulation and fibrinolysis inhibition, leading to pulmonary and renal dysfunction akin to that observed in human trauma or sepsis. The administration of Captopril (1 mg/kg), an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, was found to mitigate both pulmonary and renal dysfunction in this rodent model. Rats treated with Captopril exhibited reduced lung weights and enhanced arterial oxygen partial pressure (PaO2). Albumin levels in the lungs remained unchanged, indicating Captopril's lack of effect on protein extravasation. Captopril effectively prevented renal injury, evidenced by reductions in elevated serum urea and kidney weight. Furthermore, kidney fibrin content was substantially lower in Captopril-treated animals compared to those receiving only thrombin and AMCA. It is hypothesized that Captopril's pulmonary benefits stem from a vasodilatory action, mediated by decreased circulating Angiotensin II and increased prostacyclin (secondary to elevated bradykinin). Similarly, Captopril may reduce the thrombin-induced increase in glomerular filtration, thereby minimizing fibrin monomer aggregation in the glomeruli and consequently reducing fibrin deposition and kidney damage.

Angiotensin Converting Enzyme Inhibition with Captopril on Intravascular Coagulation-Mediated Pulmonary and Renal Insufficiency in Rats. In rats, the induction of intravascular coagulation and subsequent inhibition of fibrinolysis via thrombin and tranexamic acid (AMCA) injections results in pulmonary and renal insufficiency that mirrors conditions following trauma or sepsis in humans. Treatment with Captopril (1 mg/kg), an angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, lessened the severity of both pulmonary and renal insufficiency within this rat model. Among rats administered this enzyme-blocking agent, lung weights were lower, and PaO2 showed improvement. The albumin content within the lungs was unaffected, suggesting Captopril did not influence protein extravasation. Captopril prevented renal damage, which was indicated by a decrease in elevated serum urea and reduced kidney weight. The quantity of fibrin in the kidneys was also notably lower than in animals given only thrombin and AMCA. It is proposed that Captopril's impact on the lungs might be due to a vasodilatory effect, resulting from a reduction in circulating Angiotensin II and an elevation in prostacyclin (attributable to an increase in bradykinin). Captopril may, through the same mechanism, attenuate the increased glomerular filtration known to occur after thrombin injection, thereby diminishing the aggregation of fibrin monomers in the glomeruli and leading to reduced fibrin deposition and subsequent kidney damage.

Mitigation of Intravascular Coagulation-Induced Pulmonary and Renal Failure in Rats by Captopril, an ACE Inhibitor. Intravascular coagulation, coupled with fibrinolysis inhibition, induced in rats by thrombin and tranexamic acid (AMCA) administration, precipitates pulmonary and renal failure resembling conditions observed after human trauma or sepsis. A single dose of Captopril (1 mg/kg), an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, was found to decrease both pulmonary and renal failure in this experimental rat model. Treated rats exhibited diminished lung weights and improved arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2). Lung albumin levels remained constant, signifying that Captopril did not affect protein leakage. Renal injury, characterized by elevated serum urea and increased kidney weight, was averted by Captopril. Furthermore, the amount of fibrin detected in the kidneys was considerably less than in control animals receiving thrombin and AMCA only. The beneficial pulmonary effects of Captopril are suggested to arise from a vasodilatory action, mediated by a decrease in circulating Angiotensin II and a rise in prostacyclin (consequent to increased bradykinin). Captopril may similarly reduce the known thrombin-induced increase in glomerular filtration, thereby curtailing the aggregation of fibrin monomers within the glomeruli, which would lead to less fibrin deposition and, consequently, reduced kidney damage.

Captopril prevented renal damage, as evidenced by a reduction in elevated serum urea and kidney weight. The quantity of fibrin within the kidneys was also substantially less compared to rats given thrombin and AMCA alone. We propose that Captopril's effects on the lungs are likely due to a vasodilatory mechanism, involving a decrease in circulating Angiotensin II and an increase in prostacyclin (mediated by elevated bradykinin). Captopril might also, through this same mechanism, mitigate the rise in glomerular filtration known to occur after thrombin administration, thus diminishing the aggregation of fibrin monomers in the glomeruli and resulting in less fibrin deposition and subsequent reduction in kidney injury.

Prevalence of YMDD motif mutations among lamivudine-naive Iranian patients with chronic hepatitis B. Lamivudine is a standard treatment for chronic hepatitis B patients. Prior research indicates that YMDD motif mutants, representing lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus, can arise as inherent genomic variations in chronic hepatitis B patients not receiving lamivudine. This study's objective was to ascertain the prevalence of these YMDD motif mutations in lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients within Iran. The investigation enrolled 77 chronic hepatitis B patients who had no history of lamivudine therapy. Serum samples were analyzed using polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) to identify YMDD motif mutants. Additionally, all participants underwent testing for liver enzymes, anti-HCV, HBeAg, and anti-HBe. Among the 77 participants, 73% were male and 27% were female. The average ALT and AST levels were 124.4+/-73.4 IU/l and 103.1+/-81 IU/l, respectively. HBeAg was detected in 40% of patients, while anti-HBe was present in 60%. All patients tested negative for anti-HCV. Significantly, YMDD motif mutants were not identified in any of the patients, irrespective of their liver enzyme levels or HBeAg/anti-HBe status. Despite reports of the spontaneous occurrence of YMDD motif mutants in chronic hepatitis B patients not treated with lamivudine, these specific mutations were absent in the cohort of Iranian lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients examined.

Occurrence of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-naive chronic hepatitis B patients from Iran. BACKGROUND: Lamivudine is a therapeutic agent for individuals with chronic hepatitis B. Evidence from recent studies suggests that YMDD motif mutants, indicative of resistant hepatitis B virus, manifest as natural genomic variability in chronic hepatitis B patients who have not received lamivudine. This study aimed to determine the frequency of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients in an Iranian cohort. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Seventy-seven chronic hepatitis B patients, all of whom were lamivudine-nave, participated in the study. Serum samples were subjected to polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) for the identification of YMDD motif mutants. Concurrently, all patients were assessed for liver enzymes, anti-HCV, HBeAg, and anti-HBe. RESULTS: Of the 77 patients, 73% were male and 27% were female. The mean ALT and AST concentrations were 124.4+/-73.4 and 103.1+/-81 IU/l, respectively. HBeAg positivity was observed in 40% of patients, and anti-HBe positivity in 60%. Anti-HCV results were negative for all participants. Notably, no YMDD motif mutants were detected in any of the patients, regardless of their liver enzyme levels or the presence of HBeAg or anti-HBe. CONCLUSION: While the natural emergence of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients has been documented, these mutants were not identified within the examined population of Iranian lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients.

Detection of YMDD motif mutations in lamivudine-nave Iranian chronic hepatitis B patients. BACKGROUND: Chronic hepatitis B is commonly treated with lamivudine. Contemporary research indicates that YMDD motif mutants, which represent lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus, can occur as part of the natural genomic variation in chronic hepatitis B patients who have not received lamivudine. The current study was designed to investigate the presence of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients residing in Iran. PATIENTS AND METHODS: The study cohort comprised 77 chronic hepatitis B patients who had no prior exposure to lamivudine. To screen for YMDD motif mutants, serum samples from these patients were analyzed using polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP). Additionally, liver enzyme levels, anti-HCV, HBeAg, and anti-HBe status were determined for all patients. RESULTS: The study participants consisted of 73% males and 27% females (n=77). Mean serum ALT and AST concentrations were recorded as 124.4+/-73.4 IU/l and 103.1+/-81 IU/l, respectively. HBeAg was positive in 40% of patients, while anti-HBe was positive in 60%. All patients yielded negative results for anti-HCV. Despite varying liver enzyme levels and the presence of HBeAg or anti-HBe, YMDD motif mutants were consistently absent in all enrolled patients. CONCLUSION: Although reports describe the natural manifestation of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-untreated patients with chronic hepatitis B, this investigation did not find evidence of these mutants in the studied group of Iranian lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients.

A survey of YMDD motif mutations in lamivudine-unexposed Iranian chronic hepatitis B virus patients. BACKGROUND: Lamivudine serves as a treatment for chronic hepatitis B patients. Recent scientific literature reports that YMDD motif mutants, associated with lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus, are observed as inherent genetic variations in chronic hepatitis B patients who have not been treated with lamivudine. Our investigation aimed to quantify the occurrence of YMDD motif mutants within a population of lamivudine-unexposed chronic hepatitis B patients in Iran. PATIENTS AND METHODS: A cohort of 77 chronic hepatitis B patients, all without prior lamivudine treatment, was enrolled. Detection of YMDD motif mutants in serum samples was performed using polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP). Comprehensive clinical assessments, including liver enzyme assays, anti-HCV, HBeAg, and anti-HBe tests, were also conducted for every patient. RESULTS: The patient demographic included 73% males and 27% females among the 77 participants. Average ALT levels were 124.4+/-73.4 IU/l, and average AST levels were 103.1+/-81 IU/l. Forty percent of patients were HBeAg positive, and 60% were anti-HBe positive. Anti-HCV antibodies were absent in all individuals. Critically, YMDD motif mutants were not identified in any of the patients, irrespective of their measured liver enzyme levels or serological markers for HBeAg or anti-HBe. CONCLUSION: While the natural development of YMDD motif mutants in lamivudine-untreated chronic hepatitis B patients has been documented internationally, these mutants were not found in the examined Iranian chronic hepatitis B patient population naive to lamivudine.

Etiology of Acute Thrombotic Microangiopathy in Renal Transplant Recipients. The occurrence of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a recognized complication in individuals undergoing renal transplantation, frequently manifesting as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This study aimed to identify the etiologies of TMA within a cohort of kidney transplant recipients and to contextualize these findings with existing literature. A retrospective analysis of 25 transplant biopsies performed at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, between June 2003 and June 2004, was conducted to investigate TMA causes. Pre- and post-transplant crossmatching was performed when feasible. Five cases of TMA were identified. Of these, three originated from the 25 transplantations performed at the study institution, while two involved patients referred for follow-up after receiving transplants abroad. Etiologically, three cases were linked to cyclosporine, and one case involved both cyclosporine and tacrolimus. The fifth case exhibited characteristics of TMA associated with antiphospholipid syndrome in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus. Literature indicates that recurrent HUS is the most common cause of post-transplant HUS, with drug-induced toxicity (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), procoagulant states, and antibody-mediated rejection also contributing. Our investigation revealed drug-related factors, primarily cyclosporine, as the predominant cause of TMA. The observed frequency of TMA in this study (20%) was consistent with percentages reported in the literature.

Acute Thrombotic Microangiopathy Genesis in Kidney Transplant Patients. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) is a recognized post-renal transplant complication, often presenting as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This research sought to ascertain the underlying causes of TMA in kidney transplant recipients and to review pertinent literature. Our methodology involved examining 25 transplant biopsy slides from procedures conducted at King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, between June 2003 and June 2004, to pinpoint TMA etiologies. Pre- and post-transplant crossmatching was executed as appropriate. Five instances of TMA were discovered. Three cases originated from the 25 transplants performed at the hospital, with the remaining two cases referred following overseas transplantation. Cyclosporine was implicated in three cases, while one case was attributable to both cyclosporine and tacrolimus. The fifth patient presented with TMA features connected to antiphospholipid syndrome within the context of systemic lupus erythematosus. Existing literature highlights recurrence of HUS as the leading cause of HUS in renal transplant patients, alongside drug toxicity (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), procoagulant conditions, and antibody-mediated rejection. Our findings demonstrated that drug-related factors, predominantly cyclosporine, constituted the most frequent etiology of TMA. The 20% incidence of TMA in this study mirrored rates documented in the literature.

Investigation into Acute Thrombotic Microangiopathy Etiologies Following Renal Transplantation. A common issue for patients after renal transplantation is thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA), frequently presenting as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). The current study aimed to delineate the etiologies of TMA in recipients of renal transplants and to critically engage with the existing scientific literature. Between June 2003 and June 2004, an inquiry was conducted at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by scrutinizing the slides from all 25 transplant biopsies performed during this twelve-month period to identify TMA causes. Pre- and post-transplant crossmatching procedures were undertaken whenever feasible. The investigation identified five cases of TMA. Of these, three cases arose from the 25 transplantations performed at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital, whereas two other cases involved patients whose transplantations were performed abroad, referred for subsequent care. Cyclosporine was implicated in three cases, and one case was attributed to the combined effect of cyclosporine and tacrolimus. The final case manifested features of TMA associated with an antiphospholipid syndrome in a patient diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus. According to published literature, recurrence of HUS stands as the most prevalent cause of HUS in post-transplant patients, with other contributing factors including drug-related toxicity (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), hypercoagulable states, and antibody-mediated rejection. Our study determined that drug-related causes, primarily cyclosporine, were the most frequent drivers of TMA. The 20% frequency of TMA observed in this investigation aligns with proportions reported in the broader literature.

Determinants of Acute Thrombotic Microangiopathy in Kidney Transplant Recipients. Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) represents a well-established complication in patients who have undergone renal transplantation, often observed as a manifestation of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This study's objective was to ascertain the specific determinants of TMA among renal transplant recipients and to provide a discussion informed by the scientific literature. To achieve this, a review of 25 transplant biopsy slides conducted over a one-year period, from June 2003 to June 2004, at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, was undertaken to identify the underlying causes of TMA. Where possible, pre- and post-transplant crossmatching data were also considered. A total of five TMA cases were uncovered. Three of these cases originated from the 25 transplantations performed at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital, while the remaining two cases involved patients who received transplants internationally and were referred for follow-up. Concerning the identified causes, three cases were linked to cyclosporine, and one case was attributed to the concurrent administration of cyclosporine and tacrolimus. The fifth case presented with TMA characteristics consistent with an antiphospholipid syndrome in an individual suffering from systemic lupus erythematosus. Literature findings indicate that recurrence of HUS is the most prevalent etiology of HUS in individuals post-renal transplantation, with additional causes encompassing drug-induced toxicity (e.g., cyclosporine, tacrolimus), hypercoagulable conditions, and rejection mediated by antibodies. Within the scope of this study, drug-related factors, predominantly cyclosporine, were identified as the most common cause of TMA. The incidence of TMA in this study, at 20%, corresponded to the percentages documented in published research.

Clotiazepam as a Cause of Acute Hepatitis. This report details a patient's development of acute hepatitis characterized by extensive hepatocellular necrosis, occurring seven months after beginning clotiazepam administration. The patient, who had been receiving the thienodiazepine derivative clotiazepam, experienced rapid recovery upon drug discontinuation. Subsequent administration of several chemically related benzodiazepines did not hinder this recovery or lead to a hepatitis relapse. These findings demonstrate clotiazepam's potential to induce acute hepatitis and indicate a lack of cross-hepatotoxicity between clotiazepam and these related benzodiazepines.

Acute Hepatitis Associated with Clotiazepam Use. We present a case of a patient diagnosed with acute hepatitis, featuring extensive hepatocellular necrosis, emerging seven months after initiating treatment with clotiazepam, a thienodiazepine derivative. Cessation of clotiazepam administration resulted in immediate patient recovery. Furthermore, the subsequent use of several structurally similar benzodiazepines neither impeded the recovery process nor triggered a recurrence of hepatitis. This clinical observation provides evidence that clotiazepam can precipitate acute hepatitis and suggests an absence of cross-hepatotoxicity between clotiazepam and the tested benzodiazepines.

A Case of Clotiazepam-Mediated Acute Hepatitis. A patient experienced acute hepatitis, marked by extensive hepatocellular necrosis, after seven months of receiving clotiazepam, a thienodiazepine derivative. Prompt resolution of the condition followed the discontinuation of clotiazepam. The subsequent administration of various benzodiazepines, which are chemically related to clotiazepam, did not negatively impact recovery or lead to any hepatitis relapse. This finding indicates that clotiazepam is capable of inducing acute hepatitis and further suggests that cross-hepatotoxicity between clotiazepam and several benzodiazepines is unlikely.

Clotiazepam's Role in Acute Hepatitis Development. We document a patient's development of acute hepatitis, characterized by extensive hepatocellular necrosis, approximately seven months after beginning treatment with clotiazepam, a thienodiazepine derivative. Discontinuation of clotiazepam led to swift recovery. Subsequent therapeutic use of several benzodiazepines, chemically analogous to clotiazepam, neither hindered the patient's recovery nor precipitated a recurrence of hepatitis. This observation establishes clotiazepam as a potential inducer of acute hepatitis and implies the absence of cross-hepatotoxicity between clotiazepam and various other benzodiazepines.

Efficacy of intramuscular hepatitis B immune globulin and lamivudine combination therapy for preventing hepatitis B recurrence post-liver transplantation. The combined administration of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIg) and lamivudine has significantly enhanced the survival of HBsAg-positive patients following liver transplantation by preventing hepatitis B recurrence. This investigation sought to assess the outcomes of liver transplantation in patients afflicted with hepatitis B virus (HBV). Through a retrospective analysis of patient charts and an organ transplant database, 51 individuals (43 males, 8 females) who underwent transplantation for benign HBV-related cirrhotic diseases between June 2002 and December 2004 and survived beyond three months were identified. HBIg was initially administered intravenously for the first week, followed by intramuscular delivery thereafter. Over a median follow-up period of 14.1 months, the total recurrence rate among the 51 patients was 3.9% (2/51). Patient survival rates were 88.3% at one year and 82.4% at two years, respectively. Among 10 patients receiving a 100 mg daily oral dose of lamivudine for two weeks prior to transplantation, seroconversion was observed in 57.1% (4/7) of HBV-DNA positive patients and 62.5% (5/8) of HBeAg positive patients, rendering them negative. Intramuscular HBIg demonstrated good tolerability across all patients. In conclusion, the regimen of lamivudine alongside intramuscular HBIg effectively averts HBV recurrence in allografts subsequent to liver transplantation.

A prophylactic strategy combining intramuscular hepatitis B immune globulin and lamivudine against post-transplant hepatitis B recurrence. BACKGROUND: The prophylactic combination of hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIg) and lamivudine has substantially improved the survival of HBsAg positive patients by preventing hepatitis B recurrence after liver transplantation. This study aimed to assess the outcomes following liver transplantation for patients with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. METHODS: A retrospective analysis of patient records and an organ transplant database identified 51 patients (43 men and 8 women) who underwent transplantation for benign HBV-related cirrhotic diseases between June 2002 and December 2004 and survived for more than three months. HBIg administration involved an initial intravenous phase during the first week, followed by intramuscular administration. RESULTS: At a median follow-up duration of 14.1 months, the cumulative recurrence rate in the 51 patients was 3.9% (2/51). The patient survival rates were 88.3% at one year and 82.4% at two years. A daily oral dose of 100 mg lamivudine, given for two weeks pre-transplantation to 10 patients, resulted in 57.1% (4/7) of HBV-DNA positive and 62.5% (5/8) of HBeAg positive patients achieving negative status. Intramuscular HBIg was well tolerated by all patients. CONCLUSION: The concurrent use of lamivudine and intramuscular HBIg provides effective prevention of HBV recurrence in allografts following liver transplantation.

Comparative Acute Renal Toxicity of Doxorubicin-Loaded Cyanoacrylate Nanoparticles and Free Doxorubicin. This study investigated the acute renal toxicity of doxorubicin-loaded nanoparticles (DXNP) in both healthy rats and those with experimental glomerulonephritis. In normal rats, free doxorubicin (DX) (5 mg/kg) resulted in 2/6 fatalities within one week, while all control animals, free nanoparticles (NP), and DXNP-treated rats survived. Proteinuria was threefold higher in DXNP-treated animals compared to DX-treated ones, with free NP causing no proteinuria. Kidneys showed 2.7 times greater DXNP concentration than free DX two hours post-injection (p < 0.025). Among rats with immune experimental glomerulonephritis, 5/6 DX-treated rats died within seven days, whereas all animals receiving DXNP, NP, or no treatment survived. Proteinuria manifested in all groups, but was 2-5 times more severe (p > 0.001) and extended after doxorubicin administration (400-700 mg/day), without a significant difference between DXNP and DX. Unloaded NP treatment mirrored control group behavior. These findings indicate that, under the experimental conditions described, DXNP led to fewer animal deaths than free DX, notwithstanding its heightened renal toxicity. Both improved survival and the observed nephrosis are most plausibly linked to increased uptake of DXNP by cells of the mononuclear phagocyte system, including mesangial cells.

Renal Disposition and Acute Toxicity of Doxorubicin-Loaded Cyanoacrylate Nanoparticles. The acute renal toxicity of doxorubicin-loaded nanoparticles (DXNP) was assessed in both healthy rats and those afflicted with experimental glomerulonephritis. Among normal rats, a single dose of free doxorubicin (DX) (5 mg/kg) caused the death of 2 out of 6 animals within seven days, contrasting with the complete survival of control animals and those given either free nanoparticles (NP) or DXNP. Animals treated with DXNP exhibited proteinuria that was three times greater than in those receiving DX, while free NP elicited no proteinuria. At two hours post-administration, DXNP accumulated in kidneys at a concentration 2.7 times higher than free DX (p < 0.025). In rats with immune-mediated experimental glomerulonephritis, 5 out of 6 DX-treated rats perished within seven days, unlike those treated with DXNP, NP, or untreated controls, all of whom survived. While proteinuria developed across all series, it was 2 to 5 times more intense (p > 0.001) and prolonged following doxorubicin treatment (400-700 mg/day), with no statistically significant difference between DXNP and DX groups. Rats administered unloaded NP exhibited behavior consistent with controls. The present data demonstrate that, within these experimental parameters, DXNP caused fewer mortalities than free DX, despite manifesting increased renal toxicity. Both these observationsenhanced survival and nephrosisare likely attributable to an augmented cellular capture of DXNP by components of the mononuclear phagocyte system, including mesangial cells.

Elevated Renal Toxicity of Doxorubicin-Loaded Cyanoacrylate Nanoparticles Despite Improved Survival. A three-fold increase in proteinuria was observed in DXNP-treated animals compared to DX-treated counterparts, with free NP administration eliciting no proteinuria. Kidney concentration of DXNP was 2.7 times higher than free DX two hours after injection (p < 0.025). Within the immune experimental glomerulonephritis model, 5 of 6 DX-treated rats died within 7 days, a stark contrast to the survival of all animals receiving DXNP, NP, or no intervention. Proteinuria manifested in all series, but was between 2 and 5 times more pronounced (p > 0.001) and extended after doxorubicin therapy (400-700 mg/day), with no significant distinction between DXNP and DX. Rats receiving unloaded NP behaved identically to controls. These findings indicate that, under the experimental conditions, DXNP resulted in fewer animal fatalities than free DX, even though it exhibited heightened renal toxicity. The dual outcomes of enhanced survival and nephrosis are most probably linked to the augmented uptake of DXNP by cells of the mononuclear phagocyte system, including mesangial cells.

Proteinuria was evident in all series, yet it was 2-5 times more intense (p > 0.001) and prolonged following doxorubicin treatment (400-700 mg/day), showing no significant difference between DXNP and DX. Congenital Anomalies Observed Following Maternal Sulphasalazine Exposure. Major congenital anomalies were identified in three infants born to two mothers who had inflammatory bowel disease and received sulphasalazine therapy throughout their pregnancies. In the case of a singleton pregnancy, the mother had ulcerative colitis, and her male infant presented with coarctation of the aorta and a ventricular septal defect. For the twin pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with Crohn's disease. The first twin, a female, exhibited a left Potter-type IIa polycystic kidney and a rudimentary left uterine cornu. The second twin, a male, displayed certain characteristics of Potter's facies, hypoplastic lungs, agenesis of kidneys and ureters, and talipes equinovarus. These findings suggest that sulphasalazine might be teratogenic, despite previous reports indicating otherwise.

Clinical Evidence Pointing to Sulphasalazine's Teratogenic Potential. Three infants whose mothers were treated with sulphasalazine for inflammatory bowel disease throughout gestation exhibited significant congenital malformations. In one instance involving a singleton pregnancy, the mother had ulcerative colitis, and the male infant was found to have a coarctation of the aorta and a ventricular septal defect. The second case involved a twin pregnancy where the mother suffered from Crohn's disease. The female first twin presented with a left Potter-type IIa polycystic kidney and a rudimentary left uterine cornu. The male second twin showed features consistent with Potter's facies, alongside hypoplastic lungs, absent kidneys and ureters, and talipes equinovarus. These observations lead to the suggestion of sulphasalazine's potential teratogenicity, despite conflicting prior literature.

Potentiation of Aminonucleoside Nephrosis by Protamine Co-administration. An experimental model of focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) was established in rats through the concurrent administration of puromycin-aminonucleoside (AMNS) and protamine sulfate (PS). Male Sprague-Dawley rats, which had undergone uninephrectomy three weeks prior, received daily subcutaneous injections of AMNS (1 mg/100 g body weight) and intravenous PS (two distinct doses of 2.5 mg/100 g body weight) over a four-day period. This injection regimen was subsequently repeated three more times at 10-day intervals. Animals were euthanized on days 24, 52, and 80. They exhibited the development of nephrotic syndrome, ultimately progressing to renal failure. The trajectory of creatinine clearance demonstrated a decline, showing a statistically significant difference (P < 0.01) compared to control groups treated with AMNS alone, PS alone, or saline. Glomerular examination revealed alterations characteristic of progressive FSGS. Initial ultrastructural investigations indicated a significant deficit of perfused ruthenium red particles on the lamina rara externa and pronounced modifications within the epithelial cell cytoplasm. These findings suggest that the co-administration of PS intensifies the glomerular toxicity of AMNS, thereby facilitating the rapid onset of progressive FSGS in rats, culminating in end-stage renal disease.

Augmented Aminonucleoside Nephrosis through Concurrent Protamine Administration. A rat model of focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) was developed by the simultaneous provision of puromycin-aminonucleoside (AMNS) and protamine sulfate (PS). Male Sprague-Dawley rats, having undergone uninephrectomy three weeks beforehand, were administered daily subcutaneous AMNS (1 mg/100 g body weight) and intravenous PS (two separate doses of 2.5 mg/100 g body weight) for four consecutive days. This injection series was replicated three additional times at 10-day intervals. Euthanasia of the animals occurred on days 24, 52, and 80. The animals manifested nephrotic syndrome and eventually renal failure. The creatinine clearance time-course curve exhibited a reduction and a significant disparity (P < 0.01) when compared to each control cohort, including those receiving only AMNS, only PS, or saline. Their glomeruli displayed features consistent with progressive FSGS. Early ultrastructural analysis unveiled a substantial absence of perfused ruthenium red particles on the lamina rara externa and notable changes in the epithelial cell cytoplasm. Consequently, it is proposed that PS administration exacerbates the toxic effects of AMNS on the glomerulus, leading to the prompt induction of progressive FSGS in rats, ultimately resulting in end-stage renal disease.

Intensification of Aminonucleoside Nephrosis by Co-administration of Protamine. An experimental animal model for focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) was established in rats via the combined delivery of puromycin-aminonucleoside (AMNS) and protamine sulfate (PS). Male Sprague-Dawley rats, subjected to uninephrectomy three weeks prior, received daily subcutaneous injections of AMNS (1 mg/100 g body weight) and intravenous PS (in two distinct doses of 2.5 mg/100 g body weight) over a four-day period. This injection sequence was repeated on three subsequent occasions, with 10-day intervals between series. The animals were humanely sacrificed on days 24, 52, and 80. They progressed to develop nephrotic syndrome and, ultimately, renal failure. The time-dependent decrease in creatinine clearance was statistically significant (P < 0.01) when contrasted with individual control groups administered AMNS alone, PS alone, or saline. Histopathological examination of their glomeruli revealed characteristics of progressive FSGS. Initial ultrastructural assessments indicated a notable scarcity of perfused ruthenium red particles on the lamina rara externa and pronounced alterations within the epithelial cell cytoplasm. It is therefore concluded that the administration of PS enhances AMNS-induced glomerular toxicity, thereby facilitating the rapid progression to FSGS in rats, culminating in end-stage renal disease.

Exacerbation of Aminonucleoside Nephrosis by Concomitant Protamine Treatment. A rodent model of focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) was developed by concurrently administering puromycin-aminonucleoside (AMNS) and protamine sulfate (PS) to rats. Male Sprague-Dawley rats, having undergone uninephrectomy three weeks beforehand, were given daily subcutaneous AMNS (1 mg/100 g body weight) and intravenous PS (two separate doses of 2.5 mg/100 g body weight) over four days. This regimen of injections was subsequently repeated three more times, with 10-day breaks. Animals were euthanized on days 24, 52, and 80. They developed features of nephrotic syndrome and eventually experienced renal failure. The time-course of creatinine clearance demonstrated a reduction that was significantly different (P < 0.01) from that observed in each control group, comprising those receiving AMNS only, PS only, or saline. Glomerular pathology indicated changes consistent with progressive FSGS. Ultrastructural investigations during the early phase showed a considerable lack of perfused ruthenium red particles on the lamina rara externa and marked changes within the epithelial cell cytoplasm. Thus, it is hypothesized that the co-administration of PS exacerbates AMNS's toxic impact on the glomerulus, thereby accelerating the development of progressive FSGS in rats, ultimately leading to end-stage renal disease.

Identification of a Novel Nonsense Mutation in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene (Haplotype 4) in Eastern European Phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited condition resulting from a deficiency in hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). Numerous mutations in the PAH gene have been documented, revealing linkage disequilibrium between RFLP haplotypes and specific mutations. A previously uncharacterized molecular lesion was detected in exon 7 of the PAH gene in a Hungarian PKU patient through direct sequencing of PCR-amplified DNA. This C-to-T transition leads to the substitution of Arg243 with a termination codon, and the mutated allele is linked to haplotype 4 of the PAH gene. The mutation is observed in two out of nine mutant haplotype 4 alleles in Eastern European populations but is absent in Western European and Asian populations. The low frequency of this mutant allele and its limited geographical range imply a recent mutational event on a normal haplotype 4 background within Eastern Europe.

Discovery of a Nonsense Mutation within the PAH Gene (Haplotype 4-Associated) in Eastern European Phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria (PKU) arises from an inherited deficit of hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). Previous research has detailed several mutations within the PAH gene, establishing linkage disequilibrium between RFLP haplotypes and specific genetic alterations. Using direct sequencing of PCR-amplified DNA, a novel molecular defect was uncovered in exon 7 of the PAH gene in a Hungarian individual with PKU. This specific C-to-T transition results in the replacement of Arginine at position 243 with a stop codon, and this variant allele correlates with haplotype 4 of the PAH gene. Data indicate its presence in two of nine mutant haplotype 4 alleles among individuals from Eastern Europe, while it is not detected in those from Western Europe or Asia. The infrequency of this allele and its geographically restricted presence suggest that this mutational event emerged recently on a wild-type haplotype 4 background within Eastern Europe.

Characterization of a Haplotype 4-Linked Nonsense Mutation in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene in Eastern European Phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by insufficient hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) activity. Multiple mutations in the PAH gene have been previously documented, demonstrating a relationship of linkage disequilibrium between RFLP haplotypes and particular mutations. A novel genetic alteration was identified in exon 7 of the PAH gene in a Hungarian PKU patient. This discovery was made through direct sequencing of DNA amplified via PCR. The mutation involves a C-to-T transition, which leads to the substitution of Arginine at position 243 with a premature termination codon. This mutated allele is specifically associated with haplotype 4 of the PAH gene. Its prevalence is recorded as two out of nine mutant haplotype 4 alleles among Eastern European individuals, yet it is entirely absent in populations from Western Europe and Asia. The rare occurrence of this allele and its localized geographic distribution imply a recent origin of this mutation on a normal haplotype 4 background within the Eastern European region.

Genetic Basis of Phenylketonuria in Eastern Europe: A Haplotype 4-Associated Nonsense Mutation of the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic genetic condition arising from a deficit in hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). Numerous mutations within the PAH gene have been previously identified, with observed linkage disequilibrium between RFLP haplotypes and specific mutations. A new molecular lesion was elucidated in exon 7 of the PAH gene in a Hungarian patient diagnosed with PKU, utilizing direct sequencing of PCR-amplified DNA. This C-to-T nucleotide substitution results in a nonsense codon at position 243, replacing Arginine. Crucially, this mutant allele is linked to haplotype 4 of the PAH gene. Analysis revealed its presence in two of nine mutant haplotype 4 alleles within Eastern European cohorts, but it was not found among individuals from Western European or Asian ancestries. The scarcity of this mutant allele and its confined geographical pattern suggest its recent emergence from a wild-type haplotype 4 lineage in Eastern Europe.

Evaluation of Perinatal Hepatitis B and Rubella Prevention Practices in New Hampshire Hospitals. This study aimed to assess the adherence to recommended perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention protocols within New Hampshire. Data were meticulously extracted from 2,021 paired mother-infant records, focusing on the 2000 birth cohort across the state's 25 delivery hospitals. The evaluation encompassed prenatal screening for both hepatitis B and rubella, the administration of the hepatitis B vaccine birth dose to all infants, the provision of hepatitis B immune globulin to infants of hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers, rubella immunity status, and in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine uptake among nonimmune women. Key findings indicated high prenatal screening rates for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%). While 76.2% of all infants received the hepatitis B vaccine birth dose, all infants born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers were administered hepatitis B immune globulin. Multivariate logistic regression identified the month of delivery and infant birth weight as independent predictors for hepatitis B vaccination, with significantly lower rates in January (48.5%) and February (67.5%) 2000 compared to other months, and the highest in December 2000 (88.2%). The highest rubella nonimmunity rate (9.5%) was observed in women born between 1971 and 1975, with 75.6% of nonimmune women receiving in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine. In conclusion, New Hampshire's birthing hospitals demonstrated substantial compliance with national guidelines for perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention, alongside identified opportunities for enhancement.

Perinatal Hepatitis B and Rubella Prevention Performance in New Hampshire Delivery Facilities. An objective of this research was to review the current performance of established perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention strategies across New Hampshire. Information was obtained from 2,021 linked mother-infant records pertaining to the 2000 birth cohort within New Hampshire's 25 maternity hospitals. The review focused on: prenatal hepatitis B and rubella screening; initial hepatitis B vaccine dose for all newborns; hepatitis B immune globulin for infants of mothers positive for hepatitis B surface antigen; rubella serostatus; and in-hospital postpartum rubella immunization for susceptible women. Results showed robust prenatal screening coverage for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%). The hepatitis B vaccine birth dose was administered to 76.2% of all neonates, with 100% of infants born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers receiving hepatitis B immune globulin. Multivariate logistic regression analysis indicated that both the delivery month and infant birth weight independently predicted hepatitis B vaccination status. Notably, vaccination proportions in January (48.5%) and February 2000 (67.5%) were lower than in any other months, with December 2000 reaching the highest at 88.2%. A 9.5% rubella nonimmunity rate was highest among women born from 1971 to 1975, and 75.6% of these nonimmune women received postpartum rubella vaccination in the hospital. The study concludes that New Hampshire's birthing hospitals largely comply with national perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention guidelines, while also pointing out specific areas where further improvement is feasible.

Compliance Audit of Perinatal Hepatitis B and Rubella Prevention in New Hampshire Birthing Hospitals. The aim of this investigation was to conduct an audit of the current adherence to recommended perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention measures within New Hampshire. Data for the assessment were extracted from 2,021 mother-infant record pairs corresponding to the 2000 birth cohort, originating from New Hampshire's 25 delivery hospitals. The audit specifically examined: prenatal screening for hepatitis B and rubella, the provision of the hepatitis B vaccine birth dose to all infants, the administration of hepatitis B immune globulin to infants born to mothers positive for hepatitis B surface antigen, rubella immunity levels, and the provision of in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine to women found to be nonimmune. Findings revealed high prenatal screening rates for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%). The hepatitis B vaccine birth dose was administered to 76.2% of all infants, and all infants of hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers received hepatitis B immune globulin. Multivariate logistic regression analysis demonstrated that the month of delivery and infant birth weight were independent factors influencing hepatitis B vaccination. Vaccination rates were lowest in January (48.5%) and February 2000 (67.5%), compared to other months, and peaked in December 2000 (88.2%). Women born between 1971 and 1975 exhibited the highest rate of rubella nonimmunity at 9.5%, with 75.6% of nonimmune women receiving the in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine. The conclusion drawn is that New Hampshire's birthing hospitals largely align with national guidelines for perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention, yet certain aspects present opportunities for operational enhancement.

Implementation and Adherence to Perinatal Hepatitis B and Rubella Prevention in New Hampshire. This research sought to assess the present level of implementation and adherence to recommended perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention practices across New Hampshire. Data were derived from 2,021 matched mother-infant records for the year 2000 birth cohort, obtained from New Hampshire's 25 hospitals providing delivery services. The assessment covered: prenatal screening for hepatitis B and rubella, administration of the hepatitis B vaccine's initial dose to all infants, provision of hepatitis B immune globulin to infants of mothers positive for hepatitis B surface antigen, rubella seroimmunity status, and documented in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine for nonimmune women. High rates of prenatal screening were observed for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%). The hepatitis B vaccine birth dose was given to 76.2% of all infants. All infants whose mothers were hepatitis B surface antigen-positive received hepatitis B immune globulin. Multivariate logistic regression analysis identified month of delivery and infant birth weight as independent predictors of hepatitis B vaccination. Vaccination coverage in January (48.5%) and February 2000 (67.5%) was lower than in any other months, while December 2000 had the highest proportion (88.2%). The highest incidence of rubella nonimmunity (9.5%) was found among women born between 1971 and 1975. In-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine administration was recorded for 75.6% of nonimmune women. In summary, New Hampshire's birthing facilities demonstrate commendable adherence to national guidelines for perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention, though areas for strategic improvement are evident.

Naproxen-induced renal papillary necrosis. A 31-year-old male patient with rheumatoid arthritis, previously treated with sulindac, fenoprofen calcium, high-dose salicylates, and gold salts, developed renal papillary necrosis (RPN) four months following the initiation of naproxen therapy. No other factors predisposing to RPN were identified. Sulindac replaced naproxen, resulting in no subsequent adverse renal effects over a twelve-month period. This report reviews prior instances linking RPN to anti-inflammatory drug use and explores the potential advantages of sulindac for patients who have experienced renal toxicity from other anti-inflammatory agents.

A Case of Renal Papillary Necrosis Attributed to Naproxen. Renal papillary necrosis (RPN) manifested in a 31-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis four months after starting naproxen therapy. This patient had a history of treatment with sulindac, fenoprofen calcium, high-dose salicylates, and gold salts. No alternative predisposing factors for RPN were found. Upon discontinuing naproxen and initiating sulindac, no further renal complications were observed over the ensuing 12 months. We examine earlier publications connecting RPN with the use of anti-inflammatory drugs and consider sulindac's potential benefits for patients demonstrating renal toxicity from alternative anti-inflammatory agents.

Naproxen as an Etiological Factor in Renal Papillary Necrosis. A 31-year-old male patient diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis, with a therapeutic history including sulindac, fenoprofen calcium, high-dose salicylates, and gold salts, developed renal papillary necrosis (RPN) subsequent to four months of naproxen administration. Comprehensive investigation revealed no other predisposing causes for RPN. The replacement of naproxen with sulindac resulted in the absence of additional adverse renal sequelae over a 12-month observation period. This article presents a review of existing literature correlating RPN with anti-inflammatory pharmaceutical agents and evaluates the potential utility of sulindac in individuals exhibiting renal compromise from other anti-inflammatory drugs.

Lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus leading to hyperosmolar nonketotic coma. We present the case of a 45-year-old male with a decade-long history of manic depression managed with lithium, who presented with hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma. For five years prior, he had experienced polyuria and polydipsia, with consistently negative glucose results on urinalysis. Following the resolution of hyperglycemia, polyuria persisted despite normalized blood glucose levels. Water deprivation testing confirmed nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, which was likely attributable to lithium therapy. Our hypothesis suggests that the development of type 2 diabetes in this individual, combined with chronic polyuria from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, was the precipitating factor for hyperosmolar dehydration.

A case of hyperosmolar nonketotic coma stemming from lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This report details a 45-year-old man, receiving lithium for 10 years for manic depression, who was hospitalized with hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma. He had reported polyuria and polydipsia for five years, during which time urinalyses repeatedly showed no glucose. After the initial episode of hyperglycemia resolved, he continued to exhibit polyuria despite euglycemia; subsequent water deprivation tests indicated nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, probably induced by lithium. We postulate that the chronic polyuria, secondary to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, contributed to precipitating hyperosmolar dehydration when the patient developed type 2 diabetes.

The role of lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus in the development of hyperosmolar nonketotic coma. A 45-year-old male, with a 10-year history of manic depression treated with lithium, was admitted in hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma. He had experienced polyuria and polydipsia for five years, and urinalysis during this period consistently showed no glucose. Post-recovery from hyperglycemia, polyuria persisted despite normal blood glucose levels; water deprivation testing confirmed nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, likely induced by lithium. We propose that the chronic polyuria resulting from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, in conjunction with the subsequent onset of type 2 diabetes, led to the precipitation of hyperosmolar dehydration in this patient.

Hyperosmolar nonketotic coma associated with lithium-therapy and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. We describe a 45-year-old man who developed hyperosmolar, nonketotic coma. He had a 10-year history of manic depression, for which he received lithium. Over the preceding five years, he reported polyuria and polydipsia, with glucose-negative urinalyses. Even after his hyperglycemia resolved, polyuria continued despite blood glucose levels returning to normal. Water deprivation testing established a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, which was presumed to be lithium-induced. Our hypothesis is that the chronic polyuria stemming from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, once the patient developed type 2 diabetes, was sufficient to cause hyperosmolar dehydration.

The Common Genetic Root of Phenylketonuria among Yemenite Jews. Phenylketonuria (PKU), an inherited metabolic disorder, arises from recessive mutations in the gene encoding hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). Its global incidence varies significantly, reaching its highest rates (approximately 1 in 5,000 live births) in populations such as Yemenite Jews, and also in Ireland and western Scotland. While numerous point mutations typically account for most PKU cases in European populations, this study identifies a single molecular defectspecifically, a deletion spanning the third exon of the PAH geneas the sole cause of PKU among Yemenite Jews. Molecular screening of a random sample from this community revealed a high frequency of carriers for this defective gene. Furthermore, despite tracing the deleted PAH gene to 25 distinct locations across Yemen, family histories and official documents of the Yemenite Jewish community indicate that the common ancestor of all carriers of this genetic defect lived in Sana, the capital of Yemen, prior to the eighteenth century.

Molecular Basis and Ancestral Linkage of Phenylketonuria in Yemenite Jews. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a metabolic disease resulting from recessive mutations in the gene responsible for producing the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). The prevalence of PKU shows considerable variation across different geographical regions, with the highest rates (around 1 in 5,000 live births) observed in groups like Yemenite Jews, and also in Ireland and western Scotland. In contrast to the European population, where various point mutations are commonly found, we report that a specific molecular anomalya deletion encompassing the third exon of the PAH geneis exclusively responsible for all PKU cases within the Yemenite Jewish community. Examination of a random sample of Yemenite Jews using a molecular probe designed to detect carriers of this deletion indicated a substantial frequency of the altered gene within this population. Although the deleted PAH gene was identified in 25 different locations throughout Yemen, historical records and family lineages of the Yemenite Jewish community establish that the common ancestor of all individuals carrying this genetic defect resided in Sana, Yemens capital, before the eighteenth century.

Etiology and Historical Tracing of Phenylketonuria in the Yemenite Jewish Population. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) in the liver. The incidence of PKU varies widely worldwide, being particularly high (approximately 1 in 5,000 live births) among Yemenite Jews, as well as in Ireland and western Scotland. Most PKU cases in the European population are attributable to a limited number of distinct point mutations. Here, we demonstrate that a single molecular defecta deletion affecting the third exon of the PAH geneis the underlying cause for every PKU case among Yemenite Jews. A molecular probe designed to identify carriers of this deletion, when applied to a random sample of Yemenite Jews, revealed a high frequency of the defective gene in this community. Although the deleted PAH gene was detected in 25 different sites throughout Yemen, family histories and official records of the Yemenite Jewish community pinpoint a common ancestor who lived in Sana, the capital of Yemen, before the eighteenth century, as the origin of this genetic defect for all carriers.

Furthermore, despite the deleted PAH gene being traced to 25 distinct localities across Yemen, genealogical records and official documents from the Yemenite Jewish community confirm that the shared progenitor of all carriers of this genetic defect lived in Sana, the capital of Yemen, prior to the eighteenth century.

Glyburide-Associated Hepatic Injury. Drug-induced hepatotoxicity, while frequently observed, is uncommonly linked with sulfonylureas. For glyburide, a second-generation sulfonylurea, only two brief accounts of hepatotoxicity have been published previously. Two individuals diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus developed an acute hepatitis-like syndrome shortly after commencing glyburide therapy. Serologic testing yielded no evidence of viral infection, and a liver biopsy revealed a histological pattern consistent with drug-induced hepatitis. Both patients experienced rapid recovery following discontinuation of glyburide and maintained good health during a 1-year follow-up period. Glyburide has the potential to induce an acute hepatitis-like illness in certain individuals.

Acute Hepatitis Manifestation Linked to Glyburide. Although drug-induced hepatotoxicity is a prevalent issue, its association with sulfonylureas has been infrequently documented. Specifically for glyburide, a second-generation sulfonylurea, only two concise reports of hepatotoxicity exist. We present two cases of patients with type II diabetes mellitus who developed an acute hepatitis-like syndrome soon after initiating glyburide treatment. Viral infection was ruled out by serologic studies, and liver biopsy findings were histologically indicative of drug-induced hepatitis. Both patients achieved prompt recovery upon cessation of glyburide and showed sustained well-being over a 1-year follow-up. Glyburide may precipitate an acute hepatitis-like illness in susceptible individuals.
