Glyburide has the potential to induce an acute hepatitis-like presentation in some individuals.

Identification of Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency Carriers Using Fibroblasts and Lymphocytes. We assessed pyruvate carboxylase (E.C. 6.4.1.1) activity in peripheral lymphocytes and cultured skin fibroblasts derived from the family members of an individual diagnosed with hepatic, cerebral, renal cortical, leukocyte, and fibroblast pyruvate carboxylase deficiency (PC Portland deficiency). Lymphocyte activity levels were recorded as 3339% for the mother, 1129% for the father, 82103% for the brother, and 3848% for the sister, relative to the lowest normal range. In fibroblasts, the patient's mother exhibited 42% activity, and the father showed 34%, each compared to the lowest normal. These findings confirm the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of the disease and establish the utility of lymphocytes and fibroblasts for carrier identification. A 21-hour fasting period did not elevate pyruvate carboxylase or mitochondrial PEPCK activity in lymphocytes.

Assessing Carrier Status for Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency via Fibroblast and Lymphocyte Analysis. Pyruvate carboxylase (E.C. 6.4.1.1) activity was measured in circulating peripheral lymphocytes and cultured dermal fibroblasts from the relatives of a patient presenting with hepatic, cerebral, renal cortical, leukocyte, and fibroblast pyruvate carboxylase deficiency (PC Portland deficiency). The mother's lymphocyte activity ranged from 33% to 39%, the father's from 11% to 29%, the brother's from 82% to 103%, and the sister's from 38% to 48%, all expressed as a percentage of the minimum normal level. Fibroblast activity for the patient's mother and father was found to be 42% and 34%, respectively, relative to the lowest normal activity. This evidence indicates an autosomal recessive inheritance for the disorder and confirms that both lymphocytes and fibroblasts are viable tools for detecting carriers. Notably, a 21-hour fast did not increase pyruvate carboxylase or mitochondrial PEPCK activity in lymphocytes.

Diagnostic Utility of Fibroblasts and Lymphocytes for Pyruvate Carboxylase Deficiency Carrier Detection. The activity of pyruvate carboxylase (E.C. 6.4.1.1) was quantified in peripheral circulating lymphocytes and cultivated skin fibroblasts from the family members of an individual afflicted with hepatic, cerebral, renal cortical, leukocyte, and fibroblast pyruvate carboxylase deficiency, known as PC Portland deficiency. Lymphocyte activities were determined to be 3339% for the mother, 1129% for the father, 82103% for the brother, and 3848% for the sister, relative to the lowest normal reference value. Correspondingly, fibroblasts obtained from the patient's mother and father demonstrated activities of 42% and 34%, respectively, against the lowest normal range. These collective data establish that the condition is transmitted through autosomal recessive inheritance and confirm the efficacy of employing lymphocytes and fibroblasts for the identification of carriers. A 21-hour fasting period had no observed effect on increasing pyruvate carboxylase or mitochondrial PEPCK activity in lymphocytes.

The Impact of Colchicine on Familial Mediterranean Fever: A Family Case Study. The Impact of Glyceryl Trinitrate on Sphincter of Oddi Spasm Induced by Prostigmine-Morphine. This investigation aimed to assess the influence of glyceryl trinitrate on prostigmine-morphine-elicited sphincter of Oddi spasm in nine female patients diagnosed with sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia. The methodology involved inducing sphincter of Oddi spasm via the administration of 0.5 mg intramuscular prostigmine and 10 mg subcutaneous morphine, with visualization achieved through quantitative hepatobiliary scintigraphy. The entire experimental protocol was then reiterated during a continuous infusion of glyceryl trinitrate (Nitrolingual at 1 g/kg/min for 120 minutes). Prostigmine-morphine challenge resulted in notable elevations in the time to peak activity (Tmax) over the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33  5.05 versus 22.77  3.26) and the common bile duct (CBD: 60.44  5.99 versus 40.0  2.88), as well as in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) over the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04  16.01 versus 27.37  2.19), HH (117.61  14.71 versus 31.85  3.99), and CBD (158.11  9.18 versus 40.1  6.24), indicative of a complete sphincter of Oddi spasm. Subsequently, glyceryl trinitrate infusion fully restored these prostigmine-morphine-induced quantitative parameter alterations to normal levels (Tmax over LP: 11.33  1.13; HH: 18.88  1.48; CBD: 36.22  1.92; and T1/2 over LP: 28.21  1.83; HH: 33.42  3.10; CBD: 41.66  6.33), signifying a potent sphincter-relaxing effect. These findings offer the initial substantiation of glyceryl trinitrate's efficacy against morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm in human subjects. Given its capacity to counteract the pronounced effects of morphine, glyceryl trinitrate holds potential therapeutic relevance for sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.

Glyceryl Trinitrate's Efficacy Against Sphincter of Oddi Spasm Triggered by Prostigmine-Morphine. The objective of this study was to assess the effectiveness of glyceryl trinitrate in alleviating sphincter of Oddi spasm induced by prostigmine-morphine in nine female patients suffering from sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia. The methodology involved inducing sphincter of Oddi spasm using a combination of 0.5 mg intramuscular prostigmine and 10 mg subcutaneous morphine, with real-time visualization accomplished via quantitative hepatobiliary scintigraphy. The entire experimental sequence was repeated during a continuous infusion of glyceryl trinitrate, administered as Nitrolingual at a rate of 1 g/kg/min over 120 minutes. Results demonstrated that prostigmine-morphine provocation led to significant increases in the time to peak activity (Tmax) for the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33  5.05 vs. 22.77  3.26) and the common bile duct (CBD: 60.44  5.99 vs. 40.0  2.88), and in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) for the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04  16.01 vs. 27.37  2.19), HH (117.61  14.71 vs. 31.85  3.99), and CBD (158.11  9.18 vs. 40.1  6.24), indicative of a severe sphincter of Oddi spasm. Glyceryl trinitrate infusion subsequently fully normalized these prostigmine-morphine-induced quantitative abnormalities (Tmax over LP: 11.33  1.13; HH: 18.88  1.48; CBD: 36.22  1.92; and T1/2 over LP: 28.21  1.83; HH: 33.42  3.10; CBD: 41.66  6.33), suggesting a potent relaxant action on the sphincter. In conclusion, these findings represent the initial human evidence for glyceryl trinitrate's effectiveness against morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm. Considering its ability to overcome the substantial effect of morphine, glyceryl trinitrate may be a relevant therapeutic option for sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.

Modulation of Prostigmine-Morphine-Induced Sphincter of Oddi Spasm by Glyceryl Trinitrate. This study sought to evaluate how glyceryl trinitrate modulates sphincter of Oddi spasm, which was pharmacologically induced by prostigmine-morphine, in a cohort of nine female patients presenting with sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia. The methodology involved the induction of sphincter of Oddi spasm through combined prostigmine (0.5 mg intramuscularly) and morphine (10 mg subcutaneously) administration, with its progression monitored via quantitative hepatobiliary scintigraphy. This entire sequence was then replicated while subjects received a continuous glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Nitrolingual, 1 g/kg/min over 120 minutes). Prostigmine-morphine challenge significantly elevated the time to peak activity (Tmax) in the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33  5.05 versus 22.77  3.26) and common bile duct (CBD: 60.44  5.99 versus 40.0  2.88), alongside increases in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) for the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04  16.01 versus 27.37  2.19), HH (117.61  14.71 versus 31.85  3.99), and CBD (158.11  9.18 versus 40.1  6.24), confirming complete sphincter of Oddi spasm. Remarkably, glyceryl trinitrate infusion completely counteracted these prostigmine-morphine-elicited changes in quantitative parameters (Tmax over LP: 11.33  1.13; HH: 18.88  1.48; CBD: 36.22  1.92; and T1/2 over LP: 28.21  1.83; HH: 33.42  3.10; CBD: 41.66  6.33), underscoring its effective sphincter-relaxing properties. These findings constitute the first human demonstration of glyceryl trinitrate's effectiveness in resolving morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm. As glyceryl trinitrate proved capable of overcoming even the profound effects of morphine, it may hold significant therapeutic utility in managing sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.

Glyceryl Trinitrate's Reversal of Prostigmine-Morphine-Evoked Sphincter of Oddi Spasm. The current investigation was designed to determine the capacity of glyceryl trinitrate to counteract prostigmine-morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm in a cohort of nine female patients diagnosed with sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia. The methodology involved inducing sphincter of Oddi spasm by administering 0.5 mg prostigmine intramuscularly and 10 mg morphine subcutaneously, which was subsequently visualized and quantified using hepatobiliary scintigraphy. This entire experimental procedure was then replicated during a continuous intravenous infusion of glyceryl trinitrate (Nitrolingual, 1 g/kg/min for 120 minutes). Prostigmine-morphine challenge consistently resulted in statistically significant elevations in the time to peak activity (Tmax) over the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33  5.05 compared to 22.77  3.26) and the common bile duct (CBD: 60.44  5.99 compared to 40.0  2.88), as well as in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) over the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04  16.01 compared to 27.37  2.19), HH (117.61  14.71 compared to 31.85  3.99), and CBD (158.11  9.18 compared to 40.1  6.24), thus confirming a complete spasm at the sphincter of Oddi level. Crucially, glyceryl trinitrate infusion completely restored the prostigmine-morphine-induced deviations in these quantitative parameters to baseline levels (Tmax over LP: 11.33  1.13; HH: 18.88  1.48; CBD: 36.22  1.92; and T1/2 over LP: 28.21  1.83; HH: 33.42  3.10; CBD: 41.66  6.33), thereby demonstrating its effective relaxant action on the sphincter. These results offer the inaugural human evidence of glyceryl trinitrate's efficacy in addressing morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm. Given its proven ability to overcome the potent spasmogenic effect of morphine, glyceryl trinitrate holds potential significance in the therapeutic management of sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.

Specific Linkage of Hereditary Prostate Cancer to the HPC1 Locus on Chromosome 1q24-25 in Early-Onset Swedish Families. Familial clustering accounts for an estimated 5%-10% of prostate cancer cases, suggesting inherited susceptibility. Prior research identified linkage to the 1q24-25 region (HPC1) in a cohort of 91 North American and Swedish families (Smith et al. 1996). This report details an analysis of 40 Swedish families with hereditary prostate cancer (12 previously studied, 28 newly identified) showing linkage within a 25-cM interval of 1q24-25 using 40 markers. Across the entire family set, a maximum two-point LOD score of 1.10 was observed at D1S413 (recombination fraction [theta] = 0.1), alongside a maximum NPL Z score of 1.64 at D1S202 (P = 0.05). Notably, the evidence for linkage to this region predominantly arose from the subgroup of 12 families characterized by early-onset prostate cancer (diagnosis before age 60 years). In these 12 families, the maximum LOD score reached 2.36 at D1S202 (theta = 0.0), with an NPL Z score of 3.23 at D1S202 (P = 0.0003), and an average age at diagnosis of 59.8 years. These findings indicate that HPC1 functions as a significant susceptibility locus for hereditary prostate cancer, especially in cases with an early age of diagnosis.

Significant linkage to this region was almost exclusively concentrated in the subset of 12 families with early-onset disease (diagnosis before age 60 years). Within these 12 early-onset families, a maximum LOD score of 2.36 was recorded at D1S202 (theta = 0.0), alongside an NPL Z score of 3.23 at D1S202 (P = 0.0003), with a mean diagnostic age of 59.8 years. Identification of a Myogenic Transcription Program Activated by the PAX3-FKHR Fusion Oncogene Using cDNA Microarrays. Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, an aggressive pediatric cancer affecting striated muscle, is characterized in 60% of instances by a t(2;13)(q35;q14) translocation. This genetic event leads to the fusion of PAX3, a developmental transcription factor crucial for limb myogenesis, with FKHR, a member of the forkhead family of transcription factors. While the resulting PAX3-FKHR gene exhibits transforming capabilities, its impact on gene expression remains largely undefined. To explore the actions of these transcription factors, both Pax3 and PAX3-FKHR were introduced into NIH 3T3 cells, followed by analysis of gene expression changes using a murine cDNA microarray comprising 2,225 elements. Our investigation revealed that PAX3-FKHR, but not PAX3, initiated a myogenic transcription program, encompassing the upregulation of transcription factors such as MyoD, Myogenin, Six1, and Slug, alongside numerous genes pertinent to various aspects of muscle function. Among these, the growth factor gene Igf2 and its binding protein Igfbp5 were particularly noteworthy. The relevance of this model was supported by the confirmation that three of these genes (IGFBP5, HSIX1, and Slug) were also expressed in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines. This research employed cDNA microarrays to elucidate the gene expression pattern induced by an oncogenic transcription factor and underscores the significant myogenic characteristics of PAX3-FKHR within NIH 3T3 cells.

cDNA Microarray Revelation of Myogenic Transcription Program Activation by the PAX3-FKHR Fusion Oncogene. Characterized by a t(2;13)(q35;q14) translocation in 60% of cases, alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma represents an aggressive pediatric cancer of striated muscle. This translocation results in the fusion of PAX3, a transcription factor essential for limb myogenesis during development, with FKHR, a member of the forkhead family of transcription factors. Although the resultant PAX3-FKHR gene possesses oncogenic properties, its influence on gene expression has largely been unexplored. To investigate the effects of these transcription factors, Pax3 and PAX3-FKHR were introduced into NIH 3T3 cells, and subsequent gene expression alterations were assessed using a murine cDNA microarray containing 2,225 elements. We discovered that PAX3-FKHR, unlike PAX3, activated a myogenic transcription program. This program included the induction of transcription factors such as MyoD, Myogenin, Six1, and Slug, in addition to a suite of genes implicated in various facets of muscle function. Notably, this group featured the growth factor gene Igf2 and its binding protein Igfbp5. The congruence of this model was indicated by the validation that IGFBP5, HSIX1, and Slug were also expressed in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines. This study leverages cDNA microarrays to uncover the gene expression profile instigated by an oncogenic transcription factor and highlights the profound myogenic capabilities of PAX3-FKHR in NIH 3T3 cells.

Demonstration of Myogenic Transcription Program Activation by the PAX3-FKHR Fusion Oncogene through cDNA Microarray Analysis. Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, an aggressive pediatric striated muscle malignancy, is distinguished in 60% of cases by a t(2;13)(q35;q14) translocation. Orbital Adhesion and Ocular Motility Impairment Following Subtenon Carboplatin for Retinoblastoma. The background notes the recent use of focal subtenon carboplatin injections as a presumably benign adjunct to systemic chemotherapy for intraocular retinoblastoma. This study aimed to document our clinical observations of compromised ocular motility in patients who received subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy. Abnormal ocular motility was identified in 10 consecutive retinoblastoma patients treated with subtenon carboplatin. Under general anesthesia, ocular manipulation and forced duction testing were performed, comparing motility post-tumor control with that at diagnosis. Histological analysis was conducted on eyes subsequently enucleated due to treatment failure (n = 4). All 12 eyes across the 10 patients, who received 1 to 6 subtenon carboplatin injections as part of multimodality therapy for intraocular retinoblastoma, exhibited limited ocular motility. Histopathology of one eye revealed numerous lipophages in the periorbital fat adjacent to the optic nerve, indicating phagocytosis of prior fat cells and suggesting preceding fat necrosis. Enucleations proved technically challenging and posed a risk of globe rupture due to extensive orbital soft tissue adhesions. In conclusion, subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy is linked to substantial orbital soft tissue fibrosis, resulting in mechanical limitation of eye movements and complicating subsequent enucleation procedures. Consequently, subtenon carboplatin is not devoid of toxicity and should be reserved for specific clinical scenarios.

Adverse Ocular Motility Outcomes Associated with Subtenon Carboplatin for Retinoblastoma Treatment. Subtenon carboplatin injections have recently been adopted as a supposedly non-toxic complement to systemic chemotherapy for intraocular retinoblastoma. Our objective was to report clinical findings concerning abnormal ocular motility in patients receiving this chemotherapy. Abnormal ocular motility was observed in 10 consecutive retinoblastoma patients who had undergone subtenon carboplatin treatment. During general anesthesia, eyes were assessed via forced duction testing, comparing motility after tumor resolution to that at initial diagnosis. Four eyes enucleated due to treatment failure underwent histological examination. All 12 eyes of the 10 patients, who received 1 to 6 injections of subtenon carboplatin as part of their multimodality therapy for intraocular retinoblastoma, demonstrated restricted ocular movement. Histopathological evaluation of one enucleated eye revealed abundant lipophages in the periorbital fat surrounding the optic nerve, suggesting phagocytosis of pre-existing fat cells and prior fat necrosis. Enucleation surgeries were technically difficult and carried a high risk of globe rupture due to widespread orbital soft tissue adhesions. We conclude that subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy leads to significant fibrosis of orbital soft tissues, which mechanically restricts eye movements and complicates subsequent enucleation. Therefore, subtenon carboplatin is not without toxicity, and its application should be judiciously restricted to specific indications.

Unanticipated Ocular Toxicity and Motility Dysfunction Following Subtenon Carboplatin in Retinoblastoma. The recent adoption of focal subtenon carboplatin injections as a purportedly toxicity-free adjunct to systemic chemotherapy for intraocular retinoblastoma formed the background of this investigation. The study's aim was to document our clinical observations regarding anomalous ocular motility in patients treated with subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy. Anomalous ocular motility was identified in a series of 10 consecutive retinoblastoma patients who had received subtenon carboplatin. Under general anesthesia, eyes were evaluated using forced duction testing, with ocular motility post-tumor control compared against motility at diagnosis. Histological assessment was performed on the four eyes subsequently enucleated due to therapeutic failure. Across all 10 patients, 12 eyes, which had received between 1 and 6 subtenon carboplatin injections as part of their combined therapeutic regimen for intraocular retinoblastoma, displayed compromised ocular motility. Histopathological examination of one eye revealed a high concentration of lipophages within the periorbital fat surrounding the optic nerve, suggesting the phagocytosis of existing fat cells and preceding fat necrosis. Enucleation procedures proved challenging and carried an elevated risk of globe rupture, attributable to extensive adhesions within the orbital soft tissues. This study concludes that subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy is associated with pronounced fibrosis of orbital soft tissues, which impedes eye movements mechanically and renders subsequent enucleation procedures arduous. Consequently, subtenon carboplatin is not without adverse effects, and its use should be limited to clearly defined indications.

Mechanical Ocular Motility Restriction After Subtenon Carboplatin for Retinoblastoma: Implications for Toxicity and Enucleation. Focal subtenon carboplatin injections have been recently employed as an adjunct to systemic chemotherapy for intraocular retinoblastoma, with the assumption of minimal toxicity. Our objective was to report our clinical experience regarding abnormal ocular motility in patients treated with subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy. We noted abnormal ocular motility in 10 consecutive retinoblastoma patients who had received subtenon carboplatin. During ocular manipulation under general anesthesia, eyes were assessed using forced duction testing, comparing motility after tumor control with motility at diagnosis. For the four eyes enucleated due to treatment failure, histological examinations were performed. Limitation of ocular motility was detected in all 12 eyes of the 10 patients who received 1 to 6 injections of subtenon carboplatin as part of their multimodality therapy for intraocular retinoblastoma. Histopathological examination of one eye revealed numerous lipophages in the periorbital fat around the optic nerve, indicating phagocytosis of previously existing fat cells and suggesting prior fat necrosis. The enucleations were technically demanding and presented a hazard for globe rupture because of extensive orbital soft tissue adhesions. We conclude that subtenon carboplatin chemotherapy is associated with significant fibrosis of orbital soft tissues, which mechanically restricts eye movements and complicates subsequent enucleation. Contrary to initial presumptions, subtenon carboplatin is not free of toxicity, and its use should be strictly confined to specific indications.

Attenuation of diethylnitrosamine-induced carcinogenesis by concurrent phenobarbital administration in rats. This investigation aimed to clarify the impact of phenobarbital (PB), at an ingested dose of 15 mg per rat, on carcinogenesis when co-administered with diethylnitrosamine (DEN, 10 mg/kg/day). Wistar rats (180 g) were subjected to treatment with DEN only or with DEN + PB for periods of 2, 4, and 6 weeks, following an established hepatocarcinogenesis protocol. Following the completion of treatment, a significant reduction in the quantity and dimensions of induced PAS-positive preneoplastic foci was observed when PB was concurrently given with DEN for 4 and 6 weeks. The suppression of mitosis and formation of micronuclei, typically noted after partial hepatectomy in DEN-exposed rats, were also substantially diminished in the DEN + PB treated group. For the 2-week treatment duration, PB's presence did not significantly alter these latter parameters. In rats receiving DEN + PB, both survival was extended and tumor incidence was lowered compared to results from DEN alone. It is concluded that PB, known to promote carcinogenesis when administered sequentially after DEN, mitigates the carcinogen's impact when given alongside it. This 'anti-carcinogen' action influences both the initiation and promotion phases of precancerous lesions. Further biochemical studies are underway to gain deeper insight into this 'paradoxical' effect of PB.

Inhibitory effect of phenobarbital on diethylnitrosamine-induced carcinogenesis when co-administered in rats. The objective of this study was to elucidate the influence of phenobarbital (PB), administered at an ingested dose of 15 mg per rat, on the carcinogenic process when delivered simultaneously with diethylnitrosamine (DEN; 10 mg/kg/day). Wistar rats weighing 180 g were exposed to either DEN alone or DEN combined with PB for durations of 2, 4, and 6 weeks, adhering to our established schedule for hepatic carcinogenesis. Post-treatment, a notable decrease in both the number and size of induced PAS-positive preneoplastic foci was evident when PB was provided concurrently with DEN for 4 and 6 weeks. Furthermore, the mitotic inhibition and the generation of micronuclei, typically observed following partial hepatectomy in DEN-treated animals, were significantly reduced in rats treated with DEN + PB. Conversely, when the treatment lasted only 2 weeks, PB's presence did not significantly modify these latter indicators. DEN + PB treated rats exhibited prolonged survival and a reduced incidence of tumors compared to those receiving DEN alone. The conclusion drawn is that PB, which typically enhances carcinogenesis when administered subsequent to DEN exposure, diminishes the carcinogen's effect when provided simultaneously. This 'anti-carcinogen' action affects both the initiation and promotion of pre-cancerous lesions. Ongoing biochemical investigations aim to provide further understanding of this 'paradoxical' PB phenomenon.

Reduction of diethylnitrosamine-induced carcinogenesis by concurrent phenobarbital dosing in rats. This research aimed to investigate the effect of phenobarbital (PB), at a sustained dose of 15 mg per rat, on carcinogenesis when concurrently administered with diethylnitrosamine (DEN; 10 mg/kg/day). Wistar rats, weighing 180 g, received treatment with either DEN exclusively or a combination of DEN + PB over periods of 2, 4, and 6 weeks, following our established hepatocarcinogenesis regimen. Following the treatment phase, a statistically significant reduction was observed in both the count and dimensions of induced PAS-positive preneoplastic foci when PB was co-administered with DEN for 4 and 6 weeks. The mitotic arrest and the formation of micronuclei, typically observed after partial hepatectomy in DEN-exposed rats, were also significantly curtailed in the DEN + PB treatment group. However, for a treatment duration of only 2 weeks, PB's inclusion did not significantly alter these specific parameters. Animals treated with DEN + PB demonstrated extended survival and a lower tumor incidence in comparison to those receiving DEN alone. It is concluded that PB, which acts as a promoter of carcinogenesis when given after DEN treatment, exerts a suppressive effect on the carcinogen's action when administered simultaneously with DEN. This 'anti-carcinogen' impact influences both the initiation and promotion stages of precancerous lesions. Biochemical investigations are currently ongoing to obtain additional information regarding this 'paradoxical' PB effect.

Modulatory role of phenobarbital in diethylnitrosamine-induced carcinogenesis through concomitant administration in rats. The current study was designed to clarify the influence of phenobarbital (PB), at an ingested dose of 15 mg per rat, on the carcinogenic process when administered in conjunction with diethylnitrosamine (DEN; 10 mg/kg/day). One hundred eighty-gram Wistar rats were treated either with DEN alone or with DEN plus PB for durations of 2, 4, and 6 weeks, in accordance with our protocol for inducing hepatocarcinogenesis. Upon completion of the treatment, a significant decrease in both the number and size of induced PAS-positive preneoplastic foci was noted when PB was provided simultaneously with DEN for 4 and 6 weeks. Furthermore, the mitotic inhibition and the production of micronuclei, typically observed after partial hepatectomy in DEN-treated rats, were significantly diminished in the DEN + PB treated cohort. In instances where treatment lasted merely 2 weeks, the presence of PB did not significantly affect these aforementioned parameters. Compared to rats treated with DEN alone, DEN + PB treated rats exhibited prolonged survival and a decreased incidence of tumors. The findings indicate that PB, while acting as a carcinogen promoter when administered following DEN exposure, reduces the carcinogenic effect when delivered concurrently. This 'anti-carcinogen' action targets both the initiation and promotion phases of precancerous lesions. Biochemical investigations are presently underway to gain further insight into this 'paradoxical' effect of PB.

Germline RB1 Gene Mutations in Patients Presenting with Isolated Unilateral Retinoblastoma. The development of most isolated unilateral retinoblastoma cases is initiated by somatic inactivation of both RB1 gene alleles. However, some affected individuals can transmit a predisposition to retinoblastoma to their offspring. This study aimed to ascertain the frequency and characteristics of germline RB1 gene mutations in patients with isolated unilateral retinoblastoma. DNA from peripheral blood and tumor tissue was analyzed for this purpose. Analysis of tumors from 54 (71%) of 76 informative patients revealed loss of constitutional heterozygosity (LOH) at intragenic loci. Additionally, constitutional deletions were identified in 3 of 13 uninformative patients. To detect mutations, SSCP, hetero-duplex analysis, sequencing, and Southern blot analysis were performed on 39 randomly selected tumors. Mutations were identified in 21 (91%) of 23 tumors exhibiting LOH. Among 16 tumors without LOH, one mutation was found in 6 (38%), while both mutations were detected in 9 (56%). In total, 45 mutations were identified across tumors from 36 patients. Of these, 39 mutationscomprising 34 small mutations, 2 large structural alterations, and hypermethylation in 3 tumorswere absent in the corresponding peripheral blood DNA. A constitutional mutation was detected in 6 (17%) of the 36 patients, with one of these mutations being associated with reduced expressivity. The presence of a constitutional mutation showed no correlation with an earlier age at treatment. Somatic mosaicism was confirmed in one patient via molecular analysis of peripheral blood DNA and RNA. Furthermore, mosaicism was suggested in two patients lacking detectable peripheral blood mutations, as one displayed multifocal tumors and the other subsequently developed bilateral retinoblastoma. In conclusion, these findings underscore that retinoblastoma manifestation and transmissibility are contingent upon the initial mutation's nature, its timing in development, and the quantity and types of affected cells.

Prevalence and Characteristics of Constitutional RB1 Mutations in Isolated Unilateral Retinoblastoma. While tumor initiation in the majority of patients with isolated unilateral retinoblastoma involves somatic inactivation of both RB1 gene alleles, a subset of these individuals can pass on retinoblastoma susceptibility to their progeny. Our study sought to determine the frequency and specific nature of constitutional RB1-gene mutations in this patient cohort. We conducted DNA analyses on samples from peripheral blood and tumor tissue. Among 76 informative patients, 54 (71%) of their tumors exhibited loss of constitutional heterozygosity (LOH) at intragenic loci. Constitutional deletions were found in 3 of 13 uninformative patients. For 39 randomly chosen tumors, mutation detection was performed using SSCP, hetero-duplex analysis, sequencing, and Southern blot analysis. Twenty-one (91%) of 23 tumors with LOH contained mutations. In tumors without LOH, one mutation was detected in 6 (38%) of 16 cases, and both mutations were identified in 9 (56%). Cumulatively, 45 mutations were discovered in tumors from 36 patients. Thirty-nine of these mutations, including 34 small mutations, 2 large structural alterations, and hypermethylation in 3 tumors, were not present in the matching peripheral blood DNA. A constitutional mutation was identified in 6 (17%) of the 36 patients; notably, one of these is recognized for its reduced expressivity. No association was observed between the presence of a constitutional mutation and an early age at treatment. Molecular analysis of peripheral blood DNA and RNA confirmed somatic mosaicism in one patient. Additionally, mosaicism was suspected in two patients where no peripheral blood mutation was detected, with one presenting multifocal tumors and the other later developing bilateral retinoblastoma. These results emphasize that the expression and hereditary potential of retinoblastoma are influenced by the initial mutation's type, its developmental timing, and the number and kinds of cells involved.

Identification of Germline RB1-Gene Mutations in Isolated Unilateral Retinoblastoma Patients. The initiation of tumor growth in most patients with isolated unilateral retinoblastoma typically results from somatic inactivation of both RB1 gene alleles. Nevertheless, a proportion of these patients possess the capacity to transmit retinoblastoma predisposition to their descendants. Our research aimed to ascertain the frequency and characteristics of constitutional RB1-gene mutations in individuals diagnosed with isolated unilateral retinoblastoma. We analyzed DNA extracted from both peripheral blood and tumor tissue. Analysis of tumors from 54 (71%) of 76 informative patients revealed loss of constitutional heterozygosity (LOH) at intragenic sites. Furthermore, 3 of 13 uninformative patients presented with constitutional deletions. To pinpoint mutations, SSCP, hetero-duplex analysis, sequencing, and Southern blot analysis were employed on 39 randomly selected tumors. Mutations were identified in 21 (91%) of 23 tumors exhibiting LOH. Among 16 tumors lacking LOH, a single mutation was found in 6 (38%) cases, while both mutations were detected in 9 (56%) of these tumors. Overall, 45 mutations were detected in tumors from 36 patients. Of these, 39 mutationscomprising 34 small mutations, 2 large structural alterations, and hypermethylation in 3 tumorswere absent in the corresponding peripheral blood DNA. A constitutional mutation was identified in the DNA of 6 (17%) of the 36 patients; one such mutation is known to be linked to reduced expressivity. The presence of a constitutional mutation did not correlate with an early age at treatment. Somatic mosaicism was directly demonstrated in one patient through molecular analysis of peripheral blood DNA and RNA. Additionally, mosaicism was hypothesized in two patients without detectable peripheral blood mutations, as one presented with multifocal tumors and the other subsequently developed bilateral retinoblastoma. Our conclusions highlight that the clinical expression and transmissibility of retinoblastoma are governed by the nature of the primary mutation, its developmental stage, and the quantity and types of cells affected.

Investigation of Constitutional RB1-Gene Mutations in Unilateral Retinoblastoma. While somatic inactivation of both RB1 gene alleles initiates tumor development in the majority of patients with isolated unilateral retinoblastoma, a subset can confer retinoblastoma predisposition to their progeny. To determine the frequency and specific characteristics of constitutional RB1-gene mutations in these patients, we examined DNA from peripheral blood and tumor tissue. Tumor analysis from 54 (71%) of 76 informative patients revealed loss of constitutional heterozygosity (LOH) at intragenic loci. Constitutional deletions were present in 3 of 13 uninformative patients. For mutation identification in 39 randomly selected tumors, SSCP, hetero-duplex analysis, sequencing, and Southern blot analysis were utilized. Mutations were detected in 21 (91%) of 23 tumors exhibiting LOH. Among 16 tumors without LOH, one mutation was identified in 6 (38%), while both mutations were found in 9 (56%). In total, 45 mutations were ascertained in tumors from 36 patients. Thirty-nine of these mutations, including 34 small mutations, 2 large structural alterations, and hypermethylation in 3 tumors, were not discernible in the associated peripheral blood DNA. A constitutional mutation was found in 6 (17%) of the 36 patients; one of these is recognized for its attenuated expressivity. No correlation was established between the presence of a constitutional mutation and an earlier age at treatment. Somatic mosaicism was unequivocally shown in one patient via molecular analysis of peripheral blood DNA and RNA. Furthermore, mosaicism was inferred in two patients lacking detectable peripheral blood mutations: one displayed multifocal tumors, and the other later developed bilateral retinoblastoma. In summary, our findings emphasize that retinoblastoma's manifestation and transmissibility are contingent on the primary mutation's nature, its occurrence in development, and the number and types of affected cells.

Concurrent Hereditary TP53 Codon 292 and Somatic P16INK4A Codon 94 Mutations in a Li-Fraumeni Syndrome Kindred. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by various childhood and adult cancers. While hereditary TP53 mutations are rare in general human cancers, they are frequently reported in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Additionally, hereditary mutations in TP57KIP2, P15INK4B, and P16INK4A, which influence the cell cycle similarly to TP53, have been documented in certain cancer types. We investigated the mutation patterns of TP53, P57KIP2, P15INK4B, and P16INK4A in the peripheral blood, and the loss of heterozygosity (homo/hemizygous deletion) of TP53 and P15INK4B/P16INK4A in two tumor tissues, from a Turkish family diagnosed with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. The propositus presented with a seminoma, his daughter with a medulloblastoma, and a healthy cousin exhibited a TP53 codon 292 missense point mutation (AAA->ATA; Lys->Ile) in peripheral blood cells. Tumor tissue from the propositus's seminoma demonstrated loss of heterozygosity in the TP53 gene. Analyses of tumor tissues from both the propositus and his daughter revealed a P16INK4A codon 94 missense point mutation (GCG->GAG; Ala->Glu) co-occurring with the hereditary TP53 mutation. This P16INK4A codon 94 mutation identified in our family represents a novel finding in Li-Fraumeni syndrome. No other genetic alterations were observed in TP53, P57KIP2, P15INK4B, and P16INK4A. The presence of the P16INK4A mutation alongside the hereditary TP53 mutation, irrespective of TP53 gene loss of heterozygosity (in seminoma/medulloblastoma), may suggest a shared mechanism in tumorigenesis. Furthermore, alterations in the TP53 and P16INK4A genes could serve as tumor markers within this family.

Genetic Alterations Involving Hereditary TP53 Codon 292 and Somatic P16INK4A Codon 94 in a Li-Fraumeni Syndrome Family. Li-Fraumeni syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder, is characterized by various cancer types in both children and adults. Our study focused on a Turkish family diagnosed with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, analyzing the mutational profiles of TP53, P57KIP2, P15INK4B, and P16INK4A in peripheral blood and the loss of heterozygosity (homo/hemizygous deletion) of TP53 and P15INK4B/P16INK4A in two tumor specimens. The proband was affected by seminoma, his daughter by medulloblastoma, and a healthy cousin carried a TP53 codon 292 missense point mutation (AAA->ATA; Lys->Ile) in peripheral blood cells. Loss of heterozygosity in the TP53 gene was detected in the tumor tissue from the proband's seminoma. Examination of tumor tissues from the proband and his daughter revealed a P16INK4A codon 94 missense point mutation (GCG->GAG; Ala->Glu) in conjunction with the inherited TP53 mutation. The concomitant presence of the P16INK4A mutation and the hereditary TP53 mutation, with or without TP53 gene loss of heterozygosity (in seminoma/medulloblastoma), suggests a potential common mechanism underlying tumorigenesis. These genetic changes in TP53 and P16INK4A could potentially serve as tumor markers for our family.

Co-occurrence of a Hereditary TP53 Codon 292 Mutation and a Somatic P16INK4A Codon 94 Mutation in a Li-Fraumeni Syndrome Case Study. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder marked by diverse cancer presentations in both childhood and adulthood. While hereditary TP53 mutations are rarely encountered in various human cancers, they are frequently associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Urinary Bladder Carcinoma Risk in Wegener's Granulomatosis and its Association with Cyclophosphamide Exposure. This study aimed to characterize and evaluate the risk of bladder cancer, and its association with cyclophosphamide therapy, in individuals diagnosed with Wegener's granulomatosis. A cohort of 1065 Wegener's granulomatosis patients, identified from the population-based, nationwide Swedish Inpatient Register between 1969 and 1995, was established. Bladder cancer diagnoses within this group were ascertained via linkage with the Swedish Cancer Register. A nested matched case-control study was conducted within the cohort to quantify the association between cyclophosphamide exposure and bladder cancer, utilizing odds ratios (ORs) as a measure of relative risk. Furthermore, the cumulative risk of bladder cancer post-Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis and the relative prevalence of pre-existing bladder cancer at the time of Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis were assessed within the cohort. The median cumulative cyclophosphamide doses were 113 g for cases (n = 11) and 25 g for controls (n = 25). Bladder cancer risk increased twofold for each 10 g increment in cyclophosphamide dose (OR = 2.0, 95% CI 0.8-4.9). Treatment duration exceeding one year corresponded to an eightfold elevated risk (OR = 7.7, 95% CI 0.9-69). The absolute bladder cancer risk within the cohort reached 10% at 16 years following a Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis. A history of bladder cancer was observed to be (non-significantly) twice as prevalent as anticipated at the time of Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis. These findings indicate a dose-response association between cyclophosphamide and bladder cancer risk, substantial cumulative risks within the overall cohort, and suggest the potential involvement of risk factors preceding the onset of Wegener's granulomatosis.

The Influence of Cyclophosphamide on Urinary Bladder Cancer Development in Wegener's Granulomatosis Patients. The objective of this research was to investigate and define the risk of bladder cancer, and its connection to cyclophosphamide administration, in patients afflicted with Wegener's granulomatosis. From the national, population-based Swedish Inpatient Register, a cohort comprising 1065 patients with Wegener's granulomatosis, diagnosed between 1969 and 1995, was compiled. To evaluate the relationship between cyclophosphamide and bladder cancer, a matched case-control study was performed, nested within the cohort, using odds ratios (ORs) as the measure of relative risk. Additionally, the cohort's cumulative risk of bladder cancer after a Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis and the relative prevalence of a prior bladder cancer history at the time of Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis were determined. Median cumulative cyclophosphamide doses were 113 g for cases (n = 11) and 25 g for controls (n = 25). The risk of bladder cancer was observed to double with every 10 g increase in cyclophosphamide (OR = 2.0, 95% CI 0.8 to 4.9). A treatment duration exceeding one year was linked to an eightfold increase in risk (OR = 7.7, 95% CI 0.9 to 69). The cohort's absolute risk for bladder cancer reached 10% at 16 years post-Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis, and a history of bladder cancer was (non-significantly) twice as common as expected when Wegener's granulomatosis was diagnosed. These results indicate a dose-response relationship between cyclophosphamide exposure and bladder cancer risk, along with high cumulative risks across the entire cohort, and suggest the existence of potential risk factors predating Wegener's granulomatosis.

Evaluation of Urinary Bladder Neoplasm Risk and its Relationship with Cyclophosphamide in Wegener's Granulomatosis. The primary objective of this investigation was to evaluate and detail the risk of bladder neoplasm and its relationship to cyclophosphamide administration in patients with Wegener's granulomatosis. Utilizing the population-based, nationwide Swedish Inpatient Register, a cohort of 1065 patients with Wegener's granulomatosis, spanning the years 1969-1995, was established. Through a connection with the Swedish Cancer Register, all subjects within this cohort diagnosed with bladder neoplasm were identified. A matched case-control analysis, nested within the cohort, determined the association between cyclophosphamide and bladder neoplasm using odds ratios (ORs) to quantify relative risk. Additionally, the cohort's cumulative risk of bladder neoplasm after Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis, and the relative incidence of a history of bladder neoplasm at the point of Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis, were estimated. Results indicated that the median cumulative cyclophosphamide doses were 113 g for cases (n = 11) and 25 g for controls (n = 25). The risk of bladder neoplasm showed a twofold increase for every 10 g increment in cyclophosphamide (OR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.8 to 4.9). A treatment duration exceeding one year was linked to an eightfold higher risk (OR = 7.7, 95% CI 0.9 to 69). The absolute risk for bladder neoplasm in the cohort attained 10% after 16 years subsequent to a Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis, and a history of bladder neoplasm was (non-significantly) twice as frequent as expected at the time of Wegener's granulomatosis diagnosis. Collectively, these data highlight a dose-response relationship between cyclophosphamide and bladder neoplasm risk, significant cumulative risks within the entire cohort, and suggest the possibility of pre-existing risk factors before the diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis.

Detection of BRCA1 Mutations in Primary Breast and Ovarian Carcinomas. Loss of heterozygosity data from familial tumors indicate that BRCA1, a gene imparting susceptibility to ovarian and early-onset breast cancer, functions as a tumor suppressor. The BRCA1 region also exhibits allelic loss in sporadic breast and ovarian cancers, suggesting that somatic BRCA1 mutations may occur in these tumors. The BRCA1 coding region was screened for mutations in primary breast and ovarian tumors demonstrating allele loss at the BRCA1 locus. Mutations were identified in 3 of 32 breast and 1 of 12 ovarian carcinomas; all four mutations were germline alterations and presented in early-onset cancers. These results suggest that mutation of BRCA1 may not be critical in the development of the majority of breast and ovarian cancers that arise in the absence of a mutant germline allele.

Prevalence and Nature of BRCA1 Alterations in Primary Breast and Ovarian Carcinomas. Data from familial tumor loss of heterozygosity imply that BRCA1, a gene conferring susceptibility to early-onset breast and ovarian cancer, encodes a tumor suppressor. Mutations were detected in 3 of 32 breast and 1 of 12 ovarian carcinomas; all four identified mutations were germline and associated with early-onset disease. This suggests that BRCA1 mutation may not be a pivotal factor in the pathogenesis of most breast and ovarian cancers developing without a pre-existing germline allele.

Germline and Somatic BRCA1 Mutations in Primary Breast and Ovarian Carcinomas. Based on loss of heterozygosity data from familial tumors, BRCA1, a gene linked to susceptibility to ovarian and early-onset breast cancer, is considered a tumor suppressor. The BRCA1 region is also prone to allelic loss in sporadic breast and ovarian cancers, indicating that somatic BRCA1 mutations might be present in these tumors. The BRCA1 coding sequence was assessed for mutations in primary breast and ovarian tumors displaying allelic loss at the BRCA1 locus. Mutations were identified in 3 out of 32 breast and 1 out of 12 ovarian carcinomas; all four detected alterations were germline and observed in early-onset cases. Essential Role of the Tumor Suppressor Gene Brca1 in Murine Embryonic Cell Proliferation. Human BRCA1 gene mutations are linked to an elevated risk of breast and ovarian cancers. Our findings indicate that heterozygous Brca1 (+/-) mice appear normal, are fertile, and do not develop tumors by 11 months of age. Conversely, homozygous Brca1 (5-6) mutant mice exhibit embryonic lethality, perishing before day 7.5 of gestation. These mutant embryos display stunted development and a complete absence of mesoderm. While the extraembryonic region is anomalous, lethality cannot be salvaged by aggregation with wild-type tetraploid embryos. In vivo, mutant embryos do not show heightened apoptosis but demonstrate diminished cell proliferation, correlating with reduced levels of cyclin E and mdm-2, a known regulator of p53 activity. Furthermore, the expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 is markedly elevated in these mutant embryos. Supporting these in vivo observations, in vitro studies reveal severely impaired growth of mutant blastocysts. Consequently, the demise of Brca1 (5-6) mutant embryos before gastrulation may stem from a failure in the essential proliferative burst necessary for germ layer formation.

Brca1, a Tumor Suppressor Gene, is Indispensable for Embryonic Cell Proliferation in Mice. A predisposition to breast and ovarian cancers in humans is associated with mutations in the BRCA1 gene. We report that Brca1 +/- mice are normal, fertile, and free of tumors at 11 months of age. However, homozygous Brca1 (5-6) mutant mice experience lethality before day 7.5 of embryogenesis. Mutant embryos are characterized by poor development and a lack of mesoderm formation. The extraembryonic region is abnormal; notably, this lethality is not rescued by aggregation with wild-type tetraploid embryos. In vivo analysis shows that mutant embryos do not have increased apoptosis but do exhibit reduced cellular proliferation. This reduction is accompanied by decreased expression of cyclin E and mdm-2, which regulates p53 activity. A dramatic increase in the expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 is also observed in mutant embryos. These in vivo findings are corroborated by in vitro evidence of severely impaired mutant blastocyst growth. Therefore, the premature death of Brca1 (5-6) mutant embryos before gastrulation may result from an inability to achieve the necessary proliferative burst for germ layer development.

Requirement of the Tumor Suppressor Brca1 for Murine Embryonic Cell Division. Mutations within the human BRCA1 gene confer a susceptibility to breast and ovarian malignancies. Our study demonstrates that Brca1 +/- mice appear phenotypically normal, are fertile, and remain tumor-free up to eleven months of age. In contrast, homozygous Brca1 (5-6) mutant mice fail to survive beyond embryonic day 7.5. These mutant embryos present with underdeveloped structures and a total absence of mesoderm. The extraembryonic tissues are anomalous, yet their demise is not ameliorated by aggregation with wild-type tetraploid embryos. In vivo observations indicate no elevated apoptosis in mutant embryos; instead, they display diminished cell proliferation alongside reduced expression of cyclin E and mdm-2, a crucial regulator of p53. Concurrently, the expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 is substantially elevated within these mutant embryos. Further supporting these in vivo findings, mutant blastocyst expansion is profoundly hampered in vitro. Thus, the pre-gastrulation mortality of Brca1 (5-6) mutant embryos is likely attributable to a deficiency in the proliferative surge essential for the genesis of distinct germ layers.

Brca1, a Tumor Suppressor, Governs Embryonic Cellular Proliferation in the Mouse. Human BRCA1 gene mutations are linked to an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers. This investigation reveals that Brca1 +/- mice exhibit normal development, maintain fertility, and are free of tumors through 11 months. However, homozygous Brca1 (5-6) mutants do not survive past embryonic day 7.5. These mutant embryos are poorly differentiated and entirely lack mesoderm formation. The extraembryonic region shows abnormalities, but the lethality is not overcome by combining them with wild-type tetraploid embryos. Within the living organism, mutant embryos do not display elevated apoptosis but instead show a reduction in cell proliferation, coupled with lower expression levels of cyclin E and mdm-2, a factor that regulates p53 activity. Furthermore, a marked increase in the expression of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21 is observed in the mutant embryos. Confirming these in vivo observations, mutant blastocysts exhibit significantly compromised growth in vitro. Therefore, the mortality of Brca1 (5-6) mutant embryos before gastrulation might be a consequence of the failure to achieve the critical proliferative burst necessary for the development of the various germ layers.

The RB1 Locus DNA Sequence Deletions in Retinoblastoma and Mesenchymal Tumors: Structure and Protein Characterization. Retinoblastoma, a childhood malignancy, originates from mutant alleles acquired through somatic or germline mutations, which can be transmitted through the germ line. These mutations inactivate copies of a recessive oncogene, the RB1 locus, located on chromosome 13 band q14. We previously reported isolating a cDNA fragment that identifies chromosomal sequences exhibiting characteristics of the retinoblastoma gene linked to the RB1 locus. We now present evidence that this specific segment is also susceptible to somatic mutations in mesenchymal tumors, even in patients with no known predisposition to or history of retinoblastoma. These observations further support that the identified cloned sequences represent a gene frequently inactivated during tumor development. However, sequence analysis of this cDNA offers limited understanding of its normal physiological function.

Characterization of a DNA Sequence and Its Encoded Protein Subject to Deletions in Retinoblastomas and Mesenchymal Tumors. Childhood retinoblastoma results from mutant alleles, acquired as either somatic or germinal mutations, which may be inherited. These pathogenic alleles lead to the inactivation of a recessive oncogene situated at the RB1 locus on chromosome 13, band q14. We now disclose that this segment is also targeted by somatic mutations in mesenchymal tumors, observed in patients with no discernible predisposition to or prior manifestation of retinoblastoma. These findings reinforce the notion that the cloned sequences correspond to a gene frequently targeted for inactivation during tumorigenesis. Nevertheless, sequence analysis of this cDNA provides minimal insight into its natural functional role.

Detection of low beta hexosaminidase A levels in healthy individuals with apparent enzyme deficiency. Measurable beta hexosaminidase A (Hex A) activity was observed in cultured skin fibroblasts and melanoma tissue obtained from healthy subjects previously identified as having a Hex A deficiency similar to that seen in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) patients. Quantification and identification of Hex A, representing 3.5% to 6.9% of total beta hexosaminidase activity, were achieved through cellulose acetate gel electrophoresis, DEAE-cellulose ion-exchange chromatography, radial immunodiffusion, and radioimmunoassay. Prior family investigations suggested these individuals might be compound heterozygotes for the prevalent TSD mutant gene and an uncommon (allelic) mutant gene. Consequently, the proposed rare mutant gene appears to encode for the expression of diminished Hex A quantities. Heterozygotes for this rare mutant may be indistinguishable from heterozygotes for the common TSD mutant. Nevertheless, the described methods for direct visualization and quantification of Hex A could prevent erroneous positive prenatal diagnoses of TSD in fetuses exhibiting the incomplete Hex A deficiency type observed in these four healthy individuals.

Characterization of low beta hexosaminidase A activity in healthy individuals presenting with presumed enzyme deficiency. Significant beta hexosaminidase A (Hex A) activity has been ascertained in cultured skin fibroblasts and melanoma tissue from healthy individuals previously reported to exhibit Hex A deficiency, comparable to that found in patients with Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). The identification and measurement of Hex A, constituting 3.5% to 6.9% of total beta hexosaminidase activity, were accomplished via cellulose acetate gel electrophoresis, DEAE-cellulose ion-exchange chromatography, radial immunodiffusion, and radioimmunoassay. Previous family studies indicated that these subjects could be compound heterozygotes for the common TSD mutant gene and a rare (allelic) mutant gene. Therefore, the postulated rare mutant gene seems to be responsible for the production of low amounts of Hex A. Heterozygotes for the rare mutant gene may not be discernible from heterozygotes for the common TSD mutant gene. However, the direct visualization and quantification of Hex A using the outlined methodologies offer a means to avert false-positive prenatal diagnoses of TSD in fetuses with the incomplete Hex A deficiency described in the four healthy subjects.

Re-evaluation of beta hexosaminidase A levels in healthy individuals with apparent deficiency. Appreciable activity of beta hexosaminidase A (Hex A) was detected in cultured skin fibroblasts and melanoma tissue originating from healthy individuals who had previously been designated as having a Hex A deficiency indistinguishable from that in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) patients. Identification and quantification of Hex A, accounting for 3.5%-6.9% of total beta hexosaminidase activity, were performed using cellulose acetate gel electrophoresis, DEAE-cellulose ion-exchange chromatography, radial immunodiffusion, and radioimmunoassay. Prior family investigations suggested these individuals might represent compound heterozygotes carrying both the common TSD mutant gene and a rare (allelic) mutant gene. It thus appears that the hypothesized rare mutant gene leads to the expression of reduced quantities of Hex A. Individuals heterozygous for this rare mutant might be indistinguishable from those heterozygous for the common TSD mutant. Nevertheless, the direct visualization and precise quantification of Hex A through the methods detailed here could prevent erroneous positive prenatal diagnoses of TSD in fetuses affected by the incomplete Hex A deficiency observed in the four healthy subjects.

The presence of low beta hexosaminidase A in healthy individuals with a reported deficiency. Detectable beta hexosaminidase A (Hex A) activity was found in cultured skin fibroblasts and melanoma tissue from healthy individuals previously documented as exhibiting Hex A deficiency, a condition outwardly resembling that of Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) patients. The identification and accurate measurement of Hex A, comprising 3.5% to 6.9% of total beta hexosaminidase activity, were achieved through a combination of cellulose acetate gel electrophoresis, DEAE-cellulose ion-exchange chromatography, radial immunodiffusion, and radioimmunoassay. Earlier family studies proposed that these individuals could be compound heterozygotes for the prevalent TSD mutant gene and an uncommon (allelic) mutant gene. Consequently, the hypothesized rare mutant gene appears to result in the expression of diminished Hex A levels. Heterozygotes for the rare mutant may be clinically indistinguishable from heterozygotes for the common TSD mutant. However, the application of direct Hex A visualization and quantification methods, as described, holds potential for averting false-positive prenatal diagnoses of TSD in fetuses presenting with the incomplete Hex A deficiency exemplified by the four healthy individuals.

No Significant Contribution of Common BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations to Early Prostate Cancer in Jewish Men. Families with a high prevalence of hereditary breast cancer, confirmed to possess truncating mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2, exhibit an elevated incidence of prostate cancer in male kin. Our objective was to assess if prevalent germline mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2 in Ashkenazi Jewish males conferred a predisposition to prostate cancer. We analyzed genomic DNA from 83 (for BRCA1 185delAG) or 82 (for BRCA2 6174delT) Ashkenazi Jewish prostate cancer patients, predominantly diagnosed at a younger age, for the most frequent germline mutations within each gene observed in the Ashkenazi population. This investigation possessed the power to identify a 4-5-fold increase in prostate cancer risk attributable to BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations. However, only one patient (1.15%; 95% CI, 0-3.6%) carried the heterozygous BRCA1 mutant allele, and only two patients (2.4%; 95% CI, 0-6.2%) were heterozygous for the BRCA2 mutation. The frequency of these germline mutations among the prostate cancer patients mirrored their approximately 1% prevalence in the general Ashkenazi Jewish population. This indicates that, dissimilar to breast and ovarian cancers, BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations do not significantly increase men's susceptibility to prostate cancer.

Common BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations: No Link to Early Prostate Cancer in Jewish Men. A higher incidence of prostate cancer has been observed among male relatives in families with significant hereditary breast cancer, subsequently identified with terminating BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations. Our study aimed to determine if the prevalent germline mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2 in Ashkenazi Jewish men predisposed them to prostate cancer. Genomic DNA was examined from 83 (for BRCA1 185delAG) or 82 (for BRCA2 6174delT) Ashkenazi Jewish prostate cancer patients, most of whom received treatment at a relatively early age. The analysis targeted the most common germline mutation in each gene found in the Ashkenazi population. This study was designed with the power to detect a 4-5-fold elevation in prostate cancer risk stemming from BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations. Nevertheless, only one patient (1.15%; 95% confidence interval, 0-3.6%) was heterozygous for the BRCA1 mutant allele, and only two patients (2.4%; 95% confidence interval, 0-6.2%) were heterozygous for the BRCA2 mutation. The observed frequency of these germline mutations in prostate cancer patients was consistent with their approximate 1% incidence in the broader Ashkenazi Jewish population. This implies that, unlike in breast and ovarian cancers, BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations do not substantially predispose men to prostate cancer.

Lack of Association Between Common BRCA1/2 Mutations and Early Prostate Cancer in Jewish Men. Families exhibiting a high frequency of hereditary breast cancer, later found to harbor truncating mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2, show an increased rate of prostate cancer among their male family members. Consequently, this suggests that, unlike in breast and ovarian cancers, BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations do not significantly increase the predisposition of men to prostate cancer.

Common BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations: No Role in Early Prostate Cancer in Jewish Men. Families with a high incidence of inherited breast cancer, subsequently identified as carrying terminating BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, exhibit an increased incidence of prostate cancer among male family members. Our aim was to ascertain whether the prevalent germline mutations of BRCA1 or BRCA2 in Ashkenazi Jewish men predispose them to prostate cancer. Genomic DNA was investigated from 83 (for BRCA1 185delAG) or 82 (for BRCA2 6174delT) Ashkenazi Jewish patients with prostate cancer, a majority of whom received treatment at a comparatively young age, to identify the most frequent germline mutation in each gene prevalent in the Ashkenazi population. This study possessed the statistical power to detect a 4-5-fold rise in prostate cancer risk due to BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations. Nevertheless, only one patient (1.15%; 95% confidence interval, 0-3.6%) was found to be heterozygous for the BRCA1 mutant allele, and only two patients (2.4%; 95% confidence interval, 0-6.2%) were heterozygous for the BRCA2 mutation. The frequency of these germline mutations among the prostate cancer patients was consistent with their approximate 1% frequency in the general Ashkenazi Jewish population. This suggests that, unlike the scenario in breast and ovarian cancers, mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2 do not significantly predispose men to prostate cancer.

A genetic linkage map construction using six polymorphic DNA markers flanking the familial adenomatous polyposis gene on chromosome 5. This report details a genetic linkage map incorporating six polymorphic DNA markers situated proximally to the familial adenomatous polyposis (APC) gene on chromosome 5q. The analysis involved 155 genotyped individuals from nine FAP families, contributing over 90 meioses to the linkage study. Critical recombination events, informative across three or more loci, were identified, enabling robust ordering of specific map segments. No evidence of genetic heterogeneity was observed, as all families demonstrated linkage between the gene and at least one chromosome 5 marker. Recombination analysis and two-point linkage data substantiate the locus order as centromere-pi 227-C11P11-ECB27-L5.62-APC-EF5.44-YN5.48-telomere, although the precise placement of EF5.44 could be within the L5.62-APC or ECB27-L5.62 intervals. No recombinants were detected between APC and either EF5.44 or YN5.48; however, prior deletion mapping in colorectal carcinomas and linkage studies in FAP indicate that YN5.48 is located 1-3 cM from APC. The current investigation suggests that YN5.48 and L5.62 define a compact chromosomal region on chromosome 5 where the EF5.44 locus resides in very close proximity to the APC gene. These findings are valuable for utilizing flanking markers in the presymptomatic diagnosis of FAP and for providing a high-resolution map of the region to facilitate isolation of the APC gene itself, as well as for further investigating the role of chromosome 5 deletions in the pathogenesis of sporadic colorectal cancer.

High-resolution genetic mapping of the familial adenomatous polyposis locus on chromosome 5 using polymorphic DNA markers. A high-resolution genetic linkage map, comprising six polymorphic DNA markers in the vicinity of the familial adenomatous polyposis (APC) gene on chromosome 5q, is presented. Linkage analysis was conducted using over 90 meioses obtained from 155 genotyped members across nine FAP kindreds. The identification of critical recombination events, informative across multiple loci, enabled a confident establishment of partial map order. Genetic heterogeneity was not evident, as all examined families showed linkage between the FAP gene and at least one marker on chromosome 5. Data from recombination analysis and two-point linkage studies support the following marker order: centromere-pi 227-C11P11-ECB27-L5.62-APC-EF5.44-YN5.48-telomere, with a noted ambiguity for EF5.44 potentially lying within the L5.62-APC or ECB27-L5.62 intervals. Despite the absence of observed recombinants between APC and EF5.44 or YN5.48 in this study, previous research involving deletion mapping in colorectal carcinomas and linkage analysis in FAP patients suggests a distance of 1-3 cM between YN5.48 and APC. This study indicates that the loci YN5.48 and L5.62 delimit a restricted segment of chromosome 5, within which EF5.44 is positioned very close to the APC gene. The generated map not only provides essential flanking markers for presymptomatic diagnosis of FAP but also offers a dense map of the region, crucial for isolating the APC gene and for further investigations into the contribution of chromosome 5 deletions to sporadic colorectal cancer biology.

Ordering of polymorphic DNA markers defining the familial adenomatous polyposis critical region on chromosome 5. A genetic linkage map, incorporating six polymorphic DNA markers proximal to the familial adenomatous polyposis (APC) gene on chromosome 5q, is described. The study population comprised 155 genotyped individuals from nine FAP families, providing in excess of 90 meioses for detailed linkage analysis. Crucial recombination events, informative for three or more loci, were identified, enabling a precise ordering of specific segments within the map. No evidence for genetic heterogeneity was found, as all participating families demonstrated linkage between at least one chromosome 5 marker and the FAP gene. Both recombination data and two-point linkage analysis consistently supported the locus order: centromere-pi 227-C11P11-ECB27-L5.62-APC-EF5.44-YN5.48-telomere, although the specific placement of EF5.44 remains uncertain, potentially residing within the L5.62-APC or ECB27-L5.62 intervals. While no recombinants were observed between APC and either EF5.44 or YN5.48 in this investigation, existing literature on deletion mapping in colorectal carcinomas and FAP linkage analysis suggests that YN5.48 is approximately 1-3 cM from APC. This current research proposes that YN5.48 and L5.62 demarcate a small genomic interval on chromosome 5 where the EF5.44 locus is situated in very close proximity to the APC gene. These data are significant, offering flanking markers for presymptomatic FAP diagnosis and supplying a high-density map of the region, vital for the isolation of the APC gene itself and for further evaluation of chromosome 5 deletions' role in the etiology of sporadic colorectal cancer.

Elucidating genetic linkage and refining the localization of the familial adenomatous polyposis gene on chromosome 5 via polymorphic DNA markers. A genetic linkage map, featuring six polymorphic DNA markers in close proximity to the familial adenomatous polyposis (APC) gene on chromosome 5q, is presented. The study leveraged over 90 meioses derived from 155 genotyped individuals across nine FAP kindreds for comprehensive linkage analysis. Informative recombination events, identified at three or more loci, were instrumental in confidently establishing sections of the map order. The absence of genetic heterogeneity was confirmed, as all families demonstrated linkage between the FAP gene and at least one chromosome 5 marker. Recombination data, combined with two-point linkage analysis, strongly supports the locus order of centromere-pi 227-C11P11-ECB27-L5.62-APC-EF5.44-YN5.48-telomere, with the caveat that EF5.44s exact position might be within the L5.62-APC or ECB27-L5.62 intervals. Although no recombinants were found between APC and either EF5.44 or YN5.48 in this investigation, previously published deletion mapping in colorectal carcinomas and FAP linkage analyses suggest that YN5.48 is situated 1-3 cM from APC. The present study further indicates that YN5.48 and L5.62 delineate a constrained region on chromosome 5, within which the EF5.44 locus is positioned extremely close to the APC gene. These findings are not only enabling the application of flanking markers for presymptomatic FAP diagnosis but also furnishing a high-density map of the region, essential for the isolation of the APC gene itself and for continued examination of the role of chromosome 5 deletions in the pathogenesis of sporadic colorectal cancer.

Regulation of axonal chemoattractant activity by metalloprotease action. Netrin-1, an axonal chemoattractant, directs spinal commissural axons through the activation of its receptor, DCC (Deleted in Colorectal Cancer). Our research revealed that chemical metalloprotease inhibitors enhance netrin-mediated axon outgrowth when studied in vitro. We further discovered that DCC undergoes metalloprotease-dependent ectodomain shedding, and that these inhibitors prevent DCC's proteolytic processing, leading to elevated DCC protein levels on axons within spinal cord explants. Consequently, the observed enhancement of netrin activity by inhibitors likely stems from the stabilization of DCC on axons, suggesting that proteolytic activity may govern axon migration by managing the quantity of active extracellular axon guidance receptors.

Metalloprotease influence on axonal chemoattractant function. The axonal chemoattractant, netrin-1, facilitates the guidance of spinal commissural axons via its receptor, DCC (Deleted in Colorectal Cancer). Our investigation demonstrated that chemical inhibitors targeting metalloproteases augment netrin-induced axon outgrowth under in vitro conditions. Furthermore, we identified DCC as a target for metalloprotease-mediated ectodomain shedding; these inhibitors impede DCC's proteolytic cleavage, resulting in increased DCC protein abundance on axons within spinal cord explants. This suggests that the potentiation of netrin activity by these inhibitors might arise from the stabilization of DCC on axons, implying that proteolytic processes could regulate axon migration by modulating the availability of functional extracellular axon guidance receptors.

Therefore, the enhanced netrin activity observed with inhibitors could stem from the stabilization of DCC on axons, proposing that proteolytic activity may control axon migration by determining the quantity of functional extracellular axon guidance receptors.

Identification of a KIT Protooncogene Mutation in Human Piebaldism. Piebaldism, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder, manifests as congenital skin and hair patches entirely lacking melanocytes. The murine condition, dominant white spotting (W), arises from c-Kit protooncogene mutations, which encode the mast/stem cell growth factor receptor. We detected a specific KIT gene mutation in a proband presenting with classic autosomal dominant piebaldism. This mutation leads to a Gly-Arg substitution at codon 664, situated within the tyrosine kinase domain. Crucially, this substitution was absent in normal individuals and demonstrated complete linkage to the piebald phenotype within the proband's family. Consequently, piebaldism in this lineage appears to represent the human counterpart of mouse dominant white spotting (W).

The Genetic Basis of Human Piebaldism: Mutation of the KIT Protooncogene. Human piebaldism is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by congenital absence of melanocytes in distinct skin and hair patches. Paralleling this, dominant white spotting (W) in mice is caused by mutations in the c-Kit protooncogene, which encodes the receptor for mast/stem cell growth factor. Our investigation identified a KIT gene mutation in a proband displaying typical autosomal dominant piebaldism. This mutation involves a Gly-Arg substitution at codon 664, located within the tyrosine kinase domain. This specific substitution was not observed in unaffected individuals and showed absolute linkage to the piebald phenotype in the proband's family. These findings establish piebaldism in this family as the human homologue to mouse dominant white spotting (W).

Role of KIT Protooncogene Mutation in Human Piebaldism Etiology. This evidence strongly suggests that piebaldism in this family is the human counterpart to murine dominant white spotting (W).
