Erythropoietin's Reversal of Anemia-Mediated Diminishment of Cyclophosphamide Efficacy in Rat Tumors. This investigation aimed to determine how preventing anemia through recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) treatment influences cyclophosphamide cytotoxicity in solid experimental tumors. Anemia was induced by a single intravenous carboplatin dose (50 mg/kg), causing a sustained 30% decrease in hemoglobin concentration. In a separate group, anemia development was averted with rHuEPO (1000 IU/kg) administered subcutaneously thrice weekly, commencing 7 days prior to carboplatin. DS-sarcoma rat tumors were implanted subcutaneously on the hind foot dorsum four days post-carboplatin administration. Neither carboplatin nor rHuEPO monotherapy affected tumor growth rate. A single intraperitoneal dose of cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg) administered five days after implantation resulted in tumor growth delay followed by subsequent regrowth. In the anemic cohort, the growth delay was markedly shorter (8.6 days) compared to nonanemic controls (13.3 days). Conversely, in the group where anemia was prevented by rHuEPO, the growth delay matched that of nonanemic controls (13.3 days). These findings indicate that chemotherapy-induced anemia diminishes cyclophosphamide cytotoxicity in tumors, while anemia correction using rHuEPO (epoetin alpha) enhances sensitivity, likely due to improved oxygen delivery to the tumor tissue.

Recombinant Erythropoietin Counteracts Anemia-Induced Attenuation of Cyclophosphamide Cytotoxicity in Rat Tumors. The objective of this study was to assess the effect of preventing anemia with recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) on the cytotoxic activity of cyclophosphamide against solid experimental tumors. Anemia was established via a single intravenous carboplatin injection (50 mg/kg), which led to a persistent 30% reduction in hemoglobin levels. A second group received rHuEPO (1000 IU/kg) subcutaneously three times per week, beginning seven days before carboplatin application, to prevent anemia. Four days after carboplatin treatment, DS-sarcoma of the rat tumors were implanted subcutaneously onto the hind foot dorsum. Neither carboplatin nor rHuEPO treatments independently affected the tumor growth rate. When tumors were treated with a single intraperitoneal dose of cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg) five days post-implantation, a period of growth delay followed by tumor regrowth was observed. The anemic group exhibited a significantly shorter growth delay (8.6 days) compared to the nonanemic control group (13.3 days). In the group where rHuEPO prevented anemia, the growth delay was comparable to that of nonanemic controls (13.3 days). These results suggest that cyclophosphamide cytotoxicity in tumors is reduced by chemotherapy-induced anemia, and that correcting anemia with rHuEPO (epoetin alpha) increases tumor sensitivity, possibly by enhancing oxygen supply to the tumor tissue.

Amelioration of Anemia-Dependent Cyclophosphamide Cytotoxicity Impairment in Rat Tumors by Erythropoietin. This study sought to investigate the influence of anemia prevention, achieved through recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) administration, on the cytotoxic effectiveness of cyclophosphamide in experimental solid tumors. Anemia was instigated by a single intravenous dose of carboplatin (50 mg/kg), resulting in a prolonged 30% decrease in hemoglobin concentration. For a second experimental group, rHuEPO (1000 IU/kg) was subcutaneously administered three times weekly, starting one week prior to carboplatin, to preclude anemia. Four days following carboplatin treatment, DS-sarcoma of the rat tumors were surgically implanted subcutaneously onto the hind foot dorsum. It was observed that neither carboplatin nor rHuEPO treatment, when administered alone, impacted the tumor growth rate. Five days after implantation, tumors received a single intraperitoneal dose of cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg), leading to an initial growth delay followed by tumor resurgence. The anemic group demonstrated a statistically shorter growth delay (8.6 days) relative to the nonanemic control group (13.3 days). Crucially, the group in which rHuEPO prevented anemia exhibited a growth delay equivalent to that of nonanemic controls (13.3 days). These findings propose that chemotherapy-induced anemia diminishes the cytotoxic action of cyclophosphamide in tumors, whereas rectifying anemia with rHuEPO (epoetin alpha) heightens tumor sensitivity, likely attributable to an improved oxygen supply to the tumor microenvironment.

Erythropoietin Restitution of Cyclophosphamide Efficacy Against Anemia-Compromised Rat Tumors. This research aimed to evaluate the effect of preventing anemia, via recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) therapy, on cyclophosphamide cytotoxicity within solid experimental tumors. Anemia was induced using a single intravenous carboplatin dose (50 mg/kg), which resulted in a persistent 30% reduction of hemoglobin levels. In a parallel group, rHuEPO (1000 IU/kg) was administered subcutaneously three times per week, commencing seven days before carboplatin application, to prevent anemia development. Four days after carboplatin treatment, DS-sarcoma rat tumors were implanted subcutaneously on the hind foot dorsum. Neither carboplatin nor rHuEPO treatment, in isolation, affected the tumor growth kinetics. Upon treating tumors with a single intraperitoneal dose of cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg) five days post-implantation, a period of arrested growth followed by tumor progression was noted. The anemic group displayed a significantly reduced growth delay (8.6 days) compared to nonanemic controls (13.3 days). Conversely, the group where anemia was mitigated by rHuEPO treatment showed a growth delay duration comparable to nonanemic controls (13.3 days). These data suggest that chemotherapy-associated anemia compromises cyclophosphamide's cytotoxic potential in tumors, while rHuEPO (epoetin alpha) correction of anemia enhances tumor responsiveness, ostensibly due to an augmented oxygen supply to neoplastic tissue.

The Efficacy and Safety of Paclitaxel, Cisplatin, and Gemcitabine Combination Chemotherapy in Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma Management. BACKGROUND: Advanced non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) patients benefit from cisplatin-based chemotherapy combinations, which improve quality of life and survival. The emergence of novel active agents presents an opportunity for developing more effective therapeutic strategies for this disease. METHODS: This study aimed to assess the feasibility, response rates, and toxicity profile of a paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine regimen in metastatic NSCLC. Thirty-five consecutive chemotherapy-naive patients with Stage IV NSCLC and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2 were administered paclitaxel (135 mg/m intravenously over 3 hours) on Day 1, cisplatin (120 mg/m intravenously over 6 hours) on Day 1, and gemcitabine (800 mg/m intravenously over 30 minutes) on Days 1 and 8, every 4 weeks. While consolidation radiotherapy was planned for responders and 24 patients received pre-planned second-line chemotherapy post-progression, the reported response and toxicity rates pertain exclusively to the initial chemotherapy. RESULTS: All patients underwent toxicity assessment, and 34 were evaluable for response. An objective response was noted in 73.5% of patients (95% confidence interval [CI], 55.6-87.1%), including 4 complete responses (11.7%). According to intention-to-treat analysis, the overall response rate was 71.4% (95% CI, 53.7-85.4%). Across 154 treatment courses, the median dose intensity for paclitaxel was 131 mg/m (97.3%), for cisplatin 117 mg/m (97.3%), and for gemcitabine 1378 mg/m (86.2%). WHO Grade 3-4 neutropenia and thrombocytopenia occurred in 39.9% and 11.4% of patients, respectively. One treatment-related fatality was recorded. Nonhematologic toxicities were generally mild. After a median follow-up period of 22 months, the median progression-free survival was 7 months, and the median overall survival time was 16 months. CONCLUSIONS: The combined regimen of paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine demonstrates good tolerability and substantial activity in metastatic NSCLC. This therapeutic approach warrants further investigation and comparison with other cisplatin-based protocols.

Multidisciplinary Therapeutic Application of Paclitaxel, Cisplatin, and Gemcitabine Combination in Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma. BACKGROUND: Improved quality of life and survival for advanced non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) patients are associated with cisplatin-based chemotherapy regimens. The introduction of new active agents holds potential for developing more effective treatments for this malignancy. METHODS: This study's primary objective was to determine the safety, response, and tolerability of a triple-drug combinationpaclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabinefor metastatic NSCLC. Thirty-five chemotherapy-naive patients, all with Stage IV NSCLC and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2, received paclitaxel (135 mg/m IV over 3 hours) on Day 1, cisplatin (120 mg/m IV over 6 hours) on Day 1, and gemcitabine (800 mg/m IV over 30 minutes) on Days 1 and 8, administered every four weeks. While responding individuals were slated for consolidation radiotherapy and 24 patients received subsequent second-line chemotherapy following disease progression, the reported response and toxicity rates specifically pertain to the administered chemotherapy regimen. RESULTS: Toxicity was assessed in all patients; response was assessable in 34. An objective response was achieved in 73.5% of patients (95% confidence interval [CI], 55.6-87.1%), with 4 complete responses (11.7%) among them. The intention-to-treat analysis revealed an overall response rate of 71.4% (95% CI, 53.7-85.4%). Over 154 courses of therapy, the median dose intensity reached 131 mg/m for paclitaxel (97.3%), 117 mg/m for cisplatin (97.3%), and 1378 mg/m for gemcitabine (86.2%). Grade 3-4 neutropenia and thrombocytopenia (WHO criteria) affected 39.9% and 11.4% of patients, respectively. One death was attributed to treatment. Non-hematologic toxicities were reported as mild. Following a median observation period of 22 months, the median progression-free survival was 7 months, and the median overall survival was 16 months. CONCLUSIONS: The combined treatment of paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine is both well-tolerated and highly effective in metastatic NSCLC, meriting further comparative studies against existing cisplatin-based regimens.

A Clinical Evaluation of Paclitaxel, Cisplatin, and Gemcitabine in the Multimodal Treatment of Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma. BACKGROUND: For patients with advanced non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), cisplatin-based chemotherapy combinations have been shown to enhance both quality of life and survival. The availability of new active therapeutic agents suggests the potential for developing even more efficacious regimens for this condition. METHODS: This investigation aimed to determine the feasibility, response rate, and adverse effects of a paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine combination for treating metastatic NSCLC. A cohort of 35 consecutive chemotherapy-naive patients with Stage IV NSCLC and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status ranging from 0 to 2 received paclitaxel (135 mg/m IV for 3 hours) on Day 1, cisplatin (120 mg/m IV for 6 hours) on Day 1, and gemcitabine (800 mg/m IV for 30 minutes) on Days 1 and 8, administered every 4 weeks. Although consolidation radiotherapy was planned for those who responded, and 24 patients subsequently received second-line chemotherapy after disease progression, the reported response and toxicity data strictly pertain to the initial chemotherapy protocol. RESULTS: All patients were assessed for toxicity; 34 were eligible for response evaluation. An objective response was documented in 73.5% of the patients (95% confidence interval [CI], 55.6-87.1%), which included 4 complete responses (11.7%). Based on an intention-to-treat approach, the overall response rate was 71.4% (95% CI, 53.7-85.4%). Across 154 treatment courses, the median dose intensity observed was 131 mg/m for paclitaxel (97.3%), 117 mg/m for cisplatin (97.3%), and 1378 mg/m for gemcitabine (86.2%). WHO Grade 3-4 neutropenia and thrombocytopenia were observed in 39.9% and 11.4% of patients, respectively. One treatment-related death occurred. Nonhematologic toxicities were characterized as mild. With a median follow-up of 22 months, the median progression-free survival was 7 months, and the median survival duration was 16 months. CONCLUSIONS: The combination of paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine demonstrates high activity and is well-tolerated in metastatic NSCLC, thereby justifying further comparative studies against other cisplatin-based regimens.

Outcomes of a Paclitaxel, Cisplatin, and Gemcitabine Regimen within a Multidisciplinary Approach for Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma. BACKGROUND: For patients battling advanced non-small cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC), cisplatin-containing chemotherapy combinations have demonstrably improved both their quality of life and survival. The emergence of new, potent drugs presents an opportunity to devise more efficacious treatment protocols for this disease. METHODS: This investigation sought to ascertain the feasibility, rate of response, and toxicity associated with a regimen combining paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine in metastatic NSCLC. Thirty-five consecutive patients, all chemotherapy-naive with Stage IV NSCLC and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2, received paclitaxel (135 mg/m intravenously over 3 hours) on Day 1, cisplatin (120 mg/m intravenously over 6 hours) on Day 1, and gemcitabine (800 mg/m intravenously over 30 minutes) on Days 1 and 8, administered every four weeks. While responding patients were intended to receive consolidation radiotherapy, and 24 patients proceeded to pre-planned second-line chemotherapy subsequent to disease progression, the reported response and toxicity figures are exclusively attributable to the specific chemotherapy regimen administered. RESULTS: All participants were screened for toxicity; 34 were evaluable for therapeutic response. An objective response was recorded in 73.5% of patients (95% confidence interval [CI], 55.6-87.1%), including four cases of complete response (11.7%). Based on an intention-to-treat basis, the overall response rate stood at 71.4% (95% CI, 53.7-85.4%). Over 154 courses of treatment, the median dose intensity was 131 mg/m for paclitaxel (97.3%), 117 mg/m for cisplatin (97.3%), and 1378 mg/m for gemcitabine (86.2%). WHO Grade 3-4 neutropenia and thrombocytopenia manifested in 39.9% and 11.4% of patients, respectively. A single treatment-related death occurred. Non-hematologic toxicities were generally mild. Following a median observation period of 22 months, the median progression-free survival was 7 months, and the median overall survival duration was 16 months. CONCLUSIONS: The combination of paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine is well-tolerated and exhibits significant activity in metastatic NSCLC, warranting further comparative studies against other cisplatin-based regimens.

Genomic Rearrangements of the APC Tumor Suppressor Gene Identified in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a hereditary colorectal cancer syndrome, is caused by germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene. While most known APC mutations involve single-nucleotide changes or small indels that truncate the protein, intragenic APC rearrangements have been poorly characterized, and their frequency in FAP patients remains unknown. In a screen of 49 prospective FAP families, we uncovered 26 distinct germline APC mutations across 30 families. Notably, four of these mutations were genomic rearrangements, originating from Alu element-mediated homologous and nonhomologous recombinations. Two of these four rearrangements exhibited complexity, involving both nucleotide deletion and insertion. Specifically, one rearrangement led to the deletion of exons 11 and 12, while two others caused either complete or partial deletion of exon 14. The fourth rearrangement significantly altered the sequence within intron 14; although not affecting APC coding sequence at the genomic DNA level, it induced inappropriate splicing of exon 14. These rearrangements were initially detected through cDNA analysis, a method essential as traditional exon-by-exon mutation screening would not have identified them. The discovery of a splicing-affecting rearrangement without coding exon alteration further highlights the critical role of cDNA in mutation analysis. The presence of four genomic rearrangements among 30 identified mutations indicates that these alterations represent a common type of germline APC mutation.

Novel Genomic Rearrangements of the APC Tumor Suppressor Gene in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. Germline mutations within the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene are responsible for familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a hereditary form of colorectal cancer. While most reported APC mutations consist of single-nucleotide alterations, minor insertions, or small deletions that lead to truncated protein products, well-characterized intragenic rearrangements of APC have been scarce, and their prevalence among FAP patients remains unclear. Our investigation of 49 potential FAP families led to the detection of 26 distinct germline APC mutations across 30 families. Among these, four mutations were identified as genomic rearrangements, arising from homologous and nonhomologous recombinations mediated by Alu elements. Two of these four rearrangements presented as complex events, encompassing both nucleotide deletions and insertions. Specifically, one rearrangement entailed the deletion of exons 11 and 12, and two others caused either a complete or partial deletion of exon 14. The fourth rearrangement significantly altered the intronic sequence within intron 14; despite not affecting any APC coding sequence at the genomic DNA level, it provoked aberrant splicing of exon 14. These rearrangements were initially discerned through cDNA analysis and would have been missed by mutation detection methods relying on individual exon screening. The observation of a rearrangement impacting splicing without altering coding exons further underscores the significance of employing cDNA for comprehensive mutation analysis. The presence of four genomic rearrangements among 30 total mutations implies that these alterations represent a significant proportion of germline APC mutations.

Frequency and Characterization of APC Tumor Suppressor Gene Genomic Rearrangements in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a hereditary colorectal cancer predisposition syndrome, stems from germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene. While the majority of characterized APC mutations are single-nucleotide changes or small insertions/deletions that result in protein truncation, intragenic genomic rearrangements of APC have not been thoroughly described, and their prevalence in FAP patients remains undefined. In a cohort of 49 candidate FAP families, we identified 26 distinct germline APC mutations across 30 families. Notably, four of these mutations constituted genomic rearrangements, mediated by Alu elements through homologous and nonhomologous recombination events. Two of these four rearrangements were intricate, involving both deletion and insertion of nucleotides. Specifically, one rearrangement caused the deletion of exons 11 and 12, while two others led to either complete or partial deletion of exon 14. A fourth rearrangement profoundly modified the sequence within intron 14; although it did not alter any coding sequence of APC at the genomic DNA level, it did induce inappropriate splicing of exon 14. These rearrangements, which were initially discerned through cDNA analysis, would have eluded detection by mutation screening methods examining each exon individually. The finding of a rearrangement that did not affect coding exons but nevertheless impacted splicing further underscores the value of cDNA for comprehensive mutation analysis. The discovery of four genomic rearrangements among 30 total mutations strongly suggests that genomic rearrangements represent a frequent class of germline APC mutations.

Retinyl Acetate's Co-Carcinogenic Role in Butylated Hydroxyanisole-Induced Forestomach Carcinogenesis in Male F344 Rats. This study investigated the potential modulating effect of retinyl acetate (RA) on butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA)-induced tumorigenesis in the rat forestomach. Male F344 rats, aged 5 weeks, were fed diets containing either 1% or 2% BHA by weight, concurrently receiving RA-supplemented drinking water at varying concentrations (w/v) over a 52-week period. Among groups administered 2% BHA, while all animals displayed pronounced hyperplastic alterations of the forestomach epithelium, the concurrent administration of 0.25% RA significantly (P < 0.05) elevated the incidence of forestomach tumors (squamous cell papilloma and carcinoma) to 60% (9/15, including 2 rats with carcinoma) from 15% (3/20, including one rat with carcinoma) observed in the group without RA. In rats receiving 1% BHA, RA co-administration at doses of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.2%, or 0.25% demonstrated a dose-dependent augmentative influence on the progression of BHA-induced epithelial hyperplasia. Tumors, exclusively papillomas, developed in 3 rats (17%) with 0.25% RA and in one rat (10%) with 0.05% RA co-administration. RA administered alone did not induce hyperplastic changes in the forestomach. These findings suggest that RA functions as a co-carcinogen in BHA-mediated forestomach carcinogenesis in the rat.

The Joint Carcinogenic Effect of Retinyl Acetate on Butylated Hydroxyanisole-Stimulated Forestomach Cancer Development in Male F344 Rats. For rats given 1% BHA, RA supplied at concentrations of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.2%, or 0.25% displayed a dose-responsive enhancing effect on the emergence of BHA-provoked epithelial hyperplasia. Tumors, all identified as papillomas, arose in 3 rats (17%) when 0.25% RA was co-administered and in one rat (10%) with 0.05% RA co-administration. Retinyl acetate by itself did not induce hyperplastic changes within the forestomach. These results indicate that RA acted synergistically as a co-carcinogen in the BHA-driven forestomach carcinogenesis in rats.

Evaluation of Carboplatin and Liposomal Doxorubicin in Recurrent Cervical Squamous Cell Carcinoma: A Phase II Investigation. BACKGROUND: A Phase II study evaluated the activity of combined carboplatin and liposomal doxorubicin in patients with recurrent cervical carcinoma. METHODS: Thirty-seven patients presenting with recurrent squamous cell cervical carcinoma received intravenous carboplatin (area under the concentration curve [AUC], 5) and liposomal doxorubicin (Doxil; initial dose 40 mg/m^2) every 28 days to determine their antitumor efficacy and safety profile. RESULTS: Twenty-nine patients were evaluable for response, and 35 for toxicity. The overall response rate achieved was 38%. The median time to response was 10 weeks, the median response duration was 26 weeks, and median survival extended to 37 weeks. Myelosuppression was the primary toxicity, manifesting as Grade 3 and 4 neutropenia in 16 patients, anemia in 12, thrombocytopenia in 11, and neutropenic fever in 3. Five infusion-related reactions occurred in four patients during liposomal doxorubicin administration, resulting in treatment cessation for three. Grade >= 2 nonhematologic toxicities included nausea (17 patients), emesis (14 patients), fatigue (9 patients), mucositis and/or stomatitis (8 patients), constipation (6 patients), weight loss (5 patients), hand-foot syndrome (2 patients), and skin reactions (3 patients). CONCLUSIONS: The combination of carboplatin and liposomal doxorubicin demonstrates modest activity in individuals with recurrent cervical carcinoma.

CONCLUSIONS: The combination therapy of carboplatin and liposomal doxorubicin exhibits modest therapeutic efficacy in recurrent cervical carcinoma patients.

An In Vivo/In Vitro Cytogenetic Assessment of Ifosfamide, Mesna, and Their Combined Effects on Rabbit Peripheral Lymphocytes. Ifosfamide (IFO), an alkylating nitrogen mustard, functions as an antineoplastic agent but is known for its severe urotoxic effects, including hemorrhagic cystitis. To mitigate this adverse effect, IFO is often co-administered with sodium 2-sulfanylethanesulfonate (Mesna). This study investigated the cytogenetic impacts of IFO and Mesna, administered individually to rabbit lymphocytes in vivo and subsequently analyzed in vitro. Sister chromatid exchanges (SCEs), proliferation rate index (PRI), and Mitotic Index served as cytogenetic markers. Results showed that Mesna co-administration with IFO lowered SCE frequencies compared to IFO administration alone. Furthermore, high concentrations of Mesna administered independently resulted in notable reductions in PRI when contrasted with IFO at an equivalent concentration in lymphocytes. In conclusion, Mesna significantly attenuates IFO's genotoxicity, yet at elevated concentrations, it exhibits an inhibitory effect on the drug's cytostatic activity.

Cytogenetic Effects of Ifosfamide, Mesna, and Co-administration on Peripheral Rabbit Lymphocytes: An In Vivo/In Vitro Study. Ifosfamide (IFO), an antineoplastic alkylating nitrogen mustard, is associated with substantial urotoxicity, manifesting as hemorrhagic cystitis. Consequently, its administration often involves the concurrent use of sodium 2-sulfanylethanesulfonate (Mesna) to prevent or reduce this toxicity. In this in vivo/in vitro cytogenetic investigation, IFO and Mesna were individually applied to rabbit lymphocytes, which were subsequently cultured. Cytogenetic endpoints, including sister chromatid exchanges (SCEs), proliferation rate index (PRI), and Mitotic Index, were evaluated. The combined administration of Mesna with IFO led to a reduction in SCE frequency when compared to IFO given alone. Additionally, high concentrations of Mesna, when administered independently, demonstrated significant decreases in PRI in contrast to IFO applied at the same concentration to lymphocytes. This indicates that Mesna substantially diminishes IFO's genotoxic potential, although high concentrations of Mesna can concurrently inhibit the drug's cytostatic action.

Hormonal Influences on Breast Cancer Risk. A study was conducted on 50 menopausal women undergoing hormone replacement therapy. Twenty-nine of these participants had experienced surgical menopause, with a mean age of 45.7 years. The hypothesis posited that progestins could counteract estrogenic stimulation's impact on mammary and endometrial target tissues in women receiving HRT. The therapy regime involved 1.25 mg/day of conjugated estrogens (Premarin) for 21 days monthly, alongside 10 mg/day of Medroxyprogesterone acetate for 10 days each month. The average treatment duration spanned 18 months. Breast changes were monitored during follow-up through symptom assessment, physical examination, and plate thermography. Twenty-one patients reported mastodynia. Physical examination identified a slight increase in breast firmness in 12 women and a moderate increase in breast nodularity in 2 women. Thermography validated excessive breast stimulation in one woman experiencing moderate mastodynia and in five out of seven women with severe mastodynia. Reducing the estrogen dosage by half successfully normalized these conditions. The findings indicate that HRT can be administered safely, provided certain criteria are met: 1) a comprehensive preliminary patient assessment covering clinical, metabolic, cytologic, and mammographic aspects; 2) a cyclic treatment regimen incorporating a 10-day progestative phase; and 3) regular, thorough follow-up, including precise thermographic assessment of breast target tissues.

Validation of BRCA1 through Germline Mutation Analysis in Ten Families Affected by Breast and Ovarian Cancer. This study presents genetic evidence supporting the identification of the candidate BRCA1 gene by characterizing germline mutations in a cohort of 63 breast cancer patients and 10 ovarian cancer patients across ten families where cancer was linked to chromosome 17q21. Nine distinct mutations were identified following the screening of BRCA1 DNA and RNA using single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis and direct sequencing. Seven of these mutations resulted in protein truncations at various locations within the gene. A single missense mutation, independently observed in two families, caused the loss of a cysteine in the zinc binding domain. Furthermore, an intronic single basepair substitution was found to abolish an acceptor site and activate a cryptic splice site, leading to a 59 basepair insertion and subsequent chain termination. Notably, the four families exhibiting both breast and ovarian cancer harbored chain termination mutations situated in the N-terminal region of the protein.

Genetic Verification of BRCA1 via Germline Mutation Characterization in Ten Breast and Ovarian Cancer Families. Genetic data is presented to substantiate the identity of BRCA1 as a candidate gene, derived from the characterization of germline mutations in 63 individuals with breast cancer and 10 with ovarian cancer within ten families whose cancer segregated with chromosome 17q21. A total of nine unique mutations were uncovered through single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis and direct sequencing of BRCA1 DNA and RNA. Protein truncation at various sites throughout the gene was the outcome for seven of these mutations. One missense mutation, appearing independently in two families, led to the depletion of a cysteine within the zinc binding domain. Additionally, an intronic single basepair change eliminated an acceptor site and prompted the activation of a cryptic splice site, culminating in a 59 basepair insertion and chain termination. In the four families afflicted by both breast and ovarian cancer, chain termination mutations were located in the N-terminal segment of the protein.

Seven mutations resulted in the premature termination of protein synthesis at various positions across the gene. One missense mutation, independently observed in two family lineages, caused the absence of a cysteine residue within the zinc binding domain. Furthermore, an intronic single basepair substitution was found to obliterate an acceptor site and induce a cryptic splice site activation, leading to a 59 basepair insertion and subsequent chain termination. The four families presenting with both breast and ovarian cancer possessed chain termination mutations situated within the N-terminal portion of the protein.

Characterization of BRCA1 Germline Mutations Confirming Gene Identity in Ten Breast and Ovarian Cancer Kindreds. We present compelling genetic evidence affirming the identity of BRCA1 as a candidate gene, established through the characterization of germline mutations in 63 individuals diagnosed with breast cancer and 10 with ovarian cancer, drawn from ten kindreds demonstrating cancer linkage to chromosome 17q21. Nine disparate mutations were identified following the examination of BRCA1 DNA and RNA utilizing single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis and direct sequencing techniques. Seven of these mutations induced protein truncations at multiple sites across the gene. A unique missense mutation, independently identified in two separate kindreds, resulted in the deletion of a cysteine within the zinc binding domain. Moreover, an intronic single basepair alteration was observed to eliminate an acceptor site and concurrently trigger a cryptic splice site, culminating in a 59 basepair insertion and protein chain termination. Specifically, the four kindreds presenting with both breast and ovarian malignancies exhibited chain termination mutations located in the N-terminal half of the protein.

A Comprehensive Analysis of RB1 Germline Mutation Types in Hereditary Retinoblastoma. Investigations were conducted to identify germline RB1 mutations in 119 individuals diagnosed with hereditary retinoblastoma. Following initial detection of mutations in 48 patients through Southern blot hybridization and PCR fragment-length analysis, the remaining 71 patients underwent further investigation. Utilizing heteroduplex analysis, nonisotopic SSCP, and direct sequencing, germline mutations leading to premature termination codons or disrupted splice signals were discovered in 51 (72%) of these 71 patients. Additionally, four patients exhibited rare sequence variants. No specific region of the RB1 gene demonstrated a preference for single base substitutions, though recurrent transitions were noted at most of the 14 codons within RB1. Intriguingly, no mutations were found in exons 25-27, despite the presence of two CGA codons, suggesting that mutations in the 3-terminal region of RB1 might not be oncogenic. Combining these findings with previous data, mutations were ultimately identified in 99 (83%) of the 119 patients. The mutational landscape comprised 15% large deletions, 26% small length alterations, and 42% base substitutions. Importantly, no correlation was established between the position of frameshift or nonsense mutations and clinical characteristics such as age at diagnosis, tumor foci count, or the presence of nonocular tumors.

The Essential Role of BRCA1 in Transcription-Coupled Repair of Oxidative DNA Damage. BRCA1, a gene linked to breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility, codes for a zinc finger protein whose precise function remains to be elucidated. Its interaction with the DNA repair protein Rad51, alongside alterations in its phosphorylation state and cellular distribution following exposure to DNA-damaging agents, strongly implies a function for BRCA1 in DNA repair processes. This study demonstrates that mouse embryonic stem cells lacking BRCA1 exhibit impairments in performing transcription-coupled repair of oxidative DNA damage. Furthermore, these cells display heightened sensitivity to both ionizing radiation and hydrogen peroxide. These findings collectively propose that BRCA1 is involved, either directly or indirectly, in the transcription-coupled repair pathway for oxidative DNA damage.

BRCA1's Requirement for the Transcription-Coupled Repair of Oxidative DNA Damage. The BRCA1 gene, associated with susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers, produces a zinc finger protein whose function is not yet fully understood. Observations such as the binding of BRCA1 protein with the DNA repair protein Rad51, and changes in its phosphorylation and cellular location after exposure to DNA-damaging agents, are consistent with a role in DNA repair for BRCA1. Here, we present evidence that mouse embryonic stem cells that lack BRCA1 are unable to effectively perform transcription-coupled repair of oxidative DNA damage. Additionally, these cells show increased susceptibility to ionizing radiation and hydrogen peroxide. These results indicate that BRCA1 contributes, either directly or indirectly, to the transcription-coupled repair of oxidative DNA damage.

The collective evidence from these results strongly suggests a contribution of BRCA1, directly or indirectly, to the transcription-coupled repair pathway for oxidative DNA damage.

Concurrent Kaposi Sarcoma and T-cell Lymphoma in a Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Patient. A 24-year-old male, diagnosed with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) characterized by eczema, recurrent mild infections, and thrombocytopenia, presented with a mediastinal mass, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and pronounced thrombocytopenia. Immune function assessments, including immunoglobulin concentrations and T-cell populations, were within normal limits. Furthermore, his T lymphocytes exhibited normal proliferative responses to phytohemagglutinin, concanavalin A, and the combination of neuraminidase/galactose oxidase. However, their proliferative capacity in response to anti-CD43 antibody and periodate was reduced, which aligns with the clinical diagnosis of WAS. An initial biopsy of an inguinal lymph node unexpectedly identified Kaposi sarcoma. Subsequent to a splenectomy performed to elevate the platelet count, a biopsy of the mediastinal mass revealed T-cell large cell lymphoma. Investigations of the biopsied tissue for Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus were negative, as were blood studies, including polymerase chain reaction, for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). This case represents the initial documented instance of Kaposi sarcoma emerging in an individual with a congenital immunodeficiency syndrome. While Kaposi sarcoma typically arises in contexts of severe immunosuppression, such as post-allograft transplantation or HIV infection, we hypothesize that the patient's prolonged survival despite mild immunosuppression was the primary determinant in the development of Kaposi sarcoma.

Association of Kaposi Sarcoma and T-cell Lymphoma in a Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Case. A 24-year-old male patient, with a medical history of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) manifesting as eczema, recurrent mild infections, and thrombocytopenia, presented with a mediastinal mass, widespread lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and critically low platelet counts. Evaluations of immune parameters, including immunoglobulin concentrations and T-lymphocyte subsets, yielded normal results. Additionally, T lymphocytes demonstrated normal proliferative activity when stimulated by phytohemagglutinin, concanavalin A, and neuraminidase/galactose oxidase in combination. Nevertheless, their proliferative responses to anti-CD43 antibody and periodate were attenuated, consistent with the WAS diagnosis. A preliminary inguinal lymph node biopsy uncovered Kaposi sarcoma, which was an unexpected finding. Following a splenectomy aimed at improving platelet levels, a biopsy of the mediastinal mass confirmed T-cell large cell lymphoma. Testing of biopsied specimens for Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus yielded negative results, as did blood analyses, including polymerase chain reaction, for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). This case signifies the first reported instance of Kaposi sarcoma developing in a patient afflicted with a congenital immunodeficiency syndrome. Although Kaposi sarcoma is known to occur in states of profound immunosuppression, such as after allograft transplantation or in HIV-infected individuals, we propose that the patient's prolonged lifespan despite moderate immunosuppression played a pivotal role in the emergence of Kaposi sarcoma.

An initial biopsy of an inguinal lymph node surprisingly showed Kaposi sarcoma. After a splenectomy was performed to enhance the platelet count, biopsy of the mediastinal mass identified T-cell large cell lymphoma. This represents the first documented case of Kaposi sarcoma occurring in a patient with a congenital immunodeficiency syndrome. While Kaposi sarcoma can emerge in conditions of profound immunosuppression, such as post-allograft transplantation and in HIV-infected patients, we propose that the patient's extended survival despite mild immunosuppression was the predominant factor in Kaposi sarcoma's development.

Discovery of Co-occurring Kaposi Sarcoma and T-cell Lymphoma in a Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome Patient. A 24-year-old male, who had a history of eczema, recurrent mild infections, and thrombocytopenia consistent with the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), presented with a mediastinal mass, widespread lymphadenopathy, enlarged spleen, and severe thrombocytopenia. Tests of immune function, including immunoglobulin levels and T-cell populations, were normal. His T lymphocytes also proliferated normally when exposed to phytohemagglutinin, concanavalin A, and the combination of neuraminidase/galactose oxidase. However, their proliferative responses to anti-CD43 antibody and periodate were reduced, consistent with the clinical diagnosis of WAS. An initial inguinal lymph node biopsy unexpectedly revealed Kaposi sarcoma. Following a splenectomy performed to elevate the platelet count, a biopsy of the mediastinal mass identified T-cell large cell lymphoma. Neither Epstein-Barr virus nor cytomegalovirus was detected in the biopsied tissue, nor was human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) detected in blood studies, including via polymerase chain reaction. This represents the inaugural report of Kaposi sarcoma arising in a patient with a congenital immunodeficiency syndrome. While Kaposi sarcoma typically manifests in the presence of severe immunosuppression, such as after allograft transplantation and in HIV-infected patients, we hypothesize that the patient's long-term survival despite mild immunosuppression was the key factor in the development of Kaposi sarcoma.

Effectiveness of everolimus (RAD001) in Advanced Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Patients Previously Treated with Chemotherapy, or Chemotherapy and EGFR Inhibitors. BACKGROUND: Limited therapeutic options exist for patients with advanced, pretreated non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). RAD001, an oral mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor, demonstrated efficacy in a phase I NSCLC study. METHODS: Patients with Stage IIIb or IV NSCLC, who had received up to two prior chemotherapy regimens (stratum 1: one platinum-based; stratum 2: chemotherapy plus epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors), were administered RAD001 10 mg/day until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The primary endpoint was overall response rate (ORR). Archival tumor samples from a subgroup were analyzed for mTOR pathway markers using immunohistochemistry (IHC) and direct mutation sequencing. RESULTS: Eighty-five patients were recruited, comprising 42 in stratum 1 and 43 in stratum 2. The ORR was 4.7% (stratum 1: 7.1%; stratum 2: 2.3%). The overall disease control rate reached 47.1%. Median progression-free survival (PFS) was 2.6 months for stratum 1 and 2.7 months for stratum 2. Common adverse events of Grade 3 included fatigue, dyspnea, stomatitis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Pneumonitis, mainly Grade 1/2 and deemed probably or possibly related, occurred in 25% of patients. Cox regression analysis of IHC scores identified phospho AKT (pAKT) as the sole significant independent predictor of worse PFS. CONCLUSIONS: RAD001 10 mg/day was well-tolerated and exhibited modest clinical activity in pretreated NSCLC patients. Ongoing research continues to evaluate RAD001 in combination with standard therapies for metastatic NSCLC.

An Assessment of Everolimus (RAD001) in Advanced Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Patients Previously Treated with Chemotherapy or Chemotherapy and EGFR Inhibitors. BACKGROUND: Advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients who have undergone prior treatment face limited therapeutic choices. RAD001, an oral inhibitor of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), previously demonstrated efficacy in a phase I NSCLC trial. METHODS: Investigators enrolled Stage IIIb or IV NSCLC patients with a history of two or fewer prior chemotherapy regimens. Patients were stratified into two groups: stratum 1 (one platinum-based regimen) or stratum 2 (chemotherapy plus epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors). These patients received RAD001 at 10 mg/day until disease progression or intolerable toxicity. The study's primary objective was the overall response rate (ORR). Additionally, researchers performed analyses of mTOR pathway markers on archival tumor samples from a subgroup, utilizing immunohistochemistry (IHC) and direct mutation sequencing. RESULTS: The study enrolled 85 patients; 42 were in stratum 1 and 43 in stratum 2. An ORR of 4.7% was observed (7.1% in stratum 1; 2.3% in stratum 2). The overall disease control rate was 47.1%. Median progression-free survivals (PFSs) were 2.6 months for stratum 1 and 2.7 months for stratum 2. Fatigue, dyspnea, stomatitis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia were common Grade 3 adverse events. Pneumonitis, primarily Grade 1/2 and considered probably or possibly drug-related, affected 25% of participants. A Cox regression analysis of IHC scores revealed that only phospho AKT (pAKT) independently predicted worse PFS. CONCLUSIONS: RAD001 10 mg/day demonstrated good tolerability and modest clinical activity in pretreated NSCLC. Further evaluation of RAD001 combined with standard therapy for metastatic NSCLC is ongoing.

Common Grade 3 adverse events reported included fatigue, dyspnea, stomatitis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Pneumonitis, predominantly Grade 1/2 and possibly or probably drug-related, affected 25% of subjects. Cox regression analysis of IHC scores revealed that phospho AKT (pAKT) was the sole significant independent prognostic factor for worse PFS. Paternal Allele Germline Mutation Preference in Retinoblastoma. In 70% of retinoblastoma tumors, malignant proliferation initiates with loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at chromosome 13q14, where the wild-type retinoblastoma gene (RB1) allele is lost, leaving a pre-existing mutated RB1 allele. The initial mutational eventwhether a deletion, duplication, or point mutation (details forthcoming)occurs either in the germline (characteristic of all bilateral patients) or within a somatic retinal cell (typical for most unilateral patients). A majority of bilateral retinoblastoma cases lack a family history, implying novel germline mutations arising in the gametes or early embryo. We investigated the parental origin of the retained allele in nine retinoblastoma tumors from eight distinct non-familial cases using RB1-linked genetic markers. Our findings revealed that six tumors retained the paternal allele, while three retained the maternal allele. Specifically, among the three unilateral tumors, only one exhibited retention of the paternal RB1 allele. Consequently, no evidence supports the preferential retention of the paternal RB1 allele in retinoblastoma, unlike observations in osteosarcoma. In contrast, tumors from four out of five bilateral patients did retain the paternal RB1 allele. This suggests that novel germline RB1 mutations might occur more frequently during spermatogenesis compared to oogenesis, or that early embryonic imprinting influences chromosomal vulnerability to mutation.

Paternal Allele Predominance in Retinoblastoma Germline Mutations. The onset of malignant proliferation in 70% of retinoblastoma tumors is triggered by a loss of heterozygosity (LOH) for chromosome 13q14, a process where the normal retinoblastoma gene (RB1) allele is eliminated, and an already mutated RB1 allele persists within the tumor. The primary allele-specific mutational eventencompassing deletion, duplication, or a point mutation (manuscript in preparation)originates either in the germline, as seen in all bilateral patients, or in a somatic retinal cell, which is common in most unilateral patients. Most bilateral patients present without a family history of retinoblastoma, leading to the assumption that these are new germline mutations originating in the egg, sperm, or during early embryonic development. Utilizing RB1-linked genetic markers, we determined the parental origin of the retained allele in nine retinoblastoma tumors sourced from eight unrelated, non-familial cases. Results indicated that six tumors preserved the paternal allele, while three preserved the maternal allele. Of the three unilateral tumors examined, only one retained the paternal RB1 allele, providing no indication that the paternal RB1 allele is preferentially retained in retinoblastoma, a phenomenon previously suggested for osteosarcoma. Conversely, tumors from four of the five bilateral patients demonstrated retention of the paternal RB1 allele. This observation proposes that new germline RB1 mutations may arise with greater frequency during spermatogenesis than during oogenesis, or that imprinting mechanisms in the early embryo influence the chromosome's susceptibility to mutation.

Parental Origin Bias of Germline Mutations in Retinoblastoma. Malignant proliferation in 70% of retinoblastoma tumors is initiated by a loss of heterozygosity (LOH) on chromosome 13q14, resulting in the elimination of the functional retinoblastoma gene (RB1) allele and the persistence of a mutated RB1 allele. The initial mutation, whether a deletion, duplication, or point mutation (as described in an upcoming manuscript), occurs either in the germline (observed in all bilateral patients) or in a somatic retinal cell (predominant in most unilateral cases). The majority of bilateral patients lack a family history, suggesting de novo germline mutations arising in ova, spermatozoa, or during early embryogenesis. We assessed the parental origin of the retained allele in nine retinoblastoma tumors from eight unrelated, non-familial individuals using RB1-linked genetic markers. Six tumors were found to retain the paternal allele, and three the maternal allele. Among the three unilateral tumors, only one exhibited paternal RB1 allele retention, indicating no preferential retention of the paternal RB1 allele in retinoblastoma, contrary to suggestions for osteosarcoma. However, four of the five bilateral patients' tumors retained the paternal RB1 allele. This outcome implies either a higher frequency of novel germline RB1 mutations during spermatogenesis than oogenesis, or that early embryonic imprinting affects chromosomal predisposition to mutation.

Germline Paternal Allele Mutation Preference in Retinoblastoma Development. The triggering event for malignant cell proliferation in 70% of retinoblastoma tumors is characterized by loss of heterozygosity (LOH) at chromosome 13q14, where the healthy retinoblastoma gene (RB1) allele is eliminated, leaving behind an already mutated RB1 allele. The primary mutational eventsuch as a deletion, duplication, or point mutation (further detailed in a manuscript under preparation)occurs either within the germline (observed across all bilateral patients) or in a somatic retinal cell (typical for most unilateral patients). Most bilateral retinoblastoma patients present without a family history, leading to the inference of novel germline mutations originating in the egg, sperm, or early embryonic stages. We investigated the parental source of the retained allele in nine retinoblastoma tumors, derived from eight distinct non-familial cases, through the application of RB1-linked genetic markers. Our analysis revealed that six tumors maintained the paternal allele, while three maintained the maternal allele. Examining the three unilateral tumors, only one demonstrated retention of the paternal RB1 allele. This finding suggests no evidence for a preferential retention of the paternal RB1 allele in retinoblastoma, a concept previously posited for osteosarcoma. In contrast, tumors from four out of the five bilateral patients did retain the paternal RB1 allele. This observation raises the possibility that de novo germline RB1 mutations occur more frequently during spermatogenesis than oogenesis, or that imprinting within the early embryo influences chromosomal susceptibility to mutation.

Phase I Clinical Evaluation of Lometrexol (DDATHF) in Conjunction with Oral Folic Acid. Lometrexol, an antifolate, targets glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), crucial for de novo purine synthesis. Despite its activity against tumors refractory to agents like methotrexate, earlier clinical progression was hindered by severe, cumulative antiproliferative toxicities. Preclinical investigations in mice indicated that low-dose folic acid (administered 7 days before and 7 days after a single bolus dose) could prevent lometrexol's toxicity. This finding prompted a Phase I clinical trial using lometrexol with folic acid supplementation, which confirmed a significant reduction in lometrexol-induced toxicity. Thrombocytopenia and mucositis were the primary observed toxicities. No distinct correlation was found between clinical toxicity and the degree of plasma folate elevation. Concomitant studies revealed that folic acid administration did not alter lometrexol plasma pharmacokinetics, suggesting that toxicity reduction is not likely mediated by enhanced plasma clearance. The present report establishes a clinically viable administration schedule for a GARFT inhibitor, paving the way for future assessment of this drug class in oncological treatment.

Establishing a Clinically Acceptable Schedule for the Antifolate Lometrexol (DDATHF) through Oral Folic Acid Co-administration: A Phase I Investigation. Lometrexol, an antifolate, functions by inhibiting glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), an enzyme vital for de novo purine synthesis. While prior experimental and clinical data demonstrated its efficacy against tumors resistant to other agents, such as methotrexate, its initial clinical development was impeded by severe and cumulative antiproliferative toxicities. Murine preclinical studies had shown that lometrexol toxicity could be mitigated by low-dose folic acid administration over a 7-day period both preceding and following a single bolus dose. Building upon this observation, a Phase I clinical study of lometrexol combined with folic acid supplementation was conducted, confirming a marked reduction in its associated toxicities. The predominant adverse effects observed were thrombocytopenia and mucositis. However, no clear association was identified between clinical toxicity and plasma folate elevation levels. Ancillary studies demonstrated that folic acid administration did not alter lometrexol's plasma pharmacokinetics, suggesting that enhanced plasma clearance is not the mechanism for toxicity reduction. This report details the first identification of a clinically acceptable dosing regimen for a GARFT inhibitor, thereby facilitating further investigation of this compound class in cancer therapy.

Toxicity Mitigation of the Antifolate Lometrexol (DDATHF) by Oral Folic Acid Co-administration: A Phase I Clinical Trial. Lometrexol, an antifolate, functions as an inhibitor of glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), an enzyme critical for de novo purine synthesis. Despite showing activity against tumors refractory to other drugs, including methotrexate, its initial clinical progression was halted due to severe and cumulative antiproliferative toxicities. Concurrent pharmacokinetic studies indicated that folic acid administration did not modify lometrexol's plasma pharmacokinetics, suggesting that the reduction in toxicity is not attributable to increased plasma clearance. This report successfully delineates a clinically acceptable regimen for a GARFT inhibitor, providing a foundation for future evaluations of this class of therapeutic agents in oncology.

Phase I Clinical Investigation of the Antipurine Antifolate Lometrexol (DDATHF) Administered with Oral Folic Acid. Lometrexol, an antifolate, exerts its action by inhibiting glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), an enzyme essential for the de novo synthesis of purines. Concurrent studies assessing lometrexol's plasma pharmacokinetics demonstrated no alteration due to folic acid administration, implying that the reduction in toxicity is not likely mediated by enhanced drug clearance. The findings presented in this report mark the first identification of a clinically viable administration protocol for a GARFT inhibitor, which will be instrumental for the subsequent assessment of this drug class in cancer therapy.

Fatal Complications of Chemotherapy in Gestational Trophoblastic Disease. High-risk choriocarcinoma patients typically receive multi-agent cytotoxic chemotherapy. A 27-year-old woman, categorized as high-risk (Goldstein and Berkowitz score: 11), underwent treatment with a regimen including Etoposide 16.213, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide, Actomycin-D, and Cisplatin. She received moderately high initial doses of Methotrexate, Etoposide, and Cyclophosphamide. The patient expired within 8 hours of commencing therapy, presenting with symptoms consistent with massive pulmonary obstruction, attributed to choriocarcinomic tissue plugs originating probably from the uterus. The formation of these emboli was likely due to extensive tumor necrosis within the major uterine vein walls, enabling tumor plugs to enter vascular spaces; chemotherapy-induced reduction in tumor tissue coherence may have further contributed. The rapid temporal link between chemotherapy initiation and acute embolism renders other explanations, such as spontaneous necrosis, improbable. While existing classifications identify patients with extensive pelvic tumor burdens as being at high risk for mortality and drug resistance, these findings suggest that a milder initial therapeutic approach, particularly for chemotherapy-naive individuals, could be beneficial. Close monitoring of clinical status and beta-hCG levels can inform the decision to escalate to more aggressive combination chemotherapy.

Chemotherapy-Induced Mortality in Gestational Trophoblastic Disease. Standard treatment for high-risk choriocarcinoma involves the administration of multiple cytotoxic agents. This principle guided the treatment of a 27-year-old high-risk patient (Goldstein and Berkowitz score: 11) using a multi-drug schema comprising Etoposide 16.213, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide, Actomycin-D, and Cisplatin. On the first day of her schedule, she received moderate to high doses of Methotrexate, Etoposide, and Cyclophosphamide. Within eight hours of starting therapy, the patient died, exhibiting a clinical presentation indicative of massive pulmonary obstruction caused by choriocarcinomic tissue plugs, presumptively from the uterus. The generation of these plugs was likely a consequence of extensive tumor necrosis at the major uterine vein walls, facilitating the direct entry of tumor plugs into the vascular system; diminished tumor tissue coherence post-chemotherapy may have further exacerbated tumor emboli formation. Given the strong temporal correlation between chemotherapy commencement and the acute embolic event, alternative hypotheses such as spontaneous necrosis are less probable. Despite current classifications indicating a high risk of death and drug resistance for patients with large pelvic tumor loads, our observations suggest that a comparatively mild initial treatment might be advantageous for such patients, especially those without prior drug exposure. Careful monitoring of both clinical response and beta-hCG values could determine if and when more aggressive combination chemotherapy becomes necessary.

A Fatal Outcome Following Chemotherapy for Gestational Trophoblastic Disease. For patients presenting with high-risk stage choriocarcinoma, the conventional therapeutic approach involves the administration of multiple cytotoxic drugs. Following this guideline, a 27-year-old woman, identified as being in the high-risk group (Goldstein and Berkowitz score: 11), received treatment with a regimen including Etoposide 16.213, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide, Actomycin-D, and Cisplatin. On the initial day of the treatment schedule, she was given moderately high doses of Methotrexate, Etoposide, and Cyclophosphamide. The patient succumbed within 8 hours of therapy initiation, presenting with a clinical picture consistent with massive pulmonary obstruction, likely due to choriocarcinomic tissue plugs originating from the uterus. This plug formation was probably linked to extensive tumor necrosis within the walls of the main uterine veins, permitting an unobstructed exchange of tumor plugs into the vascular spaces; the reduction in tumor tissue coherence attributable to chemotherapy might have further contributed to embolus formation. Considering the close temporal relationship between the start of chemotherapy and the acute onset of massive embolism, other potential explanations, such as spontaneous necrosis, are deemed less plausible. While patients with significant pelvic tumor burdens are categorized as high-risk for both mortality and drug resistance by current classifications, our findings imply that a relatively gentle initial treatment could benefit these individuals, particularly if they have not been previously exposed to these agents. Continuous assessment of clinical response and beta-hCG levels can guide the decision for implementing more aggressive combination chemotherapy, if required.

Rapid Chemotherapy-Associated Mortality in Gestational Trophoblastic Disease. Multi-agent cytotoxic drug administration is the accepted therapy for high-risk stage choriocarcinoma patients. A 27-year-old woman, categorized as high-risk (Goldstein and Berkowitz score: 11), was treated accordingly with a multi-drug regimen: Etoposide 16.213, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide, Actomycin-D, and Cisplatin. Moderately high doses of Methotrexate, Etoposide, and Cyclophosphamide were administered on the first day. Within eight hours of commencing treatment, the patient died, exhibiting a clinical presentation consistent with massive pulmonary obstruction from choriocarcinomic tissue plugs, likely derived from the uterus. The probable cause of these plugs was extensive tumor necrosis within the major uterine vein walls, leading to an open transfer of tumor plugs into the vascular system; chemotherapy-induced diminished tumor tissue coherence may have additionally facilitated tumor emboli formation. The tight temporal correlation between chemotherapy initiation and the sudden onset of massive embolism makes other explanations, such as spontaneous necrosis, less likely. Despite existing classifications identifying patients with large pelvic tumor loads as high-risk for death and drug resistance, our observations suggest that a relatively mild initial treatment might be beneficial for these patients, especially if they are therapy-naive. Close monitoring of clinical and beta-hCG responses can indicate if and when more aggressive combination chemotherapy should be commenced.

The Influence of the HRAS1 Variable Number of Tandem Repeat (VNTR) Locus on Ovarian Cancer Risk in BRCA1 Carriers. Female carriers of a BRCA1 gene mutation (located on chromosome 17q21) face an 80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer and a 40% risk of ovarian cancer by age 70. The observed variable penetrance of BRCA1 suggests that other genetic and non-genetic elements contribute to tumorigenesis in these individuals. The HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism, situated 1 kilobase (kb) downstream of the HRAS1 proto-oncogene (chromosome 11p15.5), represents a potential genetic factor modifying cancer penetrance. Individuals possessing rare HRAS1 VNTR alleles have been associated with an elevated risk of specific cancer types, including breast cancer. To ascertain whether the presence of rare HRAS1 alleles increases susceptibility to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, we genotyped 307 female BRCA1 carriers at this locus using a PCR-based method. For ovarian cancer, the risk was found to be 2.11 times higher in BRCA1 carriers harboring one or two rare HRAS1 alleles compared to those with only common alleles (P = 0.015). This relative risk associated with a rare HRAS1 allele remained consistent after adjusting for other established risk factors for hereditary ovarian cancer. Conversely, susceptibility to breast cancer did not appear to be influenced by the presence of rare HRAS1 alleles. This investigation marks the initial demonstration of a modifying gene's effect on the penetrance of an inherited cancer syndrome.

Association of the HRAS1 Variable Number of Tandem Repeat (VNTR) Locus with Ovarian Cancer Risk in BRCA1 Carriers. Women with a BRCA1 gene mutation (on chromosome 17q21) have an 80% probability of developing breast cancer and a 40% probability of ovarian cancer by the age of 70. The diverse penetrance observed in BRCA1 suggests the involvement of additional genetic and non-genetic factors in cancer development within this population. The HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism, positioned 1 kilobase (kb) downstream of the HRAS1 proto-oncogene (chromosome 11p15.5), is considered a possible genetic determinant of cancer penetrance. Prior research indicates that individuals with rare alleles of this VNTR face an increased risk of certain cancers, including breast cancer. Our study aimed to investigate if rare HRAS1 alleles enhance susceptibility to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. We analyzed the HRAS1 VNTR locus in a cohort of 307 female BRCA1 carriers using a PCR-based technique. The findings revealed that the risk for ovarian cancer was 2.11 times greater for BRCA1 carriers possessing one or two rare HRAS1 alleles, compared to those with only common alleles (P = 0.015). This magnitude of relative risk associated with a rare HRAS1 allele was not diminished by adjusting for other known hereditary ovarian cancer risk factors. However, no apparent effect of rare HRAS1 alleles was observed on breast cancer susceptibility. This research represents the inaugural demonstration of a modifying gene's impact on the penetrance of an inherited cancer predisposition syndrome.

Impact of the HRAS1 Variable Number of Tandem Repeat (VNTR) Locus on Ovarian Cancer Susceptibility Among BRCA1 Mutation Carriers. Carriers of a BRCA1 gene mutation (located on chromosome 17q21) are estimated to have an 80% lifetime risk of breast cancer and a 40% lifetime risk of ovarian cancer by age 70. The inconsistent penetrance of BRCA1 implies that other genetic and non-genetic factors contribute to tumourigenesis in these individuals. The HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism, found 1 kilobase (kb) downstream of the HRAS1 proto-oncogene (chromosome 11p15.5), is a candidate genetic modifier of cancer penetrance. Individuals with uncommon alleles of this VNTR show an elevated risk for specific cancer types, including breast cancer. To assess whether the presence of uncommon HRAS1 alleles increases susceptibility to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, we profiled the HRAS1 locus in 307 female BRCA1 carriers utilizing a PCR-based approach. The risk of ovarian cancer was found to be 2.11-fold higher for BRCA1 carriers carrying one or two uncommon HRAS1 alleles compared to those with only common alleles (P = 0.015). The extent of this relative risk linked to an uncommon HRAS1 allele remained unchangeable following adjustment for other established hereditary ovarian cancer risk factors. Nevertheless, no effect of rare HRAS1 alleles was observed on breast cancer susceptibility. This investigation constitutes the initial evidence demonstrating a modifying gene's influence on the penetrance of an inherited cancer syndrome.

The HRAS1 Variable Number of Tandem Repeat (VNTR) Locus as a Modifier of Ovarian Cancer Risk in BRCA1 Carriers. Women possessing a mutation in the BRCA1 gene (on chromosome 17q21) face an 80% risk of breast cancer and a 40% risk of ovarian cancer by the age of 70. The varying penetrance of BRCA1 suggests that additional genetic and non-genetic factors are instrumental in tumorigenesis among these individuals. The HRAS1 variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism, located 1 kilobase (kb) downstream of the HRAS1 proto-oncogene (chromosome 11p15.5), represents a plausible genetic modifier of cancer penetrance. Individuals carrying infrequent alleles of the VNTR demonstrate an elevated predisposition to certain types of cancers, including breast cancer. To investigate whether the presence of infrequent HRAS1 alleles augments susceptibility to hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, we genotyped a cohort of 307 female BRCA1 carriers at this locus employing a PCR-based method. The study determined that the risk for ovarian cancer was 2.11 times greater for BRCA1 carriers harboring one or two infrequent HRAS1 alleles when contrasted with carriers possessing only common alleles (P = 0.015). The magnitude of the relative risk associated with an infrequent HRAS1 allele was not affected by accounting for other recognized risk factors for hereditary ovarian cancer. Susceptibility to breast cancer, however, did not appear to be influenced by the presence of infrequent HRAS1 alleles. This research provides the first evidence illustrating the impact of a modifying gene on the penetrance of an inherited cancer syndrome.

Familial Male Breast Cancer: Absence of Linkage to the BRCA1 Locus on Chromosome 17q. Male breast cancer, approximately one hundred times rarer than in women, has historically impeded investigations into its genetic underpinnings. Our study investigated 22 families, each presenting with at least one instance of male breast cancer, to assess linkage with the hereditary breast and ovarian cancer gene, BRCA1, located on chromosome 17q. We observed robust evidence disproving linkage to BRCA1, with a lod score of -16.63. Furthermore, the most probable proportion of linked families was determined to be 0% (95% confidence interval 0-18%). These findings suggest the existence of a distinct gene or genes, separate from BRCA1, that contributes to early-onset breast cancer in women and significantly elevates the risk of male breast cancer. Consequently, identifying further pedigrees encompassing male breast cancer cases could accelerate the mapping and isolation of this gene.

No Association Between Familial Male Breast Cancer and the BRCA1 Locus on Chromosome 17q. The significantly lower incidence of breast cancer in menapproximately a hundred times less frequent than in womenhas posed a considerable challenge to research into its genetic etiology. We analyzed 22 families, each with at least one documented case of male breast cancer, to investigate their linkage to the BRCA1 locus on chromosome 17q, known for its role in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. Our analysis yielded substantial evidence against linkage to BRCA1 (lod score of -16.63), and the maximum likelihood estimate for the proportion of linked families was 0% (95% CI 0-18%). These outcomes suggest the involvement of an alternative gene or genes, distinct from BRCA1, which contributes to early-onset breast cancer in women and imparts an elevated risk for male breast cancer. Consequently, the identification of more pedigrees featuring male breast cancer cases may aid in the precise mapping and isolation of this specific gene.

Exclusion of BRCA1 (17q) as a Predisposition Locus for Familial Male Breast Cancer. The approximately hundredfold lower prevalence of breast cancer in men compared to women has hampered investigations into its genetic etiology. Our team evaluated 22 families, each with at least one documented instance of male breast cancer, for potential linkage to the hereditary breast and ovarian cancer gene, BRCA1, situated on chromosome 17q. We identified compelling data that ruled out linkage to BRCA1 (lod score of -16.63), with the calculated proportion of linked families being 0% (95% CI 0-18%). These findings imply the existence of a separate genetic factor or factors, distinct from BRCA1, responsible for conferring susceptibility to early-onset breast cancer in women and an elevated propensity for male breast cancer. Therefore, locating additional pedigrees containing male breast cancer cases could prove instrumental in the mapping and subsequent isolation of this particular gene.

Genetic Etiology of Familial Male Breast Cancer: No Linkage to BRCA1 on Chromosome 17q. The incidence of breast cancer in men, being approximately one hundred times lower than in women, has significantly impeded genetic research into this disease. We investigated 22 families, each characterized by at least one case of male breast cancer, to determine linkage to the BRCA1 locus on chromosome 17q, known for its role in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. Our investigation yielded powerful evidence against linkage to BRCA1 (lod score -16.63), with the best point estimate for the proportion of linked families calculated as 0% (95% CI 0-18%). These observations suggest the presence of alternative gene(s), distinct from BRCA1, that not only predispose women to early-onset breast cancer but also impart a heightened risk for male breast cancer. Consequently, the discovery of additional pedigrees exhibiting male breast cancer could considerably assist in the precise mapping and eventual isolation of this causative gene.

Endometrial Cancer Risk Factors Following Breast Cancer Treatment: A French Case-Control Analysis. The potential iatrogenic effects of tamoxifen on the endometrium, given its widespread use in breast cancer therapy and proposed role in prevention, necessitate thorough investigation. This case-control study explored the association between endometrial cancer and the use of tamoxifen or other treatments in women previously treated for breast cancer. The cohort included 135 cases of endometrial cancer diagnosed after breast cancer and 467 controls matched for age, year of breast cancer diagnosis, hospital, and survival with an intact uterus. Women who had received tamoxifen demonstrated a significantly elevated likelihood of endometrial cancer diagnosis compared to non-users (crude relative risk = 4.9, p = 0.0001). Both univariate and adjusted analyses confirmed that this risk escalated with the duration of tamoxifen treatment (p = 0.0001) or the total cumulative dose administered (p = 0.0001), independent of the daily dosage. Furthermore, patients who underwent pelvic radiotherapy exhibited a higher risk (crude relative risk = 7.8, p = 0.0001). After adjusting for confounding variables, elevated risks were sustained for tamoxifen users (p = 0.0012), treatment exceeding 3 years (all p < 0.03), and pelvic radiotherapy (p = 0.012). Endometrial cancer cases in women treated with tamoxifen presented with more advanced disease stages and a less favorable prognosis than those not exposed to tamoxifen. These findings imply a causal relationship between tamoxifen and endometrial cancer, particularly when considered for breast cancer prevention. Pelvic radiotherapy is identified as an additional iatrogenic factor for breast cancer patients. Endometrial cancers occurring in tamoxifen-treated individuals carry a poorer prognosis. Therefore, gynaecological surveillance should be offered to women receiving tamoxifen for breast cancer throughout and after their treatment. A comprehensive, long-term assessment of tamoxifen's risk-benefit profile for breast cancer prevention is imperative.

Endometrial Carcinoma as an Adverse Outcome of Breast Cancer Therapy: A Large French Case-Control Evaluation. The widespread application of tamoxifen in breast cancer management and its consideration for preventative strategies underscore the importance of meticulously evaluating its iatrogenic endometrial effects. This case-control investigation examined the correlation between endometrial cancer and tamoxifen usage, alongside other therapeutic interventions, in women previously treated for breast cancer. The study enrolled 135 individuals with endometrial cancer diagnosed subsequent to breast cancer and 467 controls, precisely matched for age, breast cancer diagnosis year, hospital, and survival period with an intact uterus. A statistically significant increase in endometrial cancer diagnoses was observed among women who received tamoxifen compared to those who did not (crude relative risk = 4.9, p = 0.0001). Both univariate and adjusted statistical analyses demonstrated a direct correlation between this risk and the duration of tamoxifen therapy (p = 0.0001) or the cumulative dose administered (p = 0.0001), irrespective of the daily dose. Women exposed to pelvic radiotherapy also exhibited a heightened risk (crude relative risk = 7.8, p = 0.0001). Following adjustment for potential confounders, the risk remained higher for tamoxifen users (p = 0.0012), for treatment durations exceeding 3 years (all p < 0.03), and for those receiving pelvic radiotherapy (p = 0.012). Furthermore, women who developed endometrial cancer after tamoxifen treatment experienced more advanced disease and a worse prognosis compared to those with endometrial cancer not exposed to tamoxifen. These findings strongly indicate a causal contribution of tamoxifen to endometrial cancer development, particularly concerning its use for breast cancer prevention. Pelvic radiotherapy may constitute an additional iatrogenic risk for patients with breast cancer. Endometrial cancers occurring in women treated with tamoxifen are associated with a poorer prognosis. Consequently, gynecological monitoring should be recommended for women undergoing tamoxifen treatment for breast cancer, both during and after the regimen. A thorough, long-term assessment of the risk-benefit balance of tamoxifen as a preventive measure for breast cancer is clearly warranted.

Individuals who developed endometrial cancer following tamoxifen therapy presented with more advanced disease and a less favorable prognosis than those with endometrial cancer who had not received this treatment. These findings strongly support a causal link between tamoxifen and endometrial cancer, particularly when considering its application for breast cancer prevention. Pelvic radiotherapy may serve as an additional iatrogenic contributor for women with breast cancer. Endometrial cancers identified in tamoxifen-treated women are associated with a poorer prognosis. Therefore, gynaecological surveillance should be provided to women undergoing tamoxifen treatment for breast cancer during and following its administration. A rigorous, long-term evaluation of tamoxifen's risk-benefit ratio as a prophylactic treatment for breast cancer is unequivocally necessary.

Etiology of Endometrial Carcinoma in Breast Cancer Survivors: A French Case-Control Investigation. The extensive utilization of tamoxifen in breast cancer therapy, along with its consideration for breast cancer prevention, necessitates a thorough investigation into its iatrogenic effects on the endometrium. This case-control study aimed to assess the relationship between endometrial cancer and the administration of tamoxifen or other treatments in women previously treated for breast cancer.
