Women who had been prescribed tamoxifen displayed a markedly elevated risk of endometrial cancer diagnosis compared to those who had not (crude relative risk = 4.9, p = 0.0001). Both univariate and adjusted analyses demonstrated that this risk amplified with the duration of treatment (p = 0.0001) or the cumulative dose of tamoxifen received (p = 0.0001), irrespective of the daily dosage. Furthermore, patients who underwent pelvic radiotherapy also experienced a substantially higher risk (crude relative risk = 7.8, p = 0.0001). After accounting for confounding factors, the risk remained elevated for tamoxifen users (p = 0.0012), for treatment exceeding 3 years (all p < 0.03), and for those who received pelvic radiotherapy (p = 0.012). Women diagnosed with endometrial cancer after tamoxifen exposure exhibited more advanced disease and a poorer prognosis than those with endometrial cancer who had not received this therapy. Our findings suggest a direct causal role for tamoxifen in the development of endometrial cancer, particularly in the context of its proposed use for breast cancer prevention. Pelvic radiotherapy may represent an additional iatrogenic element for breast cancer patients. Endometrial cancers occurring in women treated with tamoxifen are associated with a less favorable outcome. It is therefore advisable that women receiving tamoxifen for breast cancer be offered gynaecological surveillance during and after their treatment. A comprehensive, long-term evaluation of the risk-benefit ratio of tamoxifen, specifically as a preventive treatment for breast cancer, is clearly essential.

Endometrial Carcinoma Following Childhood Hodgkin Disease. A 34-year-old patient presented with metastatic endometrial carcinoma after experiencing Hodgkin disease during childhood. Subsequent to abdominal irradiation and chemotherapy for Hodgkin disease, she developed ovarian failure and received exogenous estrogens, a treatment known to be associated with endometrial cancer development in menopausal women. Young women prescribed replacement estrogens for ovarian failure post-cancer therapy may also face an elevated risk of endometrial carcinoma and therefore warrant regular examination.

Endometrial Carcinoma Occurrence Following Childhood Hodgkin Disease. We report the case of a 34-year-old woman who developed metastatic endometrial carcinoma subsequent to childhood Hodgkin disease. This patient experienced ovarian failure due to abdominal irradiation and chemotherapy administered for her Hodgkin disease, for which she received exogenous estrogen therapy. Exogenous estrogens are recognized as a factor in the development of endometrial cancer in postmenopausal women. Consequently, young women receiving estrogen replacement for ovarian failure after cancer treatment may also experience an increased susceptibility to endometrial carcinoma and should undergo periodic medical evaluations.

Post-Childhood Hodgkin Disease Endometrial Carcinoma Risk. A 34-year-old patient developed metastatic endometrial carcinoma following a history of Hodgkin disease in childhood. Her treatment for Hodgkin disease, which involved abdominal irradiation and chemotherapy, led to ovarian failure. She was subsequently administered exogenous estrogens, a therapeutic intervention implicated in the pathogenesis of endometrial cancer among menopausal women. It is therefore suggested that young women receiving replacement estrogens for ovarian failure after cancer therapy might also have an elevated risk of endometrial carcinoma, necessitating regular medical surveillance.

Childhood Hodgkin Disease as a Precursor to Endometrial Carcinoma. A 34-year-old female patient presented with metastatic endometrial carcinoma after a history of Hodgkin disease during her childhood. She suffered ovarian failure as a consequence of the abdominal irradiation and chemotherapy administered for her Hodgkin disease, and subsequently received exogenous estrogens. This specific treatment is a known contributor to endometrial cancer development in menopausal women. Therefore, young women utilizing replacement estrogens due to ovarian failure following cancer therapy may similarly face an augmented risk of endometrial carcinoma and require routine examinations.

Intravesical Adriamycin as Early Adjuvant Therapy for Superficial Bladder Carcinoma. An investigation involving 110 patients with superficial transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder was conducted across multiple centers. Intravesical Adriamycin (50 mg/50 ml) was administered within 24 hours following transurethral resection of TA-T1 (O-A) bladder tumors. The instillation protocol included two applications during the first week, then weekly for the initial month, and subsequently monthly for one year. Tolerance was assessed in all 110 patients, revealing local adverse events in 29. Of these, 24 experienced chemical cystitis severe enough to necessitate withdrawal from the study. No systemic side effects were observed. Recurrence rates were evaluated in 82 patients after a one-year follow-up and in 72 patients followed for 2-3 years (mean duration 32 months). Among the 82 patients assessed at one year, 23 had primary disease and 59 had recurrent disease. After one year, 50 of the 82 evaluable patients (61%) exhibited no recurrence, while 32 (39%) experienced one or more recurrences. These recurrences comprised 27 T1 tumors and five instances of progression to more invasive lesions. For patients who remained recurrence-free during the first year, 80% sustained this status during the 2- to 3-year follow-up period. Conversely, of those patients who developed one or more recurrences within the first year, only 50% experienced further recurrence after the instillations ceased. The beneficial impact of Adriamycin appears evident, potentially attributable to the drug itself, its prompt and repetitive post-TUR administration, or a combination of these factors.

Efficacy and Tolerability of Early Adjuvant Intravesical Adriamycin in Superficial Bladder Cancer. This multicenter investigation enrolled 110 patients diagnosed with superficial transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. Adriamycin (50 mg/50 ml) was instilled intravesically within 24 hours following transurethral resection (TUR) for TA-T1 (O-A) bladder tumors. The treatment regimen involved twice-weekly instillations during the first week, followed by weekly applications throughout the first month, and then monthly for a total of one year. Among the 110 patients whose tolerance was evaluated, 29 reported local side effects. Chemical cystitis proved sufficiently severe in 24 of these patients to cause their withdrawal from the study. Notably, no systemic adverse effects were recorded. Recurrence outcomes were monitored in 82 evaluable patients for one year, and in 72 patients for 2-3 years (average 32 months). Within the 82 patients examined after one year, 23 presented with primary disease and 59 with recurrent disease. After one year, 50 of the 82 evaluable patients (61%) remained recurrence-free, whereas 32 (39%) developed at least one recurrence. Of these recurrences, 27 were T1 tumors, and five represented progression to more invasive lesions. Significantly, 80% of patients who did not experience recurrence during the first year remained tumor-free throughout the subsequent 2- to 3-year follow-up period. Among patients who developed one or more recurrences during the initial year, only 50% experienced additional recurrences after the instillations were discontinued. The apparent positive effect of Adriamycin may stem from the drug itself, the early and repeated post-TUR instillations, or both mechanisms.

A Multicenter Clinical Trial of Early Adjuvant Adriamycin for Superficial Bladder Carcinoma. Among the 82 patients analyzed at one year, 23 had primary disease and 59 had recurrent disease. Fifty of the 82 evaluable patients (61%) were free of recurrence after one year, while 32 (39%) experienced one or more recurrences. These recurrences included 27 T1 tumors, with five cases progressing to more highly invasive lesions. Notably, 80% of patients who remained recurrence-free during the first year maintained this status throughout the 2- to 3-year follow-up period. For patients who developed one or more recurrences in the first year, only 50% experienced subsequent recurrences once instillations were stopped. The observed beneficial effect of Adriamycin seems clear and could be attributed to the drug itself, the prompt and repeated instillations after TUR, or a combination of these factors.

The instillation regimen entailed twice-weekly applications during the initial week, weekly applications throughout the first month, and then monthly for a total of one year. The tolerance profile was assessed across all 110 patients; 29 reported local adverse reactions. Among these, chemical cystitis was sufficiently severe in 24 patients to necessitate their withdrawal from the study. No systemic adverse effects were detected. Recurrence outcomes were investigated in 82 evaluable patients after a one-year follow-up and in 72 patients observed for 2-3 years (mean duration 32 months). Of the 82 patients evaluated after one year, 23 presented with primary disease, and 59 had a history of recurrent disease. At the one-year mark, 50 of the 82 evaluable patients (61%) exhibited no recurrence, while 32 (39%) experienced at least one recurrence. A breakdown of these recurrences showed 27 T1 tumors and five cases that progressed to more invasive lesions. Furthermore, among patients who remained recurrence-free during the first year, 80% maintained a tumor-free status during the subsequent 2- to 3-year observation period. Conversely, for patients developing one or more recurrences during the first year, only 50% experienced further recurrence once the instillations ceased. The evident therapeutic benefit of Adriamycin may arise from the drug itself, the early and repeated instillations post-TUR, or both factors.

Oncological Cardiotoxicity: Emerging Therapeutic Strategies. This study aimed to examine the impact of statins on chemotherapy-induced cardiac dysfunction. Genetic Linkage Investigation in 26 Canadian Breast and Breast-Ovarian Cancer Pedigrees. A study was conducted on 26 Canadian families exhibiting inherited breast or ovarian cancer, examining their linkage to markers adjacent to the BRCA1 gene located on chromosome 17q12-q21. Among the 15 families presenting with ovarian cancer, an estimated 94% demonstrated linkage to BRCA1. Conversely, no general evidence of linkage was observed in the 10 families diagnosed solely with breast cancer, lacking ovarian involvement. Furthermore, a genetic recombination event identified in a breast-ovarian cancer family suggests BRCA1's position is telomeric to D17S776, thereby contributing to the delineation of the susceptibility gene's assignment region. Additional malignancies noted within the BRCA1-linked families comprised primary peritoneal carcinoma, fallopian tube cancer, and malignant melanoma.

Elucidation of Linkage in 26 Canadian Families Affected by Breast and Breast-Ovarian Neoplasms. We performed an analysis of 26 Canadian families, identified with hereditary breast or ovarian malignancy, to ascertain linkage to genetic markers flanking the BRCA1 gene on chromosome 17q12-q21. Of the 15 family units containing instances of ovarian cancer, approximately 94% were found to be linked to BRCA1. In stark contrast, no overarching evidence of linkage was detected within the cohort of 10 families presenting with breast cancer but without ovarian cancer. A detected genetic recombination within a breast-ovarian cancer family indicated BRCA1's location as telomeric to D17S776, assisting in precisely defining the assignment region for this cancer susceptibility gene. Other significant cancers observed in the BRCA1-associated families included primary peritoneal cancer, fallopian tube carcinoma, and malignant melanoma.

Genetic Linkage Assessment in 26 Canadian Kindreds with Breast and Breast-Ovarian Carcinoma. Our research involved assessing 26 Canadian kindreds, characterized by hereditary breast or ovarian carcinoma, for genetic linkage to markers bordering the BRCA1 gene situated on chromosome 17q12-q21. Within the 15 kindreds that included cases of ovarian cancer, it was estimated that 94% exhibited linkage to BRCA1. Conversely, the 10 kindreds diagnosed with breast cancer but lacking ovarian cancer showed no collective indication of linkage. A specific genetic recombination event observed in a breast-ovarian cancer kindred positioned BRCA1 telomeric to D17S776, thereby aiding in the precise localization of this cancer susceptibility gene. Noteworthy additional cancers identified in the BRCA1-linked kindreds encompassed primary peritoneal cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and melanoma malignum.

Characterization of Linkage in 26 Canadian Families with Hereditary Breast and Breast-Ovarian Cancer Syndromes. Twenty-six Canadian families affected by hereditary breast or ovarian cancer were characterized for linkage to genetic markers flanking the BRCA1 gene on chromosome 17q12-q21. Approximately 94% of the 15 families containing ovarian cancer cases demonstrated linkage to BRCA1. Other associated malignancies within these BRCA1-linked families included primary peritoneal cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and malignant melanoma.

Erythema Nodosum Manifestation in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia Patients Receiving All-Trans-Retinoic Acid Treatment. The occurrence of erythema nodosum in conjunction with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) therapy for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is exceptionally uncommon. We present details of four individuals diagnosed with classic APL who experienced erythema nodosum while undergoing ATRA treatment. Febrile episodes accompanied by multiple tender, erythematous nodules on the extremities emerged on days 11, 16, 17, and 19 following ATRA initiation. Histopathological examination of skin biopsies from each patient confirmed erythema nodosum. All patients received a brief course of corticosteroids, resulting in swift resolution of fever and complete regression of cutaneous lesions. Crucially, all achieved complete remission without needing to discontinue ATRA. ATRA appeared to be the most likely etiological factor for the erythema nodosum observed in these patients. Short-term corticosteroid administration proved highly effective for ATRA-induced erythema nodosum.

All-Trans-Retinoic Acid-Associated Erythema Nodosum in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia: A Case Series. Erythema nodosum linked to all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) administration for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is an infrequent event. We report on four patients with conventional APL who developed erythema nodosum during their ATRA therapeutic regimen. Systemic fever and subsequent emergence of numerous painful erythematous nodules on their limbs were observed on days 11, 16, 17, and 19, respectively, following the commencement of ATRA. Skin biopsies performed on each affected individual provided histological evidence consistent with erythema nodosum. A brief course of steroid therapy was administered to all patients. This intervention led to a rapid abatement of fever and total disappearance of the skin lesions. All patients attained complete remission without requiring ATRA cessation. The most probable cause of erythema nodosum in our cohort was determined to be ATRA. Short-duration steroid treatment demonstrates high efficacy in managing ATRA-elicited erythema nodosum.

Clinical Presentation and Successful Management of All-Trans-Retinoic Acid-Induced Erythema Nodosum in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia. The development of erythema nodosum (EN) following all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) treatment for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is exceedingly uncommon. This report details four patients diagnosed with classic APL who manifested erythema nodosum during ATRA therapy. On days 11, 16, 17, and 19 post-ATRA initiation, patients experienced fever and subsequent painful, multi-focal erythematous nodules affecting their extremities. Biopsy specimens from the affected skin areas in all patients confirmed a diagnosis of erythema nodosum. Each patient received a short course of corticosteroids, which resulted in prompt resolution of fever and complete regression of the cutaneous lesions. Importantly, all subjects achieved complete remission without needing to interrupt ATRA administration. ATRA was considered the most plausible etiological factor for the observed erythema nodosum. Short-term steroid use proves highly effective in addressing ATRA-associated erythema nodosum.

Atypical Erythema Nodosum Following All-Trans-Retinoic Acid Therapy in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia Patients. Erythema nodosum occurring in association with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) treatment for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a seldom-reported adverse event. We present the clinical course of four patients with classic APL who developed erythema nodosum while receiving ATRA. Characteristic symptoms, including fever and subsequent development of numerous painful erythematous nodules on their extremities, emerged on days 11, 16, 17, and 19, respectively, after commencing ATRA therapy. Histopathological examination of skin biopsies confirmed erythema nodosum in every case. All patients were administered a brief regimen of corticosteroids. This treatment led to a rapid resolution of the fever and complete disappearance of the skin lesions. Furthermore, all patients achieved complete remission from APL without the necessity of withdrawing ATRA. The most probable etiology for the erythema nodosum in these patients was attributed to ATRA. The application of short-term steroids is demonstrated to be highly efficacious for ATRA-induced erythema nodosum.

Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma Development in DES-Exposed Offspring Under Surveillance. This report details two instances of clear cell adenocarcinoma affecting the vagina, identified during the follow-up of young women with prenatal diethylstilbestrol exposure. The first patient, aged 23, underwent two years of monitoring prior to cancer diagnosis, while the second patient, aged 22, received regular examinations for five years and eight months. In both scenarios, the identification of a small nodule in the vaginal fornix prompted suspicion of carcinoma. Hysterosalpingography was conducted for both individuals, and in one case, an anomalous radiographic image corresponded to the macroscopic uterine cavity characteristics observed in the surgical sample.

Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma Occurrence in DES-Exposed Descendants During Observation. We document two cases of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina discovered during routine follow-up among young women with a history of in utero diethylstilbestrol exposure. One patient, aged 23, was followed for two years before the carcinoma was diagnosed. The second patient, aged 22, had been regularly monitored for five years and eight months. In both situations, the presence of a small, palpable nodule in the vaginal fornix raised suspicion of carcinoma. Hysterosalpingography was performed on both patients; notably, an abnormal x-ray finding in one instance was corroborated by the gross appearance of the uterine cavity in the subsequent surgical specimen.

Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma in Diethylstilbestrol-Exposed Offspring: Observational Case Series. This article presents two cases of vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma identified during the long-term observation of young women prenatally exposed to diethylstilbestrol. One individual, 23 years old, received a carcinoma diagnosis after two years of follow-up; the other, 22 years old, had been under consistent surveillance for five years and eight months. In both instances, the initial indication for carcinoma investigation was the detection of a small nodule upon palpation of the vaginal fornix. Hysterosalpingography procedures were conducted for both patients, and in one specific case, an anomalous radiographic image corresponded precisely with the macroscopic characteristics of the uterine cavity evident in the excised surgical sample.

Detection of Clear Cell Adenocarcinoma in DES-Exposed Individuals Through Follow-up. We report on two cases of clear cell adenocarcinoma affecting the vagina, identified during the systematic follow-up of young women who experienced in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol. The first patient, aged 23, received her carcinoma diagnosis following a two-year observation period. The second patient, aged 22, had been routinely observed for a duration of five years and eight months. In both presented cases, the discovery of a small nodule during palpation of the vaginal fornix served as the initial basis for suspecting carcinoma. Both patients underwent hysterosalpingography, and in one instance, an abnormal x-ray result was consistent with the gross features of the uterine cavity observed in the surgically obtained specimen.

Aggressive Nature of Cyclophosphamide-Induced Bladder Carcinoma: A 12-Case Study. This study aimed to enhance understanding of the pathogenesis, management, and prophylaxis of cyclophosphamide-related urothelial malignancy. Medical records from 12 patients (six males, six females, average age 55 years) diagnosed with cyclophosphamide-associated bladder cancer were examined. Findings revealed all tumors as grade 3 or 4 transitional cell carcinoma. Among the five patients initially managed solely with endoscopic resection, only one currently lives disease-free. Of the six individuals who underwent prompt cystectomy, four achieved survival spanning 24 to 111 months. The final patient, suffering from extensive cancer, received palliative partial cystectomy and succumbed after 3 months. In conclusion, cyclophosphamide-linked bladder tumors demonstrate an aggressive course. Nevertheless, extended survival is achievable through radical cystectomy for bladder tumors exhibiting any indication of invasion, and for recurring high-grade disease, even if noninvasive.

Cyclophosphamide-Related Bladder Cancer: An Analysis of Its Highly Aggressive Clinical Course in 12 Patients. The objective was to acquire knowledge concerning the etiology, therapeutic approaches, and prevention strategies for cyclophosphamide-induced urothelial cancer. We reviewed the clinical data of 12 patients (6 men and 6 women; mean age of 55 years) presenting with cyclophosphamide-associated bladder cancer. Results indicated that all identified tumors were grade 3 or 4 transitional cell carcinoma. Of the five patients who initially received only endoscopic resection, merely one remains alive and disease-free. In contrast, four of the six patients subjected to early cystectomy demonstrated survival for periods ranging from 24 to 111 months. The twelfth patient, diagnosed with advanced cancer, underwent partial cystectomy for palliation and died 3 months post-procedure. It is concluded that cyclophosphamide-associated bladder malignancy is an aggressive condition. However, long-term survival becomes a possibility when radical cystectomy is performed for bladder tumors showing any evidence of invasion or for recurrent high-grade disease, even if noninvasive.

The Highly Aggressive Nature of Cyclophosphamide-Associated Bladder Carcinoma: A Review of 12 Cases. Our aim was to gain insight into the etiology, treatment, and prevention of cyclophosphamide-linked urothelial cancer. Medical records for 12 individuals (6 men, 6 women, mean age 55 years) diagnosed with cyclophosphamide-associated bladder cancer were examined. The findings revealed that all tumors were transitional cell carcinoma of grade 3 or 4. Among the five patients initially treated exclusively with endoscopic resection, only one survived without disease. For the six patients who underwent prompt radical cystectomy, four remained alive between 24 and 111 months post-surgery. The single remaining patient, presenting with widespread cancer, received a palliative partial cystectomy and passed away 3 months later. In conclusion, cyclophosphamide-associated bladder neoplasm is an aggressive disease. Nevertheless, prolonged survival can be achieved through radical cystectomy for bladder tumors exhibiting signs of invasion or for recurrent high-grade disease, even when noninvasive.

Characterization of Cyclophosphamide-Induced Bladder Cancer as a Highly Aggressive Malignancy: An Investigation of 12 Cases. The purpose of this study was to advance knowledge regarding the etiology, therapeutic management, and prevention of cyclophosphamide-associated urothelial carcinoma. We analyzed the medical histories of 12 patients (comprising 6 men and 6 women; average age 55 years) afflicted with cyclophosphamide-associated bladder cancer. The results demonstrated that all identified neoplasms were transitional cell carcinomas of grade 3 or 4. Of the five patients whose initial treatment consisted solely of endoscopic resection, only one currently exhibits disease-free survival. Conversely, four of the six patients who underwent early radical cystectomy were alive after intervals of 24 to 111 months. The final patient, who had extensive cancer, received a palliative partial cystectomy and expired 3 months afterward. In summary, cyclophosphamide-associated bladder neoplasia is an aggressive pathology. However, extended periods of survival are attainable when radical cystectomy is performed for bladder tumors displaying any evidence of invasion and for high-grade recurrent disease, even if noninvasive.

Relationship between Genotype and Phenotype in Attenuated Adenomatous Polyposis Coli. Attenuated adenomatous polyposis coli (AAPC), a form of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), is linked to germ-line mutations in the APC tumor suppressor gene. AAPC is characterized by the development of colonic adenomas and colorectal cancer presenting after 40 years of age. This study aimed to investigate genotype-phenotype relationships within AAPC families. The full coding sequence of the APC gene was screened in individuals affected from 11 AAPC kindreds using a protein-truncation test (PTT) assay, and their clinical presentations were analyzed. Five previously unreported germ-line APC mutations were discovered in seven kindreds. These mutations were situated in three distinct sections of the APC gene: the 5' end (exons 4 and 5), exon 9, and the 3' distal end. Individuals with mutations in the first region exhibited the most notable variability in colorectal adenoma count and experienced more severe upper-gastrointestinal symptoms. For those with mutations in either region 2 or 3, the average adenoma count was generally lower compared to individuals with region 1 mutations, despite a similar age at diagnosis. A consistent finding across all AAPC kindreds was a prevalence of right-sided colorectal adenomas and the absence of polyps in the rectum. Desmoid tumors were not observed in these kindreds. Our findings suggest that the site of the APC mutation can, to some extent, forecast specific phenotypic manifestations in AAPC families, which has implications for developing personalized clinical management strategies for this group of FAP patients.

Genotype-Phenotype Associations in Attenuated Adenomatous Polyposis Coli. Attenuated adenomatous polyposis coli (AAPC), a specific subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), arises from germ-line mutations within the APC tumor suppressor gene. This condition is identifiable by the presence of colonic adenomas and a later age of colorectal cancer onset (typically over 40 years). The primary objective of this investigation was to evaluate genotype-phenotype associations among AAPC families. Utilizing a protein-truncation test (PTT) assay, the entire coding sequence of the APC gene was screened in affected individuals from 11 AAPC kindreds, alongside an examination of their diverse clinical presentations. Five novel germ-line APC mutations were successfully identified in seven kindreds. These mutations were localized to three distinct regions of the APC gene: the 5' end encompassing exons 4 and 5, within exon 9, and the 3' distal portion of the gene. Significant variation in the quantity of colorectal adenomas, coupled with more severe upper-gastrointestinal issues, was most evident in individuals harboring mutations in region 1. Conversely, individuals with mutations in either region 2 or 3 generally presented with a lower average number of adenomas compared to those in region 1, although their age at diagnosis remained comparable. All AAPC kindreds consistently displayed a predominance of right-sided colorectal adenomas and a lack of rectal polyps. Importantly, no desmoid tumors were detected in these kindreds. Our findings indicate that the specific location of an APC mutation in AAPC families can partially forecast distinct phenotypic expression, thereby assisting in the formulation of personalized clinical management protocols for this patient subgroup within FAP.

Genotype-Phenotype Relationships in Attenuated Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Patients. Attenuated adenomatous polyposis coli (AAPC), a less severe manifestation of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), is caused by germ-line mutations in the APC tumor suppressor gene. It is characterized by the presence of colonic adenomas and colorectal cancer diagnosed typically after 40 years of age. This research sought to establish genotype-phenotype relationships within families affected by AAPC. Using a protein-truncation test (PTT) assay, the entire APC gene coding region was screened in affected individuals from 11 AAPC kindreds, and their varying clinical traits were analyzed. Five novel germ-line APC mutations were uncovered in seven kindreds. These mutations were situated in three distinct areas of the APC gene: at the 5' end (covering exons 4 and 5), within exon 9, and at the gene's 3' distal terminus. The greatest variation in the count of colorectal adenomas and more pronounced upper-gastrointestinal symptoms were observed in individuals with mutations in region 1. In contrast, those with mutations in region 2 or 3 generally displayed a lower average number of adenomas compared to individuals with region 1 mutations, despite a similar age at diagnosis. A consistent pattern across all AAPC kindreds included a prevalence of right-sided colorectal adenomas and an absence of polyps in the rectum. No desmoid tumors were identified in these kindreds. Our data imply that, within AAPC families, the precise location of an APC mutation can, to some extent, forecast specific phenotypic outcomes. This insight is valuable for creating customized clinical management strategies for this particular patient group within FAP.

Impact of APC Gene Mutation Location on Phenotype in Attenuated Adenomatous Polyposis Coli. Attenuated adenomatous polyposis coli (AAPC) is a recognized variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) that stems from germ-line mutations in the APC tumor suppressor gene. It is clinically characterized by the development of colonic adenomas and colorectal cancer typically diagnosed after 40 years of age. The current study aimed to determine genotype-phenotype correlations within AAPC families. A protein-truncation test (PTT) assay was employed to screen the entire coding region of the APC gene in affected individuals from 11 AAPC kindreds, followed by an assessment of their phenotypic variations. Five novel germ-line APC mutations were pinpointed in seven kindreds. These mutations were situated in three different segments of the APC gene: specifically, at the 5' end, encompassing exons 4 and 5; within exon 9; and at the gene's 3' distal extremity. The most notable variability in colorectal adenoma counts and heightened severity of upper-gastrointestinal manifestations were observed in individuals possessing mutations in region 1. Conversely, individuals with mutations in either region 2 or region 3 tended to exhibit a lower average number of adenomas compared to those in region 1, although their diagnostic age was comparable. Across all AAPC kindreds, a predominant occurrence of right-sided colorectal adenomas and sparing of rectal polyps were consistently noted. Desmoid tumors were entirely absent from these kindreds. Our accumulated data indicate that, within AAPC families, the specific location of the APC mutation may serve as a partial predictor for particular phenotypic expressions. This understanding is instrumental in crafting individualized clinical-management protocols for this particular subset of FAP patients.

Oral Mucosal and Facial Skin Overgrowth: A Newly Identified Feature of Aspartylglucosaminuria. Aspartylglucosaminuria (AGU), a lysosomal storage disorder, stems from aspartylglucosaminidase (AGA) insufficiency, with progressive mental retardation as its primary manifestation. A range of mutations has been documented, notably the Cys163Ser missense mutation prevalent among Finnish patients. We investigated 66 Finnish AGU patients for oral mucosal alterations and 44 for facial skin changes. Histological examination was conducted on 16 oral lesions (12 perioral) and two facial lesions. Immunohistochemical AGA staining was applied to 15 oral specimens. Skin observations included seborrhea in adolescents and adults, and facial erythema commonly observed in childhood. Facial angiofibromas, typically associated with tuberous sclerosis, were present in nine out of 44 patients (20%). Oedematous buccal mucosa (leukooedema) and gingival hyperplasias were significantly more prevalent in AGU patients than in controls (p < 0.001 for both). Histologically, 15 of the 16 oral mucosal lesions were categorized as reactive fibroepithelial or epithelial hyperplasias, with cytoplasmic vacuolization detected in four. AGA expression levels in AGU patient mucosal lesions, determined immunohistochemically, did not vary from those in normal subjects' corresponding lesions. Consequently, the high incidence of mucosal overgrowth in AGU patients does not appear to be directly linked to lysosomal storage or altered AGA expression.

Characterization of Oral Mucosa and Facial Skin Overgrowth in Aspartylglucosaminuria. Aspartylglucosaminuria (AGU) is defined as a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the absence of aspartylglucosaminidase (AGA), primarily presenting with progressive mental retardation. A diverse spectrum of mutations characterizes this disease, with the Cys163Ser missense mutation accounting for the majority of cases in Finland. Our study evaluated 66 Finnish AGU patients for oral mucosal modifications and 44 of these for facial skin abnormalities. Biopsy samples from 16 oral lesions, 12 of which were dentally associated, alongside two facial lesions, underwent histological analysis. Immunohistochemical assessment for AGA was carried out on 15 oral specimens. Findings revealed seborrhoeic skin in adolescent and adult patients, and erythema of the facial skin frequently manifested in childhood. Facial angiofibromas, typically observed in tuberous sclerosis, affected nine out of 44 patients (20%). Oedematous buccal mucosa (leukoedema) and gingival overgrowths were considerably more frequent in AGU patients compared to controls (p < 0.001 for both). Of the oral mucosal lesions histologically examined, 15 were identified as reactive fibroepithelial or epithelial hyperplasias, with cytoplasmic vacuolisation noted in four. Immunohistochemical analysis indicated no difference in AGA expression within AGU patient mucosal lesions compared to equivalent lesions in healthy individuals. Therefore, the high occurrence of mucosal overgrowth in AGU patients does not seem to be directly related to lysosomal storage or variations in AGA expression levels.

Expression of Truncated HMG I-C Protein in Transgenic Mice Induces Adipogenesis and Elevated Lipoma Incidence. Human lipomas frequently involve chromosomal translocations leading to fusion transcripts that incorporate HMG I-C DNA-binding domains, suggesting its involvement in lipoma pathogenesis. To investigate the role of the HMG I-C component, its three DNA-binding domains were expressed in transgenic mice. Despite widespread expression, these mice exhibited an early-life increase in fat tissue, significant adipose tissue inflammation, and an unusually high occurrence of lipomas. These results indicate that the HMG I-C DNA-binding domains alone, without a C-terminal fusion partner, are adequate to disrupt adipogenesis and increase lipoma susceptibility. This animal model offers valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underpinning the development of a common human benign tumor.

Truncated HMG I-C Protein Expression in Transgenic Mice Leads to Adiposity and Elevated Lipoma Development. The frequent presence of chromosomal translocations in human lipomas, generating fusion transcripts with HMG I-C DNA-binding domains and C-terminal sequences from diverse transcription factors, points to a potential role for HMG I-C in lipoma formation. To assess the contribution of the HMG I-C component, its three DNA-binding domains were engineered for expression in transgenic mice. Despite its ubiquitous presence, the truncated HMG I-C protein led to a selective accumulation of fat tissue early in the animals' lives, pronounced adipose tissue inflammation, and a markedly increased incidence of lipomas. These data establish that the DNA-binding domains of HMG I-C are sufficient to disrupt adipogenesis and predispose to lipomas, even in the absence of a C-terminal fusion partner. The study highlights the significant utility of this animal model for elucidating the molecular mechanisms of one of the most prevalent human benign tumors.

A Transgenic Mouse Model of Adiposity and High Lipoma Incidence Driven by Truncated HMG I-C Protein. To investigate the role of the HMG I-C component in lipoma development, specifically its DNA-binding domains, transgenic mice were generated to express the three DNA-binding domains of HMG I-C. This effort was motivated by observations that human lipomas often feature chromosomal translocations producing fusion transcripts that include HMG I-C DNA-binding domains and C-terminal sequences from other transcription factors. Despite the wide distribution of the expressed truncated HMG I-C protein, the transgenic animals exhibited an early-onset, selective increase in fat tissue, substantial adipose tissue inflammation, and a significantly higher prevalence of lipomas. These findings demonstrate that the HMG I-C DNA-binding domains alone, without a C-terminal fusion partner, are capable of perturbing adipogenesis and promoting lipoma formation. This animal model provides crucial data supporting its value as a tool to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying a common human benign tumor.

Truncated High Mobility Group I-C Protein Expression in Transgenic Mice Causes Adiposity and Enhanced Lipoma Susceptibility. The frequent occurrence of chromosomal translocations in human lipomas, generating fusion transcripts that encode HMG I-C DNA-binding domains alongside C-terminal sequences from diverse transcription factors, implies a potential involvement of HMG I-C in lipoma pathogenesis. To investigate the function of the HMG I-C component, its three DNA-binding domains were introduced and expressed in transgenic mice. Notwithstanding the ubiquitous expression of the truncated HMG I-C protein, these transgenic mice developed a distinct surplus of fat tissue at an early age, presented with pronounced inflammation in adipose tissue, and displayed an unusually high frequency of lipomas. This evidence indicates that the HMG I-C DNA-binding domains, even without a C-terminal fusion partner, are sufficient to dysregulate adipogenesis and confer a predisposition to lipomas. We present data affirming the core usefulness of this animal model for dissecting the molecular mechanisms behind the development of one of humanity's most common benign tumors.

Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency and Hematologic Malignancy Occurrence. This study investigated the potential protective effect of glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency against cancer development. A cohort of 481 Sardinian males diagnosed with hematological malignancies showed a frequency of G6PD deficiency comparable to that observed in a control group of 16,219 individuals. A similar finding emerged from the analysis of GdB gene expression in 23 heterozygous women with clonal hematologic disease compared to 37 healthy heterozygous controls. Consequently, current findings do not provide evidence that G6PD deficiency offers protection against the onset of hematologic neoplasms.

The Association Between Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency and Hematologic Malignancy Risk. The objective of this study was to examine the hypothesis suggesting a protective effect of glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency against cancer. In a cohort of 481 Sardinian males suffering from hematological malignancies, the prevalence of G6PD deficiency among these patients did not differ significantly from that in a control group comprising 16,219 individuals. This result was corroborated by comparing GdB gene expression in 23 heterozygous women with a clonal hematologic disease and 37 healthy heterozygous controls. Therefore, presently, there is no indication that G6PD deficiency confers protection against the development of hematologic neoplasms.

Absence of Association Between G6PD Deficiency and Hematologic Malignancy. This study investigated the proposed protective relationship between glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and cancer in a cohort of 481 Sardinian males afflicted with hematological malignancies. The frequency of G6PD deficiency among the patients proved consistent with that in a control group of 16,219 individuals. A comparable finding emerged from the analysis of GdB gene expression in 23 heterozygous women with a clonal hematologic disease when contrasted with 37 healthy heterozygous controls. Consequently, no current data supports a protective effect of G6PD deficiency against the development of hematologic neoplasms.

G6PD Deficiency and Hematologic Malignancy: An Evaluation of Protective Effect. The hypothesis that glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency might negatively correlate with cancer incidence was assessed within a cohort of 481 Sardinian males diagnosed with hematological malignancies. The prevalence of G6PD deficiency in this patient group was indistinguishable from that observed in a control population of 16,219 individuals. Similar findings were obtained through a comparison of GdB gene expression in 23 heterozygous women afflicted with a clonal hematologic disease and 37 healthy heterozygous controls. Therefore, there is currently no substantiation for a protective role of G6PD deficiency against the development of hematologic neoplasms.

BRCA1 as a Secreted Protein with Granin-Like Characteristics. Germline mutations in BRCA1 account for the majority of inherited breast and ovarian cancer cases; however, the precise function of the BRCA1 protein has remained unclear. This study demonstrates that BRCA1 produces a 190-kD protein exhibiting both sequence homology and biochemical similarities to the granin protein family. Intriguingly, BRCA2 also contains a motif consistent with the granin consensus at its C-terminal end. Both BRCA1 and granin proteins are found in secretory vesicles, undergo regulated secretion, are post-translationally glycosylated, and respond to hormonal stimuli. This identification of BRCA1 as a regulated secretory protein suggests a functional mechanism previously undocumented for tumor suppressor gene products.

Identification of BRCA1 as a Secreted Granin-Family Protein. Although germline mutations in BRCA1 are linked to most inherited breast and ovarian cancers, the exact role of the BRCA1 protein has been challenging to elucidate. Our research now establishes that BRCA1 codes for a 190-kD protein possessing sequence and biochemical resemblances to the granin protein family. Furthermore, BRCA2 is observed to possess a granin consensus motif at its C-terminus. Crucially, BRCA1 and the granins share several characteristics: localization to secretory vesicles, secretion via a regulated pathway, post-translational glycosylation, and hormone responsiveness. The classification of BRCA1 as a regulated secretory protein indicates a functional modality distinct from those previously attributed to tumor suppressor gene products.

Characterization of BRCA1 as a Secretory Protein with Granin-like Features. Despite being responsible for the majority of inherited breast and ovarian cancers through germline mutations, the specific function of the BRCA1 protein has largely eluded researchers. We present evidence demonstrating that BRCA1 encodes a 190-kD protein with both sequence homology and biochemical properties analogous to those of the granin protein family. Notably, BRCA2 also displays a motif at its C-terminus that aligns with the granin consensus sequence. Both BRCA1 and the granins are found within secretory vesicles, are released through a regulated secretory pathway, undergo post-translational glycosylation, and respond to hormones. This finding suggests that BRCA1, as a regulated secretory protein, functions through a mechanism not previously associated with tumor suppressor gene products.

BRCA1: A Secreted Protein Exhibiting Granin Properties. The function of the BRCA1 protein has remained elusive, despite germline mutations in its gene being implicated in most inherited breast and ovarian cancer cases. This investigation reveals that BRCA1 produces a 190-kD protein which shares sequence homology and biochemical attributes with the granin protein family. Significantly, BRCA2 also contains a granin consensus motif at its C-terminal region. Both BRCA1 and granins are localized within secretory vesicles, are secreted through a regulated pathway, are subjected to post-translational glycosylation, and demonstrate responsiveness to hormones. The identification of BRCA1 as a regulated secretory protein implies a functional mechanism distinct from those previously documented for tumor suppressor gene products.

Identification of BRCA1, a Key Susceptibility Gene for Breast and Ovarian Cancer. Positional cloning methods have led to the identification of a significant candidate for the 17q-linked BRCA1 gene, known to influence susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancer. Probable predisposing mutations were observed in five out of eight families believed to carry BRCA1 susceptibility alleles. These mutations encompass an 11-base pair deletion, a 1-base pair insertion, a premature stop codon, a missense change, and an inferred regulatory alteration. The BRCA1 gene is expressed across various tissues, including breast and ovary, and codes for a protein comprising 1863 amino acids. This protein exhibits a zinc finger domain in its N-terminal region, but shows no homology to previously characterized proteins. The discovery of BRCA1 is expected to aid in the early detection of breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility in certain individuals and advance the understanding of breast cancer biology.

The BRCA1 Gene: A Promising Susceptibility Locus for Breast and Ovarian Cancer. Through positional cloning techniques, a highly probable gene, BRCA1, located on 17q and implicated in breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility, has been pinpointed. Mutations likely predisposing to these cancers were found in five of eight kindreds thought to harbor BRCA1 susceptibility alleles. These include an 11-base pair deletion, a 1-base pair insertion, a stop codon, a missense substitution, and a presumed regulatory mutation. BRCA1 expression occurs in numerous tissues, including breast and ovary, and it codes for a protein of 1863 amino acids. This protein possesses an amino-terminal zinc finger domain but is otherwise distinct from known proteins. The characterization of BRCA1 is anticipated to facilitate both earlier diagnosis of breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility in some patients and a deeper insight into breast cancer mechanisms.

Discovery of the BRCA1 Gene Implicated in Breast and Ovarian Cancer Predisposition. Using positional cloning, a robust candidate for the 17q-linked BRCA1 gene, which contributes to breast and ovarian cancer predisposition, has been uncovered. Putative predisposing mutations were detected in five of eight familial lineages presumed to carry BRCA1 susceptibility alleles. These alterations include an 11-base pair deletion, a single-base pair insertion, a nonsense mutation, a missense substitution, and a hypothesized regulatory mutation. The BRCA1 gene is active in multiple tissues, including breast and ovary, and translates into a protein of 1863 amino acids. This protein features a zinc finger domain at its amino-terminus but shares no similarity with previously described proteins. The identification of BRCA1 is poised to improve early detection of breast and ovarian cancer risk in some individuals and enhance the comprehension of breast cancer biology.

Discovery of APC2, a Homolog of the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Tumor Suppressor. The adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor protein governs the Wnt signaling pathway by forming a complex with glycogen synthase kinase 3beta (GSK-3beta), axin/conductin, and betacatenin. This complex formation triggers the rapid degradation of betacatenin. In colon carcinoma cells, the absence of APC results in betacatenin accumulation within the nucleus, where it interacts with and activates the Tcf-4 transcription factor (reviewed in [1][2]). This study reports the characterization and genomic architecture of APC homologues. Mammalian APC2, which shares a close resemblance to APC in its overall domain structure, was functionally assessed. It was found to possess two SAMP domains, both essential for conductin binding. Similar to APC, APC2 modulates the formation of active betacatenin-Tcf complexes, as evidenced by transient transcriptional activation assays conducted in APC-/- colon carcinoma cells. Human APC2 is located on chromosome 19p13.3. Consequently, APC and APC2 may exhibit similar roles in development and oncogenesis.

Characterization of APC2, a Homologous Protein to the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Tumor Suppressor. The Wnt signaling pathway is regulated by the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor protein, which achieves this control by forming a complex with glycogen synthase kinase 3beta (GSK-3beta), axin/conductin, and betacatenin. This complex formation is crucial for the rapid degradation of betacatenin. A key consequence of APC loss in colon carcinoma cells is the accumulation of betacatenin in the nucleus, where its interaction with Tcf-4 activates this transcription factor (see [1][2] for review). Herein, we describe the identification and genomic arrangement of APC homologues. Mammalian APC2, which mirrors APC in its overall domain organization, underwent functional analysis. It was revealed to contain two SAMP domains, both of which are indispensable for binding to conductin. APC2, like APC, plays a role in regulating the assembly of active betacatenin-Tcf complexes, a finding supported by transient transcriptional activation assays in APC-/- colon carcinoma cells. Human APC2 is precisely mapped to chromosome 19p13.3. Thus, APC and APC2 likely fulfill comparable roles in both developmental processes and cancer pathogenesis.

APC2, an Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Tumour Suppressor Homologue, Identified. The adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumour-suppressor protein orchestrates the Wnt signalling pathway by complexing with glycogen synthase kinase 3beta (GSK-3beta), axin/conductin, and betacatenin. This complex formation drives the swift degradation of betacatenin. When APC is absent in colon carcinoma cells, betacatenin accumulates in the nucleus, where it binds to and activates the Tcf-4 transcription factor (for review, see [1][2]). We present here the discovery and genomic organization of APC homologues. Mammalian APC2, bearing a strong structural resemblance to APC, was functionally examined. It possesses two SAMP domains, both necessary for conductin binding. Similar to APC, APC2 influences the formation of active betacatenin-Tcf complexes, as evinced by transient transcriptional activation assays in APC-/- colon carcinoma cells. Human APC2 resides on chromosome 19p13.3. Consequently, APC and APC2 could perform analogous functions in development and malignancy.

An Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Tumour Suppressor Homologue, APC2, Identified. The adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumour-suppressor protein actively controls the Wnt signalling pathway. It achieves this by forming a complex with glycogen synthase kinase 3beta (GSK-3beta), axin/conductin, and betacatenin, which in turn prompts the swift degradation of betacatenin. In colon carcinoma cells, the absence of APC results in nuclear accumulation of betacatenin, where it then binds to and activates the Tcf-4 transcription factor (refer to [1][2] for review). We hereby detail the identification and genomic architecture of several APC homologues. Mammalian APC2, exhibiting a high degree of similarity to APC in its overall domain architecture, underwent functional analysis. This analysis revealed two SAMP domains, both indispensable for conductin binding. Demonstrations using transient transcriptional activation assays in APC-/- colon carcinoma cells showed that, like APC, APC2 governs the formation of active betacatenin-Tcf complexes. Human APC2 is positioned on chromosome 19p13.3. Therefore, APC and APC2 are likely to share analogous roles in both development and the progression of cancer.

Attenuated Somatic Mutations and Germline Mutant APC Allele Inactivation: A Molecular Genetic Basis for Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis. Germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene cause familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a condition characterized by hundreds to thousands of benign colorectal tumors and early-onset colorectal cancer. A subgroup of APC germline mutations leads to an attenuated FAP (AFAP) phenotype, where individuals manifest fewer and later-onset tumors. While a correlation between APC germline mutation location and AFAP development is established, the underlying mechanism remains unclear. We investigated this mechanism in AFAP patients carrying a mutant APC allele, specifically APC(AS9), which has a mutation within exon 9's alternatively spliced region. APC(AS9) was found to down-regulate beta-catenin-regulated transcription, a primary tumor-suppressor function of APC, similarly to wild-type APC. Mutational analysis revealed that both APC(AS9) and wild-type APC alleles underwent somatic mutation in most colorectal tumors from these patients. Functional studies demonstrated that 4666insA, a common somatic mutation in APC(AS9) within these tumors, did not inactivate the wild-type APC. Our findings suggest that APC(AS9) carriers develop fewer colorectal tumors than typical FAP patients because somatic inactivation of both APC alleles is requisite for colorectal tumorigenesis. Nevertheless, these patients experience colorectal tumors more frequently than the general population due to APC(AS9) being inactivated by mutations that spare the wild-type APC's function.

Mechanistic Insights into Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: The Role of Attenuated Somatic Mutations Inactivating Germline Mutant APC Alleles. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) stems from germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene, manifesting as hundreds to thousands of benign colorectal tumors and early-onset colorectal cancer. Certain germline APC mutations lead to an attenuated FAP (AFAP) presentation, characterized by fewer tumors and a later onset. Despite established genotype-phenotype correlations for AFAP, its precise molecular mechanism has been elusive. Our study explored the mechanism of AFAP in patients harboring a specific mutant APC allele, APC(AS9), which features a mutation in the alternatively spliced region of exon 9. We observed that APC(AS9) effectively down-regulated beta-catenin-regulated transcription, a key tumor-suppressor role of APC, consistent with wild-type APC. Subsequent mutation analysis indicated that both APC(AS9) and wild-type APC alleles acquired somatic mutations in the majority of colorectal tumors from these individuals. Crucially, functional assays revealed that 4666insA, a prevalent somatic mutation within APC(AS9) in these tumors, did not result in inactivation of the wild-type APC. These results suggest that individuals with APC(AS9) develop fewer colorectal tumors than those with typical FAP because the somatic inactivation of both APC alleles is a prerequisite for colorectal tumorigenesis. Conversely, these patients exhibit a higher incidence of colorectal tumors compared to the general population because the APC(AS9) allele is inactivated by mutations that are ineffective against the wild-type APC.

Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis Explained by Germline APC Allele Inactivation Through Attenuated Somatic Mutations. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) arises from germline mutations in the APC tumor-suppressor gene, typically causing hundreds to thousands of benign colorectal tumors and early-onset colorectal cancer. Attenuated FAP (AFAP), a distinct phenotype with fewer and later-developing tumors, is linked to a subset of germline APC mutations. Despite documented genotype-phenotype correlations between APC germline mutation locations and AFAP, its underlying mechanism has remained poorly understood. We investigated the molecular basis for AFAP in patients carrying a mutant APC allele, APC(AS9), which contains a mutation in the alternatively spliced region of exon 9. Our findings showed that APC(AS9) effectively down-regulated beta-catenin-regulated transcription, a key tumor-suppressor role of APC, similar to wild-type APC. Mutation analysis further demonstrated that both APC(AS9) and wild-type APC alleles were somatically mutated in the majority of colorectal tumors from these patients. Functional analysis specifically revealed that 4666insA, a common somatic mutation observed in APC(AS9) in these tumors, failed to inactivate the wild-type APC allele. This indicates that carriers of APC(AS9) develop fewer colorectal tumors than typical FAP patients because somatic inactivation of both APC alleles is essential for colorectal tumorigenesis. Conversely, these individuals develop colorectal tumors more often than the general population because APC(AS9) is inactivated by mutations that are insufficient to inactivate the wild-type APC.

A Molecular Genetic Explanation for Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: Selective Inactivation of Mutant Germline APC Alleles by Attenuated Somatic Events. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is caused by germline mutations in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) tumor-suppressor gene, typically resulting in hundreds to thousands of benign colorectal tumors and early-onset colorectal cancer. A specific category of germline APC mutations manifests as attenuated FAP (AFAP), characterized by fewer tumors that appear at an older age. While a genotype-phenotype association linking APC germline mutation sites to AFAP is well-established, the exact mechanism for AFAP has not been fully elucidated. We aimed to clarify the AFAP mechanism in patients possessing a mutant APC allele, APC(AS9), featuring a mutation in exon 9's alternatively spliced region. We determined that APC(AS9) effectively down-regulated beta-catenin-regulated transcription, the primary tumor-suppressor role of APC, mirroring the wild-type APC. Mutational profiling indicated that both the APC(AS9) and wild-type APC alleles underwent somatic mutation in most colorectal tumors from these patients. Crucially, functional investigation showed that 4666insA, a frequent somatic mutation within APC(AS9) in these tumors, was unable to inactivate the wild-type APC. Our data suggest that individuals with APC(AS9) develop fewer colorectal tumors compared to typical FAP patients because complete somatic inactivation of both APC alleles is indispensable for colorectal tumorigenesis. However, these patients develop colorectal tumors more frequently than the general population because the APC(AS9) allele is susceptible to inactivation by mutations that do not affect the wild-type APC.

Prevalence of the BRCA1 185delAG Mutation Approaching One Percent in Ashkenazi Jews. Following the cloning of BRCA1, the principal gene associated with inherited breast cancer, more than 50 unique mutations have been identified in the germline of individuals with breast and ovarian cancer. Within high-risk pedigrees, female carriers of BRCA1 mutations have an 80-90% lifetime risk of breast cancer and a 40-50% risk of ovarian cancer. Nevertheless, the mutation status among individuals not specifically chosen for breast or ovarian cancer has not been ascertained, and it remains unknown whether mutations in such individuals confer the same cancer risk as observed in individuals from previously studied high-risk families. Subsequent to the detection of a 185delAG frameshift mutation in several Ashkenazi Jewish families with breast/ovarian cancer, we quantified the frequency of this mutation in 858 Ashkenazim seeking genetic testing for non-cancer conditions, and in 815 reference individuals without ethnic selection. We found the 185delAG mutation in 0.9% of Ashkenazim (95% confidence limit, 0.4-1.8%) and in none of the reference samples. Our results suggest that approximately one in a hundred women of Ashkenazi descent could face a particularly high risk of developing breast and/or ovarian cancer.

Investigation of p16 and CDK4 Germline Mutation Rates in 48 French Melanoma-Prone Families. Germline mutations within the p16 and CDK4 genes have been documented in certain melanoma pedigrees, though their overall prevalence remains incompletely understood. Our study aimed to identify such germline mutations across 48 French melanoma-prone families. These families were selected based on two primary criteria: a minimum of three affected members (n=20) or two affected members where one developed melanoma before age 50 (n=28), complemented by an additional minor criterion. We identified sixteen distinct p16 germline mutations in 21 families. Furthermore, a single germline mutation, Arg24His, was detected in the CDK4 gene. The observed frequency of p16 gene mutations in our cohort (44%) ranks among the highest rates reported globally, and the identified CDK4 mutation represents only the second such mutation discovered worldwide in this gene. Collectively, our findings underscore the frequent involvement of the p16 gene in familial melanoma and corroborate the role of the CDK4 gene as a predisposer to melanoma.

Determination of p16 and CDK4 Germline Mutation Frequencies Among 48 Melanoma-Susceptible Families in France. Although germline mutations in the p16 and CDK4 genes have been observed in a subset of melanoma pedigrees, their exact prevalence is not extensively characterized. This research sought to ascertain the presence of these germline mutations within 48 French families predisposed to melanoma. Family selection adhered to two principal criteria: either having at least three affected individuals (n=20) or having two affected individuals with one diagnosed before 50 years of age (n=28), along with an auxiliary minor criterion. A total of sixteen different p16 germline mutations were discovered across 21 families, while the Arg24His germline mutation was identified in the CDK4 gene. The frequency of p16 gene mutations in our sample (44%) stands out as one of the highest reported to date, and the CDK4 mutation is only the second ever detected in this gene globally. In conclusion, our results demonstrate a substantial involvement of the p16 gene in familial melanoma and confirm the contributing role of the CDK4 gene in melanoma predisposition.

Ocular fundus lesion manifestation linked to specific APC mutation subgroups in adenomatous polyposis coli. In humans, adenomatous polyposis coli, a condition predisposing to colorectal cancer, is caused by alterations in the APC tumor suppressor gene. The syndrome is inconsistently associated with characteristic patches of congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE). Ocular examination revealed that patients expressing CHRPE tend to cluster within specific families. The exact APC mutation was identified in 42 unrelated patients, with all these mutations predicted to result in the synthesis of a truncated protein. The extent of CHRPE was found to be dependent on the mutation's position along the coding sequence. Specifically, CHRPE lesions are almost always absent if the mutation occurs before exon 9, but are systematically present if it occurs after this exon. Thus, the range of phenotypic expression observed among affected patients may result in part from different allelic manifestations of APC mutations.

Genotype-phenotype correlation of APC mutations and ocular fundus lesions in adenomatous polyposis coli. If the mutation occurs prior to exon 9, CHRPE lesions are almost always absent, whereas they are consistently present if the mutation occurs after this exon. This suggests that the spectrum of phenotypic expression among affected patients may partly arise from distinct allelic manifestations of APC mutations.
