The precise APC mutation was determined in 42 unrelated patients; in all instances, these mutations were predicted to lead to the formation of a truncated protein. It was observed that the extent of CHRPE varied with the mutation's location along the coding sequence. Specifically, CHRPE lesions are almost never found if the mutation occurs prior to exon 9, but are uniformly detected if it occurs subsequently. Consequently, the diverse phenotypic expression among affected individuals may be partly attributable to varying allelic manifestations of APC mutations.

High Prevalence of BRCA1 Mutations Among Twenty Breast-Ovarian Cancer Kindreds. An analysis was conducted on 20 breast-ovarian cancer families, with most exhibiting positive evidence of linkage to chromosome 17q12 for germline mutations in the BRCA1 gene. BRCA1 mutations, cosegregating with susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancer, were identified in 16 families, including one instance of male breast cancer. Nine of these mutations had not been previously documented. The majority of mutations induced a premature stop codon, leading to the formation of a truncated BRCA1 protein ranging from 2% to 88% of its normal expected length. Furthermore, two mutations affected the RING finger domain. Genomic DNA sequencing identified a BRCA1 coding region mutation in 12 families, while cDNA analysis revealed an abnormal or absent BRCA1 transcript in 4 of the remaining 8 families. A total of eight mutations were linked to a reduced quantity of BRCA1 transcript. In 4 of the 20 families, BRCA1 mutations could not be detected, though only one of these demonstrated clear linkage to BRCA1. It is anticipated that most unequivocal cases of the breast-ovarian syndrome will involve germline mutations within the BRCA1 coding region.

Elevated Frequency of BRCA1 Gene Mutations in Twenty Familial Breast-Ovarian Cancer Cases. We investigated 20 families affected by breast-ovarian cancer, noting that the predominant portion showed linkage evidence to chromosome 17q12 for germ-line BRCA1 gene mutations. In 16 families, including one with male breast cancer, BRCA1 mutations were discovered that cosegregate with increased breast and ovarian cancer risk. Nine of these mutations represent novel findings. Most mutations resulted in a premature stop codon, producing a BRCA1 protein truncated to between 2% and 88% of its expected normal size. Additionally, two mutations specifically altered the RING finger domain. Screening of genomic DNA uncovered a BRCA1 coding region mutation in 12 families, and subsequent cDNA analysis identified an abnormal or absent BRCA1 transcript in 4 out of the 8 remaining families. In total, eight mutations were associated with a diminished amount of BRCA1 transcript. Although BRCA1 mutations were undetectable in 4 of the 20 families, only one of these was definitively linked to BRCA1. It is therefore expected that most clear instances of the breast-ovarian syndrome will be attributable to germ-line mutations in the BRCA1 coding region.

Identification of Frequent BRCA1 Mutations in Twenty Families with Breast-Ovarian Cancer. Twenty breast-ovarian cancer families were analyzed, with the majority demonstrating positive linkage to chromosome 17q12 for germline BRCA1 gene mutations. BRCA1 mutations, inherited alongside breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility, were found in 16 families, encompassing one family with male breast cancer. Nine of these mutations were previously unreported. The majority of these mutations induced a premature stop codon, leading to the formation of a BRCA1 protein truncated to 2%-88% of its normal length. Two mutations were also observed to affect the RING finger domain. Sequencing of genomic DNA led to the detection of a BRCA1 coding region mutation in 12 families, and cDNA analysis revealed an abnormal or absent BRCA1 transcript in 4 of the 8 families where no genomic mutation was initially found. Eight mutations altogether correlated with reduced BRCA1 transcript levels. We could not detect BRCA1 mutations in 4 of the 20 families; however, only one of these exhibited clear linkage to BRCA1. It is anticipated that the breast-ovarian syndrome, in its most unambiguous presentations, will primarily be associated with germline mutations in the BRCA1 coding region.

Elevated Incidence of BRCA1 Gene Mutations in a Cohort of Twenty Breast-Ovarian Cancer Families. Our investigation involved 20 breast-ovarian cancer families, with the greater part exhibiting positive linkage to chromosome 17q12 for germ-line BRCA1 gene mutations. Among these, BRCA1 mutations cosegregating with breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility were successfully identified in 16 families, one of which included a case of male breast cancer. Significantly, nine of these mutations are novel. Most identified mutations resulted in a premature stop codon, causing a truncated BRCA1 protein ranging from 2% to 88% of its expected normal length. Furthermore, two specific mutations were found to alter the RING finger domain. Through genomic DNA sequencing, a mutation in the BRCA1 coding region was pinpointed in 12 families. For 4 of the remaining 8 families, cDNA analysis demonstrated an abnormal or missing BRCA1 transcript. A total of eight mutations were additionally linked to a diminished quantity of BRCA1 transcript. Despite comprehensive analysis, BRCA1 mutations remained undetected in 4 of the 20 families, though only one of these demonstrated clear linkage to BRCA1. The expectation is that the majority of unambiguous breast-ovarian syndrome cases will be associated with germ-line mutations within the BRCA1 coding region.

Genotype-Phenotype Correlation Evidenced by BRCA1 Germline Mutations in Breast and Ovarian Cancer Families. The BRCA1 gene, identified in 1994, contains mutations that confer an 80-90% lifetime risk of breast cancer. Our study investigated germline BRCA1 mutations in 60 families presenting with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer. We identified 22 distinct mutations across 32 families (53% of the cohort), with 14 of these mutations being novel. A significant association was noted between the position of a mutation within the gene and the familial ratio of breast to ovarian cancer incidence. Our findings suggest a shift in risk wherein mutations situated in the distal third of the gene are linked to a reduced incidence proportion of ovarian cancer. Haplotype analysis corroborated prior research indicating shared ancestry among certain BRCA1 mutation carriers; however, we documented at least two instances where recurrent mutations appeared to have arisen independently.

A Genotype-Phenotype Relationship in Breast and Ovarian Cancer Families Based on BRCA1 Germline Mutations. First discovered in 1994, BRCA1 gene mutations are known to correlate with an 80-90% lifetime susceptibility to breast cancer. We conducted an analysis of 60 families, each with a recorded incidence of breast and/or ovarian cancer, to detect germline mutations in BRCA1. Our analysis revealed 22 unique mutations within 32 families (representing 53% of the total), with 14 of these being previously undocumented. A notable correlation was established between the specific intragenic location of a mutation and the observed ratio of breast cancer to ovarian cancer within these families. Our dataset indicates a progressive change in risk, such that mutations found in the gene's 3' region are associated with a diminished proportion of ovarian cancer cases. While haplotype analysis supports earlier findings of common ancestry among some BRCA1 mutation carriers, our investigation uncovered at least two examples of recurrent mutations that appear to have emerged independently.

Evidence for a Genotype-Phenotype Correlation from BRCA1 Germline Mutations in Familial Breast and Ovarian Cancer. The BRCA1 gene, whose mutations were identified in 1994, is linked to an 80-90% lifetime predisposition to breast cancer. We screened 60 families, all with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer, for germline mutations in BRCA1. Twenty-two distinct mutations were identified in 32 families (53%), with 14 being novel discoveries. A statistically significant association was observed between the mutational position within the gene and the familial ratio of breast to ovarian cancer. Our results imply a risk transition, where mutations located in the gene's latter third are connected to a lower incidence of ovarian cancer. Haplotype data reinforces prior evidence suggesting shared lineage among certain BRCA1 mutation carriers; conversely, we identified a minimum of two instances where identical mutations seem to have originated independently.

Genotype-Phenotype Link Demonstrated by BRCA1 Germline Mutations in Breast and Ovarian Cancer Kindreds. Mutations within the BRCA1 gene, first isolated in 1994, are recognized for contributing to an 80-90% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer. We undertook the analysis of 60 kindreds, each characterized by a familial incidence of breast and/or ovarian cancer, to pinpoint germline BRCA1 mutations. From this cohort, 22 unique mutations were detected across 32 families (53%), with 14 representing previously unreported variants. A compelling correlation was established between the precise locus of a mutation within the gene and the internal family ratio of breast to ovarian cancer cases. Our findings intimate a gradient of risk, indicating that mutations occurring in the distal third of the gene correlate with a reduced prevalence of ovarian cancer. While haplotype analysis corroborates earlier observations suggesting common ancestry among some BRCA1 mutation carriers, we also uncovered at least two examples of recurring mutations that appear to have arisen de novo.

I1307K APC and hMLH1 Mutations in a Non-Jewish Kindred with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer. We report on a French Canadian kindred afflicted with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) that harbors a novel truncating mutation within hMLH1. Of note, the I1307K APC polymorphism, which is associated with an elevated risk of colorectal cancer, is also detected in this family. This I1307K polymorphism had previously been identified exclusively in individuals self-identifying as Ashkenazi Jewish. Furthermore, within this specific family, no correlation appears to exist between the I1307K polymorphism and the manifestation or absence of cancer.

Identification of I1307K APC and hMLH1 Mutations in a Non-Jewish Family with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer. A French Canadian hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) lineage is herein characterized, exhibiting a novel truncating mutation in hMLH1. Significantly, the I1307K APC polymorphism, known to be linked with an increased colorectal cancer risk, is also present within this lineage. This I1307K polymorphism has historically been found solely in individuals reporting Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry. Moreover, in the context of this family, the I1307K polymorphism demonstrates no apparent association with either the presence or absence of cancer.

A Novel Truncating hMLH1 Mutation and the I1307K APC Polymorphism in a Non-Jewish HNPCC Kindred. We detail a French Canadian hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) family carrying a previously undescribed truncating mutation in the hMLH1 gene. Notably, the I1307K APC polymorphism, recognized for its association with an elevated risk of colorectal cancer, is also observed in this family. This I1307K polymorphism has, until now, been reported exclusively in individuals of self-declared Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Furthermore, within this specific family, there is no discernible connection between the I1307K polymorphism and the presence or absence of a cancer diagnosis.

Uncovering I1307K APC and hMLH1 Mutations in a Non-Ashkenazi Jewish Family with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer. This study describes a French Canadian hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) family, found to possess a novel truncating mutation within hMLH1. Intriguingly, the I1307K APC polymorphism, which is known to heighten colorectal cancer risk, is likewise identified in this family. The I1307K polymorphism has exclusively been reported in individuals of self-professed Ashkenazi Jewish origin in prior studies. Importantly, for this specific family, no relationship is evident between the I1307K polymorphism and the occurrence or non-occurrence of cancer.

Association of the APC I1307K Allele with Cancer Risk in an Ashkenazi Jewish Community Cohort. Mutations within the Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (APC) gene are conventionally linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a highly penetrant autosomal dominant condition typified by numerous intestinal polyps and, absent surgical intervention, the progression to colorectal cancer (CRC). APC functions as a tumor-suppressor gene, undergoing somatic loss in neoplastic tissue. The I1307K allele of APC arises from a germline T-to-A transversion, transforming the wild-type sequence into a genetically unstable homopolymer tract (A8) susceptible to somatic mutation. Previous research documented the I1307K allele in 6.1% of unselected Ashkenazi Jews, with elevated proportions observed in Ashkenazim possessing family or personal histories of CRC (ref. 2). To ascertain the influence of I1307K on cancer development, our study genotyped 5,081 Ashkenazi volunteers from a community-based survey. We then compared the risk of developing colorectal, breast, and other cancers between individuals identified as I1307K carriers and non-carriers, along with their respective first-degree relatives.

Evaluating Cancer Risk Associated with the APC I1307K Allele in a Community-Based Population of Ashkenazi Jews. The Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (APC) gene's mutations are classically linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an autosomal dominant disorder with high penetrance, characterized by the formation of multiple intestinal polyps and, without surgical treatment, the eventual development of colorectal cancer (CRC). APC serves as a tumor-suppressor gene, with somatic loss occurring in cancerous growths. The germline T-to-A transversion that creates the APC I1307K allele converts the normal sequence into a homopolymer tract (A8) that is genetically volatile and prone to somatic mutations. This I1307K allele was identified in 6.1% of unselected Ashkenazi Jews and in higher proportions among Ashkenazi individuals with family or personal histories of CRC (ref. 2). To assess the role of I1307K in carcinogenesis, we performed genotyping on 5,081 Ashkenazi volunteers within a community survey framework. Cancer risks, specifically for colorectal, breast, and other cancers, were subsequently compared between I1307K carriers and non-carriers, including their first-degree relatives.

Prevalence and Cancer Risk Implications of the APC I1307K Allele in an Ashkenazi Jewish Community Sample. Mutations within the APC gene are fundamentally associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a highly penetrant autosomal dominant condition marked by numerous intestinal polyps and, in the absence of surgical intervention, the progression to colorectal cancer (CRC). The APC gene functions as a tumor suppressor, with somatic loss frequently observed in neoplastic lesions. The I1307K allele results from a germline T-to-A transversion, which alters the wild-type sequence into a homopolymer tract (A8) exhibiting genetic instability and a propensity for somatic mutation. The I1307K allele was previously reported in 6.1% of unselected Ashkenazi Jews and at increased frequencies in Ashkenazi individuals with a familial or personal history of CRC (ref. 2). Our objective was to investigate the contribution of I1307K to cancer risk; therefore, we genotyped 5,081 Ashkenazi participants in a community-based health assessment. The likelihood of developing colorectal, breast, and other cancers was subsequently contrasted between genotyped I1307K carriers and non-carriers, as well as their first-degree relatives.

Investigation of the APC I1307K Genetic Variant and Cancer Susceptibility in an Ashkenazi Jewish Community Setting. Classically, mutations of the APC gene are linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a highly penetrant autosomal dominant disorder typified by the presence of multiple intestinal polyps and, if surgical intervention is not performed, the onset of colorectal cancer (CRC). As a tumor-suppressor gene, APC undergoes somatic loss within tumors. The APC I1307K allele originates from a germline T-to-A transversion, converting the standard sequence into a homopolymer tract (A8) that is inherently unstable genetically and prone to somatic mutation. This I1307K allele was identified in 6.1% of unselected Ashkenazi Jews, with higher proportions noted among Ashkenazim having family or personal histories of CRC (ref. 2). To assess the implications of I1307K for cancer development, our research involved genotyping 5,081 Ashkenazi volunteers as part of a community survey. We compared the incidence of colorectal, breast, and other cancers between individuals carrying the I1307K genotype and non-carriers, and also examined their first-degree relatives.

Expression Patterns of iNOS, bFGF, and TGF-beta1 in Vasodilator-Induced Rat Arteritis. Investigated the immunohistochemical expression of iNOS, bFGF, and TGF-beta1 in arteritis caused by fenoldopam and theophylline in rats. Rats received fenoldopam via 24-hour IV infusion, with or without subsequent daily oral theophylline. iNOS antigens were notably abundant in ED-1-positive cells at 5 and 8 days post-fenoldopam infusion (DPI), irrespective of theophylline. bFGF antigens showed marked abundance in ED-1-positive cells at 1 and 3 DPI. TGF-beta1 antigens were detected in ED-1-positive cells from 5 DPI onwards. These findings suggest that the peak expression of iNOS antigen precedes that of bFGF antigen, and bFGF might exert a suppressive effect on iNOS expression within these rat arteritis models. Conversely, TGF-beta1 was not implicated in suppressing iNOS expression in these specific models.

Immunohistochemical Analysis of iNOS, bFGF, and TGF-beta1 in Rat Arteritis Induced by Fenoldopam and Theophylline: Potential Interactions. An immunohistochemical examination was conducted to assess the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) in arteritis induced by the vasodilators fenoldopam and theophylline in rats. Animals were administered fenoldopam through a 24-hour intravenous infusion, followed by optional repeated daily oral doses of theophylline. Remarkable abundance of iNOS antigens was observed in ED-1-positive cells on days 5 and 8 post-fenoldopam infusion (DPI), regardless of concurrent theophylline administration. bFGF antigens were prominently present in ED-1-positive cells on 1 and 3 DPI. TGF-beta1 antigens appeared in ED-1-positive cells from 5 DPI onward. These results indicate that the peak expression of iNOS antigen was succeeded by that of bFGF antigen, implying a potential suppressive role for bFGF on iNOS expression in these rat arteritis models. In contrast, TGF-beta1 was not found to exert a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these models.

Investigation of iNOS, bFGF, and TGF-beta1 Expression in Vasodilator-Mediated Rat Arteritis. We immunohistochemically investigated the expression profiles of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) in rat models of arteritis induced by the vasodilators fenoldopam and theophylline. Rats received a 24-hour intravenous infusion of fenoldopam, either followed by or without repeated daily oral doses of theophylline. Significant levels of iNOS antigens were detected in ED-1-positive cells on day 5 and day 8 post-fenoldopam infusion (DPI), irrespective of theophylline administration. High levels of bFGF antigens were observed in ED-1-positive cells on day 1 and day 3 DPI. TGF-beta1 antigens became detectable in ED-1-positive cells starting from day 5 DPI. These findings suggest a sequential peak expression where iNOS antigen peaked before bFGF antigen, further indicating that bFGF may suppress iNOS expression in these rat arteritis models. Conversely, TGF-beta1 did not appear to have a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these models.

Immunohistochemical Analysis of iNOS, bFGF, and TGF-beta1 in Arteritis Induced by Fenoldopam and Theophylline in Rats. An immunohistochemical investigation was performed to assess the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) in arteritis models established in rats using the vasodilators fenoldopam and theophylline. The experimental protocol involved a 24-hour intravenous infusion of fenoldopam, either followed by or not followed by repeated daily oral administrations of theophylline. iNOS antigens were remarkably abundant in ED-1-positive cells on days 5 and 8 following fenoldopam infusion (DPI), independent of theophylline treatment. In contrast, bFGF antigens showed remarkable abundance in ED-1-positive cells on days 1 and 3 DPI. TGF-beta1 antigens were identified in ED-1-positive cells commencing on day 5 DPI. These observations imply that the peak expression of iNOS antigen was subsequently followed by that of bFGF antigen, suggesting a potential suppressive effect of bFGF on iNOS expression within these specific rat arteritis models. However, TGF-beta1 was not deemed to exert a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these models.

Elevated Venous Thromboembolism Risk with Docetaxel and Thalidomide Co-administration in Metastatic Androgen-Independent Prostate Cancer. This study aimed to ascertain the frequency of venous thromboembolism (VTE) among patients suffering from advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer, specifically comparing those treated with docetaxel monotherapy against those receiving docetaxel combined with thalidomide. A retrospective analysis of a randomized phase II trial was conducted at a National Institutes of Health clinical research center. The patient cohort comprised seventy men, aged 50-80 years, all diagnosed with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer. Interventions included either intravenous docetaxel at 30 mg/m2/week for three consecutive weeks, followed by a one-week break, or the concurrent administration of continuous oral thalidomide 200 mg nightly alongside the identical docetaxel regimen. This four-week cycle was repeated until the observation of excessive toxicity or disease progression. Key findings demonstrated that none of the 23 patients administered docetaxel alone experienced VTE, whereas VTE was observed in 9 out of 47 patients (19%) who received docetaxel combined with thalidomide (p=0.025). In conclusion, the inclusion of thalidomide in docetaxel-based treatment for prostate cancer significantly escalates the incidence of VTE. Clinicians are advised to consider this potential complication when integrating thalidomide into chemotherapy protocols.

Higher Incidence of Venous Thromboembolism in Metastatic Androgen-Independent Prostate Cancer Patients Receiving Docetaxel and Thalidomide Combination Therapy. The objective of this investigation was to assess the prevalence of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in individuals with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer treated with either docetaxel solely or a combination of docetaxel and thalidomide. The methodology involved a retrospective examination of a randomized phase II trial conducted at a National Institutes of Health clinical research center. Participants were seventy men, ranging from 50 to 80 years of age, afflicted with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer. The treatment protocols consisted of either intravenous docetaxel 30 mg/m2/week for three weeks followed by one week off, or the concurrent administration of continuous oral thalidomide 200 mg every evening in addition to the identical docetaxel schedule. This four-week cycle was sustained until signs of unacceptable toxicity or disease progression emerged. Principal results indicated that no VTE events occurred among the 23 patients who received docetaxel alone, whereas 9 of the 47 patients (19%) treated with docetaxel plus thalidomide developed VTE (p=0.025). Consequently, the integration of thalidomide with docetaxel in the management of prostate cancer substantially increases the frequency of VTE. Practitioners should be cognizant of this possible adverse event when incorporating thalidomide into chemotherapeutic regimens.

Increased Prevalence of Venous Thromboembolism Linked to Concomitant Docetaxel and Thalidomide in Metastatic Androgen-Independent Prostate Cancer. This study sought to ascertain the rate of venous thromboembolism (VTE) among patients with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer who underwent treatment with either docetaxel as a single agent or in conjunction with thalidomide. The design was a retrospective analysis derived from a randomized phase II trial performed at a National Institutes of Health clinical research center. Seventy men, aged 50-80 years, with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer, comprised the patient cohort. The therapeutic interventions involved either intravenous docetaxel administered at 30 mg/m2/week for 3 sequential weeks, followed by a 1-week pause, or the regimen of continuous oral thalidomide 200 mg each evening combined with the identical docetaxel schedule. This 4-week cycle was repeated until excessive toxicity or disease progression necessitated cessation. The main results revealed that VTE did not manifest in any of the 23 patients who received docetaxel alone, in contrast to 9 of 47 patients (19%) who received docetaxel alongside thalidomide, developing VTE (p=0.025). The conclusion drawn is that the augmentation of docetaxel therapy with thalidomide in prostate cancer significantly elevates the frequency of VTE. Clinicians ought to be mindful of this potential complication when utilizing thalidomide as an adjunct to chemotherapy.

Association Between Combined Docetaxel-Thalidomide Regimen and Elevated Venous Thromboembolism Rates in Metastatic Androgen-Independent Prostate Cancer. The primary goal of this research was to investigate the incidence of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients afflicted with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer, comparing those receiving docetaxel monotherapy against those on a combined docetaxel and thalidomide treatment. A retrospective analysis of data from a randomized phase II trial conducted at a National Institutes of Health clinical research center formed the study's design. The patient group consisted of 70 men, aged between 50 and 80 years, all diagnosed with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer. The intervention entailed either intravenous docetaxel 30 mg/m2/week for a period of three consecutive weeks, followed by one week without treatment, or the administration of continuous oral thalidomide 200 mg every evening coupled with the same docetaxel regimen. This four-week cycle was repeated until the occurrence of undue toxicity or disease progression. Measurements and main results demonstrated that zero VTE cases were observed among the 23 patients on docetaxel alone, whereas 9 out of 47 patients (19%) receiving docetaxel plus thalidomide experienced VTE (p=0.025). This study concludes that the addition of thalidomide to docetaxel for prostate cancer treatment substantially increases the VTE rate. Healthcare professionals should be cognizant of this possible adverse event when incorporating thalidomide into chemotherapeutic protocols.

A p16INK4a-Unresponsive CDK4 Variant Targeted by Cytolytic T Lymphocytes in Human Melanoma. A mutated cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) was discovered as a tumor-specific antigen recognized by HLA-A2.1-restricted autologous cytolytic T lymphocytes (CTLs) within a human melanoma. This altered CDK4 allele was detected in autologous cultured melanoma cells and metastatic tissue, but absent from the patient's lymphocytes. The specific mutation, an arginine-to-cysteine substitution at residue 24, constituted a component of the CDK4 peptide targeted by CTLs and impeded the binding of the CDK4 inhibitor p16INK4a, yet not p21 or p27KIP1. The identical mutation was observed in one further melanoma among the 28 cases examined. These findings indicate that a CDK4 mutation can generate a tumor-specific antigen and can disrupt the cell-cycle control mediated by the tumor suppressor p16INK4a.

Immunogenic p16INK4a-Resistant CDK4 Mutation in Human Melanoma Cells. An HLA-A2.1-restricted autologous cytolytic T lymphocyte (CTL) response in a human melanoma was directed against a mutated cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4), which functioned as a tumor-specific antigen. The presence of this mutated CDK4 allele was confirmed in autologous cultured melanoma cells and metastasis tissue, but not in the corresponding patient's lymphocytes. This mutation, characterized by an arginine-to-cysteine change at amino acid position 24, was integral to the CDK4 peptide recognized by CTLs and also abrogated the binding of the CDK4 inhibitor p16INK4a, though not that of p21 or p27KIP1. Out of 28 melanomas investigated, this exact mutation was identified in one additional case. These data propose that CDK4 mutations are capable of both generating a tumor-specific antigen and disrupting the cell-cycle regulation typically governed by the tumor suppressor p16INK4a.

Discovery of a Cytolytic T Lymphocyte-Targeted, p16INK4a-Nonresponsive CDK4 Mutant in Human Melanoma. In a human melanoma, a mutated cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) was determined to be a tumor-specific antigen, recognized by HLA-A2.1-restricted autologous cytolytic T lymphocytes (CTLs). This specific mutated CDK4 allele was found within autologous cultured melanoma cells and metastatic tissue, yet was absent from the patient's lymphocytes. The mutation, involving an arginine-to-cysteine exchange at residue 24, formed part of the CDK4 peptide that CTLs recognized and crucially prevented the attachment of the CDK4 inhibitor p16INK4a, but not p21 or p27KIP1. Among 28 melanomas screened, the identical mutation was detected in one additional sample. These outcomes suggest that a mutation within CDK4 can both establish a tumor-specific antigen and interfere with the cell-cycle regulation normally controlled by the tumor suppressor p16INK4a.

A Melanoma-Derived CDK4 Mutant Inducing T-Cell Responses and p16INK4a Resistance. Within a human melanoma, a variant of cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) was identified as a tumor-specific antigen targeted by HLA-A2.1-restricted autologous cytolytic T lymphocytes (CTLs). This variant CDK4 allele was observed in autologous cultured melanoma cells and metastasis tissue, but it was not present in the patient's lymphocytes. The alteration, an arginine-to-cysteine exchange at position 24, constituted a key part of the CDK4 peptide recognized by CTLs and importantly precluded the binding of the CDK4 inhibitor p16INK4a, though not that of p21 or p27KIP1. The same genetic modification was identified in one further melanoma out of 28 total melanomas analyzed. These findings underscore that a CDK4 mutation can both generate a tumor-specific antigen and impede the cell-cycle regulation provided by the tumor suppressor p16INK4a.

Hemorrhagic Cystitis Induced by Busulfan. This report details a case of busulfan-associated hemorrhagic cystitis. The condition resolved spontaneously subsequent to drug discontinuation. A comparison of the histological characteristics of busulfan cystitis with those observed in radiation- and cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis is presented, supported by a review of the global literature. Given busulfan's established propensity for inducing cellular atypia and malignancy elsewhere in the body, routine urinary cytology is recommended for individuals undergoing extended busulfan treatment.

Busulfan-Associated Hemorrhagic Cystitis. We present a case documenting hemorrhagic cystitis attributed to busulfan administration. Resolution of the condition occurred spontaneously upon the cessation of the medication. The histological resemblances between busulfan-related cystitis and those resulting from radiation and cyclophosphamide exposure are explored, incorporating a review of international scientific publications. Considering busulfan's recognized potential to cause cellular atypia and carcinoma in various tissues, long-term busulfan recipients are advised to undergo periodic urinary cytological screening.

A Case of Busulfan-Related Hemorrhagic Cystitis. An instance of hemorrhagic cystitis occurring as a consequence of busulfan therapy is described. Discontinuation of the drug led to spontaneous amelioration of the symptoms. Histological commonalities between busulfan-induced cystitis and forms caused by radiation and cyclophosphamide are examined, along with a comprehensive review of the available world literature. Due to busulfan's documented capacity to promote cellular atypia and neoplastic transformation in other locations, it is proposed that patients receiving prolonged busulfan treatment undergo regular urinary cytology examinations.

Manifestation of Hemorrhagic Cystitis Due to Busulfan. This paper reports a patient case involving hemorrhagic cystitis instigated by busulfan. The condition resolved without intervention following the stopping of the agent. The discussion addresses the histopathological similarities between busulfan cystitis and that arising from radiation or cyclophosphamide, complemented by a survey of the global scientific literature. In light of busulfan's established role in generating cellular atypia and carcinomatous changes in other anatomical sites, routine urinary cytology is suggested for patients on extended busulfan regimens.

The dominant negative impact of the APC1309 mutation and its role in FAP genotype-phenotype correlation. Colorectal tumorigenesis commences with the inactivation of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene product. Patients with familial APC (FAP) carry germline mutations in the APC gene and develop numerous colorectal adenomas and subsequent carcinomas early in life. The severity of the disease correlates with the position of the inherited APC mutation, indicating a genotype-phenotype relationship. This correlation, alongside the clustering of both germline and sporadic APC mutations in the central region of the APC gene, suggests a dominant negative effect by certain APC mutants. Loss of APC function was recently demonstrated to enhance beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription in colon epithelial cells. Here, we provide experimental evidence for a dominant negative effect exerted by APC gene products associated with severe polyposis. Wild-type APC activity in beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription was strongly inhibited by a mutant APC truncated at codon 1309. In contrast, mutant APC gene products associated with attenuated polyposis (at codon 386 or 1465) only weakly interfered with wild-type APC activity. These findings propose a molecular explanation for the genotype-phenotype correlation in FAP patients and support the hypothesis that colorectal tumor growth might be, in part, driven by selection for a mutation in the mutation cluster region.

The APC1309 mutation's dominant negative influence in elucidating FAP genotype-phenotype correlations. The inactivation of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene product initiates colorectal tumorigenesis. Individuals with familial APC (FAP) possess germline mutations in the APC gene, leading to the early manifestation of multiple colorectal adenomas and later carcinomas. Disease severity is directly linked to the location of the inherited APC mutation, establishing a genotype-phenotype correlation. This observation, combined with the fact that both germline and sporadic APC mutations frequently cluster in the central region of the APC gene, points to a dominant negative impact of specific APC mutants. Recent research showed that a loss of APC function results in amplified beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription in colon epithelial cells. This study offers experimental proof for a dominant negative effect from APC gene products connected to severe polyposis. Wild-type APC activity in beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription was potently suppressed by a mutant APC that is truncated at codon 1309. Conversely, mutant APC gene products associated with attenuated polyposis (e.g., at codon 386 or 1465) only marginally impaired wild-type APC activity. These results suggest a molecular basis for the genotype-phenotype correlation observed in FAP patients and bolster the idea that colorectal tumor growth may be partly propelled by selection for a mutation within the mutation cluster region.

The APC1309 mutation's dominant negative action explaining genotype-phenotype links in familial adenomatous polyposis. Colorectal tumor formation begins with the deactivation of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene product. Patients afflicted with familial APC (FAP) inherit germline mutations in the APC gene, resulting in the early development of numerous colorectal adenomas and subsequent carcinomas. A clear genotype-phenotype correlation exists, where the severity of the disease corresponds to the specific position of the inherited APC mutation. This correlation, coupled with the clustering of both germline and sporadic APC mutations within the central region of the APC gene, indicates a dominant negative effect from certain APC variants. It has been recently demonstrated that a reduction in APC function leads to enhanced beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription in colon epithelial cells. Herein, we provide empirical evidence for a dominant negative effect by APC gene products implicated in severe polyposis. A mutant APC, specifically truncated at codon 1309, significantly hampered wild-type APC activity in beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription. In contrast, mutant APC products linked to attenuated polyposis phenotypes (at codon 386 or 1465) only minimally disrupted wild-type APC function. These findings put forth a molecular rationale for the observed genotype-phenotype correlation in FAP patients and lend credence to the concept that colorectal tumor progression might, in part, be driven by selection for mutations within the mutation cluster region.

The dominant negative influence of the APC1309 mutation as a potential basis for FAP genotype-phenotype relationships. Inactivation of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene product initiates colorectal tumorigenesis. Individuals with familial APC (FAP) carry inherited germline mutations in the APC gene, leading to the early emergence of multiple colorectal adenomas and subsequent carcinomas. The severity of the disease exhibits a correlation with the specific locus of the inherited APC mutation, thereby establishing a genotype-phenotype relationship. This, together with the observation that both germline and sporadic APC mutations aggregate in the central region of the APC gene, suggests a dominant negative effect of particular APC mutants. Previous research has shown that a decrease in APC function results in heightened beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription in colon epithelial cells. This paper presents experimental validation for a dominant negative effect of APC gene products, particularly those associated with severe polyposis. A mutant APC protein, truncated at codon 1309, profoundly suppressed wild-type APC activity in beta-catenin-/Tcf-mediated transcription. Conversely, mutant APC gene products associated with attenuated polyposis (e.g., at codon 386 or 1465) showed only minor interference with wild-type APC activity. These data offer a molecular explanation for the genotype-phenotype correlation in FAP patients and strengthen the argument that colorectal tumor growth may be partly driven by selection for mutations in the mutation cluster region.

Testosterone and dietary fat as promoters of prostate carcinogenesis in genetically susceptible rats. Spontaneous prostate adenocarcinomas occurred in germfree (GF) Lobund strain Wistar (LW) rats fed vegetable diet L-485, exhibiting a 10% incidence at an average age of 34 months. Conventional LW rats, receiving testosterone implants at 4 months of age, showed an elevated prostate cancer incidence after a mean 14-month interval: 24% developed gross tumors, increasing to 40% with the inclusion of microscopic lesions. Preliminary data suggest that testosterone-treated LW rats consuming the L-485 diet, supplemented with up to 20% corn oil, developed prostate cancer within 6-12 months. In contrast, aged GF Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats exhibited no spontaneous prostate cancer. Conventional SD rats fed diet L-485 and administered testosterone developed only prostatitis. Consequently, genetic susceptibility is a fundamental prerequisite for experimental prostate cancer studies, warranting consideration in experimental designs.

The enhancing impact of testosterone and dietary fat on prostate cancer development in genetically predisposed rats. Lobund strain Wistar (LW) rats, raised germfree (GF) and maintained on vegetable diet L-485, spontaneously developed prostate adenocarcinomas, observed in 10% of animals at an average age of 34 months. Conventional LW rats, administered testosterone implants at 4 months old, subsequently displayed a higher prostate cancer prevalence following an average 14-month period: 24% presented with macroscopic tumors, while 40% were affected when microscopic tumors were included. Initial findings indicate that LW rats treated with testosterone and fed the same diet, enriched with up to 20% corn oil, developed prostate cancer within 6-12 months. Conversely, aged germfree Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats did not manifest spontaneous prostate cancer. Conventional SD rats given diet L-485 and testosterone treatment only developed prostatitis. Therefore, genetic susceptibility should be regarded as a core requirement when designing studies on experimental prostate cancer.

Role of testosterone and dietary fat in promoting prostate carcinogenesis among genetically susceptible rat strains. Prostate adenocarcinomas emerged spontaneously in 10% of germfree (GF) Lobund strain Wistar (LW) rats consuming the L-485 vegetable diet, with an average onset at 34 months of age. Conventional LW rats, implanted with testosterone at 4 months old, exhibited a greater incidence of prostate cancer after an average 14-month period: 24% developed discernible tumors, and this increased to 40% when microscopic tumors were counted. Early results suggest that testosterone-treated LW rats, whose L-485 diet was augmented with corn oil to 20% fat, developed prostate cancer over 6-12 months. Notably, aged GF Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats showed no spontaneous prostate cancer development. Conventional SD rats on diet L-485, despite testosterone treatment, only developed prostatitis. Accordingly, experimental protocols for prostate cancer research should consider genetic susceptibility as an essential foundational element.

Dietary fat and testosterone promote prostate carcinogenesis in genetically susceptible rat models. In contrast, conventional LW rats implanted with testosterone at 4 months of age experienced a significantly higher incidence of prostate cancer after an average 14-month interval: 24% exhibited gross tumors, a figure that rose to 40% with the inclusion of microscopic tumors. Preliminary findings demonstrate that LW rats treated with testosterone and consuming the L-485 diet, further supplemented with corn oil to constitute 20% fat, developed prostate cancer within 6-12 months. Aged germfree Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats, however, did not develop spontaneous prostate cancer. Furthermore, conventional SD rats receiving diet L-485 and testosterone treatment only manifested prostatitis. This evidence underscores the importance of genetic susceptibility as a fundamental prerequisite for experimental prostate cancer studies, advising its consideration in study designs.

Identification of BRCA1 Founder Mutations in Polish Breast-Ovarian Cancer Families. A hospital-based investigation was conducted to ascertain potential BRCA1 and BRCA2 founder mutations within the Polish population. The cohort comprised 66 Polish families, each exhibiting at least three related females afflicted with breast or ovarian cancer, with at least one diagnosis occurring before age 50. This group included 27 families with both breast and ovarian cancers, 4 with ovarian cancers exclusively, and 35 with breast cancers only. Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes from at least one affected woman per family. The complete coding sequences of BRCA1 and BRCA2 were screened for germline mutations via SSCP, with subsequent direct sequencing of observed variants. Mutations were identified in 35 (53%) of the 66 families examined. With one exception, all detected mutations were within the BRCA1 gene. BRCA1 abnormalities were present in all four families affected solely by ovarian cancer, in 67% of the 27 families with both breast and ovarian cancer, and in 34% of the 35 families with breast cancer only. The single family carrying a BRCA2 mutation presented with the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Seven distinct mutations were uncovered; five of these were observed in multiple families. Overall, recurrent mutations were found in 33 (94%) of the 35 families with identified mutations. Three specific BRCA1 alterations5382insC, C61G, and 4153delAconstituted 51%, 20%, and 11% of the total identified mutations, respectively.

This hospital-based study aimed to characterize potential founder mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes within the Polish demographic. Germline mutations across the entire coding regions of BRCA1 and BRCA2 were screened using SSCP, followed by direct sequencing of any detected variants. Mutations were identified in 35 (53%) of the 66 families investigated. All but one of these mutations were located in the BRCA1 gene. BRCA1 abnormalities were observed in all four families with ovarian cancer only, in 67% of the 27 families with both breast and ovarian cancer, and in 34% of the 35 families with breast cancer only. A single family with a BRCA2 mutation displayed the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Seven different mutations were detected; five of which appeared in two or more families. In total, recurrent mutations were present in 33 (94%) of the 35 families exhibiting mutations. Three particular BRCA1 mutations5382insC, C61G, and 4153delAcontributed to 51%, 20%, and 11% of the identified mutations, respectively.

Development and Application of Multiplex Heteroduplex Analysis for Rapid Detection of Regionally Clustered Germ-line BRCA1 Mutations. The UKCCCR Familial Ovarian Cancer Study Group notes that germ-line mutations within the BRCA1 gene contribute to a significant number of families affected by early-onset breast and/or ovarian cancer. Since its isolation last year, over 65 unique mutations have been identified across the coding region, complicating genetic analysis. We have developed a multiplex heteroduplex analysis method, a single-step screening procedure capable of evaluating one-quarter of the coding sequence and detecting approximately 50% of BRCA1 mutations previously documented in breast/ovarian cancer families. This technique was applied to analyze BRCA1 in 162 families with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer, leading to the identification of 12 distinct mutations in 35 of these families.

An Efficient Multiplex Heteroduplex Analysis for Identifying Clustered Germ-line BRCA1 Mutations. Germ-line mutations in the BRCA1 gene are responsible for a substantial proportion of familial early-onset breast and/or ovarian cancers, as highlighted by the UKCCCR Familial Ovarian Cancer Study Group. The detection of more than 65 distinct mutations scattered across the gene's coding region since its isolation last year has rendered BRCA1 analysis both time-consuming and technically challenging. To address this, we devised a multiplex heteroduplex analysis. This single-step screening procedure examines one-quarter of the coding sequence and can identify roughly 50% of all BRCA1 mutations reported in breast/ovarian cancer kindreds to date. Applying this method to 162 families with a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer enabled the detection of 12 distinct mutations in 35 families.

Multiplex Heteroduplex Analysis: A Tool for Swift Detection of Clustered Germ-line BRCA1 Mutations. The UKCCCR Familial Ovarian Cancer Study Group recognizes that germ-line BRCA1 gene mutations account for a considerable number of early-onset breast and/or ovarian cancer cases within families. With over 65 unique mutations identified throughout the coding region since BRCA1's isolation last year, gene analysis presents significant challenges in terms of time and technical complexity. We developed a multiplex heteroduplex analysis strategy designed for single-step screening, covering one-quarter of the coding sequence and capable of detecting approximately 50% of all BRCA1 mutations thus far documented in breast/ovarian cancer families. This technique was employed to screen BRCA1 in 162 families experiencing a history of breast and/or ovarian cancer, successfully identifying 12 distinct mutations across 35 families.

Since its discovery last year, more than 65 specific mutations have been found dispersed across the coding region, rendering comprehensive genetic analysis laborious and technically demanding. Our team devised a multiplex heteroduplex analysis, which functions as a single-step screening procedure, analyzing a quarter of the coding sequence and detecting about 50% of all BRCA1 mutations currently reported in breast/ovarian cancer families. Through the application of this method to 162 families with a documented history of breast and/or ovarian cancer, we identified 12 distinct mutations in 35 families.

High frequency of PTEN/MMAC1 inactivation in primary prostate carcinoma. Sporadic prostate carcinoma represents the most prevalent male malignancy in Western populations, yet key genetic events driving the progression of this often-lethal disease are not fully understood. Prior cytogenetic and allelotype investigations have consistently reported a high incidence of loss of heterozygosity on chromosome 10q in sporadic prostate cancer. Deletion mapping studies precisely localized a minimal region of loss to chromosome 10q23. A novel tumor suppressor gene, PTEN/MMAC1, was recently identified within this 10q23 region and previously shown to be inactivated by mutation in three prostate cancer cell lines. In this study, we performed microsatellite analysis on 80 prostate tumors, detecting 10q23 deletions in 23 cases. Subsequent sequence analysis of the complete PTEN/MMAC1 coding region and assessment for homozygous deletions using novel intragenic markers in these 23 tumors with 10q23 LOH revealed a second mutational event in 10 (43%) tumors. This finding confirms PTEN/MMAC1 as a principal target for inactivation due to 10q loss in sporadic prostate cancer.

PTEN/MMAC1 inactivation prevalence in primary prostate cancer. Despite being the most common male cancer in the Western world, the significant genetic mechanisms underlying the progression of sporadic prostate carcinoma, often a fatal disease, remain largely uncharacterized. Numerous cytogenetic and allelotyping studies have previously documented a frequent loss of heterozygosity on chromosomal arm 10q in sporadic prostate cancer cases. Deletion mapping efforts definitively pinpointed chromosome 10q23 as the minimal region of this loss. PTEN/MMAC1, a recently discovered tumor suppressor gene situated at 10q23, was previously found to be inactivated via mutation in three prostate cancer cell lines. Our investigation involved screening 80 prostate tumors using microsatellite analysis, which identified deletions on chromosome 10q23 in 23 specimens. We then conducted sequence analysis of the entire PTEN/MMAC1 coding region and assessed for homozygous deletion using new intragenic markers in these 23 cases exhibiting 10q23 LOH. The detection of a second mutational event in 10 (43%) of these tumors establishes PTEN/MMAC1 as a primary inactivation target implicated in 10q loss within sporadic prostate cancer.

High incidence of PTEN/MMAC1 gene inactivation in primary prostate carcinoma. Sporadic prostate carcinoma, the most common male malignancy in Western countries, still has many of its major genetic events, crucial for the progression of this often-fatal disease, yet to be fully defined. Previous cytogenetic and allelotype research has consistently reported widespread loss of heterozygosity on chromosomal arm 10q in sporadic prostate cancer. Deletion mapping studies unequivocally identified 10q23 as the minimal region of loss. PTEN/MMAC1, a new tumor suppressor gene, was recently isolated from this 10q23 region and mutations in it were found to cause inactivation in three prostate cancer cell lines. We screened 80 prostate tumors through microsatellite analysis, detecting deletions on chromosome 10q23 in 23 instances. Subsequently, we performed sequence analysis of the complete PTEN/MMAC1 coding region and tested for homozygous deletions using novel intragenic markers in these 23 cases exhibiting 10q23 LOH. The identification of a second mutational event in 10 (43%) of these tumors confirms PTEN/MMAC1 as a key inactivation target associated with 10q loss in sporadic prostate cancer.

Pervasive PTEN/MMAC1 inactivation in primary prostate cancer specimens. Although sporadic prostate carcinoma constitutes the predominant male cancer in the Western world, many significant genetic alterations underpinning the progression of this frequently lethal malignancy remain obscure. Numerous preceding cytogenetic and allelotype investigations have documented a considerable frequency of loss of heterozygosity on chromosome 10q in sporadic prostate cancer. Deletion mapping studies have precisely demarcated chromosome 10q23 as the minimal locus of this loss. A novel tumor suppressor gene, PTEN/MMAC1, was recently identified within this 10q23 region and previously observed to be inactivated by mutation in three prostate cancer cell lines. Our study involved microsatellite analysis of 80 prostate tumors, revealing deletions on chromosome 10q23 in 23 cases. We then conducted comprehensive sequence analysis of the PTEN/MMAC1 coding region and assayed for homozygous deletions using newly developed intragenic markers in these 23 tumors exhibiting 10q23 LOH. The discovery of a second inactivating mutational event in 10 (43%) of these tumors establishes PTEN/MMAC1 as a primary gene targeted for inactivation by 10q loss in sporadic prostate cancer.

The contribution and penetrance of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in hereditary breast cancer families. Through the Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium, an evaluation of BRCA1 and BRCA2's role in inherited breast cancer was conducted. This involved linkage and mutation analysis across 237 families, each presenting with a minimum of four breast cancer diagnoses. Family selection criteria did not consider the presence of ovarian or other malignancies. Overall, genetic linkage indicated BRCA1 as the cause in approximately 52% of families and BRCA2 in 32%, with 16% (95% confidence interval [CI] 6%-28%) showing no linkage to either gene, implying the involvement of alternative predisposition loci. In families affected by both breast and ovarian cancer, BRCA1 accounted for the majority (81%) of cases, while BRCA2 was responsible for most other instances (14%). Conversely, the predominant cause of breast cancer in families with both male and female affected individuals was BRCA2 (76%). The highest proportion (67%) of families attributed to other genetic factors was observed among those with solely four or five cases of female breast cancer. These estimations proved largely stable, irrespective of modifications to the assumed BRCA1 penetrance model or the inclusion/exclusion of BRCA1 mutation data. Within BRCA1-linked families subjected to standard screening, mutations in the coding sequence or splice sites were identified in an estimated 63% (95% CI 51%-77%) of cases. The sensitivity of detection was equivalent for direct sequencing and alternative methods. BRCA2 penetrance was determined by optimizing the LOD score within BRCA2-mutation-positive families, considering all potential penetrance functions. The calculated cumulative breast cancer risk reached 28% (95% CI 9%-44%) by 50 years of age and 84% (95% CI 43%-95%) by 70 years of age. Corresponding ovarian cancer risks were 0.4% (95% CI 0%-1%) by age 50 and 27% (95% CI 0%-47%) by age 70. Lifetime breast cancer risk appeared comparable to that in BRCA1 carriers, though a slightly reduced risk was suggested for BRCA2 carriers under 50 years old.

Analysis of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genetic factors and disease penetrance in familial breast cancer. A study by the Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium aimed to ascertain the involvement of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in hereditary breast cancer. This was achieved through linkage and mutation analyses performed on 237 families, each characterized by a minimum of four breast cancer diagnoses. Recruitment of families proceeded irrespective of co-occurring ovarian or other cancer types. Globally, an estimated 52% of families exhibited disease linkage to BRCA1, 32% to BRCA2, and 16% (95% CI 6%-28%) demonstrated no linkage to either gene, implying the existence of additional susceptibility genes. For families presenting with both breast and ovarian cancer, BRCA1 was responsible for the majority (81%) of cases, with BRCA2 contributing to most remaining cases (14%). Conversely, in families affected by both male and female breast cancer, BRCA2 was the primary genetic cause (76%). The greatest proportion (67%) of families whose disease was attributed to other genes occurred in those with only four or five female breast cancer diagnoses. These estimations were largely unaffected by alterations to the presumed BRCA1 penetrance model or by the inclusion or exclusion of BRCA1 mutation data. Among BRCA1-linked families screened using standard methodologies, mutations were identified within the coding sequence or splice sites in approximately 63% (95% CI 51%-77%) of instances. The calculated sensitivity proved identical for both direct sequencing and alternative methods. BRCA2 penetrance was assessed by maximizing the LOD score in families carrying BRCA2 mutations, across all feasible penetrance functions. The projected cumulative breast cancer risk attained 28% (95% CI 9%-44%) by 50 years of age and 84% (95% CI 43%-95%) by 70 years of age. Corresponding ovarian cancer risks were 0.4% (95% CI 0%-1%) at age 50 and 27% (95% CI 0%-47%) at age 70. While lifetime breast cancer risk seemed comparable to that of BRCA1 carriers, a hint of reduced risk was noted for BRCA2 carriers aged under 50 years.

Characterization of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genetic predisposition and penetrance in breast cancer kindreds. The Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium undertook an evaluation of the roles of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in hereditary breast cancer. The inclusion of families did not depend on the presence of ovarian or other types of cancer. Among families afflicted by both breast and ovarian cancer, BRCA1 was responsible for the predominant proportion (81%), with BRCA2 accounting for the majority of the remaining cases (14%). Conversely, BRCA2 was the genetic basis for the majority (76%) of families exhibiting both male and female breast cancer. The greatest percentage (67%) of families whose disease was linked to other genes was observed in those exclusively presenting with four or five female breast cancer cases. These estimations remained largely unaffected by adjustments to the assumed BRCA1 penetrance model or by the inclusion or exclusion of BRCA1 mutation data. For families with BRCA1-linked disease, subjected to a standard screening method, mutations were identified in the coding sequence or splice sites in an estimated 63% (95% CI 51%-77%) of cases. The sensitivity calculation yielded identical results for direct sequencing and other methodological approaches. The penetrance of BRCA2 was determined by maximizing the LOD score in BRCA2-mutation-carrying families, considering all feasible penetrance functions. The projected cumulative risk of breast cancer reached 28% (95% CI 9%-44%) by age 50 and 84% (95% CI 43%-95%) by age 70. Associated ovarian cancer risks were 0.4% (95% CI 0%-1%) by 50 years of age and 27% (95% CI 0%-47%) by 70 years of age. Lifetime breast cancer risk appeared comparable to that observed in BRCA1 carriers; however, a reduced risk was suggested for BRCA2 carriers under 50 years of age.

An examination of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genetic variability and penetrance in familial breast cancer. The Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium conducted an assessment of the roles of BRCA1 and BRCA2 in inherited breast cancer. This involved performing linkage and mutation analyses on a cohort of 237 families, each characterized by a minimum of four breast cancer cases, gathered by the Consortium. Enrollment of families did not depend on the presence of ovarian or other cancer types. In total, disease linkage was attributed to BRCA1 in an approximate 52% of families and to BRCA2 in 32%, with 16% (95% CI 6%-28%) showing no association with either gene, indicating the potential involvement of other predisposing genes. For families affected by breast-ovarian cancer, BRCA1 was responsible for the majority (81%), with BRCA2 accounting for a significant portion of the remainder (14%). Conversely, BRCA2 was the causal gene in the majority (76%) of families exhibiting both male and female breast cancer. The highest proportion (67%) of families whose disease stemmed from other genes was identified in those with solely four or five female breast cancer cases. These estimations were not significantly impacted by modifying the presumed penetrance model for BRCA1 or by either incorporating or omitting BRCA1 mutation data. Among BRCA1-linked families screened using standard approaches, mutations in the coding sequence or splice sites were detected in an estimated 63% (95% CI 51%-77%). The sensitivity estimate was identical for both direct sequencing and other employed techniques. BRCA2 penetrance was ascertained by maximizing the LOD score in families with BRCA2 mutations, considering the full range of possible penetrance functions. The calculated cumulative breast cancer risk reached 28% (95% CI 9%-44%) by age 50 and 84% (95% CI 43%-95%) by age 70. Concomitant ovarian cancer risks were 0.4% (95% CI 0%-1%) by 50 years of age and 27% (95% CI 0%-47%) by 70 years of age. The lifetime breast cancer risk appears comparable to that observed in BRCA1 carriers, although a tendency towards a lower risk was noted in BRCA2 carriers under 50 years of age.

Molecular characterization of the APC gene region in familial polyposis using yeast artificial chromosomes. Two yeast artificial chromosomes (YACs), encompassing a 1.1 megabase pair DNA segment around the MCC and APC genes at 5q21, have been successfully isolated and detailed. A strategy commencing with the MCC gene was employed to pinpoint constitutional submicroscopic deletions in familial adenomatous polyposis patients, aiming to precisely delineate the APC gene's locus. For this objective, MCC gene-identified YACs were screened against a chromosome 5-specific cosmid library, generating a supply of DNA probes for genomic analysis. The cosmids thus acquired were subsequently utilized to evaluate a panel of somatic cell hybrids, which contained chromosome 5 isolated from patients suspected of harboring interstitial deletions. This screening methodology led to the validation of a minor heterozygous deletion in a polyposis patient, which partially overlaps with one of the two isolated YACs. This particular YAC has been demonstrated to harbor the complete APC gene, alongside a substantial segment of DNA adjacent to its 5' end, thereby representing a significant asset for functional investigations through its introduction into colorectal tumor-derived cell lines.

Yeast artificial chromosomes as a resource for mapping the familial polyposis APC gene region. Two yeast artificial chromosomes (YACs), collectively covering 1.1 megabase pairs of DNA within the 5q21 chromosomal region, encompassing the MCC and APC genes, have been isolated and thoroughly characterized. An International Haplotype and Phenotype Characterization of Six Recurrent BRCA1 Mutations in 61 Families. BRCA1 mutations are observed in breast and ovarian cancer families across various geographic regions. This study aimed to determine the origin of these mutations and their associated specific phenotypes. We constructed a haplotype using nine polymorphic markers within or immediately flanking the BRCA1 locus in 61 breast/ovarian cancer families, each selected for possessing one of six recurrent BRCA1 mutations. No significant differences were identified regarding age at diagnosis, whether assessed by specific mutation or family. A suggestive trend (P = 0.069) indicated an impact of the specific mutation on the relative incidence of breast versus ovarian cancer. Notably, 57% of affected women with the 1294del40 BRCA1 mutation presented with ovarian cancer, whereas 14% of affected women carrying the BRCA1 intron 5 splice-site mutation exhibited ovarian cancer. The estimated age of origin for these individual BRCA1 mutations ranged from 9 to 170 generations. Overall, substantial haplotype conservation was evident across the genomic region. Divergences in haplotypes were primarily attributed to mutations within short-tandem-repeat markers, though instances of recombination were also detected. Furthermore, evidence suggested multiple, independent mutational origins for BRCA1 in several cases.

Genetic Origins and Phenotypic Correlates of Six Recurrent BRCA1 Mutations in a Cohort of 61 Families. BRCA1 mutations are frequently identified in breast and ovarian cancer families across varied geographical populations. This investigation sought to elucidate the ancestral origins of these mutations and their specific phenotypic expressions. For example, 57% of women with the 1294del40 BRCA1 mutation developed ovarian cancer, contrasting with 14% of affected women possessing the BRCA1 intron 5 splice-site mutation. The emergence of these particular BRCA1 mutations is estimated to have occurred between 9 and 170 generations in the past. Generally, significant haplotype conservation was noted across the region, with observed haplotype variations frequently stemming from short-tandem-repeat marker mutations, alongside some instances indicative of recombination. Moreover, evidence for several independent BRCA1 mutational events was found in multiple cases.

International Haplotype and Phenotype Investigation of Six Recurrent BRCA1 Mutations in 61 Families. BRCA1 mutations are established to be present in breast and ovarian cancer families across varied geographical locations. Somatic APC Gene Mutations in Colorectal Tumors: Prevalence of a Mutation Cluster Region. An analysis of somatic adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene mutations in 63 colorectal tumors (comprising 16 adenomas and 47 carcinomas) from both familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and non-FAP patients revealed significant findings. Beyond the loss of heterozygosity (LOH) observed at the APC locus in 30 tumors, 43 additional somatic mutations were identified. These included 21 point mutations (16 nonsense, 2 missense, and 3 intronic at splicing sites) and 22 frameshift mutations arising from deletions (19 cases, 1-31 bp) or insertions (3 cases, 1 bp). An additional 1-bp deletion was noted in an intron proximal to a splicing site. Consequently, 41 (95%) of the 43 identified mutations led to the truncation of the APC protein. A notable observation was that over 60% of these somatic APC gene mutations aggregated within a specific segment of exon 15, termed the mutation cluster region (MCR), despite this region representing less than 10% of the gene's coding sequence. When these mutational data were integrated with LOH results, it was determined that over 80% of tumors (14 adenomas and 39 carcinomas) harbored at least one APC gene mutation, with more than 60% of these (9 adenomas and 23 carcinomas) presenting two mutations. These findings strongly indicate a fundamental association between somatic APC gene mutations and the pathogenesis of a substantial proportion of colorectal tumors.

APC Gene Somatic Mutations in Colorectal Neoplasms: Characterization and Truncating Effects Within a Cluster Region. Somatic mutations within the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene were investigated across 63 colorectal tumors (16 adenomas, 47 carcinomas) originating from both familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and non-FAP individuals. Frameshift mutations, resulting from deletions or insertions, accounted for 22 cases; specifically, 19 deletions ranged from one to 31 base pairs, and 3 were single base-pair insertions. An additional 1-bp deletion occurred in an intron near a splicing site. Crucially, 41 (95%) of the 43 detected mutations ultimately caused truncation of the APC protein. Significantly, more than 60% of the somatic APC gene mutations were concentrated within a compact segment of exon 15, designated as the mutation cluster region (MCR), which constitutes under 10% of the gene's coding sequence. By integrating these mutational data with LOH findings, it was established that over 80% of tumors (14 adenomas and 39 carcinomas) exhibited at least one APC gene mutation, and over 60% of these (9 adenomas and 23 carcinomas) carried two mutations. These observations provide strong evidence supporting the association of somatic APC gene mutations with the genesis of the vast majority of colorectal tumors.

DCC Protein Expression as a Prognostic Indicator in Colorectal Carcinoma. Background: Allelic loss of chromosome 18q is associated with an unfavorable prognosis in stage II colorectal cancer, with the deleted in colorectal cancer (DCC) gene being a potential candidate for inactivation. This study aimed to determine if DCC protein expression within tumor cells serves as a prognostic marker in colorectal carcinoma. Methods: DCC expression was assessed via immunohistochemistry in 132 paraffin-embedded samples from patients with curatively resected stage II and III colorectal carcinomas. A Cox proportional-hazards model was employed to adjust for covariates including age, sex, tumor site, tumor differentiation grade, and adjuvant therapy utilization. Results: DCC expression emerged as a robust positive predictor of survival in both stage II and stage III colorectal carcinomas. For stage II patients with DCC-expressing tumors, the five-year survival rate was 94.3%, compared to 61.6% for those with DCC-negative tumors (P < 0.001). In stage III disease, corresponding survival rates were 59.3% and 33.2% (P = 0.03), respectively. Conclusions: DCC functions as a prognostic marker in patients afflicted with stage II or stage III colorectal cancer. Specifically, in stage II colorectal carcinomas, the absence of DCC identifies a patient subgroup whose lesions exhibit behaviors akin to stage III cancers, potentially holding therapeutic relevance for this cohort.

Prognostic Significance of DCC Protein in Colorectal Cancer. Background: A poor outcome in stage II colorectal cancer patients is linked to allelic loss of chromosome 18q, with the DCC (deleted in colorectal cancer) gene being a candidate for the underlying genetic inactivation. We investigated the utility of DCC protein expression in tumor cells as a prognostic marker in colorectal carcinoma. Methods: Immunohistochemical evaluation of DCC expression was performed on 132 paraffin-embedded specimens obtained from patients with curatively resected stage II and III colorectal carcinomas. The Cox proportional-hazards model was utilized for covariate adjustment, encompassing age, sex, tumor site, degree of tumor differentiation, and use of adjuvant therapy. Results: DCC expression demonstrated strong positive predictive value for survival across both stage II and stage III colorectal carcinomas. Patients with stage II disease whose tumors expressed DCC achieved a five-year survival rate of 94.3%, in contrast to 61.6% for those with DCC-negative tumors (P < 0.001). For stage III disease, the five-year survival rates were 59.3% and 33.2% for DCC-positive and DCC-negative tumors, respectively (P = 0.03). Conclusions: DCC serves as a prognostic marker in individuals diagnosed with stage II or stage III colorectal cancer. Within stage II colorectal carcinomas, the absence of DCC identifies a distinct subgroup of patients whose tumors demonstrate an aggressive phenotype similar to stage III cancers, suggesting potential therapeutic implications.

BRCA1's Association with Histone Deacetylase Complex Components. Germ-line mutations in the tumor-suppressor gene BRCA1 are linked to an elevated risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers. BRCA1 features a carboxyl-terminal domain (BRCT), a motif also found in several other proteins crucial for maintaining genome integrity. To elucidate BRCA1's function, our investigation aimed to identify proteins that interact with its BRCT domain. We utilized a purified BRCT polypeptide as a probe in a Far Western analysis to screen a human placenta cDNA expression library. Our findings indicate that BRCA1 establishes interactions, both in vivo and in vitro, with the Rb-binding proteins RbAp46 and RbAp48, as well as with Rb. Furthermore, the BRCT domain demonstrates an association with the histone deacetylases HDAC1 and HDAC2. These results unequivocally show that BRCA1 forms interactions with constituents of the histone deacetylase complex, thereby offering a potential explanation for its involvement in various cellular processes such as transcription, DNA repair, and recombination.

Discovery of BRCA1 Interactions with Histone Deacetylase Complex Constituents. Additionally, the BRCT domain establishes an association with the histone deacetylases HDAC1 and HDAC2. These findings collectively demonstrate that BRCA1 interacts with components of the histone deacetylase complex, which may account for its participation in diverse processes including transcription, DNA repair, and recombination.

The Role of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor and Its Receptor Overexpression in Estrogen-Induced Rat Pituitary Tumor Angiogenesis. Estrogens are implicated in various human and animal cancers and can stimulate tumor angiogenesis in the pituitaries of Fischer 344 rats. The precise mechanisms underlying this estrogen-mediated induction of tumor angiogenesis during carcinogenesis remain to be fully understood. To investigate estrogen's influence on tumor angiogenesis regulation in the pituitaries of female rats, blood vessel density was assessed via factor VIII related antigen (FVIIIRAg) immunohistochemistry. Additionally, the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor/vascular permeability factor (VEGF/VPF) was analyzed using Western blot and immunohistochemical methods, while VEGF receptor (VEGFR-2/Flk-1/KDR) expression was also examined through immunohistochemistry. Our findings revealed that 17beta-estradiol (E2) triggers neovascularization, alongside the growth and expansion of blood vessels, within 7 days of exposure. This pronounced tumor angiogenic potential correlated with increased VEGF/VPF protein expression in the E2-treated pituitary glands of ovariectomized (OVEX) rats. Combined VEGF/VPF and FVIIIRAg immunohistochemistry, along with endothelial specific lectin (UEA1) binding studies, indicated that the initial elevation of VEGF protein expression occurred in both blood vessels and non-endothelial cells. However, following 15 days of E2 exposure, VEGF/VPF protein expression in the non-endothelial cell population markedly decreased, becoming confined to the blood vessels. The specific function of VEGF derived from non-endothelial cells is currently unclear. Furthermore, immunohistochemical analyses showed a significant elevation of VEGFR-2 (flk-1/KDR) expression in the endothelial cells of microblood vessels after 7 days of E2 exposure. These results propose that the heightened expression of VEGF and its receptor (VEGFR-2) is instrumental in the initial stages of regulating estrogen-induced tumor angiogenesis in the rat pituitary.

Investigations using VEGF/VPF and FVIIIRAg immunohistochemistry, alongside endothelial-specific lectin (UEA1) binding, indicated that the initial rise in VEGF protein expression was evident in both blood vessels and non-endothelial cells. Nevertheless, after 15 days of E2 exposure, VEGF/VPF protein expression in the non-endothelial cell population underwent a sharp decline, becoming confined exclusively to the blood vessels. The precise function of non-endothelial-derived VEGF is currently not understood. Additionally, immunohistochemical evaluations demonstrated a significant upregulation of VEGFR-2 (flk-1/KDR) expression within the endothelial cells of microblood vessels after 7 days of E2 exposure. These results strongly suggest that the overexpression of VEGF and its receptor (VEGFR-2) is pivotal in the initial phase of regulating estrogen-induced tumor angiogenesis in the rat pituitary.

Identification of Eight BRCA1 Gene Alterations in Ten Breast/Ovarian Cancer Kindreds, Including One with Male Breast Cancer. Epidemiological genetic studies indicate that BRCA1 mutations contribute to approximately half of early-onset familial breast cancer and a majority of familial breast/ovarian cancer cases. The recent cloning of BRCA1 now permits direct mutation identification, although the viability of presymptomatic screening for cancer susceptibility remains uncertain. We examined genomic DNA from a single affected individual from each of 24 families, all presenting with at least three instances of ovarian or breast cancer, employing SSCP assays. Deviant SSCP bands underwent subcloning and sequencing. Allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization was utilized to confirm sequence alterations and to screen DNA from control subjects. Six frameshift and two missense mutations were identified across 10 distinct families. A frameshift mutation was found in a male proband afflicted with both breast and prostate cancer. A 40-bp deletion was observed in a patient who developed intra-abdominal carcinomatosis one year subsequent to prophylactic oophorectomy. Mutations were distributed throughout the gene, with only one appearing in multiple families. These findings further corroborate that inherited breast and ovarian cancers can arise from a diverse range of BRCA1 mutations. The results also suggest that creating a screening test for BRCA1 mutations will pose significant technical challenges. The discovery of a mutation in a family affected by male breast cancer, a condition not previously associated with BRCA1, additionally underscores the potential complexities in genetic counseling for individuals known to carry such mutations.
