Identification of a Novel Missense Mutation in RB1 Associated with Mild Retinoblastoma Phenotype in a Pedigree. Employing single strand conformation polymorphism analysis, we investigated all 27 exons of the RB1 gene in a family exhibiting a mild retinoblastoma phenotype. Within this family, affected individuals presented with unilateral tumors, and linkage analysis successfully identified unaffected mutation carriers. A unique band shift was detected in exon 21 via SSCP, corresponding to a missense mutation that converts cysteine to arginine at nucleotide position 28 of the exon. This mutation also abrogated an NdeI restriction enzyme recognition site. Comprehensive analysis of all family members confirmed that this missense mutation co-segregated with patients diagnosed with tumors or those predicted to carry the predisposing mutation based on linkage studies. These findings suggest the existence of another RB1 gene region where mutations merely alter gene function, thereby posing significant considerations for genetic counseling in families presenting with such distinct phenotypes.

Germline Mutation Site at APC Determines Somatic Mutation Type in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: Revisiting Knudson's Two-Hit Hypothesis. The Adenomatous Polyposis Coli (APC) gene is frequently regarded as a classic tumor suppressor. In familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), truncating germline and somatic mutations, or less commonly, allelic loss, are observed in tumors. Similarly, most sporadic colorectal cancers exhibit two APC mutations. However, observations from attenuated polyposis, mild disease associated with missense germline variants, and the somatic mutation cluster region (codons 1250-1450) suggest that APC mutations may not simply lead to protein function loss. Our investigations reveal that FAP patients possessing germline APC mutations within a constrained region (at most codons 1194-1392) predominantly exhibit allelic loss in their colorectal adenomas. This contrasts with other FAP patients, whose second hits are typically truncating mutations within the mutation cluster region. These findings indicate that distinct APC mutations confer varying selective advantages to cells, with those near codon 1300 providing the most significant benefit. Allelic loss is particularly favored in cells harboring a single mutation close to codon 1300. Furthermore, a different germline-somatic APC mutation pattern is evident in FAP desmoids. Consequently, APC does not align with the definition of a classical tumor suppressor. Our results also propose a novel mechanism for disease severity: a wider range of selected mutations in tumors effectively increases the somatic mutation rate, resulting in a greater number of tumors.

Germline APC Mutation Locus Influences Somatic Mutation Profile in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis: A Refined Understanding of Knudson's Two-Hit Model. The APC gene is widely acknowledged as a quintessential tumor suppressor. In familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) tumors, both truncating germline and somatic mutations, alongside occasional allelic loss, are prevalent. A majority of sporadic colorectal cancers also manifest two APC mutations. Nevertheless, evidence from attenuated polyposis, missense germline variants associated with milder disease, and the somatic mutation cluster region (codons 1250-1450) implies that APC mutations' effects might extend beyond simple protein function abolition. Our study identified that FAP patients with germline APC mutations situated within a restricted range (maximum codons 1194-1392) primarily exhibit allelic loss in their colorectal adenomas. This observation stands in opposition to other FAP patients, where secondary hits are frequently truncating mutations within the mutation cluster region. Our data suggest that diverse APC mutations bestow distinct selective advantages upon cells, with mutations proximal to codon 1300 offering the greatest advantage. Specifically, allelic loss is strongly selected for in cells possessing an initial mutation near codon 1300. A distinct germline-somatic APC mutation correlation is also observed in FAP desmoids. Therefore, APC cannot be classified as a classical tumor suppressor. Moreover, our findings introduce a novel mechanism for disease severity: a broader selection of mutations in tumors translates to an effectively elevated somatic mutation rate, leading to increased tumor burden.

Pooled Linkage Analysis of Hereditary Prostate Cancer to 1q24-25 from 772 ICPCG Families. Previous linkage investigations indicated a prostate cancer-susceptibility locus at 1q24-25. However, subsequent reports from additional family collections yielded conflicting outcomes. Furthermore, evidence for locus heterogeneity emerged through the identification of other putative hereditary prostate cancer loci on Xq27-28, 1q42-43, and 1p36. This investigation details a consolidated analysis of six markers within the 1q24-25 region, utilizing 772 families affected by hereditary prostate cancer. These families were ascertained by members of the International Consortium for Prostate Cancer Genetics (ICPCG) from North America, Australia, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. Globally, evidence for linkage was observed, with a peak parametric multipoint LOD score assuming heterogeneity (HLOD) of 1.40 (P = 0.01) at D1S212. The estimated proportion of linked families (alpha) was 0.06 (1-LOD support interval 0.01-0.12). This evidence was not detectable via a nonparametric approach, likely attributable to extensive heterogeneity. Subsequent parametric analysis identified a substantial influence of male-to-male disease transmission within families. Among the subset of 491 such families, the peak HLOD reached 2.56 (P = 0.0006), and alpha was 0.11 (1-LOD support interval 0.04-0.19), contrasting with HLODs of 0 in the remaining 281 families. Within families demonstrating male-to-male transmission, alpha increased alongside an early mean age at diagnosis, supporting the linkage of a prostate cancer-susceptibility gene to 1q24-25, albeit within a specific subset of prostate cancer families. While HPC1 represents a minor fraction of all families affected by hereditary prostate cancer, it appears to assume a more prominent role in families characterized by several members affected at an early age and showing male-to-male disease transmission.

Ophthalmic manifestations potentially linked to isotretinoin therapy. A total of 261 ocular adverse events were documented in 237 patients receiving isotretinoin, a medication frequently prescribed for severe cystic acne. Reversible side effects include blepharoconjunctivitis, subjective dry eye sensations, blurred vision, contact lens intolerance, and photodermatitis. More severe ocular adverse reactions, such as papilledema, pseudotumor cerebri, and white or gray subepithelial corneal opacities, are also reversible upon cessation of the drug. Reported instances of diminished dark adaptation are currently undergoing investigation. Isotretinoin is contraindicated during pregnancy due to numerous documented congenital anomalies following maternal exposure, including microphthalmos, orbital hypertelorism, and optic nerve hypoplasia.

BRCA1 R841W: A Potential Common Mutation Exhibiting a Moderate Phenotype. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an elevated risk of breast and ovarian cancer, frequently manifesting at an early age. Numerous distinct mutations are observed within the BRCA1 gene, including several recurrent instances, each contributing to a substantial proportion of families predisposed to hereditary cancer. These prevalent mutations play an etiological role in a multitude of breast and ovarian cancer occurrences, offering an opportunity to investigate genotype-phenotype correlations and gene-environment interactions in individuals sharing an identical BRCA1 lesion. We document a novel missense variant in BRCA1, specifically 2640 C->T (R841W), identified in three instances from a cohort comprising 305 breast and 79 ovarian cancer patients from Orange County, CA. These comprised consecutive, population-representative cases, unselected based on age or familial medical history. All three cases presented with a robust family history of breast, ovarian, or other malignancies potentially linked to a BRCA1 defect, and family members demonstrated significant concordance of cancer incidence with the presence of R841W. The age at cancer onset was not consistently distinguishable from typical sporadic cases. Screening a sample of 413 unrelated individuals to assess the hypothesis of R841W being a rare polymorphism revealed one additional occurrence in a woman diagnosed with breast cancer at 77 years, with a parental history of cancer. R841W is posited to be an etiologically significant lesion, contributing to approximately 1% (with a 95% confidence interval of 0-1.7%) of all breast and ovarian cancers within this specific population.

R841W is deemed to be an etiologically significant lesion, implicated in approximately 1% (95% confidence interval: 0-1.7%) of all breast and ovarian cancers within this cohort.

Quinine-Induced Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome: A Case Report. Hemolytic-uremic syndrome resulting from quinine consumption is a recently identified condition, with merely two prior reports detailing four cases in existing literature. We present a fifth instance. This reaction might be triggered by antibodies that react against platelets when quinine is present. Therapeutic interventions have encompassed plasma exchange, prednisone, aspirin, and dipyridamole. All affected individuals have recovered a degree of renal function. Nevertheless, it remains ambiguous whether pharmacological management or natural resolution accounts for this amelioration. Quinine-related hemolytic-uremic syndrome is likely more prevalent than currently understood. Recognizing this reaction promptly and preventing subsequent quinine exposure is crucial, given its apparent recurrent nature.

Quinine Ingestion as a Trigger for Hemolytic-Uremic Syndrome. The occurrence of hemolytic-uremic syndrome following quinine intake represents a novel observation, with only four cases previously documented across two publications. This paper details a fifth patient. The underlying mechanism may involve antibodies targeting platelets in the presence of quinine. Management strategies have included plasma exchange, prednisone, aspirin, and dipyridamole. While all patients experienced some recovery of renal function, it is not clear whether this improvement was due to therapeutic intervention or spontaneous recovery. Hemolytic-uremic syndrome linked to quinine is probably underdiagnosed. Prompt identification of this reaction and avoidance of subsequent quinine administration are vital, as the condition appears to recur.

It is probable that quinine-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome occurs more frequently than currently acknowledged. Early recognition of this adverse reaction and prevention of further quinine exposure are essential, given its propensity for recurrence.

It is likely that quinine-induced hemolytic-uremic syndrome is more common than currently recognized. Therefore, timely identification of this reaction and discontinuation of quinine exposure are critical, as the condition appears to be recurrent.

Compensatory P-glycoprotein Upregulation in the Blood-Brain Barrier of MRP2-Deficient TR(-) Rats Mimics Seizure-Induced Induction in Wild-Type Animals. The multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2), a drug efflux transporter primarily in hepatocyte apical domains and potentially in brain capillary endothelial cells forming the blood-brain barrier (BBB), is absent in transport-deficient (TR(-)) Wistar rats. These rats have been instrumental in identifying MRP2 substrates, such as phenytoin at the BBB. Recognizing the potential for compensatory transporter changes in genetically deficient models, this study examined P-glycoprotein (Pgp) expression, a key BBB drug efflux transporter, in TR(-) rat brains compared to wild-type Wistar rats. Immunohistochemistry, utilizing specific monoclonal antibodies for MRP2 and Pgp, revealed MRP2 labeling in normal Wistar rat brain microvessels, absent in TR(-) rats. Importantly, TR(-) rats demonstrated significant Pgp upregulation in brain capillary endothelial cells, a phenomenon not observed in liver sections. This Pgp overexpression in the BBB was comparable to that induced by pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats. Furthermore, experiments with the Pgp substrate phenobarbital and inhibitor tariquidar confirmed that Pgp in TR(-) rats is functional and compensates for the MRP2 deficiency in the BBB. These findings suggest Pgp's crucial role in compensating for MRP2 deficiency at the BBB, supporting MRP2's protective function by mitigating brain injury from cytotoxic compounds. Moreover, TR(-) rats represent a valuable model for investigating the effects of BBB Pgp overexpression on drug brain access, without requiring seizure induction.

Blood-Brain Barrier P-glycoprotein Elevation in MRP2-Null TR(-) Rats Parallels Seizure-Evoked Increases in Control Animals. MRP2, a drug efflux transporter found predominantly in apical hepatocytes and conceivably in apical brain capillary endothelial cells of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), is absent in the transport-deficient (TR(-)) Wistar rat mutant. This strain has been highly beneficial for identifying MRP2 substrates by comparing compound concentrations or activities in MRP2-deficient versus transport-competent Wistar rats. Our prior research identified phenytoin as an MRP2 substrate in the BBB using this methodology. However, the potential for compensatory upregulation of other transporters in genetically deficient models led us to investigate brain P-glycoprotein (Pgp) expression, a major BBB drug efflux transporter, in TR(-) rats versus non-mutant Wistar rats. We performed immunohistochemistry on brain and liver sections from TR(-) and normal Wistar rats, employing a novel MRP2 antibody and the C219 Pgp antibody. Immunofluorescence revealed extensive MRP2 labeling of brain microvessels in normal Wistar rats, which was absent in TR(-) rats. Crucially, TR(-) rats exhibited a significant increase in Pgp within brain capillary endothelial cells compared to wild-type controls, a change not apparent in liver. A similar extent of Pgp overexpression in the BBB also occurred following pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats. Systemic administration of phenobarbital (Pgp substrate) and tariquidar (Pgp inhibitor) in TR(-) rats confirmed Pgp's functionality and its compensatory role for the lack of MRP2 in the BBB. Consequently, these data highlight Pgp's significant contribution to compensating for MRP2 deficiency at the BBB. This compensatory mechanism likely serves to protect the brain from cytotoxic agents, thus reinforcing the concept of MRP2's protective function in the BBB. Furthermore, TR(-) rats offer a compelling model to explore the ramifications of BBB Pgp overexpression on cerebral drug access, obviating the need for seizure induction or other Pgp-stimulating events.

Blood-Brain Barrier P-glycoprotein Overexpression in MRP2-Deficient TR(-) Rats: A Parallel to Seizure-Induced Upregulation in Wild-Type Counterparts. The multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2), an efflux transporter predominantly situated at the apical domain of hepatocytes and potentially at the apical membrane of brain capillary endothelial cells forming the blood-brain barrier (BBB), is missing in the transport-deficient (TR(-)) Wistar rat mutant. This rat strain has proven invaluable for discerning MRP2 substrates by contrasting tissue concentrations or functional activities in MRP2-deficient animals with those in transport-competent Wistar rats. Our recent findings, utilizing this approach, established phenytoin as a BBB MRP2 substrate. However, a limitation of studies in genetically deficient models is the potential for compensatory alterations, such as the upregulation of other transporters. This prompted an investigation into brain P-glycoprotein (Pgp) expression, a primary drug efflux transporter at the BBB, in TR(-) rats compared to non-mutant Wistar rats. Methods involved immunohistochemical assessment of MRP2 and Pgp expression in brain and liver sections of TR(-) and normal Wistar rats, employing a novel, highly selective MRP2 antibody and the C219 Pgp antibody. Results showed robust immunofluorescence labeling of brain microvessels by the MRP2 antibody in normal Wistar rats, entirely absent in TR(-) rats. Notably, TR(-) rats exhibited significant Pgp upregulation within brain capillary endothelial cells relative to wild-type controls. No comparable Pgp upregulation was evident in liver sections. Intriguingly, similar Pgp overexpression in the BBB was observed following pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats. Experiments involving systemic administration of the Pgp substrate phenobarbital and the selective Pgp inhibitor tariquidar in TR(-) rats corroborated Pgp's functional capacity and its compensatory role for the absence of MRP2 in the BBB. In conclusion, these data indicate that Pgp assumes a critical role in compensating for MRP2 deficiency within the BBB. Given that such a compensatory mechanism likely aims to mitigate cerebral injury from cytotoxic compounds, these findings support the notion of MRP2's protective function in the BBB. Furthermore, our results suggest that TR(-) rats offer an intriguing model for exploring the consequences of BBB Pgp overexpression on drug access to the brain, without the necessity of inducing seizures or other Pgp-enhancing stimuli.

P-glycoprotein Compensatory Upregulation in MRP2-Null Rat Brain Mimics Seizure-Associated Induction. The multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2), a drug efflux transporter primarily expressed in the apical domain of hepatocytes and putatively at the apical membrane of brain capillary endothelial cells constituting the blood-brain barrier (BBB), is absent in the transport-deficient (TR(-)) Wistar rat mutant. This animal model has proven valuable for elucidating MRP2 substrates by contrasting tissue concentrations or functional activities in MRP2-deficient rats with those in transport-competent counterparts. Our previous work, employing this strategy, identified phenytoin as a BBB MRP2 substrate. However, a recognized limitation in genetically deficient models is the potential for compensatory upregulation of other transporters. Consequently, we investigated brain P-glycoprotein (Pgp) expression, a major drug efflux transporter in the BBB, in TR(-) rats relative to nonmutant Wistar rats. Immunohistochemistry was utilized to assess MRP2 and Pgp expression in brain and liver sections of both TR(-) and normal Wistar rats, employing a novel, highly selective MRP2 antibody and the C219 Pgp antibody. Immunofluorescence staining revealed abundant MRP2 labeling of cerebral microvessels in normal Wistar rats, a finding entirely absent in TR(-) rats. Critically, TR(-) rats exhibited a significant upregulation of Pgp in brain capillary endothelial cells compared to wild-type controls, with no comparable Pgp upregulation observed in liver sections. A similar degree of Pgp overexpression in the BBB was attained following pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats. Experiments involving systemic administration of the Pgp substrate phenobarbital and the selective Pgp inhibitor tariquidar in TR(-) rats provided evidence that Pgp is functional and acts to compensate for the absence of MRP2 in the BBB. These data collectively underscore Pgp's substantial role in compensating for MRP2 deficiency within the BBB. Given that such compensation likely mitigates cerebral injury from cytotoxic compounds, these findings support the concept of MRP2's protective role in the BBB. Furthermore, our data suggest that TR(-) rats offer a compelling tool for investigating the implications of Pgp overexpression in the BBB on drug access to the brain, without recourse to seizure induction or other Pgp-modulating events.

Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease Associated with Valproate Treatment. Valproic acid (VPA) is an effective antiepileptic agent, although its administration can lead to increased body weight. We present a case of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in a child who developed obesity during VPA therapy. Laboratory data indicated hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance. Following the discontinuation of VPA, the patient experienced significant weight loss, a reduction in body mass index, and the normalization of metabolic and endocrine markers; moreover, ultrasound imaging demonstrated complete resolution. This case suggests that obesity, hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, and prolonged VPA treatment may collectively contribute to NAFLD development, a condition that is reversible upon VPA cessation.

Development of Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease During Valproic Acid Treatment. Valproic acid (VPA) demonstrates efficacy in various forms of epilepsy, yet its application is linked to a potential increase in body weight. We describe an instance of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) observed in a pediatric patient who became obese during VPA administration. Laboratory assessments revealed hyperinsulinemia accompanied by insulin resistance. Upon cessation of VPA therapy, our patient exhibited considerable weight reduction, a decreased body mass index, and the restoration of normal metabolic and endocrine profiles; furthermore, ultrasonographic findings indicated complete recovery. This case implies a potential link between obesity, hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, and extended VPA treatment in the pathogenesis of NAFLD, highlighting its reversibility after VPA discontinuation.

Occurrence of Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease in Patients Undergoing Valproate Therapy. Investigations showed hyperinsulinemia alongside insulin resistance. Subsequent to the withdrawal of VPA, the patient experienced substantial weight loss, a decline in body mass index, and the return to normal metabolic and endocrine states; in addition, ultrasound measurements confirmed full resolution. The current case indicates that obesity, hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, and long-term VPA exposure could collectively contribute to the onset of NAFLD, a side effect shown to be reversible following VPA cessation.

Clinical laboratory results demonstrated hyperinsulinemia coupled with insulin resistance. Following the termination of VPA therapy, the patient achieved significant weight reduction, a lower body mass index, and normalized metabolic and endocrine parameters; moreover, a complete normalization was observed via ultrasound imaging. This presented case suggests an association between obesity, hyperinsulinemia, insulin resistance, and prolonged VPA treatment in the etiology of NAFLD, further indicating that this adverse effect is reversible upon VPA cessation.

An X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Gene Exhibiting Unexpected Homology with ABC Transporters. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is an X-linked disorder affecting 1 in 20,000 males, manifesting as either childhood cerebral ALD or adult adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN). The childhood form is more severe, with neurological symptoms appearing between 5-12 years and rapid central nervous system demyelination leading to death within a few years. AMN represents a milder variant, presenting at 15-30 years of age with a more gradual progression. Adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) can be the sole clinical sign of ALD. The core biochemical defect in ALD involves the buildup of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) due to defective peroxisomal beta-oxidation. Although VLCFA-CoA oxidation in patient fibroblasts was normal, suggesting the VLCFA-CoA synthetase gene as a potential candidate, this study employed positional cloning to pinpoint a gene partially deleted in 6 out of 85 independent ALD patients. In family studies, these deletions co-segregated with the disease. A shared deletion was observed in two brothers displaying differing ALD clinical phenotypes. Candidate exons were identified via computational genomic sequence analysis, facilitating the isolation of complementary DNAs through exon connection and cDNA library screening. The resultant protein sequence demonstrates substantial sequence identity to a 70K peroxisomal membrane protein, crucial for peroxisome biogenesis and a member of the ATP-binding cassette superfamily of transporters.

Identification of an X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Gene with Unexpected ABC Transporter Homology. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), an X-linked condition, affects approximately 1 in 20,000 males, manifesting either as cerebral ALD in childhood or adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) in adulthood. The pediatric form, cerebral ALD, is more severe, with neurological symptoms typically commencing between ages 5-12, characterized by rapid central nervous system demyelination and subsequent death within a few years. The fundamental biochemical defect in ALD is the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) due to impaired peroxisomal beta-oxidation. Although VLCFA-CoA oxidation was normal in patient fibroblasts, prompting consideration of the VLCFA-CoA synthetase gene as a candidate, we utilized positional cloning to pinpoint a gene partially deleted in 6 of 85 unrelated ALD patients. In instances of familial transmission, these deletions co-segregated with the disease. An identical deletion was also found in two brothers presenting with distinct ALD clinical presentations. Exon candidates were identified through computational analysis of genomic sequences, enabling the isolation of complementary DNAs via exon connection and cDNA library screening. The derived protein sequence exhibits significant identity to a 70 kDa peroxisomal membrane protein, which participates in peroxisome biogenesis and is classified within the ATP-binding cassette superfamily of transporters.

Mitigation of Lithium-Induced Diabetes Insipidus Syndrome by Amiloride: Impact on Tissue Lithium in Rats. This study examined amiloride's influence on polydipsia and polyuria induced by chronic lithium chloride treatment in rats, alongside its effects on lithium concentrations in plasma, brain, kidney, thyroid, and red blood cells. Amiloride administration acutely (6 or 12 hours) and subacutely (3 days) reduced water consumption and urine output. At 6 hours post-amiloride, renal medullary lithium content decreased, while other organs showed no change. By 12 hours, a minor elevation in lithium levels was observed across all tissues. Following 3 days of co-treatment, a notable increase in plasma and tissue lithium was evident, despite a decrease in water intake. Across all experimental conditions, the amelioration of the lithium-induced diabetes insipidus-like syndrome by amiloride correlated with a reduction in the renal medulla-to-blood lithium ratio and an elevation in plasma potassium. The findings suggest that acute amiloride may alleviate polydipsia and polyuria in lithium-treated patients, but extended use could lead to hazardous elevated lithium levels.

Amiloride's Impact on Lithium-Induced Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus and Lithium Distribution in Rat Tissues. The present investigation assessed the effects of amiloride on lithium-induced polydipsia and polyuria, as well as its influence on lithium concentrations within the plasma, brain, kidney, thyroid, and red blood cells of rats receiving chronic LiCl. Amiloride administration resulted in diminished drinking and urine volumes in both acute (6 or 12 hours) and subacute (3 days) experimental settings. Six hours post-amiloride, a decrease in lithium content was observed specifically in the renal medulla, unlike other organs examined. After 12 hours, all assayed tissues exhibited a slight elevation in lithium levels. Following 3 days of co-treatment, a significant rise in plasma and tissue lithium concentrations coincided with a reduction in water consumption. Consistently across all experiments, the alleviation of the lithium-induced diabetes insipidus-like syndrome by amiloride was linked to a decreased ratio of renal medulla lithium to blood lithium and an increase in plasma potassium. It is concluded that while acute amiloride might provide relief for polydipsia and polyuria in lithium-treated patients, extended supplementation could lead to dangerously elevated lithium levels.

Amiloride's Efficacy in Counteracting Lithium-Induced Diabetes Insipidus-like Syndrome and Its Effects on Lithium Pharmacokinetics in Rats. This study investigated amiloride's influence on the lithium-induced polydipsia and polyuria, and concurrently, on lithium concentrations in the plasma, brain, kidney, thyroid, and red blood cells of rats chronically treated with LiCl. Amiloride effectively reduced water intake and urine volume in acute (6 or 12 hours) and subacute (3 days) experiments. Six hours after amiloride administration, a decrease in lithium content was noted specifically in the renal medulla, but not in other tissues. By 12 hours, a minor increment in lithium levels was detected across all examined tissues. After 3 days of concurrent administration, a substantial elevation in plasma and tissue lithium concentrations was observed, accompanying the reduction in water consumption. In all experimental phases, the amelioration of the lithium-induced diabetes insipidus-like syndrome by amiloride was associated with a diminished ratio of renal medullary lithium to blood lithium and an increase in plasma potassium. These findings suggest that acute amiloride administration could alleviate symptoms in lithium-treated patients suffering from polydipsia and polyuria, but prolonged use carries the risk of elevated and potentially hazardous lithium levels.

Amiloride-Mediated Attenuation of Lithium Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus and its Impact on Lithium Tissue Levels in Rats. The current research explored the impact of amiloride on lithium-induced polydipsia and polyuria, alongside its effects on lithium concentrations in the plasma, brain, kidney, thyroid, and red blood cells of rats previously administered LiCl. Amiloride demonstrably decreased both drinking and urine volumes in short-term (6 or 12 hours) and medium-term (3 days) experiments. An initial reduction in renal medullary lithium content was observed 6 hours after amiloride, a change not mirrored in other organs. However, at 12 hours, all tissues showed a slight rise in lithium levels. Subsequent to 3 days of combined treatment, a significant increase in plasma and tissue lithium concentrations was noted, which coincided with the observed decrease in water intake. Across all experimental conditions, the attenuation of the lithium-induced diabetes insipidus-like syndrome by amiloride correlated with a lower ratio of lithium concentration in the renal medulla to that in the blood, and an elevation in plasma potassium. Consequently, acute amiloride administration may offer symptomatic relief for lithium-treated patients experiencing polydipsia and polyuria, but sustained use risks dangerously elevated lithium levels.

Evaluation of Parasympathetic and Sympathetic Neurogenic Mechanisms in Rat Cyclophosphamide-Induced Cystitis. In cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in rats, impaired detrusor function and altered muscarinic receptor expression and effects are known. This study aimed to ascertain whether neuronal transmission is also affected by cystitis. Responses of urinary strip preparations from control and cyclophosphamide-pretreated rats to electrical field stimulation and various agonists were examined in the presence and absence of muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptor antagonists. Generally, atropine diminished contractions, but notably, it also reduced responses to low-intensity electrical field stimulation (1-5 Hz) in inflamed preparations, a contrast to controls. In both types of preparations, purinoceptor desensitization with alpha,beta-methylene adenosine-5'-triphosphate (alpha,beta-meATP) led to further reductions at low frequencies (<10 Hz). Muscarinic receptor antagonists, including atropine, 4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine (4-DAMP) ('M(1)/M(3)/M(5)-selective'), methoctramine ('M(2)-selective'), and pirenzepine ('M(1)-selective'), antagonized the tonic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contractile response more effectively than the phasic component. 4-DAMP inhibited tonic contractions in controls more potently than methoctramine and pirenzepine. In inflamed preparations, the muscarinic receptor antagonism on the phasic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contraction was diminished, and the antagonism by pirenzepine and 4-DAMP on the tonic component was substantially less efficient than in controls. Conversely, methoctramine augmented  rather than decreased  the tonic responses at high frequencies in inflamed tissues. While contractions to carbachol and ATP were equivalent in inflamed and control strips when normalized to a reference potassium response, isoprenaline-induced relaxations were smaller in inflamed strips. Consequently, in cystitis, substantial changes in efferent functional responses are evident. Postjunctional beta-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxations are reduced, and effects mediated by prejunctional inhibitory muscarinic receptors may be enhanced.

In Vitro Assessment of Autonomic Regulation in Rat Bladder Dysfunction Induced by Cyclophosphamide. Cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in the rat is characterized by detrusor dysfunction and modified muscarinic receptor expression and effects. The current investigation explored whether neuronal transmission might be impacted by this cystitis. Responses of urinary bladder strip preparations from control and cyclophosphamide-exposed rats to electrical field stimulation and various agonists were measured with and without muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptor antagonists. Atropine consistently reduced contractions, but distinctively from controls, it also lessened responses to low electrical field stimulation intensity (1-5 Hz) in the inflamed samples. Desensitization of purinoceptors using alpha,beta-methylene adenosine-5'-triphosphate (alpha,beta-meATP) further decreased responses at frequencies below 10 Hz in both sets of preparations. Muscarinic receptor antagonists  atropine, 4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine (4-DAMP) ('M(1)/M(3)/M(5)-selective'), methoctramine ('M(2)-selective'), and pirenzepine ('M(1)-selective')  demonstrated greater antagonism of the tonic component of electrical field stimulation-evoked contractile responses compared to the phasic component. Specifically, 4-DAMP showed stronger inhibition of tonic contractions in controls than methoctramine and pirenzepine. In inflamed preparations, the muscarinic receptor antagonism on the phasic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contraction was reduced, and the efficacy of pirenzepine and 4-DAMP antagonism on the tonic component was markedly lower than observed in controls. Moreover, in inflamed preparations, methoctramine led to an increase, rather than a decrease, in tonic responses at high frequencies. Contractions induced by carbachol and ATP were similar in inflamed and control strips when scaled against a potassium reference, but isoprenaline-induced relaxations were attenuated in inflamed strips. Therefore, cystitis precipitates significant alterations in efferent functional responses, including diminished postjunctional beta-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxations and potentially augmented effects from prejunctional inhibitory muscarinic receptors.

An In Vitro Investigation of Neuroeffector Function in Cyclophosphamide-Induced Rat Cystitis. In rats afflicted with cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis, detrusor function is compromised, and the expression and actions of muscarinic receptors are altered. This research sought to determine if the neuronal transmission pathway is similarly affected by the presence of cystitis. Urinary strip preparations obtained from control animals and rats pretreated with cyclophosphamide underwent assessment of their responses to electrical field stimulation and specific agonists, in the absence and presence of muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptor blocking agents. Generally, atropine mitigated contractions, but uncharacteristically for controls, it also attenuated responses to low electrical field stimulation intensities (1-5 Hz) in the inflamed preparations. Desensitization of purinoceptors using alpha,beta-methylene adenosine-5'-triphosphate (alpha,beta-meATP) caused additional reductions at frequencies less than 10 Hz in both preparation types. Muscarinic receptor antagonists (atropine, 4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine (4-DAMP) ('M(1)/M(3)/M(5)-selective'), methoctramine ('M(2)-selective'), and pirenzepine ('M(1)-selective')) antagonized the tonic element of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contractile response more potently than the phasic element. 4-DAMP exhibited greater potency in inhibiting tonic contractions in control tissues compared to methoctramine and pirenzepine. In inflamed preparations, the muscarinic receptor antagonism on the phasic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contraction was diminished, and the inhibitory effect of pirenzepine and 4-DAMP on the tonic component was considerably less effective than in control groups. In a contrasting finding to controls, methoctramine elevated  instead of reduced  the tonic responses at high frequencies. While carbachol and ATP-induced contractions were comparable in inflamed and control strips when expressed relative to a reference potassium response, isoprenaline-induced relaxations were reduced in inflamed strips. Thus, cystitis leads to significant modifications of efferent functional responses, characterized by reduced postjunctional beta-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxations and a potential increase in prejunctional inhibitory muscarinic receptor effects.

In Vitro Analysis of Autonomic Neuromodulation in Rat Bladder with Cyclophosphamide-Induced Cystitis. Cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in rats is associated with impaired detrusor function and alterations in muscarinic receptor expression and their effects. The current study investigated whether neuronal transmission itself might be influenced by cystitis. Responses of urinary strip preparations from both control and cyclophosphamide-pretreated rats were analyzed following electrical field stimulation and exposure to agonists, both with and without the presence of muscarinic, adrenergic, and purinergic receptor antagonists. Atropine generally decreased contractions, but notably, in inflamed preparations, it also attenuated responses to low-intensity electrical field stimulation (1-5 Hz), differing from observations in controls. In both control and inflamed tissues, purinoceptor desensitization achieved with alpha,beta-methylene adenosine-5'-triphosphate (alpha,beta-meATP) resulted in further reductions at low frequencies (<10 Hz). The muscarinic receptor antagonists, specifically atropine, 4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine (4-DAMP) ('M(1)/M(3)/M(5)-selective'), methoctramine ('M(2)-selective'), and pirenzepine ('M(1)-selective'), antagonized the tonic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contractile response more profoundly than the phasic component. 4-DAMP demonstrated superior potency in inhibiting tonic contractions in control strips when compared to methoctramine and pirenzepine. However, in inflamed preparations, the muscarinic receptor antagonism on the phasic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contraction was diminished, and the antagonism by pirenzepine and 4-DAMP on the tonic component was considerably less effective than in controls. Furthermore, methoctramine, contrary to its action in controls, increased tonic responses at high frequencies in inflamed tissues. While contractions induced by carbachol and ATP were found to be similar in inflamed and control strips when referenced to a potassium response, isoprenaline-induced relaxations were reduced in inflamed strips. In conclusion, cystitis is characterized by substantial changes in efferent functional responses, including reduced postjunctional beta-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxations and a potential augmentation of prejunctional inhibitory muscarinic receptor effects.

Peripheral Mechanism of L-Dopa in Reversing Ammonia Coma in Rats. Ammonia-induced coma was induced in rats through an intraperitoneal administration of 1.7 mmol NH4CL, manifesting within 10 to 15 minutes. This comatose state was prevented by prior gastric intubation of 1.68 mmol L-dopa, administered 15 minutes before the ammonium salt injection. The prophylactic effect of L-dopa was associated with simultaneous reductions in both blood and brain ammonia levels, an elevation in brain dopamine concentrations, and an increased renal excretion of ammonia and urea. Crucially, intraventricular dopamine infusion, even when sufficient to achieve comparable brain dopamine increases, failed to prevent the ammonia coma and did not alter blood or brain ammonia levels. Furthermore, bilateral nephrectomy negated the beneficial impact of L-dopa on blood and brain ammonia, thereby failing to prevent the ammonia coma. These findings demonstrate that the observed decrease in blood and brain ammonia, and the prevention of ammonia coma following L-dopa administration, are attributable to dopamine's peripheral influence on renal function, rather than its central nervous system activity. Such results offer a plausible explanation for the therapeutic benefits noted in some encephalopathic patients treated with L-dopa.

L-Dopa's Peripheral Renal Action in Preventing Ammonia Coma in a Rodent Model. The induction of ammonia coma in rats occurred 10 to 15 minutes post-intraperitoneal injection of 1.7 mmol NH4CL. This coma was successfully averted by administering 1.68 mmol L-dopa via gastric intubation 15 minutes prior to the ammonium salt. The efficacy of L-dopa correlated with a reduction in both blood and brain ammonia, an increase in brain dopamine, and enhanced renal excretion of ammonia and urea. To discern the mechanism, an intraventricular infusion of dopamine, which increased brain dopamine to a similar degree, did not prevent the ammonia coma or influence blood and brain ammonia concentrations. Moreover, bilateral nephrectomy abolished the advantageous effect of L-dopa on blood and brain ammonia, consequently failing to prevent ammonia coma. These observations establish that the decrease in blood and brain ammonia, along with the prevention of ammonia coma by L-dopa, is explainable by the peripheral impact of dopamine on kidney function, rather than its central effects. This provides a compelling rationale for the observed positive outcomes in certain encephalopathic patients receiving L-dopa therapy.

Demonstration of a Peripheral Mechanism for L-Dopa's Attenuation of Ammonia Coma in Rats. Ammonia coma was generated in rats within 10 to 15 minutes following an intraperitoneal injection of 1.7 mmol NH4CL. Pre-treatment with 1.68 mmol L-dopa, delivered by gastric intubation 15 minutes prior to the ammonium salt, prevented the onset of this coma. The protective action of L-dopa was linked to a concomitant decrease in blood and brain ammonia, an elevation in brain dopamine, and an augmented renal excretion of both ammonia and urea. To clarify the locus of action, intraventricular infusion of dopamine, despite raising brain dopamine levels to an equivalent extent, failed to prevent ammonia coma and did not influence blood or brain ammonia concentrations. Furthermore, bilateral nephrectomy eliminated L-dopa's beneficial influence on blood and brain ammonia, thereby failing to prevent the ammonia coma. These findings conclusively indicate that the reduction in blood and brain ammonia, and the prevention of ammonia coma following L-dopa administration, are attributable to the peripheral effects of dopamine on kidney function rather than its central activity. This offers a rational basis for the therapeutic benefits observed in some encephalopathic patients receiving L-dopa.

Renal-Dependent Prevention of Ammonia Coma by L-Dopa in a Rat Model. In rats, an intraperitoneal injection of 1.7 mmol NH4CL consistently induced ammonia coma within 10 to 15 minutes. This comatose state was successfully prevented by orally administering 1.68 mmol L-dopa via gastric intubation 15 minutes before the ammonium salt. The observed efficacy of L-dopa was correlated with a decrease in blood and brain ammonia concentrations, an increase in brain dopamine, and an elevated renal excretion of ammonia and urea. Further investigation revealed that intraventricular infusion of dopamine, sufficient to match the increase in brain dopamine, did not prevent ammonia coma nor did it affect blood and brain ammonia levels. Significantly, bilateral nephrectomy abolished the protective effect of L-dopa on blood and brain ammonia, and consequently, the ammonia coma was not prevented. Therefore, the reduction in blood and brain ammonia and the prevention of ammonia coma subsequent to L-dopa administration are explained by the peripheral action of dopamine on renal function, rather than through its central effects. These findings provide a compelling explanation for the beneficial clinical outcomes seen in some encephalopathic patients treated with L-dopa.

Adrenomyeloneuropathy Phenotype Prevalence in 30 Dutch X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Kindreds. X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) is an inherited peroxisomal beta-oxidation disorder, leading to saturated very long-chain fatty acid accumulation and subsequent central/peripheral demyelination, alongside adrenal cortex and testicular dysfunction. Its phenotypic presentation varies considerably, with childhood cerebral ALD (CCALD) and adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) as primary forms. We investigated 30 Dutch kindreds, identified by the Dutch X-ALD/AMN Study Group, characterizing 77 male patients. Of these, 35 (46%) presented with AMN, while 24 (31%) had CCALD or adolescent cerebral ALD (AdolCALD). These observed proportions diverge significantly from earlier studies, which reported AMN in 25-28% and CCALD or AdolCALD in 53-57% of patients. Our data suggest that AMN could be the predominant X-ALD phenotype within the Netherlands.

X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Phenotypic Manifestations in 30 Dutch Kindreds: High Prevalence of Adrenomyeloneuropathy. X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD), an inherited condition characterized by defective peroxisomal beta-oxidation, causes the accumulation of saturated very long-chain fatty acids, resulting in both central and peripheral demyelination, and adrenal cortex and testicular impairment. The disease exhibits substantial phenotypic variability, with childhood cerebral ALD (CCALD) and adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) being the principal variants. This study examined 30 Dutch kindreds, well-known to the Dutch X-ALD/AMN Study Group, and identified phenotypes in 77 male patients. A total of 35 (46%) were diagnosed with AMN, and 24 (31%) with CCALD or adolescent cerebral ALD (AdolCALD). These percentages represent a significant departure from previously documented figures, where AMN occurred in 25-28% and CCALD or AdolCALD in 53-57% of patients. Our findings strongly suggest that AMN represents the most common X-ALD phenotype, at least within the Dutch population.

Adrenomyeloneuropathy as the Most Frequent X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Phenotype in 30 Dutch Kindreds. X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) is an inherited disorder rooted in dysfunctional peroxisomal beta-oxidation, leading to the buildup of saturated very long-chain fatty acids. This accumulation damages the central and peripheral nervous systems through demyelination and compromises adrenal cortex and testicular function. The disease spectrum is highly diverse, with childhood cerebral ALD (CCALD) and adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) being key presentations. Our research involved phenotyping 77 male patients from 30 Dutch kindreds known to the Dutch X-ALD/AMN Study Group. The analysis revealed that 35 patients (46%) exhibited AMN, while 24 (31%) presented with CCALD or adolescent cerebral ALD (AdolCALD). These proportions significantly diverge from prior reports that indicated AMN in 25-28% and CCALD or AdolCALD in 53-57% of patients. The results from our study suggest that AMN may constitute the most prevalent X-ALD phenotype, specifically within the Netherlands.

X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy Phenotype Characterization in 30 Dutch Kindreds: Adrenomyeloneuropathy's Elevated Frequency. X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD) represents an inherited metabolic disease, originating from impaired peroxisomal beta-oxidation and causing the aggregation of saturated very long-chain fatty acids. This biochemical defect leads to central and peripheral demyelination, coupled with dysfunction of the adrenal cortex and testes. The clinical expression of X-ALD is notably variable, with childhood cerebral ALD (CCALD) and adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN) representing the primary manifestations. We undertook a study of 30 Dutch kindreds, affiliated with the Dutch X-ALD/AMN Study Group, to phenotype 77 male patients. Our findings indicated that 35 individuals (46%) displayed the AMN phenotype, whereas 24 (31%) exhibited CCALD or adolescent cerebral ALD (AdolCALD). These percentages significantly contrast with figures from earlier publications, which typically reported AMN in 25-28% of patients and CCALD or AdolCALD in 53-57%. Based on our observations, it appears that AMN could be the most common phenotype of X-ALD, particularly within the Dutch population.

A Kinetic Variant of Phenylketonuria Arising from a 3-Base Pair In-Frame Deletion in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene. Phenylketonuria (PKU), an autosomal recessive disorder, stems from a deficiency in the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). While a complete absence of PAH activity leads to classic PKU, residual enzyme function can result in variant disease forms. This report details a mild PKU variant linked to a 3-base pair in-frame deletion (delta 194) within the PAH gene, which causes a significantly reduced enzyme affinity for phenylalanine (Km = 160 nM). Functional assays confirm that this specific deletion is responsible for the observed mutant phenotype. Given the deletion's localization to the third exon, a region lacking homology with other hydroxylases, it is proposed that exon 3 plays a critical role in determining the enzyme's substrate specificity for phenylalanine. Furthermore, the absence of this deletion in 98 tested PKU patients suggests that this genetic event is likely a recent occurrence, originating on a haplotype 2 gene background within Portugal.

Characterization of a Phenylketonuria Kinetic Variant Caused by a 3-Base Pair In-Frame Deletion in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive condition resulting from insufficient hepatic phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) enzyme activity. The phenotypic spectrum ranges from typical PKU, associated with absent PAH activity, to variant forms exhibiting some residual enzyme function. Our study describes a 3-base pair in-frame deletion (delta 194) in the PAH gene that underlies a mild variant of PKU. This genetic alteration results in a markedly diminished affinity of the enzyme for phenylalanine, quantified by a Km of 160 nM. We present functional evidence establishing the deletion's direct causality for the mutant enzymatic phenotype. The deletion's presence in exon 3, an area without homology to other hydroxylase enzymes, leads us to hypothesize that this exon is integral to the enzyme's specific interaction with phenylalanine. Population screening of 98 PKU patients did not identify this particular deletion, indicating its probable recent emergence on a haplotype 2 gene background in Portugal.

Genetic Basis of a Phenylketonuria Kinetic Variant: A 3-Base Pair In-Frame Deletion in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene. The autosomal recessive disorder Phenylketonuria (PKU) is fundamentally caused by a deficiency of the liver enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). While total absence of PAH activity is characteristic of classical PKU, variant forms of the disease arise when residual enzymatic function persists. Here, we document a mild PKU variant stemming from a 3-base pair in-frame deletion (delta 194) within the PAH gene. This deletion is associated with a pronounced reduction in the enzyme's affinity for phenylalanine, with a Km value of 160 nM. We provide rigorous functional validation demonstrating that this specific deletion is responsible for the observed mutant enzymatic characteristics. The deletion's location within the third exon, which exhibits no sequence homology with other hydroxylases, suggests exon 3's involvement in the enzyme's substrate specificity for phenylalanine. An analysis of 98 PKU patients revealed no other instances of this specific deletion, implying a recent molecular origin on a haplotype 2 gene background in Portugal.

The Role of a 3-Base Pair In-Frame Deletion in the Phenylalanine Hydroxylase Gene in a Kinetic Phenylketonuria Variant. Phenylketonuria (PKU), an autosomal recessive disease, arises from impaired activity of the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH). The disease presents as typical PKU when PAH activity is absent, or as variant forms when some residual enzyme function is present. We report the discovery of a 3-base pair in-frame deletion (delta 194) in the PAH gene, found in a mild PKU variant. This specific genetic alteration results in a significantly reduced affinity of the enzyme for phenylalanine, evidenced by a Km of 160 nM. Functional studies conclusively demonstrate the deletion's causative role in the observed mutant phenotype. Considering that this deletion is situated in the third exon of the gene, an area distinct from other hydroxylases, we propose that exon 3 is crucial for the enzyme's specificity towards phenylalanine. Furthermore, screening 98 PKU patients revealed no other carriers of this deletion, suggesting its recent occurrence on a haplotype 2 gene within the Portuguese population.

Investigating Angiogenesis as a Therapeutic Target for Ribavirin-Induced Hemolytic Anemia. BACKGROUND/AIMS: Ribavirin has recently been identified as an angiogenesis inhibitor, and several known angiogenesis inhibitors, such as sunitinib and sorafenib, are associated with acute hemolysis. Our objective was to explore a potential association among hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and soluble angiogenesis markers, which could represent modifiable factors for developing anti-anemia strategies. METHODS: A cohort of fourteen patients with chronic hepatitis C virus infection received treatment with pegylated interferon alpha 2a and ribavirin. Serum levels of hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and the angiogenesis markers vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and angiopoietin-2 were assessed both pre- and post-treatment. RESULTS: A statistically significant reduction in haptoglobin levels was observed by the conclusion of the treatment period. Hemoglobin levels also declined, though this decrease was not statistically significant. Contrary to existing literature, serum levels of the angiogenesis factors did not change significantly following pegylated interferon and ribavirin therapy. Furthermore, no correlation was identified between angiogenesis soluble markers and either hemoglobin or haptoglobin. CONCLUSION: This study represents the initial investigation into a connection between soluble angiogenesis markers and ribavirin-induced anemia in individuals with hepatitis C, revealing no discernible relationship. Future studies involving a larger patient population are necessary to identify modifiable elements that could enhance the safety profile of ribavirin treatment.

The Therapeutic Potential of Angiogenesis in Ribavirin-Associated Hemolytic Anemia. BACKGROUND/AIMS: Recent observations indicate that ribavirin possesses angiogenesis-inhibiting properties, and various angiogenesis inhibitors, including sunitinib and sorafenib, are known to induce acute hemolysis. Our study aimed to determine if a relationship exists between hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and soluble angiogenesis markers, as these are potentially modifiable and could inform strategies to mitigate anemia. METHODS: Fourteen individuals with chronic hepatitis C virus infection were administered pegylated interferon alpha 2a in conjunction with ribavirin. Measurements of serum hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and the angiogenesis markers vascular endothelial growth factor and angiopoietin-2 were performed before and after the therapeutic regimen. RESULTS: A significant reduction in haptoglobin levels was recorded by the end of the treatment course. Hemoglobin concentrations also decreased, but this change was not statistically significant. In contrast to reports in the literature, no significant alteration in serum angiogenesis factor levels was detected following pegylated interferon and ribavirin therapy. Moreover, no correlation was found between the soluble angiogenesis markers and either hemoglobin or haptoglobin. CONCLUSION: As the first study exploring a link between soluble angiogenesis markers and ribavirin-induced anemia in hepatitis C patients, we found no evidence of such a relationship. Further research with an expanded patient cohort is essential to identify modifiable factors that could enhance the safety of ribavirin therapy.

Angiogenesis as a Potential Intervention Target for Ribavirin-Induced Hemolytic Anemia. BACKGROUND/AIMS: Ribavirin has recently been shown to inhibit angiogenesis, and several angiogenesis inhibitors, such as sunitinib and sorafenib, are known to precipitate acute hemolysis. Our objective was to investigate the relationship among hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and soluble angiogenesis markers, given their potential as modifiable factors in developing strategies against anemia. METHODS: Fourteen patients with chronic hepatitis C virus infection underwent treatment involving pegylated interferon alpha 2a and ribavirin. Serum concentrations of hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and the angiogenesis markers vascular endothelial growth factor and angiopoietin-2 were measured both prior to and following treatment. RESULTS: A significant decline in haptoglobin levels was observed upon completion of the treatment period. Hemoglobin levels also demonstrated a decrease, although this was not statistically significant. Contrary to findings in published literature, no significant change in serum levels of angiogenesis factors was noted with pegylated interferon and ribavirin therapy. Furthermore, no correlation was identified between angiogenesis soluble markers and either hemoglobin or haptoglobin. CONCLUSION: This pioneering study in the literature examined a potential link between soluble angiogenesis markers and ribavirin-induced anemia in patients with hepatitis C, ultimately finding no such association. Subsequent research involving a greater number of patients is necessary to pinpoint modifiable factors that could improve the safety profile of ribavirin therapy.

Assessing Angiogenesis as a Treatment Strategy for Ribavirin-Associated Hemolytic Anemia. BACKGROUND/AIMS: Ribavirin has recently been identified as an angiogenesis inhibitor, and several angiogenesis inhibitors like sunitinib and sorafenib are known to cause acute hemolysis. This study aimed to explore a potential link between hemoglobin, haptoglobin, and soluble angiogenesis markers, which are considered modifiable and could contribute to strategies combating anemia. METHODS: Fourteen patients diagnosed with chronic hepatitis C virus infection received therapy combining pegylated interferon alpha 2a and ribavirin. Serum levels of hemoglobin, haptoglobin, vascular endothelial growth factor, and angiopoietin-2 were analyzed both before and after the treatment course. RESULTS: A significant decrease in haptoglobin levels was recorded at the culmination of the treatment period. Hemoglobin levels also decreased, though this change was not statistically significant. Contrary to expectations from existing literature, serum concentrations of angiogenesis factors did not significantly alter with pegylated interferon and ribavirin therapy. Furthermore, no correlation was established between the soluble angiogenesis markers and either hemoglobin or haptoglobin. CONCLUSION: This represents the initial investigation in the scientific literature into a connection between soluble angiogenesis markers and ribavirin-induced anemia in hepatitis C patients, and we observed no such relationship. Future investigations with larger patient cohorts are warranted to identify modifiable factors that could enhance the safety of ribavirin treatment.

Characterization of ALD Gene Mutations in Twenty Families Affected by Adrenoleukodystrophy/Adrenomyeloneuropathy. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), an X-linked inherited metabolic condition, represents the most prevalent congenital peroxisomal disorder. It results in demyelination within both the central and peripheral nervous systems. Impaired beta-oxidation of saturated very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs; C22:0-C26:0) in peroxisomes is known to cause VLCFA accumulation in the central nervous system's leukoid regions, peripheral nerves, adrenal glands, and blood. The ALD gene, which encodes a 745-amino-acid protein, was recently discovered. We screened for ALD gene mutations in patients with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy (ALD/AMN) from 20 kindreds. Direct sequencing of eight reverse-transcribed ALD-gene mRNA fragments revealed eleven missense, two nonsense, five deletion, and one insertion mutation. Four of these mutations were identified as de novo. Confirmation of all mutations in carriers was achieved through genomic DNA sequencing. No correlation was observed between the mutation type and the phenotype's severity. These mutations were absent in the ALD gene of 30 healthy individuals.

Mutational Analysis of the ALD Gene in Twenty Kindreds with Adrenoleukodystrophy/Adrenomyeloneuropathy. As the most common inborn peroxisomal disease, X-linked inherited metabolic disorder adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) induces demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems. The defective peroxisomal beta-oxidation of saturated very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs; C22:0-C26:0) leads to their accumulation in the central nervous system's white matter, peripheral nerves, the adrenal gland, and circulating blood. The ALD gene, encoding a 745-amino-acid protein, has been recently identified. In this study, patients diagnosed with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy (ALD/AMN) from 20 families underwent screening for ALD gene mutations. Direct sequencing of eight fragments derived from reverse-transcribed ALD-gene mRNA identified eleven missense mutations, two nonsense mutations, five deletions, and one insertion. Four mutations were determined to be de novo events. Genomic DNA sequencing subsequently confirmed all identified mutations in carriers. No association was found between the specific mutation type and the observed severity of the phenotype. Importantly, these mutations were not detected in the ALD gene among 30 healthy controls.

Genetic Evaluation of ALD Gene Mutations in Twenty Adrenoleukodystrophy/Adrenomyeloneuropathy Families. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), an X-linked inherited metabolic disorder, is recognized as the most frequent congenital peroxisomal disease. This condition manifests as demyelination in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. Deficiencies in the peroxisomal beta-oxidation of saturated very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs; C22:0-C26:0) are known to result in VLCFA accumulation in CNS leukoid areas, peripheral nerves, adrenal glands, and the bloodstream. The ALD gene, coding for a 745-amino-acid protein, has been recently characterized. Our research involved screening 20 kindreds with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy (ALD/AMN) for mutations within the ALD gene. Through direct sequencing of eight reverse-transcribed ALD-gene mRNA fragments, we uncovered eleven missense, two nonsense, five deletion, and one insertion mutation. Four of these mutations were demonstrated to be de novo. Subsequent sequencing of genomic DNA confirmed all mutations in carriers. Crucially, no correlation was observed between the specific mutation type and the clinical phenotype's severity. These identified mutations were absent from the ALD gene of 30 healthy individuals.

Molecular Characterization of ALD Gene Variants in Twenty Adrenoleukodystrophy/Adrenomyeloneuropathy Kinreds. Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), an X-linked metabolic disorder with hereditary origins, constitutes the predominant inborn peroxisomal disease. Its pathology involves demyelination affecting both the central and peripheral nervous systems. The impaired beta-oxidation of saturated very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs; C22:0-C26:0) within peroxisomes is established as the cause of VLCFA accumulation in white matter regions of the central nervous system, peripheral nerves, the adrenal gland, and blood. The ALD gene, which specifies a 745-amino-acid protein, was recently identified. We undertook a screening of the ALD gene for mutations in patients with adrenoleukodystrophy/adrenomyeloneuropathy (ALD/AMN) originating from 20 families. Using direct sequencing of eight reverse-transcribed ALD-gene mRNA fragments, we detected eleven missense, two nonsense, five deletion, and one insertion mutation. Four of these mutations were demonstrably de novo occurrences. Each mutation's presence was validated in carriers via genomic DNA sequencing. Importantly, no relationship between the mutation's specific type and the severity of the phenotype was discernible. Furthermore, these mutations were not found within the ALD gene of 30 healthy individuals.

Optimal Ribavirin Dose Reduction Timing for Hemolysis in Chronic Hepatitis C Combination Therapy. BACKGROUND: Hemolytic anemia represents a significant adverse effect of interferon and ribavirin combination therapy. Ribavirin-induced hemolysis often necessitates dose reduction. This retrospective cohort study aimed to determine the most appropriate timing for ribavirin reduction in patients experiencing hemolysis during combination therapy. METHODS: Of 160 patients receiving 24-week combination therapy for HCV-genotype 1b with high viral load, 37 developed anemia (hemoglobin <10 g/dl or associated symptoms). These 37 patients subsequently had their ribavirin dose reduced by one 200 mg tablet daily. Following this reduction, 27 patients (Group A) completed the full 24-week course, while 10 patients (Group B) discontinued due to hemoglobin levels falling below 8.5 g/dl or severe anemia-related adverse events. We evaluated the ultimate efficacy and safety in both groups post-reduction. RESULTS: The sustained virological response (SVR) rate was 29.6% (8/27) in Group A and 10% (1/10) in Group B. The combined SVR and biological response rate of 34.4% (12/27) in Group A was marginally higher than 10% (1/10) in Group B (P = 0.051). Furthermore, the rate of therapy continuation was significantly higher in patients with a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dl at the time of ribavirin reduction compared to those with <10 g/dl (P = 0.036). CONCLUSIONS: Reducing ribavirin when hemoglobin levels are 10 g/dl is recommended, considering both efficacy and safety outcomes.

Timing of Ribavirin Dose Modulation in Hemolytic Chronic Hepatitis C Patients Under Combination Therapy. BACKGROUND: Hemolytic anemia is a primary side effect of interferon and ribavirin combination therapy, frequently leading to ribavirin dose reduction. This retrospective cohort investigation sought to identify the appropriate timing for ribavirin dose reduction in patients experiencing hemolysis during such treatment. METHODS: Among 160 patients with HCV-genotype 1b and high viral load undergoing 24-week combination therapy, 37 developed anemia (hemoglobin <10 g/dl or related symptoms). These 37 patients subsequently received a daily reduction of one 200 mg ribavirin tablet. Post-reduction, 27 patients (Group A) completed the 24-week treatment, whereas 10 patients (Group B) could not continue therapy due to hemoglobin drops below 8.5 g/dl or severe anemia-related effects. Efficacy and safety were assessed in both groups after the ribavirin reduction. RESULTS: Sustained virological response (SVR) was achieved by 29.6% (8/27) in Group A and 10% (1/10) in Group B. The cumulative SVR plus biological response in Group A (34.4%, 12/27) was slightly superior to Group B (10%, 1/10) (P = 0.051). Therapy continuation rates were higher for patients whose hemoglobin was 10 g/dl at the time of reduction, compared to those with <10 g/dl (P = 0.036). CONCLUSIONS: A ribavirin dose reduction when hemoglobin levels are at or above 10 g/dl is advisable for maintaining both efficacy and managing side effects.

Determining the Appropriate Time for Ribavirin Dosage Reduction in Hepatitis C Patients Experiencing Hemolysis During Interferon-Based Therapy. BACKGROUND: Hemolytic anemia stands as a principal adverse event associated with combination therapy involving interferon and ribavirin. This ribavirin-induced hemolysis frequently necessitates a reduction in drug dosage. This clinical retrospective cohort study investigated the optimal moment to decrease ribavirin in patients who developed hemolysis during their combination treatment. METHODS: Out of 160 patients undergoing a 24-week regimen of combination therapy for HCV-genotype 1b with a high viral load, 37 experienced anemia, characterized by hemoglobin levels below 10 g/dl or other anemia-related manifestations. Following this, these 37 patients had their ribavirin dose lowered by one 200 mg tablet daily. Subsequent to the ribavirin reduction, 27 of these 37 patients (designated Group A) were able to persist with the combination therapy for the entire 24 weeks. Conversely, 10 patients (designated Group B) were unable to continue treatment because their hemoglobin levels fell to or below 8.5 g/dl or they suffered severe anemia-related side effects. The study evaluated the ultimate efficacy and safety profiles after ribavirin reduction in both Group A and Group B. RESULTS: A sustained virological response (SVR) was observed in 29.6% (8/27) of Group A and 10% (1/10) of Group B. The combined rate of SVR and biological response in Group A, at 34.4% (12/27), showed a marginal superiority over Group B's 10% (1/10) (P = 0.051). Regarding hemoglobin levels at the time of ribavirin reduction, the proportion of patients continuing therapy was greater for those with 10 g/dl hemoglobin compared to those with <10 g/dl (P = 0.036). CONCLUSIONS: Decreasing the ribavirin dose at a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dl appears appropriate, considering both treatment efficacy and adverse event management.

Ribavirin Dose Modification Timing in Chronic Hepatitis C Patients with Hemolysis During Combination Treatment. BACKGROUND: The combination of interferon and ribavirin frequently induces hemolytic anemia, a significant adverse event that often mandates a reduction in ribavirin dosage. This retrospective clinical cohort study investigated the most opportune time for ribavirin dose reduction in patients developing hemolysis during combination therapy. METHODS: From a cohort of 160 patients receiving 24-week combination therapy for HCV-genotype 1b and high viral load, 37 developed anemia, defined by a hemoglobin level below 10 g/dl or presenting with anemia-related symptoms. For these 37 patients, the daily ribavirin dose was reduced by one 200 mg tablet. Post-reduction, 27 patients (Group A) successfully completed the full 24-week combination therapy course. However, 10 patients (Group B) discontinued therapy due to hemoglobin levels decreasing to <8.5 g/dl or the occurrence of severe anemia-related side effects. The study assessed the final efficacy and safety outcomes in both Group A and Group B after the ribavirin reduction. RESULTS: Sustained virological response (SVR) rates were 29.6% (8/27) in Group A and 10% (1/10) in Group B. Group A exhibited a slightly higher rate of SVR plus biological response, at 34.4% (12/27), compared to Group B's 10% (1/10) (P = 0.051). Patients with a hemoglobin level of 10 g/dl at the point of ribavirin reduction demonstrated a higher rate of therapy continuation than those with <10 g/dl (P = 0.036). CONCLUSIONS: A ribavirin dose reduction when hemoglobin levels are at or above 10 g/dl is deemed appropriate concerning both treatment effectiveness and the management of adverse effects.

Investigation of Chronic Carbamazepine Administration in Rats: Efficacy, Toxicity, and Impact on Plasma and Tissue Folate Levels. Folate deficiency is a frequently observed issue during long-term antiepileptic drug (AED) regimens. Carbamazepine (CBZ), a widely utilized AED, has been linked to this problem in some clinical investigations. A rat model was established to study the consequences of prolonged CBZ therapy on folate concentrations within the animal. During the model's development, it was discovered that propylene glycol, a common vehicle, when administered in high doses independently, demonstrated anticonvulsant properties against induced seizures and suppressed weight gain. Furthermore, seizures provoked by hexafluorodiethyl ether (HFDE) proved to be a more sensitive indicator of CBZ's protective effect compared to seizures induced by maximal electroshock (MES). Oral administration of CBZ as an aqueous suspension at 250 mg/kg every 8 hours offered sustained protection against HFDE-induced seizures and exhibited minimal toxicity, as evidenced by weight gain over an 8-week treatment period. However, the CBZ concentrations measured in the plasma and brain of these animals were lower than what is typically considered protective. This CBZ treatment did not exert any apparent detrimental effect on the rat's folate concentrations; in fact, liver folate levels rose after 6 weeks of treatment, and plasma folate levels increased at 8 weeks.

Evaluation of Chronic Carbamazepine Treatment in Rats: Efficacy, Adverse Effects, and Folate Concentration Changes in Plasma and Tissues. Chronic antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy often presents with folate depletion, a concern that has been associated with carbamazepine (CBZ) in several clinical studies. To investigate the influence of chronic CBZ administration on folate levels in rats, an animal model was developed. An unexpected finding during the model's creation was that the vehicle, propylene glycol, at elevated doses, offered protection against induced seizures and hindered weight gain. It was also determined that hexafluorodiethyl ether (HFDE)-induced seizures provided a more sensitive measure of CBZ's protective capacity than maximal electroshock (MES)-induced seizures. Administering CBZ orally as an aqueous suspension at 250 mg/kg every 8 hours consistently protected against HFDE-induced seizures and showed negligible toxicity, assessed by weight gain over an 8-week duration. Despite this observed protection, CBZ levels in the plasma and brain of treated animals were below concentrations generally deemed therapeutic. Importantly, this specific CBZ regimen did not negatively impact rat folate concentrations; instead, folate levels increased in the liver after 6 weeks and in the plasma by 8 weeks of treatment.
