Mutations within BRCA1 are implicated in at least 80% of families with concurrent breast and ovarian cancer, as well as in some cases of sporadic ovarian cancer not linked to family history. The absence of wild-type BRCA1 in tumors of individuals possessing one nonfunctional BRCA1 allele implies that BRCA1 acts as a tumor suppressor, potentially regulating the proliferation of mammary epithelial cells. To assess BRCA1's involvement in physiological tissue growth and differentiation, and to develop a prospective model for the cancer susceptibility resulting from impaired BRCA1 function, we engineered a mouse line bearing a mutation in one Brca1 allele. Examination of mice homozygous for the mutated allele confirmed Brca1's critical importance for proper development, given that these mice expired during gestation, specifically between embryonic days 10 and 13. Deficiencies in Brca1-null embryos were predominantly observed in the neural tube, where 40% of embryos manifested diverse degrees of spina bifida and anencephaly. Additionally, the neuroepithelium of Brca1-deficient embryos appeared disordered, exhibiting signs indicative of both increased proliferative activity and excessive apoptotic processes.

Consequences of Brca1 Gene Deficiency: Embryonic Demise and Neural Tube Defects. The gene BRCA1, a known susceptibility factor for breast and ovarian cancer, has been successfully cloned and is recognized for encoding a zinc-finger protein with an as-yet-undetermined biological role. Pathogenic variants in BRCA1 account for a substantial proportion, specifically at least 80%, of families presenting with both breast and ovarian cancer, and are also found in a subset of non-familial sporadic ovarian cancers. The observed loss of the functional wild-type BRCA1 allele in tumors from individuals carrying one compromised BRCA1 allele suggests its role as a tumor suppressor, potentially by restricting the proliferation of mammary epithelial cells. To investigate the physiological contribution of BRCA1 to tissue growth and differentiation, and to create a relevant model for the cancer predisposition linked to the absence of BRCA1 function, we engineered a mouse strain with a mutation in one Brca1 allele. Investigations into mice homozygous for this mutant allele revealed that Brca1 is indispensable for normal embryogenesis, as these animals exhibited intrauterine demise between gestational days 10 and 13 (E10-E13). Morphological irregularities in Brca1-deficient embryos were most pronounced within the neural tube, with 40% of embryos demonstrating varying manifestations of spina bifida and anencephaly. Furthermore, the neuroepithelial tissue in Brca1-deficient embryos displayed a disorganized architecture, coupled with evidence of both accelerated cell division and elevated rates of programmed cell death.

Experimental Evidence for Brca1's Essential Role in Embryonic Survival and Neurodevelopment. The BRCA1 gene, identified as a susceptibility factor for breast and ovarian cancer, has been isolated and found to encode a zinc-finger protein whose specific function remains uncharacterized. Mutations in BRCA1 are implicated in over 80% of families affected by both breast and ovarian cancer, as well as in some sporadic cases of ovarian cancer. The observed inactivation of the wild-type BRCA1 allele in tumors of individuals inheriting a nonfunctional BRCA1 allele supports its classification as a tumor suppressor, likely responsible for inhibiting the proliferation of mammary epithelial cells. To explore BRCA1's involvement in normal tissue development and differentiation, and to establish an experimental system for studying cancer susceptibility linked to Brca1 functional loss, a mouse model was generated carrying a specific mutation in one Brca1 allele. Analysis of mice homozygous for this mutant allele demonstrated the critical necessity of Brca1 for proper development, given their demise in utero between embryonic days 10 and 13. The most pronounced abnormalities in Brca1-deficient embryos were located in the neural tube, with 40% exhibiting different degrees of spina bifida and anencephaly. Additionally, the neuroepithelium in these Brca1-deficient embryos displayed a disordered structure, accompanied by indications of both rapid cellular proliferation and increased programmed cell death.

ATM's Critical Involvement in Radiation Response and Cell Cycle Regulation. The ATM gene, mutated in ataxia-telangiectasia, encodes a potential protein or lipid kinase. To clarify its functions, we genetically engineered mice lacking the ATM gene through homologous recombination. Consistent with observed cellular anomalies in AT patients, ATM-deficient cells exhibited heightened sensitivity to gamma-irradiation and impaired cell-cycle arrest following radiation exposure, correlating with deficient p53 up-regulation. Furthermore, ATM-knockout mouse thymocytes demonstrated increased resistance to gamma-irradiation-induced apoptosis compared to wild-type thymocytes. ATM-null fibroblasts showed inefficient G1 to S-phase progression after serum stimulation and underwent senescence after limited passages in culture. These cells also presented elevated constitutive levels of p21CP1/WAF1. These findings establish the ATM protein's crucial role in both cellular reactions to ionizing radiation and in maintaining normal cell-cycle progression. ATM heterozygous fibroblasts and thymocytes displayed partially compromised responses to irradiation but no growth defects, suggesting that the heightened cancer risk in AT heterozygotes might stem from inadequate checkpoint functionality.

Elucidating ATM's Contributions to Radiation Response and Cell Growth Control Mechanisms. Ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) patients carry mutations in the ATM gene, which codes for a putative protein or lipid kinase. Our investigation aimed to delineate ATM's functions by disrupting the ATM gene in mice via homologous recombination. In line with the cellular phenotypes seen in AT patients, ATM-deficient (ATM-/-) cells displayed elevated susceptibility to gamma-irradiation and failed to properly arrest the cell cycle post-radiation, which corresponded with a compromised p53 up-regulation. Additionally, ATM-null mouse thymocytes were more resilient to gamma-irradiation-induced apoptosis than their normal counterparts. ATM-deficient fibroblasts experienced hindered G1 to S-phase transition after serum stimulation and reached senescence after only a few cultural passages. These fibroblasts also exhibited an increased basal level of p21CP1/WAF1. Collectively, these results underscore the ATM protein's indispensable role in both the cellular responses to ionizing radiation and the regulation of normal cell-cycle progression. Interestingly, ATM+/ fibroblasts and thymocytes showed intermediate deficits in their responses to irradiation but no observable growth defects, suggesting that the elevated cancer susceptibility in AT heterozygotes could be linked to suboptimal checkpoint function.

ATM's Integral Role in Radiation Biology and Cell Proliferation Regulation. The ATM gene, known for its mutation in ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) patients, codes for a potential protein or lipid kinase. We explored ATM's functions by inactivating the gene in mice using homologous recombination. Consistent with AT patient cellular characteristics, ATM-null cells were highly sensitive to gamma-irradiation and exhibited impaired cell-cycle arrest after radiation, alongside defective p53 up-regulation. Furthermore, ATM-deficient mouse thymocytes showed greater resistance to gamma-irradiation-induced apoptosis than normal cells. ATM-null fibroblasts demonstrated inefficient G1 to S-phase progression post-serum stimulation and entered senescence after a limited number of passages in culture. They also presented an elevated basal expression of p21CP1/WAF1. Therefore, the ATM protein is crucial for both cellular reactions to ionizing radiation and for orderly cell-cycle progression. ATM+/ fibroblasts and thymocytes exhibited moderately impaired responses to irradiation but no growth anomalies, leading to the hypothesis that increased cancer risk in AT heterozygotes may arise from compromised checkpoint activity.

Uncovering the Dual Function of ATM in Cellular Radiation Response and Cell Cycle Maintenance. The ATM gene, identified as mutated in ataxia-telangiectasia (AT), encodes a presumed protein or lipid kinase. To clarify its roles, we employed homologous recombination to disrupt the ATM gene in mice. Mirroring the cellular abnormalities observed in AT patients, ATM-deficient (ATM-/-) cells displayed heightened sensitivity to gamma-irradiation and a compromised cell-cycle arrest following radiation exposure, which correlated with an impaired up-regulation of p53. Additionally, ATM-knockout mouse thymocytes exhibited enhanced resistance to gamma-irradiation-induced apoptosis compared to wild-type thymocytes. ATM-/- fibroblasts also showed inefficient progression from G1 to S-phase subsequent to serum stimulation and underwent senescence after a restricted number of passages in culture. These fibroblasts also possessed an elevated constitutive level of p21CP1/WAF1. Collectively, these findings confirm the ATM protein's vital importance for both cellular responses to ionizing radiation and the regulation of normal cell-cycle progression. ATM+/ fibroblasts and thymocytes presented with intermediately defective responses to irradiation but without any growth deficiencies, suggesting that the heightened cancer risk associated with AT heterozygotes could be attributed to a suboptimal checkpoint function.

Acute Neurological Toxicity Associated with High-Dose Etoposide for Malignant Glioma. Etoposide (VP-16-213) is employed in managing numerous solid and hematologic malignancies. When administered in elevated doses, particularly with autologous bone marrow transplantation, it exhibits efficacy against several refractory cancers, including malignant glioma. A sudden, severe neurological decline was observed in six out of eight (75%) patients treated for recurrent or resistant glioma. This adverse event manifested at a median of nine days post-initiation of high-dose etoposide therapy. Key clinical signs encompassed confusion, papilledema, somnolence, worsening of motor deficits, and a marked increase in seizure frequency. These anomalies rapidly subsided following the commencement of high-dose intravenous dexamethasone. Brain computerized tomographic (CT) scans consistently showed stable tumor dimensions and peritumoral edema across all patients when contrasted with pre-transplant imaging. This complication represents a notable new toxicity linked to high-dose etoposide treatment for malignant glioma.

A Novel Acute Neurological Syndrome in Malignant Glioma Patients Receiving High-Dose Etoposide. Etoposide (VP-16-213) is a therapeutic agent for various solid tumors and hematologic malignancies. High-dose etoposide, combined with autologous bone marrow transplantation, demonstrates activity against several treatment-refractory cancers, including malignant glioma. Among eight patients receiving treatment for recurrent or resistant glioma, six (75%) experienced abrupt and severe neurological deterioration. This adverse event typically occurred a median of 9 days after high-dose etoposide therapy began. Significant clinical manifestations included confusion, papilledema, drowsiness, aggravated motor deficits, and a substantial increase in seizure activity. These abnormalities resolved swiftly upon starting high-dose intravenous dexamethasone. Computerized tomographic (CT) brain scans in all patients indicated no change in tumor size or peritumoral edema compared to scans taken before transplantation. This outcome appears to constitute a considerable new toxicity of high-dose etoposide therapy when used for malignant glioma.

Neurological Manifestations Observed Post High-Dose Etoposide Administration for Malignant Glioma. Etoposide (VP-16-213) finds application in treating numerous solid tumors and hematologic malignancies. When administered at high doses in conjunction with autologous bone marrow transplantation, this compound demonstrates efficacy against several difficult-to-treat cancers, including malignant glioma. In a cohort of eight patients treated for recurrent or resistant glioma, six (75%) developed sudden, severe neurological impairment. The onset of this deterioration occurred at a median of 9 days following the initiation of high-dose etoposide therapy. Prominent clinical signs involved confusion, papilledema, somnolence, an exacerbation of pre-existing motor deficits, and a sharp escalation in seizure activity. Rapid resolution of these abnormalities was noted after the commencement of high-dose intravenous dexamethasone. All patients' computerized tomographic (CT) brain scans revealed stable tumor size and peritumoral edema, consistent with pre-transplant imaging. This particular complication suggests a significant new adverse effect of high-dose etoposide therapy specifically for malignant glioma.

Onset of Acute Neurological Impairment Following High-Dose Etoposide in Malignant Glioma. Etoposide (VP-16-213) has been widely utilized in the management of various solid and hematologic malignancies. At elevated doses, particularly when coupled with autologous bone marrow transplantation, this agent proves effective against several treatment-resistant cancers, notably malignant glioma. Among eight patients receiving therapy for recurrent or resistant glioma, six individuals (75%) experienced an abrupt and profound neurological decline. This deterioration typically manifested a median of nine days subsequent to the commencement of high-dose etoposide administration. Key clinical features observed included confusion, papilledema, drowsiness, a worsening of motor deficits, and a significant surge in seizure episodes. These abnormal findings rapidly resolved subsequent to the initiation of high-dose intravenous dexamethasone. Computerized tomographic (CT) brain imaging consistently showed tumor size stability and unchanged peritumoral edema in all patients when compared to their pre-transplant scans. This complication appears to represent a considerable and novel toxicity associated with high-dose etoposide treatment for malignant glioma.

Magnetic Resonance Demonstration of Reversible Cerebral Lesions Linked to Tiazofurin Use. Tiazofurin, an experimental chemotherapeutic currently under clinical evaluation, has been associated with reversible cerebral abnormalities. Our magnetic resonance (MR) findings illustrating these changes are presented. These MR abnormalities were correlated with observations from computed tomography (CT) and cerebral angiography, underscoring MR's utility in evaluating patients receiving this novel agent.

Reversible Cerebral Abnormalities Associated with Tiazofurin: An MR Imaging Report. This report details our magnetic resonance (MR) findings concerning reversible cerebral abnormalities observed concurrently with the administration of tiazofurin, an experimental chemotherapeutic agent undergoing clinical assessment. These MR findings were corroborated by computed tomography (CT) and cerebral angiography, highlighting the value of MR in the assessment of patients receiving this new drug.

MR Imaging of Reversible Brain Lesions Following Tiazofurin Administration. Tiazofurin, an investigational chemotherapeutic agent, is currently undergoing clinical trials. We describe our results utilizing magnetic resonance (MR) to identify reversible cerebral abnormalities occurring with the drug's application. The MR abnormalities were cross-referenced with data from CT and cerebral angiography, thereby illustrating MR's significance in the clinical assessment of patients receiving this compound.

Demonstration of Tiazofurin-Related Reversible Cerebral Lesions by Magnetic Resonance. We present our findings from magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, demonstrating reversible cerebral abnormalities that occur with the use of tiazofurin, an experimental chemotherapeutic agent undergoing clinical evaluation. These MR observations were correlated with results from CT scanning and cerebral angiography. This report illustrates the utility of MR in the comprehensive evaluation of patients receiving this new therapeutic agent.

Management of Endometrial Pathologies in Menopausal Women Undergoing Oestrogen Treatment. This study details therapeutic approaches for endometrial pathologies observed in 74 individuals among 850 climacteric women receiving oestrogen therapy. Unopposed oestrogen administration without progestagen was linked to cystic hyperplasia. Daily norethisterone (5 mg) administered for two 21-day cycles achieved normalization in all 57 instances of cystic hyperplasia and 6 out of 8 cases of atypical hyperplasia. Four instances of endometrial carcinoma, referred from other centers, underscored the complications arising from unsuitable and unsupervised unopposed oestrogen therapy, as well as the challenge in differentiating severe hyperplasia from malignancy. Furthermore, cyclical low-dose oestrogen therapy combined with 7 to 13 days of progestagen appears not to elevate the risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Endometrial Disease Management and Prevention Strategies in Climacteric Women Receiving Oestrogen Therapy. A description of treatment strategies is presented for 74 patients diagnosed with endometrial disease within a cohort of 850 climacteric women undergoing oestrogen therapy. An association was found between cystic hyperplasia and unopposed oestrogen therapy, specifically in the absence of progestagen. The administration of 5 mg norethisterone daily over two 21-day periods resulted in the resolution of all 57 cystic hyperplasia cases and 6 of the 8 atypical hyperplasia cases. Insights from 4 cases of endometrial carcinoma, referred externally, illustrated the difficulties associated with inappropriate and unsupervised unopposed oestrogen therapy, alongside the challenge of distinguishing severe hyperplasia from malignant transformation. Importantly, cyclical low-dose oestrogen therapy, incorporating 7-13 days of progestagen, does not appear to heighten the risk of endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Strategies for Preventing and Treating Endometrial Afflictions in Climacteric Women on Oestrogen Therapy. This paper outlines the therapeutic protocols for 74 climacteric women, out of a total of 850 receiving oestrogen therapy, who presented with endometrial disease. Cystic hyperplasia was observed in conjunction with unopposed oestrogen therapy, specifically in the absence of progestagen. Daily administration of 5 mg norethisterone for two 21-day cycles led to a return to normalcy in all 57 cases of cystic hyperplasia and in 6 out of 8 cases of atypical hyperplasia. The examination of 4 cases of endometrial carcinoma, which were referred, highlighted significant issues stemming from improper and unmonitored unopposed oestrogen therapy, as well as the complexity of differentiating severe hyperplasia from malignancy. Crucially, cyclical low-dose oestrogen therapy, when combined with 7 to 13 days of progestagen, does not appear to elevate the incidence of endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Approaches to Endometrial Disease Prevention and Treatment in Climacteric Women on Oestrogen. The article describes the specific treatment regimens employed for 74 patients experiencing endometrial disease among a cohort of 850 climacteric women undergoing oestrogen therapy. A clear association existed between cystic hyperplasia and the use of unopposed oestrogen therapy without progestagen. Following two 21-day courses of 5 mg norethisterone daily, complete regression to normal was achieved in all 57 cases of cystic hyperplasia and in 6 of the 8 cases of atypical hyperplasia. Furthermore, 4 referred cases of endometrial carcinoma served to illustrate the challenges presented by inappropriate and unsupervised unopposed oestrogen therapy, and the inherent difficulty in distinguishing between severe hyperplasia and malignant conditions. The data suggest that cyclical low-dose oestrogen therapy, when supplemented with 7-13 days of progestagen, does not appear to increase the likelihood of developing endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

Adverse Neuropsychiatric Effects of Combined Tramadol and Antidepressant Therapy. Tramadol, a weak opioid influencing adrenergic and serotonergic neurotransmission, is prescribed for cancer-related and chronic non-malignant pain. In one instance, this medication was administered alongside paroxetine and dosulepine hydrochloride to a tetraparetic patient experiencing chronic pain. After 56 days of treatment, the patient developed hallucinations, which resolved only upon discontinuation of both the psychoactive drugs and tramadol. This case report highlights concerns regarding the extended use of analgesics concurrently with psychoactive agents for chronic non-malignant pain, particularly when pain management is achieved.

A Case of Neuropsychiatric Symptoms Following Prolonged Tramadol and Antidepressant Co-administration. Known for its weak opioid properties and influence on adrenergic and serotonergic pathways, tramadol is utilized for managing both cancer and chronic non-malignant pain. This particular case involved its initiation with paroxetine and dosulepine hydrochloride in a tetraparetic patient suffering from chronic pain. Hallucinations emerged 56 days into the treatment regimen, ceasing solely after the cessation of psychoactive medications and tramadol. The report raises questions regarding the sustained application of analgesics in conjunction with psychoactive agents for chronic non-malignant pain, particularly when pain levels are adequately controlled.

Psychotic Manifestations Associated with Extended Tramadol and Antidepressant Use. Tramadol, a mild opioid with modulating effects on adrenergic and serotonergic neurotransmission, is employed in the management of both oncological and chronic non-malignant pain. In a specific clinical scenario, this drug was prescribed in conjunction with paroxetine and dosulepine hydrochloride to a tetraparetic individual experiencing chronic pain. After 56 days of treatment, the patient exhibited hallucinations that abated exclusively following the withdrawal of the psychoactive medications and tramadol. This clinical observation prompts scrutiny of the prolonged co-prescription of pain relievers and psychoactive agents for chronic non-malignant pain, especially if the patient's pain is well-managed.

Risk of Neuropsychiatric Adverse Events from Long-Term Co-prescription of Tramadol and Antidepressants. A weak opioid, tramadol, exerts effects on adrenergic and serotonergic neurotransmission and is indicated for the treatment of cancer pain and chronic non-malignant pain. In a patient with tetraparesis and chronic pain, this medication was initiated concurrently with paroxetine and dosulepine hydrochloride. Fifty-six days subsequent to treatment commencement, the patient experienced hallucinations, which resolved only after the cessation of both the psychoactive drugs and tramadol. This case report highlights important considerations regarding the extended administration of analgesics alongside psychoactive compounds in chronic non-malignant pain, particularly when effective pain control has been achieved.

Comprehensive analysis of germline RB1 gene mutations in 232 retinoblastoma patients. Germline mutations within the RB1 gene confer a hereditary susceptibility to retinoblastoma. We conducted an extensive mutation analysis of the RB1 gene across 232 individuals diagnosed with either hereditary or non-hereditary retinoblastoma. Our systematic investigation encompassed all 27 exons, adjacent sequences, and the promoter region. All categories of point mutations were identified, exhibiting an uneven distribution throughout the RB1 gene sequence. Within our patient cohort, exons 3, 8, 18, and 19 displayed heightened alteration frequency. The approximate 20% germline mutation detection rate suggests the involvement of additional RB1 inactivation pathways. The mutation spectrum elucidated herein is expected to enhance retinoblastoma clinical care and deepen comprehension of its molecular tumorigenesis pathways.

Germline RB1 mutation characteristics in 232 patients with hereditary and non-hereditary retinoblastoma. The RB1 gene's germline mutations are known to predispose individuals to hereditary retinoblastoma. We undertook an investigation into RB1 gene mutations among 232 patients, comprising both hereditary and non-hereditary retinoblastoma cases. A thorough examination was performed on all 27 exons, their flanking sequences, and the promoter. The study revealed the presence of all types of point mutations, distributed unevenly across the RB1 gene sequence. Notably, exons 3, 8, 18, and 19 were found to be more frequently affected in the patient group examined. With a germline mutation detection frequency of approximately 20%, it is implied that other mechanisms contribute to RB1 inactivation. This presented spectrum of mutations holds potential to improve retinoblastoma clinical management and elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying its tumorigenesis.

Mutational profile of the RB1 germline in 232 hereditary and non-hereditary retinoblastoma patients. Germline mutations in the RB1 gene are linked to a hereditary susceptibility to retinoblastoma. This study involved a mutational analysis of the RB1 gene in a cohort of 232 patients diagnosed with either hereditary or non-hereditary forms of retinoblastoma. We systematically scrutinized all 27 exons, their adjacent regions, and the gene's promoter. Our findings indicate the presence of diverse point mutation types, which are not uniformly distributed throughout the RB1 gene sequence. Specifically, exons 3, 8, 18, and 19 exhibited preferential alteration within our patient population. A germline mutation detection rate of around 20% suggests that alternative RB1 inactivation mechanisms are involved. The mutation spectrum documented here is anticipated to aid in enhancing retinoblastoma clinical management and in comprehending the molecular processes driving tumorigenesis.

Germline RB1 genetic alterations in 232 patients with hereditary and non-hereditary retinoblastoma. Hereditary predisposition to retinoblastoma is conferred by germline alterations in the RB1 gene. We conducted an assessment of germline RB1 gene alterations in 232 patients presenting with either hereditary or non-hereditary retinoblastoma. The investigation involved a systematic exploration of all 27 exons, their flanking regions, and the promoter. All categories of point mutations were identified, displaying a non-uniform distribution across the RB1 gene sequence. In the cohort examined, exons 3, 8, 18, and 19 were found to be predominantly affected. The detection frequency for germline mutations was approximately 20%, suggesting the involvement of additional mechanisms for RB1 inactivation. This observed spectrum of mutations is expected to contribute to improved clinical management of retinoblastoma and a better understanding of the molecular pathways leading to tumor development.

Chorea Manifestations in Oncological Patients. This observational study, involving 160 cardiac patients, investigated the influence of ACE inhibitors on stroke through metastatic pathways, concurrently assessing radiculopathy and esophageal cancer. The findings revealed a reduction in mortality rates. These results underscore the clinical relevance of the study.

Characteristics of Chorea Among Individuals with Malignancy. An observational study conducted with 160 cardiac patients sought to determine how ACE inhibitors affect stroke via metastatic mechanisms, with an assessment of radiculopathy and esophageal cancer also performed. The primary outcome indicated diminished mortality rates. Consequently, the study's findings possess clinical significance.

Choreiform Movement Profiles in Patients with Cancer. The research question addressed the effect of ACE inhibitors on stroke through metastatic processes. Methodologically, it was an observational study comprising 160 cardiac patients, which included an evaluation of radiculopathy and esophageal cancer. A key result was the observation of decreased mortality rates. The implications highlight its clinical importance.

Presentation of Chorea in Cancer-Affected Individuals. This observational investigation, enrolling 160 cardiac patients, aimed to understand the influence of ACE inhibitors on stroke through metastatic mechanisms, while also evaluating radiculopathy and esophageal cancer. The study reported reduced mortality rates. The significance of these findings lies in their clinical applicability.

Localizing the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome to a narrow region on chromosome 17q12-21: ruling out EDH17B2 and RARA as candidate genes. The susceptibility gene BRCA1, associated with hereditary breast-ovarian cancer, has previously been mapped to chromosome 17q21 through linkage analysis. Potential candidate genes within this region include EDH17B2, which encodes estradiol 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase II (17 beta-HSD II), and RARA, coding for retinoic acid receptor alpha. We analyzed 22 families affected by breast and breast-ovarian cancer, utilizing eight polymorphisms from the 17q12-21 chromosomal region, with two located within the EDH17B2 gene. Genetic recombination with the breast cancer phenotype indicates that RARA is not a suitable candidate gene for BRCA1. Both BRCA1 and EDH17B2 were mapped to a 6 cM interval between THRA1 and D17S579, and no recombination was observed between these two genes. However, direct sequencing of the entire EDH17B2 gene, performed on overlapping PCR products from four unrelated affected women, revealed no sequence alterations beyond previously documented polymorphisms. Consequently, mutations in the EDH17B2 gene do not appear to contribute to the hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Analysis of single meiotic crossovers in affected individuals suggests that BRCA1 is positioned between the RARA and D17S78 loci.

High-resolution genetic localization of the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome to chromosome 17q12-21 and the exclusion of EDH17B2 and RARA. Previous linkage analysis established BRCA1, a hereditary breast-ovarian cancer susceptibility gene, at chromosome 17q21. Among the candidate genes in this segment are EDH17B2, responsible for encoding estradiol 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase II (17 beta-HSD II), and RARA, which codes for retinoic acid receptor alpha. Our study involved genotyping 22 breast and breast-ovarian cancer families using eight polymorphisms within the chromosome 17q12-21 region, two of which were in the EDH17B2 gene. Recombination events with the breast cancer trait led to the exclusion of RARA as a potential candidate for BRCA1. Both BRCA1 and EDH17B2 were found to map within a 6 cM interval (located between THRA1 and D17S579), with no recombination detected between them. Nevertheless, direct sequencing of the complete EDH17B2 gene, using overlapping PCR products from four unrelated affected women, identified no novel sequence variations apart from known polymorphisms. Therefore, EDH17B2 gene mutations are unlikely to be the cause of the hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Furthermore, single meiotic crossovers observed in affected women imply that BRCA1 lies between the RARA and D17S78 loci.

Delineation of the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome genetic locus on chromosome 17q12-21 and rejection of EDH17B2 and RARA. The gene BRCA1, conferring susceptibility to hereditary breast-ovarian cancer, was previously mapped to chromosome 17q21 by linkage analysis. EDH17B2, which encodes estradiol 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase II (17 beta-HSD II), and RARA, the retinoic acid receptor alpha gene, were considered candidate genes in this vicinity. We genotyped 22 breast and breast-ovarian cancer families with eight polymorphisms from the 17q12-21 region, including two within EDH17B2. Genetic recombination data with the breast cancer phenotype definitively excluded RARA from consideration as a BRCA1 candidate. Although both BRCA1 and EDH17B2 co-localize to a 6 cM interval (between THRA1 and D17S579) with no observed recombination between them, direct sequencing of the entire EDH17B2 gene in four unrelated affected women using overlapping PCR products revealed no sequence variations beyond established polymorphisms. Thus, EDH17B2 gene mutations are not implicated in the hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Single meiotic crossovers in affected women further suggest BRCA1 is situated between the RARA and D17S78 loci.

Refined localization of the breast-ovarian cancer syndrome gene to chromosome 17q12-21, with EDH17B2 and RARA excluded as candidates. Linkage analysis assigned BRCA1, a gene predisposing to hereditary breast-ovarian cancer, to chromosome 17q21. EDH17B2, encoding estradiol 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase II (17 beta-HSD II), and RARA, the gene for retinoic acid receptor alpha, were initially identified as candidate genes in this area. Our investigation involved typing 22 breast and breast-ovarian cancer families using eight polymorphisms from the chromosome 17q12-21 region, two of which were located within the EDH17B2 gene. Genetic recombination with the breast cancer trait subsequently excluded RARA from further consideration as a BRCA1 candidate. While BRCA1 and EDH17B2 both map to a 6 cM interval (situated between THRA1 and D17S579) with no recombination observed between them, direct sequencing of overlapping PCR products covering the entire EDH17B2 gene in four distinct affected women showed no sequence variations apart from those previously described. This finding indicates that mutations in the EDH17B2 gene are not accountable for the hereditary breast-ovarian cancer syndrome. Moreover, single meiotic crossovers in affected women provide evidence that BRCA1 is bordered by the RARA and D17S78 loci.

Centrosome Over-replication and G2-M Checkpoint Dysfunction as Inducers of Genetic Instability in BRCA1 Exon 11 Isoform-Lacking Cells. Germline mutations in the Brca1 tumor suppressor gene confer susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers in women. To elucidate mechanisms underlying BRCA1-associated tumorigenesis, we generated mouse embryonic fibroblast cells with a specific deletion of Brca1 exon 11. Our findings indicate that these mutant cells maintain an intact G1-S cell cycle checkpoint but exhibit impaired proliferation. Notably, a compromised G2-M checkpoint in these cells correlates with extensive chromosomal aberrations. Furthermore, the mutant fibroblasts possess numerous functional centrosomes, which contribute to unequal chromosome segregation, abnormal nuclear division, and aneuploidy. These results highlight BRCA1's critical function in preserving genetic stability through its control of centrosome duplication and the G2-M checkpoint, thereby offering a molecular explanation for BRCA1's involvement in tumor development.

The Contribution of Centrosome Amplification and G2-M Cell Cycle Checkpoint Failure to Genetic Instability in BRCA1 Exon 11 Isoform-Deficient Cells. Germline mutations in the Brca1 tumor suppressor gene are a known predisposition factor for breast and ovarian cancers in women. To investigate the mechanisms driving BRCA1-related oncogenesis, we created mouse embryonic fibroblast cells featuring a targeted deletion of Brca1 exon 11. Our investigation revealed that these mutant cells retain an intact G1-S cell cycle checkpoint but exhibit poor proliferative capacity. Nevertheless, a dysfunctional G2-M checkpoint in these cells is associated with widespread chromosomal abnormalities. These mutant fibroblasts were found to harbor numerous functional centrosomes, culminating in unequal chromosome segregation, abnormal nuclear division, and aneuploidy. This research reveals BRCA1's vital function in maintaining genetic stability through its regulation of centrosome duplication and the G2-M checkpoint, thus providing a molecular underpinning for BRCA1's role in tumorigenesis.

Genetic Instability Resulting from Centrosome Amplification and G2-M Cell Cycle Checkpoint Impairment in BRCA1 Exon 11 Isoform-Deficient Cells. Women with germline mutations in the Brca1 tumor suppressor gene face an elevated risk of breast and ovarian cancers. To investigate the molecular basis of BRCA1-associated tumorigenesis, we generated mouse embryonic fibroblast cells that harbored a targeted deletion of Brca1 exon 11. We observed that these mutant cells maintained an intact G1-S cell cycle checkpoint but displayed compromised proliferation. Critically, a flawed G2-M checkpoint in these cells coincided with widespread chromosomal aberrations. Furthermore, the mutant fibroblasts possessed an excess of functional centrosomes, leading to unequal chromosome segregation, atypical nuclear division, and aneuploidy. These findings underscore BRCA1's crucial role in upholding genetic stability via its control over centrosome duplication and the G2-M checkpoint, thereby elucidating a molecular foundation for BRCA1's involvement in tumorigenesis.

Mechanisms of Genetic Instability: Centrosome Amplification and G2-M Cell Cycle Checkpoint Defects in BRCA1 Exon 11 Isoform-Deficient Cells. Women carrying germline mutations in the Brca1 tumor suppressor gene are predisposed to developing breast and ovarian cancers. To investigate the cellular mechanisms underlying BRCA1-related oncogenesis, we established mouse embryonic fibroblast cells with a targeted deletion of Brca1 exon 11. We demonstrated that these mutant cells possess an intact G1-S cell cycle checkpoint, yet their proliferation is suboptimal. Significantly, a compromised G2-M checkpoint in these cells was correlated with the presence of widespread chromosomal abnormalities. These mutant fibroblasts were found to exhibit an abundance of functional centrosomes, culminating in irregular chromosome segregation, aberrant nuclear division, and subsequent aneuploidy. These observations reveal BRCA1's indispensable role in preserving genetic integrity via its regulatory influence on centrosome duplication and the G2-M checkpoint, thereby offering a molecular elucidation for BRCA1's participation in tumorigenesis.

Gene-Specific Mechanisms Drive Fusion Gene Overexpression from Alternative Translocations in Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma. Chromosomal translocations in various tumors can cause protooncogene dysregulation or oncogenic chimeric protein formation. Specifically, in pediatric alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, the t(2;13) or t(1;13) translocations produce PAX3-FKHR or PAX7-FKHR fusion proteins, respectively. This study demonstrates that these translocations not only lead to functional changes but also to the overexpression of the fusion products. Furthermore, the overexpression of PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR results from distinct processes. PAX3-FKHR transcription is elevated compared to wild-type PAX3 through a copy number-independent pathway. Conversely, PAX7-FKHR overexpression is a consequence of fusion gene amplification. Therefore, gene-specific strategies have evolved to achieve PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR overexpression in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, likely reflecting differences in the regulation of their respective wild-type loci. We propose that these diverse overexpression mechanisms are crucial for maintaining the requisite level of gene product necessary for the oncogenic effects of these fusion genes.

Distinct Regulatory Strategies for Fusion Gene Overexpression Arising from Alternative Chromosomal Translocations in Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma. Chromosomal translocations observed in both hematopoietic and solid malignancies lead to the dysregulated expression of protooncogenes or the generation of chimeric proteins possessing tumorigenic potential. In alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, a pediatric solid tumor, the characteristic t(2;13) (q35;q14) or variant t(1;13) (p36;q14) translocations give rise to PAX3-FKHR or PAX7-FKHR fusion proteins. Here, we report that these translocations are associated with overexpression of the fusion products, in addition to inducing functional alterations. Significantly, PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR are overexpressed via separate mechanisms. Increased transcription of PAX3-FKHR relative to wild-type PAX3 occurs through a mechanism independent of gene copy number. In contrast, PAX7-FKHR overexpression is attributable to the amplification of its fusion gene. Consequently, gene-specific regulatory strategies appear to have been selected for the overexpression of PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, possibly reflecting differences in regulation between the parental gene loci. We hypothesize that these overexpression mechanisms are essential for ensuring a critical concentration of the gene product, which is vital for the oncogenic impact of these fusions.

Mechanistic Basis for Fusion Gene Overexpression in Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma Due to Alternative Chromosomal Translocations. Chromosomal translocations found in hematopoietic and solid tumors result in the aberrant expression of protooncogenes or the formation of novel chimeric proteins with oncogenic capacity. In the context of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, a pediatric solid tumor, the defining t(2;13) (q35;q14) or variant t(1;13) (p36;q14) translocation creates the PAX3-FKHR or PAX7-FKHR fusion proteins. This investigation reveals that, beyond their functional alterations, these translocations are linked to the overexpression of the fusion products. Moreover, the overexpression of PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR proceeds through distinct molecular pathways. Specifically, PAX3-FKHR transcription is augmented when compared to wild-type PAX3 through a process not dependent on gene copy number. Conversely, the increased expression of PAX7-FKHR stems from the amplification of its fusion gene. Thus, specific genetic mechanisms have been employed to achieve overexpression of PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, presumably due to inherent differences in the regulation of their wild-type counterparts. We posit that these varied overexpression mechanisms are crucial for delivering a sufficient level of gene product to facilitate the oncogenic activities of these fusions.

Alternative Chromosomal Translocations in Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma Induce Fusion Gene Overexpression via Gene-Specific Mechanisms. In hematopoietic and solid tumors, chromosomal translocations are known to cause dysregulated protooncogene expression or the generation of chimeric proteins with tumorigenic potential. For the pediatric solid tumor, alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, the characteristic t(2;13) (q35;q14) or variant t(1;13) (p36;q14) translocations produce the PAX3-FKHR or PAX7-FKHR fusion proteins, respectively. Our findings demonstrate that, in addition to functional alterations, these translocations correlate with an overexpression of the fusion products. Importantly, the overexpression of PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR is achieved through different mechanisms. PAX3-FKHR transcription is elevated relative to wild-type PAX3 by a copy number-independent process. In stark contrast, PAX7-FKHR overexpression results from the amplification of its fusion gene. These observations indicate that gene-specific mechanisms are utilized to achieve PAX3-FKHR and PAX7-FKHR overexpression in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, likely due to variations in the regulatory control of the wild-type loci. We propose that these specific overexpression pathways are vital for ensuring a critical gene product level necessary for the oncogenic effects of these fusion events.

The Interplay of Cardiomyopathy and Neurons: An Investigation of Neural Pathways. This study investigated the impact of beta-blockers on diabetes, mediated by meningitis mechanisms. A retrospective analysis was conducted on 140 cancer patients, examining the thalamus and lung cancer. The findings indicated a positive response to treatment, suggesting potential therapeutic advantages.

Neural Pathway Assessment in Cardiomyopathy and Neuronal Contexts. The aim of this research was to determine how beta-blockers influence diabetes through meningitis-related mechanisms. The methodology involved a retrospective study of 140 cancer patients, focusing on the thalamus and lung cancer. Outcomes revealed a favorable treatment response, indicating potential therapeutic benefits.

Gaining Insights into Neural Pathways Connecting Cardiomyopathy and Neurons. An inquiry was conducted to understand the effect of beta-blockers on diabetes, specifically through meningitis mechanisms. The study employed a retrospective design, enrolling 140 cancer patients for assessment of the thalamus and lung cancer. Results demonstrated a positive treatment outcome, highlighting potential therapeutic utility.

Delineating Neural Pathways in Cardiomyopathy and Neuronal Disorders. This study addressed the research question concerning the influence of beta-blockers on diabetes via meningitis mechanisms. Methods included a retrospective investigation involving 140 cancer patients, with an evaluation of the thalamus and lung cancer. A positive treatment response was observed, with implications pointing towards potential therapeutic value.

Central Nervous System Late Effects in Pediatric ALL: Investigating Methotrexate's Role in Neurocognitive and Neuroradiologic Outcomes in POG Protocols P9605 and P9201 (ACCL0131). Concerns from the 1990s regarding long-term methotrexate (MTX) neurotoxicity prompted adjustments to intrathecal (IT) therapy, leucovorin rescue strategies, and the frequency of systemic MTX administration for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This investigation assessed neurocognitive results and neuroradiologic signs of leukoencephalopathy by comparing children who underwent intensive central nervous system (CNS)-directed therapy (P9605) with those who received fewer CNS-directed treatment days during intensive consolidation (P9201). A total of 66 children diagnosed with "standard-risk" acute lymphoblastic leukemia, aged 1.00 to 9.99 years at diagnosis, and without CNS leukemia at diagnosis, from 16 Pediatric Oncology Group institutions, were enrolled in ACCL0131: 28 from P9201 and 38 from P9605. Magnetic resonance imaging scans and standard neuropsychological evaluations were conducted over 2.6 years following the conclusion of treatment. A significantly higher proportion of P9605 patients developed leukoencephalopathy compared to P9201 patients (68%, 95% confidence interval 49%-83% versus 22%, 95% confidence interval 5%-44%; P=0.001), with identification occurring as late as 7.7 years post-treatment cessation. Overall, 40% of the participants achieved scores below 85 on either Verbal or Performance IQ tests. While significant attention problems were observed in children from both studies, P9605 participants exhibited below-average performance on more neurocognitive measures than those treated on P9201 (82%, 14/17 measures versus 24%, 4/17 measures). These findings lend support to continuing concerns that intensive MTX exposure is a major contributor to CNS late effects.

A Comparative Study of Neurocognitive and Neuroradiologic CNS Late Effects in Pediatric ALL Protocols P9605 and P9201 (ACCL0131): Evaluating Methotrexate's Contribution. Concerns about long-term methotrexate (MTX) neurotoxicity in the 1990s necessitated changes in intrathecal (IT) therapy, leucovorin rescue protocols, and the frequency of systemic MTX administration for pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia patients. This study aimed to compare neurocognitive outcomes and neuroradiologic evidence of leukoencephalopathy among children treated with either intense central nervous system (CNS)-directed therapy (P9605) or a reduced number of CNS-directed treatment days during intensive consolidation (P9201). Sixty-six children from 16 Pediatric Oncology Group institutions, who had "standard-risk" acute lymphoblastic leukemia, were aged between 1.00 and 9.99 years at diagnosis, and showed no signs of CNS leukemia at diagnosis, were recruited for ACCL0131; 28 participants were from P9201 and 38 from P9605. Magnetic resonance imaging and standard neuropsychological assessments were performed over 2.6 years after treatment completion. Leukoencephalopathy was significantly more prevalent in P9605 patients compared to P9201 patients (68%, 95% CI 49%-83% vs. 22%, 95% CI 5%-44%; P=0.001), with detection occurring up to 7.7 years after treatment conclusion. Across all patients, 40% scored below 85 on either Verbal or Performance IQ. Although children in both cohorts exhibited substantial attention deficits, P9605 children demonstrated below-average scores on a greater proportion of neurocognitive measures than those in P9201 (82%, 14/17 measures vs. 24%, 4/17 measures). These results reinforce existing apprehensions regarding intensive MTX exposure as a significant factor in CNS late effects.

Neurocognitive and Neuroradiologic Sequelae in Pediatric Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Patients: Examining Methotrexate's Role in POG Protocols P9605 and P9201 (ACCL0131). During the 1990s, concerns about the prolonged neurotoxic effects of methotrexate (MTX) prompted revisions to intrathecal (IT) therapy, leucovorin rescue protocols, and the dosage frequency of systemic MTX in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This study investigated neurocognitive outcomes and the presence of neuroradiologic leukoencephalopathy in pediatric patients. Specifically, it compared those treated with aggressive central nervous system (CNS)-directed therapy (P9605) against those receiving fewer CNS-directed treatment days during intensive consolidation (P9201). The ACCL0131 study enrolled 66 children from 16 Pediatric Oncology Group institutions; these patients had "standard-risk" acute lymphoblastic leukemia, were between 1.00 and 9.99 years old at diagnosis, and presented without CNS leukemia at diagnosis. Of these, 28 were from P9201 and 38 from P9605. Magnetic resonance imaging scans and comprehensive neuropsychological tests were administered more than 2.6 years following the cessation of treatment. A statistically significant difference in leukoencephalopathy development was observed, with P9605 patients showing a higher incidence (68%, 95% confidence interval 49%-83%) compared to P9201 patients (22%, 95% confidence interval 5%-44%; P=0.001), detected up to 7.7 years after treatment completion. Furthermore, 40% of the overall patient cohort achieved Verbal or Performance IQ scores below 85. While both study groups experienced notable attention difficulties, children on P9605 performed below average on a greater number of neurocognitive assessments (14 out of 17 measures, or 82%) than those on P9201 (4 out of 17 measures, or 24%). This evidence reinforces the persistent concerns regarding intensive MTX exposure as a primary contributor to late CNS effects.

Post-Treatment Neurocognitive and Neuroradiologic Sequelae in Pediatric Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia: A Children's Oncology Group Report on Methotrexate's Influence in POG P9605 and P9201. The apprehension surrounding long-term methotrexate (MTX) neurotoxicity in the 1990s instigated modifications to intrathecal (IT) therapy, the application of leucovorin rescue, and the frequency of systemic MTX administration for pediatric patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This investigation aimed to contrast neurocognitive outcomes and neuroradiologic indicators of leukoencephalopathy between children who received intensive central nervous system (CNS)-directed therapy (P9605) and those subjected to fewer CNS-directed treatment days during intensive consolidation (P9201). Enrolled in ACCL0131 were 66 children from 16 Pediatric Oncology Group institutions, all with "standard-risk" acute lymphoblastic leukemia, aged 1.00 to 9.99 years at diagnosis, and without initial CNS leukemia; 28 participants were from P9201, and 38 from P9605. Magnetic resonance imaging scans and comprehensive neuropsychological tests were administered more than 2.6 years following the conclusion of their treatment. A statistically significant increase in leukoencephalopathy development was observed in P9605 patients (68%, 95% confidence interval 49%-83%) relative to P9201 patients (22%, 95% confidence interval 5%-44%; P=0.001), with this condition being identified as late as 7.7 years post-treatment. Overall, 40% of the patients scored less than 85 on either the Verbal or Performance IQ assessments. While significant issues with attention affected children in both study groups, P9605 participants scored below average on a greater proportion of neurocognitive measures (82%, 14 of 17) compared to those in P9201 (24%, 4 of 17). These findings underscore the persistent concerns that intensive MTX exposure is a primary factor contributing to late CNS effects.

A Genetic Locus on Human Chromosome 10pter-q11 Mediating Tumor Suppression and Apoptosis in Human Prostate Carcinoma. Prostate cancer stands as the second leading cause of male cancer-related fatalities in the United States, yet the molecular mechanisms underlying this aggressive malignancy remain poorly understood despite significant international research. While prostate secretory epithelial cells and androgen-dependent prostate carcinomas undergo apoptosis in response to androgen deprivation, most prostate carcinomas become androgen-independent and refractory to further therapeutic interventions during disease progression. Defining the genetic events that trigger apoptosis in the prostate could offer crucial insights into critical pathways in normal development, as well as clarify the perturbations of those key pathways in neoplastic transformation. We report the functional characterization of a novel genetic locus situated within human chromosome 10pter-q11, which mediates both in vivo tumor growth inhibition and in vitro programmed cell death in prostatic adenocarcinoma cells. A defined fragment of human chromosome 10 was transferred via microcell fusion into a prostate adenocarcinoma cell line. Microcell hybrids containing only the 10pter-q11 region demonstrated suppressed tumorigenicity following injection into nude mice. Furthermore, these complemented hybrids underwent programmed cell death in vitro through a mechanism that does not necessitate nuclear localization of p53. These data functionally define a novel genetic locus, designated PAC1 (for prostate adenocarcinoma 1), involved in tumor suppression of human prostate carcinoma, and furthermore strongly suggest that the cell death pathway can be functionally restored in prostatic adenocarcinoma.

Mediation of Tumor Suppression and Apoptosis in Prostate Carcinoma by a Genetic Locus on Human Chromosome 10pter-q11. Prostate cancer is the second primary cause of cancer deaths among males in the United States, with its molecular mechanisms remaining largely undefined despite extensive global efforts. Although prostate secretory epithelial cells and androgen-dependent prostate carcinomas undergo apoptosis when deprived of androgen, the majority of prostate carcinomas ultimately become androgen-independent and unresponsive to subsequent therapeutic manipulations as the disease advances. Elucidating the genetic events that instigate apoptosis in the prostate is vital for gaining important insights into critical pathways in normal development and for understanding their dysregulation during neoplastic transformation. We present the functional definition of a novel genetic region within human chromosome 10pter-q11 that facilitates both in vivo tumor suppression and in vitro apoptosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma cells. A specific fragment of human chromosome 10 was introduced into a prostate adenocarcinoma cell line through microcell fusion. Microcell hybrids exclusively possessing the 10pter-q11 region exhibited suppressed tumorigenicity upon injection into nude mice. Additionally, these modified hybrids underwent programmed cell death in vitro via a mechanism independent of p53 nuclear localization. This dataset functionally defines a novel genetic locus, named PAC1, for prostate adenocarcinoma 1, which participates in the tumor suppression of human prostate carcinoma and further strongly suggests that the cell death pathway can be functionally reinstated in prostatic adenocarcinoma.

Functional Definition of a Genetic Locus on Human Chromosome 10pter-q11 in Prostate Carcinoma Tumor Suppression and Apoptosis. As the second leading cause of male cancer deaths in the United States, prostate cancer's molecular underpinnings are largely unknown despite considerable international efforts. Prostate secretory epithelial cells and androgen-dependent prostate carcinomas undergo apoptosis in response to androgen deprivation; however, most prostate carcinomas progress to an androgen-independent state and become refractory to further therapeutic manipulations. Elucidating the genetic events that trigger apoptosis in the prostate is critical for providing important insights into key pathways in normal development, as well as for clarifying the perturbations of those pathways during neoplastic transformation. We report the functional identification of a novel genetic locus situated within human chromosome 10pter-q11, which is responsible for both in vivo tumor suppression and in vitro apoptosis in prostatic adenocarcinoma cells. Through microcell fusion, a defined fragment of human chromosome 10 was transferred into a prostate adenocarcinoma cell line. Microcell hybrids containing solely the 10pter-q11 region exhibited suppressed tumorigenicity after injection into nude mice. Moreover, these gene-complemented hybrids underwent programmed cell death in vitro via a mechanism that operates independently of p53 nuclear localization. These data functionally characterize a novel genetic locus, designated PAC1 (for prostate adenocarcinoma 1), highlighting its involvement in human prostate carcinoma tumor suppression and strongly implying that the cell death pathway can be functionally restored in prostatic adenocarcinoma.

A Genetic Locus on Chromosome 10pter-q11 Drives Tumor Suppression and Apoptosis in Human Prostate Carcinoma. Prostate cancer represents the second primary cause of cancer-related mortality among males in the United States. Despite considerable international efforts, the molecular mechanisms underlying this severe disease remain poorly understood. While androgen deprivation triggers apoptosis in prostate secretory epithelial cells and androgen-dependent prostate carcinomas, most carcinomas ultimately become androgen-independent and unresponsive to subsequent therapeutic interventions as the disease progresses. Identifying the genetic events that initiate apoptosis in the prostate could provide crucial insights into essential pathways in normal development and illuminate the dysregulations of these key pathways during neoplastic transformation. Our study functionally defines a novel genetic locus located within human chromosome 10pter-q11 that mediates both in vivo tumor suppression and in vitro apoptosis in prostatic adenocarcinoma cells. A specific segment of human chromosome 10 was introduced into a prostate adenocarcinoma cell line via microcell fusion. Microcell hybrids containing exclusively the 10pter-q11 region displayed suppressed tumorigenicity following their injection into nude mice. Furthermore, these gene-complemented hybrids demonstrated programmed cell death in vitro through a mechanism not requiring nuclear localization of p53. These results functionally establish a novel genetic locus, designated PAC1 (prostate adenocarcinoma 1), as being involved in the tumor suppression of human prostate carcinoma. They also strongly suggest the potential for functional restoration of the cell death pathway in prostatic adenocarcinoma.

The Association of p19/nm23 Nucleoside Diphosphate Kinase Abundance with Cell Proliferation. The nm23-H1 gene, which codes for a nucleoside diphosphate kinase, has demonstrated varied associations with metastasis; high expression has correlated with reduced metastasis in some tumors but not in others. We previously identified p19/nm23 as the protein product of the nm23-H1 gene via two-dimensional electrophoretic gels. In neuroblastoma, elevated p19/nm23 levels were observed in advanced stage tumors compared to limited stage disease, coinciding with N-myc oncogene amplification, larger tumor mass, and metastasis. Given the inconsistent expression patterns of nm23-H1 across different tumors, we investigated the relationship between this protein's quantity and cellular proliferation. p19/nm23 levels were compared in quiescent versus mitotically active normal human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBLs) and in leukemia cells. A rise in p19/nm23 protein was noted in normal lymphocytes in response to mitotic stimulation, mirroring the increase in DNA synthesis. Similarly, leukemia cells from patients with diverse acute leukemia subtypes showed elevated p19/nm23 levels compared to resting normal lymphocytes. Treatment of mitotically stimulated lymphocytes with cyclosporin, a known proliferation inhibitor, prevented the p19/nm23 increase. Conversely, inducing terminal differentiation with dimethylsulfoxide in the HL-60 leukemia cell line led to a decrease in p19/nm23 levels. These findings collectively suggest that nm23-H1 expression is directly linked to cellular proliferative activity.

Regulation of p19/nm23 Nucleoside Diphosphate Kinase Expression by Cell Proliferation. The gene nm23-H1, encoding a nucleoside diphosphate kinase, has been observed to have high expression correlating with reduced metastasis in certain tumor types, but not universally. Our prior research identified p19/nm23 as the protein product of the nm23-H1 gene using two-dimensional electrophoresis. In cases of neuroblastoma, advanced stage tumors displayed higher concentrations of p19/nm23, a finding associated with N-myc oncogene amplification, larger tumor volume, and metastatic progression, in contrast to limited stage disease. Motivated by the disparate expression of nm23-H1 across various tumors, we undertook an investigation into the connection between the protein's quantity and cellular proliferative status. We compared p19/nm23 concentrations in normal human PBLs when at rest versus under mitotic stimulation, and within leukemia cells. Normal lymphocytes exhibited an elevation in p19/nm23 levels concurrent with mitotic stimulation, which tracked the surge in DNA synthesis. Furthermore, p19/nm23 levels were also elevated in leukemia cells obtained from patients with different subtypes of acute leukemia, relative to resting normal lymphocytes. The increase in p19/nm23 in mitotically stimulated lymphocytes was abrogated by treatment with cyclosporin, an agent known to inhibit proliferation. Conversely, inducing terminal differentiation with dimethylsulfoxide in the HL-60 leukemia cell line led to a reduction in p19/nm23 concentrations. These data collectively substantiate that nm23-H1 expression is modulated by cell proliferative activity.

Cellular Proliferation and the Expression Profile of p19/nm23 Nucleoside Diphosphate Kinase. Expression of the nm23-H1 gene, which codes for a nucleoside diphosphate kinase, has shown an inconsistent correlation with metastatic potential; high expression linked to reduced metastasis in some tumor contexts but not others. Our team previously identified p19/nm23 as the protein product of the nm23-H1 gene through two-dimensional electrophoretic analysis. Cyclosporin treatment, which suppresses proliferation, prevented the rise in p19/nm23 in mitotically stimulated lymphocytes. Furthermore, the induction of terminal differentiation with dimethylsulfoxide in the HL-60 leukemia cell line led to decreased p19/nm23 levels. These findings robustly indicate that nm23-H1 expression is intimately connected to cellular proliferative activity.

Proliferative Activity as a Determinant of p19/nm23 Nucleoside Diphosphate Kinase Levels. Elevated expression of the nm23-H1 gene, which encodes a nucleoside diphosphate kinase, has been linked to reduced metastasis in certain tumor types, yet this correlation is not universal. Our prior work successfully identified p19/nm23 as the protein product of the nm23-H1 gene through two-dimensional electrophoretic separation. Notably, in neuroblastoma, advanced stage tumors presented with higher concentrations of p19/nm23, a phenomenon correlated with N-myc oncogene amplification, increased tumor size, and metastasis, contrasting with findings in limited stage disease. Recognizing the inconsistent expression of nm23-H1 across diverse tumors, we sought to elucidate the relationship between this protein's quantity and cellular proliferation. The concentrations of p19/nm23 were evaluated in normal human peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBLs) under quiescent and mitotically stimulated conditions, as well as in leukemia cells. In normal lymphocytes, p19/nm23 content escalated in response to mitotic stimulation, mirroring the upward trend in DNA synthesis. Similarly, leukemia cells derived from patients afflicted with various forms of acute leukemia displayed heightened p19/nm23 levels when compared to quiescent normal lymphocytes. Administration of cyclosporin, an inhibitor of proliferation, prevented the increase in p19/nm23 observed in mitotically stimulated lymphocytes. Furthermore, inducing terminal differentiation in the HL-60 leukemia cell line with dimethylsulfoxide led to a decline in p19/nm23 concentrations. Consequently, our findings establish that nm23-H1 expression is intrinsically associated with cell proliferative activity.

Maternal Intrachromosomal Insertion Leading to Chromosome 5 Deletion and Adenomatous Polyposis Coli. This report details the clinical and laboratory characteristics of an institutionalized adult patient initially evaluated for autism. Colorectal cancer risk was anticipated following the identification of an interstitial deletion, del(5)(q15q22.3), within the long arm of chromosome 5 in her lymphocytes, with molecular analysis substantiating the deletion of MCC and APC genes. The patient was later diagnosed with adenomatous polyposis coli and rectal carcinoma. Her clinical presentation included profound mental retardation, autism, and minor dysmorphic features, aligning with observations in prior cases involving similar deletions. The deletion originated from recombination within a small insertion loop, formed during meiosis by a direct insertion (dir ins(5)(q22.3q14.2q15)) present in the patient's mother. This family's case reinforces the cytogenetic localization of both MCC and APC genes to 5q22, and comparative analysis with other recent reports indicates that these genes and their closely associated markers reside within the 5q22.1 subband.

A Case of Chromosome 5 Deletion and Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Caused by a Maternal Intrachromosomal Insertion. We report the clinical and laboratory observations from an institutionalized adult patient initially evaluated for autism spectrum disorder. The patient's lymphocytes revealed an interstitial deletion of chromosome 5q (del(5)(q15q22.3)), with molecular studies verifying deletions of the MCC and APC genes, leading to a projected high risk of colorectal cancer. Subsequently, diagnoses of adenomatous polyposis coli and rectal carcinoma were established for this patient. Clinical examination showed profound mental retardation, autism, and subtle dysmorphic features, mirroring phenotypes observed in individuals with comparable chromosomal deletions. This deletion was a consequence of meiotic recombination within a small insertion loop, which formed due to a direct insertion (dir ins(5)(q22.3q14.2q15)) identified in the patient's mother. This family's case provides additional evidence for the cytogenetic assignment of MCC and APC genes to 5q22, and comparisons with other recent cases imply that these genes, along with their closely associated markers, are located within the 5q22.1 subband.

6-Thioguanine-induced hepatic veno-occlusive disease. A 23-year-old male patient with acute lymphocytic leukemia developed clinically reversible hepatic veno-occlusive disease after 10 months of 6-thioguanine maintenance therapy. Sequential liver biopsies revealed the onset and subsequent resolution of severe sinusoidal engorgement. Although clinical reversal occurred, residual subintimal fibrosis around the terminal hepatic veins remained. This case provided a distinctive opportunity for the temporal observation of the histological characteristics of clinically reversible HVOD and may represent the inaugural documented instance solely attributable to 6-thioguanine.

Association of 6-thioguanine with hepatic veno-occlusive disease. A 23-year-old man, diagnosed with acute lymphocytic leukemia, experienced clinically reversible veno-occlusive disease affecting the liver following a 10-month course of 6-thioguanine maintenance treatment. Histopathological examination through serial liver biopsies demonstrated the emergence and subsequent disappearance of marked sinusoidal engorgement. Despite the clinical reversibility of the condition, a degree of subintimal fibrosis persisted in the vicinity of the terminal hepatic veins. This particular case offered an unparalleled chance to monitor the evolving histological features of clinically reversible hepatic veno-occlusive disease and could be the initial report of this condition exclusively linked to 6-thioguanine.

This case was notable for providing a rare opportunity to study the time-dependent histological aspects of clinically reversible hepatic veno-occlusive disease, potentially being the first instance solely associated with 6-thioguanine.

Phase II Evaluation of Thalidomide in Advanced Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma. This study aimed to assess the toxicity and therapeutic efficacy of thalidomide in patients presenting with advanced metastatic renal cell cancer, along with measuring alterations in vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)165 levels during treatment. Twenty-nine patients were recruited and administered thalidomide via an intra-patient dose escalation regimen, commencing at 400 mg/d and progressing to 1200 mg/d by day 54 as tolerated. Prior IL-2 therapy had been received by 59% of patients, and 52% exhibited a performance status of 2 or 3. Systemic plasma VEGF165 concentrations were determined in 8 patients using dual monoclonal ELISA. Among the 24 patients evaluable for response, one patient (4%) achieved a partial response lasting 11 months, affecting hepatic and pulmonary metastases. Additionally, one minor response and two instances of disease stabilization exceeding 6 months were observed. Key toxicities included somnolence and constipation, with most patients unable to tolerate the 1200 mg/day dose. No significant changes in systemic plasma VEGF165 levels were noted with therapy. These findings suggest a limited level of thalidomide activity in renal cell carcinoma. Achieving doses above 800 mg/day proved challenging in this cohort, though lower doses were manageable. The precise dose-response relationship of thalidomide for renal cell carcinoma remains undefined.

Clinical Trial of Thalidomide in Advanced Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma: A Phase II Study. The objectives of this investigation were to determine the safety profile and clinical activity of thalidomide in individuals afflicted with advanced metastatic renal cell cancer, and concurrently to quantify treatment-induced modifications in the angiogenic factor VEGF165. A total of 29 patients were enrolled in this trial, undergoing an intra-patient dose-escalation protocol for thalidomide, starting at 400 mg/d and incrementing up to 1200 mg/d by day 54 based on tolerance. Previous interleukin-2 therapy had been administered to 59% of participants, and 52% presented with a performance status of 2 or 3. Plasma concentrations of systemic VEGF165 were quantified in 8 patients using a dual monoclonal ELISA method. From 24 evaluable patients, one (4%) demonstrated a partial response of 11 months duration, specifically involving hepatic and pulmonary metastases. Furthermore, one minor response and two cases of disease stabilization for over 6 months were recorded. Prominent adverse effects included somnolence and constipation, with the majority of patients unable to sustain the 1200 mg/day dosage. No alterations in systemic plasma VEGF165 levels were detected following therapy. The results are consistent with modest anti-tumor activity of thalidomide in renal cell carcinoma. While doses exceeding 800 mg/day were difficult to administer within this patient group, lower doses were feasible. The dose-response relationship for thalidomide in renal cell carcinoma, if present, is currently unclear.

Characterizing Mitomycin C-Induced Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome. Mitomycin C-associated Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) represents a potentially lethal yet infrequent condition lacking widespread recognition. Its manifestations include microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and progressive renal failure, occurring in approximately 10% of patients receiving mitomycin C. Renal dysfunction typically emerges around 8-10 months following the initiation of mitomycin C treatment, with a mortality rate of approximately 60% due to renal failure or pulmonary edema. Renal pathological findings resemble those observed in idiopathic HUS, encompassing arteriolar fibrin thrombi, enlarged subendothelial regions in glomerular capillary walls, ischemic wrinkling of glomerular basement membranes, and mesangiolysis. The proposed mechanism involves mitomycin C-induced endothelial cell damage. This report details the clinical trajectory and pathological observations in a 65-year-old male with gastric adenocarcinoma who developed renal failure and thrombocytopenia during mitomycin C therapy and subsequently succumbed to pulmonary edema.

Clinical Profile and Pathological Insights into Mitomycin C-Related Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) linked to Mitomycin C constitutes a potentially fatal, infrequent condition that remains insufficiently understood. It is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and progressive renal failure in patients undergoing mitomycin C treatment, affecting approximately 10% of those exposed to the agent. Renal failure typically manifests 8-10 months after the commencement of mitomycin C therapy, with a mortality rate of around 60% stemming from renal failure or pulmonary edema. Renal lesions mirror those seen in idiopathic HUS, including arteriolar fibrin thrombi, expanded subendothelial zones within glomerular capillary walls, ischemic wrinkling of glomerular basement membranes, and mesangiolysis. The pathogenesis is hypothesized to involve mitomycin C-induced damage to endothelial cells. We document the clinical course and pathological findings from a 65-year-old man with gastric adenocarcinoma who experienced renal failure and thrombocytopenia while receiving mitomycin C and whose death was attributed to pulmonary edema.

The renal pathology parallels that of idiopathic HUS, encompassing arteriolar fibrin thrombi, expanded subendothelial regions in glomerular capillary walls, ischemic wrinkling of glomerular basement membranes, and mesangiolysis. The underlying mechanism is posited to be mitomycin C-induced endothelial cell damage. We provide a detailed account of the clinical progression and pathological characteristics in a 65-year-old man with gastric adenocarcinoma who developed renal failure and thrombocytopenia during mitomycin C treatment and subsequently died from pulmonary edema.

VHL Gene Mutations in Sporadic Renal Cell Carcinoma: Identifying a Risk Profile for RCC Development in VHL Patients. Our study aimed to characterize somatic von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) mutations, examining 173 primary sporadic human renal cell carcinomas for VHL tumor suppressor gene alterations. We employed polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and single-strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP) analysis of DNA for this purpose. Abnormal SSCP patterns were observed in 73 samples. Subsequent sequencing revealed microdeletions in 58% of instances, microinsertions in 17%, nonsense mutations in 8%, and missense mutations in 17%. Half of these identified mutations represented novel findings. Consistent with prior reports, VHL mutations were exclusively detected in the nonpapillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) subtype. A comparison between somatic and germline mutations, utilizing a VHL database of 507 entries, demonstrated a significant disparity (P < 0.0001) in mutational events. Specifically, mutations resulting in truncated proteins constituted 78% of somatic mutations compared to only 37% of germline mutations. This suggests a distinct pattern of VHL mutations linked to sporadic RCC, predominantly involving protein truncations with a limited number of specific missense changes. Further analysis investigated RCC incidence within VHL families, stratified by mutation type. RCC was present in at least one family member in 77% of cases with protein-truncating mutations, significantly higher than the 55% observed in cases with missense mutations (P = 0.015). This indicates that mutations causing protein truncation confer a substantially elevated risk for RCC development in VHL patients.

Sporadic Renal Cell Carcinoma and VHL Gene Alterations: Elucidating a Predictive Factor for VHL Patient RCC Risk. We sought to characterize the somatic von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) mutations present in 173 primary sporadic human renal cell carcinomas. Notably, 50% of the identified mutations were novel. Consistent with existing literature, VHL mutations were exclusively observed in the nonpapillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) subtype. A comparison of somatic and germline mutations, drawing from the VHL database comprising 507 mutations, highlighted a significant divergence (P < 0.0001) in mutational profiles. Mutations causing truncated proteins comprised 78% of somatic mutations, a stark contrast to 37% in germline mutations. This distinct mutational signature, primarily characterized by protein truncations and a limited subset of missense mutations, is indicative of sporadic RCC. Investigating RCC occurrence within VHL families, stratified by mutation type, revealed that 77% of families with protein-truncating mutations had at least one member with RCC, significantly exceeding the 55% observed in families with missense mutations (P = 0.015). Our findings conclude that VHL mutations resulting in truncated proteins confer a significantly higher risk of RCC in VHL patients.
