Clinical Efficacy of Lamivudine Monotherapy in Decompensated HBV-Related Cirrhosis: A Case Report. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, responsible for liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, persists as a significant health concern in Asian nations. While recent vaccine development has successfully reduced the prevalence of chronically infected carriers, established standard medical therapies are still lacking. This report details a patient with decompensated HBV-related cirrhosis who demonstrated marked improvements following antiviral treatment. A 50-year-old woman, previously unresponsive to conventional medical interventions, was referred to our hospital. Her liver severity dramatically improved after 23 months of lamivudine, a reverse transcriptase inhibitor. During this period, no drug-resistant HBV mutants emerged, and serum HBV-DNA levels remained consistently suppressed. These virological responses persisted even after antiviral therapy cessation. Furthermore, both hepatitis B surface antigen and e antigen became undetectable in this patient. Considering lamivudine administration as an initial medical therapeutic option for patients with HBV-related cirrhosis, similar to our case, is advisable, particularly in regions where liver transplantation is not readily available.

Sustained Clinical and Virological Response to Lamivudine Monotherapy in Decompensated Hepatitis B Cirrhosis. These favorable virological outcomes were sustained even after discontinuing the antiviral therapy. Moreover, both hepatitis B surface antigen and e antigen disappeared in this individual. The use of lamivudine for patients with HBV-related cirrhosis, as exemplified by our current case, warrants consideration as an initial therapeutic strategy, especially where access to liver transplantation is limited.

Evaluation of the thymidylate synthase inhibitor CB 3717 (N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid) in preclinical and early clinical investigations. N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid (CB 3717) functions as a potent, tight-binding inhibitor of thymidylate synthase (TS), with its cytotoxic effects solely attributed to this enzyme inhibition. Recent preclinical research has investigated the intracellular formation of CB 3717 polyglutamates. After exposing L1210 cells to 50 microM [3H]CB 3717 for 12 hours, high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses revealed that 30% of the recoverable radioactivity comprised CB 3717 tetra- and pentaglutamate. When tested against isolated L1210 TS, CB 3717 di-, tri-, tetra-, and pentaglutamate demonstrated significantly increased potency, being 26-, 87-, 119-, and 114-fold more potent than CB 3717, respectively, suggesting their formation may critically influence CB 3717's cytotoxicity. Initial clinical trials with CB 3717 have shown efficacy in cases of breast cancer, ovarian cancer, hepatoma, and mesothelioma. Adverse effects included hepatotoxicity, malaise, and dose-limiting nephrotoxicity, with the latter potentially resulting from drug precipitation in the renal tubules due to CB 3717's poor solubility in acidic conditions. To address this issue, a clinical trial is currently evaluating CB 3717 administration alongside alkaline diuresis. Preliminary findings from doses of 400 and 500 mg/m2 indicate a potential reduction in nephrotoxicity, with only 1 out of 10 patients experiencing renal toxicity. Hepatotoxicity and malaise remain the most common side effects. Antitumor activity has been observed in 3 patients. Pharmacokinetic analyses confirm that alkaline diuresis does not alter CB 3717 plasma concentrations or urinary excretion, and successful urinary alkalinization is achievable.

N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid (CB 3717), a thymidylate synthase inhibitor: Preclinical insights and clinical observations. CB 3717, chemically known as N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid, operates as a potent, tight-binding inhibitor of thymidylate synthase (TS), with its cytotoxic action exclusively originating from this enzyme inhibition. Contemporary preclinical investigations have concentrated on the intracellular generation of CB 3717 polyglutamates. Following a 12-hour exposure of L1210 cells to 50 microM [3H]CB 3717, analyses by high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) revealed that CB 3717 tetra- and pentaglutamate constituted 30% of the quantifiable radioactivity. As inhibitors of isolated L1210 TS, the di-, tri-, tetra-, and pentaglutamate forms of CB 3717 exhibited dramatically increased potency, being 26, 87, 119, and 114 times more potent than CB 3717 itself, respectively, implying that their formation might be a crucial determinant of CB 3717's cellular toxicity. In early-stage clinical evaluations of CB 3717, therapeutic effects have been documented in individuals with breast cancer, ovarian cancer, hepatoma, and mesothelioma. Noted adverse events included hepatotoxicity, general malaise, and dose-limiting nephrotoxicity. This kidney-related side effect is theorized to stem from the precipitation of the drug within the renal tubules, a consequence of CB 3717's poor solubility in acidic environments. To mitigate this issue, a clinical trial evaluating CB 3717 in conjunction with alkaline diuresis is currently in progress. Preliminary data from doses of 400 and 500 mg/m2 suggest a possible amelioration of nephrotoxicity, with only 1 patient out of 10 experiencing renal toxicity. Hepatotoxicity and malaise consistently emerge as the most common adverse reactions. Antitumor activity has been observed in 3 patients. Pharmacokinetic studies have established that alkaline diuresis does not influence CB 3717 plasma levels or its urinary excretion, and that effective urinary alkalinization is readily achievable.

The di-, tri-, tetra-, and pentaglutamate forms of CB 3717 demonstrated considerably enhanced potency against isolated L1210 TS, being 26, 87, 119, and 114 times more potent than CB 3717, respectively. Renal Impairment Following High-Dose Methotrexate Therapy in a Patient with Ileostomy. High-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX) serves as a crucial treatment for Burkitt lymphoma but can induce hepatic and renal toxicity when its clearance is delayed. We document a case of acute kidney injury occurring after HD-MTX administration in a patient with an ileostomy. The patient was a 3-year-old boy who had received a living-related liver transplantation for congenital biliary atresia. On day 833 post-transplantation, he was diagnosed with post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD, Burkitt-type malignant lymphoma). During initial induction therapy, he developed an ileal perforation, necessitating an ileostomy. Subsequent HD-MTX therapy led to acute renal failure, which mandated continuous hemodialysis. We proposed that intravascular hypovolemia, resulting from significant fluid loss from the ileostoma, caused acute prerenal failure. Following the recovery of his renal function, the patient was safely treated with further HD-MTX cycles by carefully controlling drainage from the ileostoma using total parenteral nutrition.

Acute Kidney Injury Secondary to High-Dose Methotrexate Administration in an Ileostomized Patient. High-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX) is a well-established therapeutic agent for Burkitt lymphoma; however, delayed drug elimination can lead to hepatic and renal adverse effects. This report details an instance of acute renal failure observed after HD-MTX treatment in a patient who had undergone an ileostomy. The patient was a 3-year-old male, diagnosed with PTLD (Burkitt-type malignant lymphoma) 833 days after a living-related liver transplantation for congenital biliary atresia. An ileal perforation during induction therapy required an ileostomy to be formed. The subsequent HD-MTX regimen precipitated acute renal failure, thereby requiring continuous hemodialysis. Our hypothesis suggests that acute prerenal failure developed due to intravascular hypovolemia, which arose from substantial fluid drainage from the ileostoma. After the patient's renal function was restored, HD-MTX therapy was safely continued by managing ileostoma output through total parenteral nutrition.

High-Dose Methotrexate-Induced Acute Renal Failure in a Patient with an Ileostomy. High-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX) is a cornerstone in the management of Burkitt lymphoma; nevertheless, its delayed clearance can result in significant hepatic and renal complications. We present a case of acute renal failure experienced after HD-MTX therapy in a patient whose condition was complicated by an ileostomy. The subject was a 3-year-old boy, 833 days post-living-related liver transplantation for congenital biliary atresia, who received a diagnosis of post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (Burkitt-type malignant lymphoma). An ileostomy was performed following an ileal perforation that occurred during induction treatment. The subsequent HD-MTX administration induced acute renal failure, which necessitated continuous hemodialysis. It is conjectured that acute prerenal failure resulted from intravascular hypovolemia, attributable to considerable fluid efflux from the ileostoma. Upon the restoration of renal capability, the patient was safely administered HD-MTX by employing total parenteral nutrition to meticulously control ileostoma drainage.

A Case of Acute Renal Dysfunction Following High-Dose Methotrexate Therapy in a Patient with an Ileostomy. While high-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX) is a critical component in the treatment of Burkitt lymphoma, its delayed metabolism carries a risk of hepatic and renal toxicity. We report on a 3-year-old male patient who developed acute renal failure subsequent to HD-MTX therapy, in the context of an existing ileostomy. This patient had received a living-related liver transplantation for congenital biliary atresia, and 833 days post-transplant, was diagnosed with post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (Burkitt-type malignant lymphoma). During induction therapy, an ileal perforation occurred, leading to the creation of an ileostomy. The subsequent HD-MTX treatment led to acute renal failure, demanding continuous hemodialysis. We presumed that substantial drainage from the ileostoma caused intravascular hypovolemia, resulting in acute prerenal failure. After renal function recovery, we successfully and safely re-administered HD-MTX by managing ileostoma fluid loss with total parenteral nutrition.

Transient Hyperammonemic Encephalopathy in Cancer Patients Receiving Continuous 5-Fluorouracil, with Dehydration and Infection. From 1986 to 1998, 29 cancer patients experienced 32 episodes of transient hyperammonemic encephalopathy linked to continuous 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) infusion. None of these individuals had pre-existing decompensated liver disease. Encephalopathy onset ranged from 0.5 to 5 days (mean: 2.6 +/- 1.3 days) following chemotherapy initiation. Plasma ammonium levels spanned 248 to 2387 g% (mean: 626 +/- 431 g%). Among the 32 episodes, 26 (81%) involved varying degrees of azotemia, 18 (56%) manifested during bacterial infections, and 14 (44%) without infection coincided with periods of dehydration. Elevated plasma ammonium levels and quicker hyperammonemia onset were observed in 18 patients with bacterial infections (p=0.003 and 0.0006, respectively) and in nine patients receiving high daily 5-FU doses (2600 or 1800 mg/m2) (p=0.0001 and < 0.0001, respectively). In 25 of 32 episodes (78%), plasma ammonium levels and mental status normalized within two days of appropriate management. In conclusion, hyperammonemic encephalopathy is a potential complication for patients receiving continuous 5-FU infusion. Azotemia, insufficient body fluids, and bacterial infections were commonly identified among these patients, underscoring the importance of recognizing this condition in individuals undergoing continuous 5-FU therapy.

Predisposing Factors for Transient Hyperammonemic Encephalopathy in Cancer Patients Undergoing Continuous 5-Fluorouracil Therapy. A review of cases from 1986 to 1998 identified 32 instances of transient hyperammonemic encephalopathy (THE) across 29 cancer patients receiving continuous 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) infusion. Plasma ammonium concentrations ranged from 248 to 2387 g% (average: 626 +/- 431 g%). A breakdown of the 32 episodes revealed that 26 (81%) involved azotemia of varying severity, 18 (56%) transpired during bacterial infections, and 14 (44%) occurred in dehydrated patients without concurrent infection. Statistically significant associations were found: higher plasma ammonium levels and more rapid onset of hyperammonemia were observed in 18 patients with bacterial infections (p=0.003 and 0.0006, respectively) and in nine patients on high daily 5-FU doses (2600 or 1800 mg/m2) (p=0.0001 and < 0.0001, respectively). Clinical resolution, characterized by normalized plasma ammonium levels and mental status, was achieved within 2 days following management in 25 of the 32 episodes (78%). It is concluded that hyperammonemic encephalopathy can manifest in patients receiving continuous 5-FU infusions. Frequent findings in these patients included azotemia, fluid deficits, and bacterial infections, highlighting the necessity of recognizing this condition during continuous 5-FU treatment.

A retrospective study spanning 1986 to 1998 documented 32 episodes of transient hyperammonemic encephalopathy, affecting 29 cancer patients receiving continuous 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) infusions. No cases involved patients with decompensated liver disease. Of the 32 documented episodes, azotemia was present in 26 (81%), bacterial infections complicated 18 (56%) cases, and dehydration without infection was observed in 14 (44%) instances. Statistically significant associations were identified between elevated plasma ammonium levels and a more rapid onset of hyperammonemia in 18 patients experiencing bacterial infections (p=0.003 and 0.0006, respectively). Similar associations were noted in nine patients receiving high daily doses of 5-FU (2600 or 1800 mg/m2) (p=0.0001 and < 0.0001, respectively). Transient Hyperammonemic Encephalopathy in Continuous 5-Fluorouracil Therapy: The Role of Dehydration and Infection. Transient hyperammonemic encephalopathy (THE) linked to continuous 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) infusion was observed in 32 episodes among 29 cancer patients between 1986 and 1998. Patients with decompensated liver disease were excluded from this cohort. The onset of THE occurred between 0.5 and 5 days after chemotherapy commenced, with a mean of 2.6 +/- 1.3 days. Plasma ammonium levels ranged from 248 to 2387 g%, averaging 626 +/- 431 g%. Analysis of the 32 episodes showed azotemia in 26 (81%) cases, bacterial infections in 18 (56%), and dehydration without infection in 14 (44%). Both bacterial infections (18 patients; p=0.003 for higher plasma ammonium, p=0.0006 for rapid onset) and high daily doses of 5-FU (9 patients receiving 2600 or 1800 mg/m2; p=0.0001 for higher plasma ammonium, p < 0.0001 for rapid onset) were significantly associated with higher plasma ammonium concentrations and faster encephalopathy development. Importantly, 25 of 32 episodes (78%) saw a return to normal plasma ammonium levels and mental status within two days following effective management. This study concludes that continuous 5-FU infusion can precipitate hyperammonemic encephalopathy. Given the frequent co-occurrence of azotemia, dehydration, and bacterial infections, clinicians should be vigilant for this condition in patients receiving continuous 5-FU.

The Therapeutic Potential of GEM-P Chemotherapy in Recurrent Hodgkin Lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) typically responds well to chemotherapy; however, for patients experiencing relapse, high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation is the preferred approach, contingent upon adequate disease control achieved through salvage chemotherapy. Conventional regimens are often administered inpatient and are associated with significant toxicity, posing challenges for delivery. Gemcitabine and cisplatin demonstrate efficacy in HL, exhibit distinct toxicity profiles from first-line agents, and can potentially be administered in an outpatient setting. This retrospective, single-centre analysis enrolled 41 eligible patients (median age 27) with relapsed or refractory HL who received gemcitabine 1,000 mg/m on days 1, 8, and 15; methylprednisolone 1,000 mg on days 1-5; and cisplatin 100 mg/m on day 15, on a 28-day cycle (GEM-P). Demographic, survival, response, and toxicity data were collected. A total of 122 cycles of GEM-P were given (median 3 cycles; range 1-6). Of these patients, 20 (48%) received GEM-P as second-line therapy and 11 (27%) as third-line treatment. The overall response rate (ORR) for the entire cohort was 80% (37% complete response (CR), 44% partial response), with 14 of 15 CRs confirmed as metabolic CR via PET scan, and an ORR of 85% in the 20 patients treated second-line. The most prevalent grade 3/4 toxicities were haematological, including neutropenia in 54% and thrombocytopenia in 51% of patients. With a median follow-up of 4.5 years from GEM-P initiation, 5-year progression-free survival was 46% (95% CI, 30-62%), and 5-year overall survival was 59% (95% CI, 43-74%). Fourteen of the 41 patients proceeded directly to autologous transplant. Consequently, GEM-P represents an effective salvage chemotherapy, characterized by substantial response rates, facilitating successful transplantation in suitable patients with relapsed or refractory HL.

Efficacy of GEM-P Chemotherapy in the Management of Relapsed Hodgkin Lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is known for its sensitivity to chemotherapy. However, patients who experience disease relapse typically undergo high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation, a strategy dependent on effective salvage chemotherapy to achieve adequate disease control. Currently employed regimens frequently necessitate inpatient administration and are challenging to deliver due to associated toxicities. Gemcitabine and cisplatin possess demonstrated activity in HL, exhibit non-overlapping toxicity profiles with initial chemotherapeutics, and are suitable for outpatient administration. This retrospective single-centre analysis investigated patients with relapsed or refractory HL who received the GEM-P regimen, comprising gemcitabine 1,000 mg/m on D1, D8, and D15; methylprednisolone 1,000 mg on D1-5; and cisplatin 100 mg/m on D15, administered every 28 days. Data on demographics, survival, response, and toxicity were collected from 41 eligible patients with a median age of 27 years. A total of 122 GEM-P cycles were administered (median 3 cycles; range 1-6). Twenty out of 41 patients (48%) received GEM-P as second-line treatment, while 11/41 (27%) received it as third-line therapy. The overall response rate (ORR) for the entire cohort was 80%, with complete responses (CR) observed in 37% and partial responses in 44%. Metabolic CR on PET was confirmed in 14 of 15 complete responders, and the ORR reached 85% among the 20 second-line patients. The most frequent grade 3/4 toxicities were haematological, specifically neutropenia (54%) and thrombocytopenia (51%). With a median follow-up period of 4.5 years from the commencement of GEM-P, the 5-year progression-free survival was 46% (95% CI, 30-62%), and the 5-year overall survival was 59% (95% CI, 43-74%). Fourteen of the 41 patients proceeded directly to autologous transplantation. GEM-P serves as an effective salvage chemotherapy, offering relatively high response rates and facilitating successful transplantation for appropriate patients with relapsed or refractory HL.

Data encompassing demographics, survival, response, and toxicity were systematically recorded. A total of 122 cycles of GEM-P were delivered (median 3 cycles; range 1-6). The overall response rate (ORR) for the entire patient cohort was 80% (complete response (CR) 37%, partial response 44%), with 14 out of 15 CRs confirmed as metabolic CR on PET imaging. Identification of a Somatic von Hippel-Lindau Mutation in Epididymal Clear Cell Papillary Cystadenoma. Papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis is a rare, benign lesion that can manifest sporadically or in association with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. Prior reports have not included immunohistochemical or molecular genetic analyses of the VHL gene for this condition. We describe two cases of clear cell papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis, both initially misidentified as metastatic renal cell carcinoma. Both lesions demonstrated positive immunohistochemical staining for low and intermediate molecular weight keratins (Cam 5.2 and AE1/AE3), EMA, vimentin, alpha 1-antitrypsin, and alpha 1-antichymotrypsin, while testing negative for CEA. Given the histological resemblance of clear cell papillary cystadenoma to renal cell carcinoma and their shared association with the von Hippel-Lindau disease complex, we investigated both cases for VHL gene mutations. A somatic VHL gene mutation was identified in one of the two tumors through polymerase chain reaction followed by single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis. Direct sequencing confirmed a cytosine to thymine transversion at nucleotide 694, resulting in an arginine to stop codon substitution after the sixth amino acid of exon 3. As the VHL gene is recognized as a tumor suppressor, VHL gene mutations may contribute to the initiation of tumorigenesis in sporadic epididymal cystadenomas.

Characterization of a Somatic VHL Gene Mutation in Clear Cell Papillary Cystadenoma of the Epididymis. Papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis represents an uncommon, benign growth that can arise either sporadically or as part of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. Previously, no immunohistochemical studies or molecular genetic investigations of the VHL gene have been documented for this lesion. This report details two instances of clear cell papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis, both initially confused with metastatic renal cell carcinoma. Immunohistochemical examination of both lesions revealed positivity for low and intermediate molecular weight keratins (Cam 5.2 and AE1/AE3), EMA, vimentin, alpha 1-antitrypsin, and alpha 1-antichymotrypsin, but negativity for CEA. Due to the histological similarities between clear cell papillary cystadenoma and renal cell carcinoma, and their shared involvement in the von Hippel-Lindau disease complex, we performed VHL gene mutation analysis on both cases. A somatic VHL gene mutation was detected in one of the two tumors using polymerase chain reaction followed by single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis. Subsequent direct sequencing identified a cytosine to thymine substitution at nucleotide 694, leading to the replacement of arginine with a stop codon after the sixth amino acid of exon 3. Considering the established role of the VHL gene as a tumor suppressor, VHL gene mutations might play a part in initiating tumorigenesis in sporadic epididymal cystadenomas.

Given the histological resemblance of clear cell papillary cystadenoma to renal cell carcinoma, and their common association within the von Hippel-Lindau disease complex, we subjected both cases to VHL gene mutation analysis. A somatic VHL gene mutation was identified in one of the two tumors through polymerase chain reaction followed by single-strand conformation polymorphism analysis. Direct sequencing confirmed a cytosine to thymine transversion at position 694, resulting in an arginine to stop codon conversion after the sixth amino acid of exon 3. Since the VHL gene is understood to function as a tumor suppressor, VHL gene mutations may contribute to the onset of tumorigenesis in sporadic epididymal cystadenomas.

Renal Pelvis Invasive Carcinoma Following Cyclophosphamide Treatment for Nonmalignant Disease. A 47-year-old female patient, who had right hydroureteronephrosis due to ureterovesical junction obstruction, developed gross hematuria after five years of cyclophosphamide treatment for cerebral vasculitis. A right nephroureterectomy was performed to control bleeding. The excised specimen revealed clinically occult invasive carcinoma of the renal pelvis. While cyclophosphamide is recognized for causing hemorrhagic cystitis and urine cytologic changes mimicking high-grade carcinoma, its link to urinary tract carcinoma is less acknowledged. Previous literature documents twenty cases of urinary bladder carcinoma and one prostate carcinoma associated with its use. This report presents the initial instance of renal pelvis carcinoma associated with cyclophosphamide treatment. It represents the third documented urinary tract malignancy linked to cyclophosphamide therapy for a non-malignant condition. The tumor's association with pre-existing hydroureteronephrosis implies that urinary stasis increased and extended the upper urinary tract epithelium's exposure to cyclophosphamide. Individuals considered for extended cyclophosphamide therapy should undergo routine assessment for obstructive uropathy.

Renal Toxicity Assessment of Select Antineoplastic Agents and Polychemotherapy. An investigation was conducted in Wistar rats to evaluate the nephrotoxic effects of specific antineoplastic agents, namely nitrogranulogen (NG), methotrexate (MTX), 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and cyclophosphamide (CY), administered individually or as a combination (MTX + 5-FU + CY, or CMF). Post-administration measurements included plasma and urine creatinine concentrations, as well as creatinine clearance. Histopathological examination of renal tissue was also performed. Monotherapy with MTX resulted in a statistically significant elevation (p = 0.0228) of plasma creatinine levels and a notable decrease (p = 0.0001) in creatinine clearance, compared to control subjects. Conversely, administration of NG, 5-FU, or CY alone did not induce a statistically significant increase in creatinine concentration or clearance when contrasted with the control group. In the polytherapy regimen (CMF), a statistically significant reduction (p = 0.0343) in creatinine clearance was observed, although plasma creatinine concentration did not significantly rise compared to controls. Cyclophosphamide monotherapy led to hemorrhagic cystitis in 40% of rats, a complication not observed when CY was combined with 5-FU and MTX. Renal histological alterations were identified after MTX, CY, and NG administration, but not following 5-FU or the combined MTX + 5-FU + CY regimen, relative to controls. These findings suggest that the nephrotoxicity associated with the combined MTX + 5-FU + CY regimen is diminished compared to its components in monotherapy.

Investigation into Renal Impairment Induced by Certain Chemotherapeutic Drugs and Their Combinations. Experiments in Wistar rats were designed to assess the nephrotoxic activity of the anticancer agents nitrogranulogen (NG), methotrexate (MTX), 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and cyclophosphamide (CY), administered either as single agents or in a combined regimen (MTX + 5-FU + CY, abbreviated as CMF). Following drug delivery, plasma and urinary creatinine levels, alongside creatinine clearance, were quantified. Furthermore, the kidneys underwent histopathological assessment. A significant rise (p = 0.0228) in plasma creatinine concentration and a profound reduction (p = 0.0001) in creatinine clearance were documented after MTX administration when contrasted with control animals. In contrast, NG, 5-FU, and CY given alone did not cause a statistically significant elevation in creatinine concentration or an increase in creatinine clearance compared to the non-cytostatic group. Under the CMF polytherapy protocol, a statistically significant decline (p = 0.0343) in creatinine clearance was detected, though creatinine concentration did not significantly elevate relative to controls. Hemorrhagic cystitis was induced by CY in 40% of rats when administered singly, but this adverse effect was absent when combined with 5-FU and MTX. Histological changes were evident in renal tissues of rats treated with MTX, CY, and NG; however, no such changes were observed after 5-FU or the joint MTX + 5-FU + CY treatment, in comparison to controls. Our research indicates that the collective nephrotoxicity of MTX + 5-FU + CY is lower than when these drugs are administered individually.

VHL-Sp1 Interaction and Transcriptional Repression of VEGF Promoter Activity. The von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene plays a critical role in clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) pathogenesis, with VHL mutations found in both von Hippel-Lindau disease-associated and sporadic RCCs. Elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA levels are observed in RCC and VHL disease-related tumors. This study investigated the VHL gene product's impact on VEGF expression. Transient cotransfection of VEGF promoter-luciferase constructs with a wild-type VHL (wt-VHL) vector in various cell lines, including 293 embryonic kidney and RCC lines, demonstrated that wt-VHL protein dose-dependently inhibited VEGF promoter activity by 5- to 10-fold. Deletion analysis identified a 144-bp GC-rich region within the VEGF promoter essential for VHL-mediated repression, which specifically binds the transcription factor Sp1 in nuclear extracts. Experiments in Drosophila cells showed that cotransfected VHL suppressed Sp1-mediated activation of the VEGF promoter, but not its basal activity. Coimmunoprecipitation confirmed VHL and Sp1 complex formation, and a direct interaction was established using a glutathione-S-transferase-VHL fusion protein with purified Sp1. Furthermore, endogenous VEGF mRNA levels were reduced in permanent RCC cell lines expressing wt-VHL, and nuclear run-on assays indicated that VHL regulates VEGF at least partially at the transcriptional level. These findings reveal a novel mechanism for VHL-mediated transcriptional repression through direct inhibition of Sp1, suggesting that impaired Sp1 inhibition could contribute to the pathogenesis of von Hippel-Lindau disease and RCC.

A 144-bp GC-rich region within the VEGF promoter, critical for VHL-mediated repression, was identified through deletion analysis; this region specifically binds the transcription factor Sp1 in crude nuclear extracts. In Drosophila cells, cotransfection of VHL specifically repressed Sp1-mediated activation of the VEGF promoter, leaving basal activity unaffected. Our subsequent coimmunoprecipitation experiments demonstrated that VHL and Sp1 are components of the same protein complex, and a direct interaction between VHL and Sp1 was confirmed using a glutathione-S-transferase-VHL fusion protein and purified Sp1. Additionally, endogenous VEGF mRNA levels were suppressed in permanent RCC cell lines stably expressing wt-VHL, and nuclear run-on studies suggested that VHL primarily regulates VEGF at the transcriptional level. These observations propose a new mechanism of VHL-mediated transcriptional repression through a direct inhibitory action on Sp1, implying that the loss of Sp1 inhibition may play a significant role in the pathogenesis of von Hippel-Lindau disease and RCC.

A Novel Mechanism: VHL Tumor Suppressor Gene Product Directly Represses VEGF Promoter Activity via Interaction with Sp1. The von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene (VHL) is recognized for its crucial involvement in the pathogenesis of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), with its mutations observed in both von Hippel-Lindau disease-associated and sporadic RCCs. Elevated vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) mRNA has been reported in RCC- and von Hippel-Lindau disease-associated tumors. In Drosophila cells, cotransfected VHL specifically repressed Sp1-mediated activation of the VEGF promoter, while not affecting its basal activity. Subsequent coimmunoprecipitation experiments confirmed that VHL and Sp1 are part of the same complex, and a direct interaction was demonstrated using a glutathione-S-transferase-VHL fusion protein and purified Sp1. Furthermore, endogenous VEGF mRNA levels were suppressed in permanent RCC cell lines expressing wt-VHL, and nuclear run-on assays indicated that VHL regulation of VEGF occurs at least partly at the transcriptional level. These observations substantiate a novel mechanism for VHL-mediated transcriptional repression through a direct inhibitory action on Sp1, implying that the absence of Sp1 inhibition may be significant in the pathogenesis of von Hippel-Lindau disease and RCC.

Etiological Aspects and Pathogenesis of Hepatic Neoplasms Linked to Oral Contraceptives. In recent years, an emergence of previously uncommon liver tumors has been observed in young women utilizing oral contraceptive steroids. The Registry for Liver Tumors Associated with Oral Contraceptives, housed at the University of California, Irvine, has confirmed 27 such cases. Furthermore, 44 cases are documented in the contemporary literature. A consistent histopathological diagnosis across these 71 cases encompasses focal nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, hamartoma, and hepatoma. Key statistical etiological contributors include the prolonged and uninterrupted administration of oral contraceptive steroids. The occurrence of eight fatalities and liver rupture in 18 patients underscores the grave nature of this newly recognized, potentially fatal adverse event.

Evaluation of Adriamycin's Cardiac and Potential Hematological Toxicity in Nonhuman Primates. Ten macaque monkeys were administered adriamycin via monthly intravenous injections at a dose of 12 mg/m2 (1 mg/kg). Cardiac insufficiency, specifically congestive heart failure, developed in eight of these ten monkeys at an average cumulative adriamycin dose of 310 mg/m2, which is considerably below the established human safe upper limit of 550 mg/m2. The histological examination of myocardial lesions revealed characteristics similar to those observed in human anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy. Furthermore, one of the ten monkeys was diagnosed with acute myeloblastic leukemia after receiving a total of 324 mg/m2 of adriamycin; the tenth monkey remains alive and healthy 26 months following its last drug dose. These findings suggest that adriamycin exhibits greater cardiotoxicity in monkeys compared to humans, and that leukemia may arise as a consequence of extended treatment with this agent.

Investigation into Adriamycin-Induced Cardiotoxicity and Leukemogenesis in Macaques. A cohort of ten macaque monkeys received adriamycin through monthly intravenous injections, each at 12 mg/m2 (1 mg/kg). Myocardial lesions examined histologically bore resemblance to those identified in human anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy. One monkey from the group of ten developed acute myeloblastic leukemia after accumulating 324 mg/m2 of adriamycin; the remaining tenth monkey is in good health 26 months post its final drug administration. Our results indicate that adriamycin possesses a stronger cardiotoxic effect in monkeys than in humans, and that prolonged therapy with this medication could potentially lead to leukemia.

Sustained Metformin Administration Mitigates Left Ventricular Dysfunction and TLR4 Signaling Post-Myocardial Infarction. Acute metformin treatment offers cardioprotection during myocardial infarction by dampening inflammatory responses, mediated by AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) activation. This study investigated the impact of chronic metformin pre-treatment on cardiac dysfunction and toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) activity following myocardial infarction, and their link to AMPK. Male Wistar rats (n=6 per group) were randomized into five groups: a normal control group and groups receiving isoproterenol after 14 days of twice-daily pre-treatment with 0, 25, 50, or 100 mg/kg metformin. Acute myocardial infarction was induced by subcutaneous isoproterenol (100 mg/kg) on days 13 and 14. Isoproterenol alone caused reductions in left ventricular systolic pressure and myocardial contractility, as indicated by LVdp/dtmax and LVdp/dtmin. Notably, left ventricular dysfunction was significantly attenuated in the 25 and 50 mg/kg metformin-treated groups. Metformin considerably lowered isoproterenol-induced increases in cardiac TLR4 mRNA, myeloid differentiation protein 88 (MyD88), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-), and interleukin 6 (IL-6) levels. Similar reductions were observed in serum TNF- and IL-6. Importantly, the 25 and 50 mg/kg doses proved more effective than 100 mg/kg. Myocardial phosphorylated AMPKa (p-AMPK) was substantially elevated by 25 mg/kg metformin, slightly by 50 mg/kg, but not by 100 mg/kg. In conclusion, chronic metformin pre-treatment reduces cardiac dysfunction after myocardial infarction and suppresses inflammatory responses, likely through the inhibition of TLR4 activities. This mechanism presents a potential therapeutic target for protecting infarcted myocardium.

Metformin's Chronic Cardioprotective Effects Post-Myocardial Infarction via TLR4 Signaling Inhibition. The protective effects of acute metformin treatment in myocardial infarction are attributed to its suppression of inflammation through AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) activation. The current investigation aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of metformin pre-treatment on cardiac function and toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) activation following myocardial infarction, alongside its relationship with AMPK. Male Wistar rats (n=6 per group) were allocated to five experimental groups: a normal control, and groups receiving isoproterenol after a 14-day chronic pre-treatment with 0, 25, 50, or 100 mg/kg metformin administered twice daily. Isoproterenol (100 mg/kg) was administered subcutaneously on days 13 and 14 to induce acute myocardial infarction. Isoproterenol administration alone resulted in diminished left ventricular systolic pressure and myocardial contractility, quantified by LVdp/dtmax and LVdp/dtmin. A significant reduction in left ventricular dysfunction was observed in the groups treated with 25 and 50 mg/kg of metformin. Metformin markedly reduced the isoproterenol-induced increases in cardiac levels of TLR4 mRNA, myeloid differentiation protein 88 (MyD88), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-), and interleukin 6 (IL-6). Corresponding decreases were also evident in serum TNF- and IL-6 levels. Notably, the 25 and 50 mg/kg doses demonstrated superior efficacy compared to 100 mg/kg. Myocardial phosphorylated AMPKa (p-AMPK) levels were significantly elevated by 25 mg/kg metformin, moderately by 50 mg/kg, but not by 100 mg/kg. Therefore, chronic metformin pre-treatment reduces cardiac impairment post-myocardial infarction and suppresses inflammatory responses, potentially through the suppression of TLR4 activities. This identified mechanism may serve as a therapeutic target for myocardial protection after infarction.

In Vivo Cardioprotective Effect of p300 Expression Against Apoptosis. Doxorubicin, an antineoplastic agent, is known to suppress cardiac-specific gene expression and trigger myocardial cell apoptosis. It also causes depletion of cardiac p300, a transcriptional coactivator vital for maintaining the differentiated phenotype of cardiac myocytes. The precise involvement of p300 in mitigating doxorubicin-induced apoptosis remained to be elucidated. To investigate this, transgenic mice with cardiac p300 overexpression and wild-type counterparts were administered doxorubicin. Compared to wild-type controls, the transgenic mice exhibited an elevated survival rate, along with better-preserved left ventricular function and cardiac alpha-sarcomeric actin expression. Myocardial cell apoptosis, induced by doxorubicin in wild-type mice, was absent in the transgenic cohort. Furthermore, p300 expression led to increased cardiac levels of bcl-2 and mdm-2, without affecting p53 or other members of the bcl-2 family. These findings conclusively demonstrate that the overexpression of p300 confers protection to cardiac myocytes from doxorubicin-induced apoptosis and diminishes the severity of acute heart failure in adult mice in vivo.

p300 Expression: A Shield Against Cardiac Myocyte Apoptosis In Vivo. The antitumor drug doxorubicin is recognized for its ability to downregulate cardiac-specific gene expression and provoke myocardial cell apoptosis. This drug also depletes cardiac p300, a transcriptional coactivator essential for maintaining the differentiated state of cardiac myocytes. However, the exact role of p300 in providing protection against doxorubicin-provoked apoptosis has not been established. To address this, transgenic mice engineered to overexpress p300 in the heart, alongside wild-type mice, underwent doxorubicin treatment. Relative to their wild-type littermates, transgenic mice displayed a higher survival rate, coupled with more intact left ventricular function and sustained cardiac expression of alpha-sarcomeric actin. While doxorubicin instigated myocardial cell apoptosis in wild-type mice, this effect was not observed in the transgenic animals. The presence of p300 correlated with elevated cardiac levels of bcl-2 and mdm-2, but not p53 or other bcl-2 family members. These results indicate that elevated p300 expression safeguards cardiac myocytes from doxorubicin-induced apoptosis and reduces the extent of acute heart failure in adult mice in vivo.

Cardiac p300 expression was associated with an increase in bcl-2 and mdm-2 levels, though no change was noted for p53 or other bcl-2 family components. These findings confirm that increased p300 expression effectively protects cardiac myocytes from doxorubicin-mediated apoptosis and lessens the severity of acute heart failure in adult mice in vivo.

Hydroxytyrosol's Efficacy Against Doxorubicin-Induced Cardiotoxicity in Breast Cancer Rats: Attenuation of Oxidative Stress and Mitochondrial Dysfunction. Oxidative stress contributes to various pathologies, including cancer, aging, and cardiovascular disease, and can enhance the therapeutic action of drugs like doxorubicin. Doxorubicin is known to induce considerable cardiotoxicity, characterized by elevated oxidative stress and impaired mitochondrial function. This study investigated whether the antioxidant hydroxytyrosol could mitigate doxorubicin-associated chronic cardiac toxicity in breast cancer-bearing rats. Thirty-six rats with chemically induced breast tumors were divided into four experimental groups: control, hydroxytyrosol (0.5 mg/kg, 5 days/week), doxorubicin (1 mg/kg/week), and a combination of doxorubicin and hydroxytyrosol. We analyzed cardiac cellular and mitochondrial disturbances, mitochondrial electron transport chain complexes I-IV, apoptosis-inducing factor, and markers of oxidative stress. Hydroxytyrosol significantly ameliorated the cardiac disturbances exacerbated by doxorubicin, manifesting as a reduction in the percentage of altered mitochondria and oxidative damage. These findings suggest that hydroxytyrosol enhances the mitochondrial electron transport chain. Ultimately, this research demonstrates that hydroxytyrosol safeguards rat hearts from doxorubicin-provoked damage by diminishing oxidative damage and mitochondrial alterations.

Attenuating Doxorubicin Cardiotoxicity in Breast Cancer Rats: The Role of Hydroxytyrosol in Oxidative Stress and Mitochondrial Function. These outcomes imply an enhancement of the mitochondrial electron transport chain by hydroxytyrosol. This study conclusively establishes that hydroxytyrosol protects against doxorubicin-mediated cardiac injury in rats by reducing oxidative damage and mitochondrial perturbations.

Incidence of Cardiac Toxicity with High-Dose Cyclophosphamide Chemotherapy for Metastatic Breast Cancer. Cyclophosphamide, an alkylating agent, is a frequent component of conditioning regimens; its high-dose nonhematological toxicity is cardiomyopathy. This study combined paclitaxel, melphalan, high-dose cyclophosphamide, thiotepa, and carboplatin in a triple sequential high-dose regimen for metastatic breast cancer patients. Analysis of 61 women with chemotherapy-responsive metastatic breast cancer, receiving 96-h infusional cyclophosphamide as part of this regimen, aimed to assess the association between peritransplant congestive heart failure (CHF) and pretreatment characteristics including EKG abnormalities, age, hypertension, prior cardiac history, smoking, diabetes mellitus, prior anthracyclines, and left-sided chest irradiation. Six of 61 women (10%) developed clinically reversible grade 3 CHF after infusional cyclophosphamide, with a median 31% decline in ejection fraction. This 10% incidence of transient cyclophosphamide-related cardiac toxicity is comparable to existing literature. Older age significantly correlated with CHF development, with median ages of 45 for the entire group and 59 for CHF patients. No association was found with other pretreatment characteristics. Consequently, oncologists should carefully monitor fluid balance in older patients. Routine EKG monitoring during infusional cyclophosphamide did not predict CHF development.

Cyclophosphamide, an alkylating agent, is a common component in many conditioning regimens, with high-dose use known to induce cardiomyopathy as its nonhematological dose-limiting toxicity. The current study involved a triple sequential high-dose regimen for patients with metastatic breast cancer, which included paclitaxel, melphalan, high-dose cyclophosphamide, thiotepa, and carboplatin. We analyzed 61 women with chemotherapy-responsive metastatic breast cancer who received 96-h infusional cyclophosphamide as part of this regimen to assess the relationship between peritransplant congestive heart failure (CHF) and the following pretreatment factors: EKG abnormalities, age, hypertension, prior cardiac history, smoking, diabetes mellitus, prior anthracyclines, and left-sided chest irradiation. Six of 61 women (10%) developed clinically reversible grade 3 CHF following infusional cyclophosphamide, exhibiting a median percent decline in ejection fraction of 31%. The observed 10% incidence of transient cyclophosphamide-related cardiac toxicity is comparable to previously documented figures. A significant correlation was established between older age and CHF development; median ages were 45 for the overall cohort and 59 for patients experiencing CHF. No association was identified with other pretreatment characteristics. Based on these findings, oncologists should exercise caution by carefully monitoring fluid balance in older patients. Routine EKG monitoring during infusional cyclophosphamide did not foresee CHF development.

A Comprehensive Assessment of Serological, Pathological, and Functional Manifestations in Doxorubicin-Induced Cardiotoxicity. While many effective cancer treatments induce significant cardiac morbidity, reliable biomarkers or functional indicators of early damage, critical for timely monitoring and intervention, remain elusive. This investigation employed a rat model of escalating doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiomyopathy, utilizing diverse methodologies, including cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to provide the most detailed time-course characterization to date of the serological, pathological, and functional events underpinning this toxicity. Hannover Wistar rats received 1.25 mg/kg DOX weekly for eight weeks, followed by a four-week "recovery" period without dosing. Electron microscopy of myocardial tissue revealed subcellular degeneration and notable mitochondrial alterations after only a single dose. Histopathological examination demonstrated progressive cardiomyocyte degeneration, hypertrophy/cytomegaly, and extensive vacuolation following two doses. Substantial replacement fibrosis, quantified via Sirius red staining, emerged during the off-dosing phase. Functional parameters, as evaluated by cardiac MRI (including left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), cardiac output, and E/A ratio), progressively declined, achieving statistical significance after two doses and culminating in "clinical" left ventricular dysfunction by 12 weeks. Significant elevations in peak myocardial contrast enhancement and serological cardiac troponin I (cTnI) became evident after eight doses, critically preceding the reduction of LVEF to below 50%. Troponin I levels exhibited positive correlations with both delayed and peak gadolinium contrast enhancement, histopathological grading, and diastolic dysfunction. In summary, subcellular cardiomyocyte degeneration represented the earliest detectable change, succeeded by progressive functional decline and observable histopathological manifestations. Myocardial contrast enhancement and cTnI elevations appeared later. Nevertheless, all identified indices preceded "clinical" LV dysfunction, thus meriting further investigation as potential predictive biomarkers.

Longitudinal Assessment of Multimodal Biomarkers and Pathofunctional Changes in Doxorubicin-Induced Cardiotoxicity. Despite the efficacy of many cancer therapeutics, significant cardiac morbidity remains a concern, compounded by a lack of early damage biomarkers or functional indicators suitable for patient monitoring and intervention. This research utilized a rat model of progressive doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiomyopathy, employing multiple diagnostic techniques, including cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to provide the most exhaustive time-course elucidation of the serological, pathological, and functional events associated with this toxicity to date. Hannover Wistar rats were administered 1.25 mg/kg DOX weekly for an eight-week duration, followed by a four-week non-dosing "recovery" period. Initial investigations via electron microscopy of the myocardium revealed subcellular degeneration and distinct mitochondrial changes after a singular dose. Histopathological analysis subsequently showed progressive cardiomyocyte degeneration, hypertrophy/cytomegaly, and extensive vacuolation following two doses. Extensive replacement fibrosis, quantified through Sirius red staining, developed during the recovery phase. Functional parameters derived from cardiac MRI, including left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), cardiac output, and E/A ratio, demonstrated a progressive decline, reaching statistical significance after two doses and culminating in "clinical" LV dysfunction by week 12. Notably, significant increases in peak myocardial contrast enhancement and serological cardiac troponin I (cTnI) were observed after eight doses, importantly preceding the reduction of LVEF to below 50%. Troponin I levels were found to correlate positively with delayed and peak gadolinium contrast enhancement, histopathological grading, and diastolic dysfunction. In summary, subcellular cardiomyocyte degeneration emerged as the earliest indicator, preceding progressive functional impairment and histopathological manifestations. Myocardial contrast enhancement and cTnI elevations appeared at a later stage. Critically, all observed indices occurred prior to the onset of "clinical" LV dysfunction, suggesting their promise as predictive biomarkers for further investigation.

Multi-Dimensional Analysis of Serological, Pathological, and Functional Evolution in Doxorubicin Cardiotoxicity. Despite the therapeutic efficacy of many anti-cancer agents, a major limitation is the considerable cardiac morbidity they induce, compounded by an absence of early damage biomarkers or functional indices for effective monitoring and intervention. This investigation employed a rat model of progressive doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiomyopathy, integrating various approaches, including cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to provide the most extensive characterization to date of the chronological progression of serological, pathological, and functional events underlying this toxicity. Hannover Wistar rats were administered 1.25 mg/kg DOX weekly for eight weeks, followed by a four-week "recovery" phase without treatment. Electron microscopy of myocardial tissue revealed subcellular degeneration and significant mitochondrial changes after a single dose. Subsequent histopathological analysis showed progressive cardiomyocyte degeneration, hypertrophy/cytomegaly, and extensive vacuolation after two doses. Extensive replacement fibrosis, quantified by Sirius red staining, was observed during the off-dosing period. Cardiac MRI assessments demonstrated progressive declines in functional parameters (including left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), cardiac output, and E/A ratio), reaching statistical significance after two doses and culminating in "clinical" LV dysfunction by week 12. Importantly, significant increases in peak myocardial contrast enhancement and serological cardiac troponin I (cTnI) emerged after eight doses, preceding the decline in LVEF to less than 50%. Furthermore, troponin I levels demonstrated positive correlations with delayed and peak gadolinium contrast enhancement, histopathological grading, and diastolic dysfunction. In essence, subcellular cardiomyocyte degeneration was identified as the initial marker, succeeded by a progressive functional deterioration and overt histopathological changes. Myocardial contrast enhancement and cTnI elevations appeared later in the sequence. Crucially, all evaluated indices occurred before the onset of "clinical" LV dysfunction, thereby justifying their continued investigation as potential predictive biomarkers.

A Prospective Investigation of Cardiac Monitoring during Fluorouracil Therapy. Cardiac toxicity linked to fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy has been noted anecdotally but lacks systematic examination. We conducted a prospective study utilizing continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring in 25 patients receiving 5-FU infusion for solid tumor treatment to determine the incidence of ischemic ST changes. Patients underwent monitoring for 23  4 hours pre-infusion and 98  9 hours during 5-FU administration. Anginal episodes were infrequent, with only one patient experiencing angina during infusion. However, asymptomatic ST changes (defined as 1 mm ST deviation) were prevalent: 6 of 25 patients (24%) exhibited ST changes before 5-FU infusion, compared to 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P < .002). The rate of ischemic episodes per patient per hour was 0.05  0.02 prior to 5-FU versus 0.13  0.03 during 5-FU (P < .001); the duration of ECG alterations was 0.6  0.3 minutes per patient per hour pre-5-FU compared to 1.9  0.5 minutes per patient per hour during 5-FU (P < .01). ECG changes were more common in individuals with documented coronary artery disease. Two sudden deaths were recorded, both occurring at the completion of the chemotherapy course. Our findings indicate that 5-FU infusion is associated with a notable increase in silent ST segment deviation, suggestive of ischemia, particularly in patients with coronary artery disease. The underlying mechanism and clinical importance of these ECG changes warrant further investigation.

Cardiac Ischemic Events During Fluorouracil Chemotherapy: A Prospective Monitoring Study. Despite anecdotal reports of cardiac toxicity associated with fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy, this phenomenon has not been rigorously investigated. Our prospective study employed continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring in 25 patients undergoing 5-FU infusion for solid tumor treatment, aiming to evaluate the occurrence of ischemic ST segment alterations. Monitoring periods spanned 23  4 hours before 5-FU infusion and 98  9 hours during the infusion. Angina was rare, observed in only one patient during 5-FU administration. Conversely, asymptomatic ST changes (defined as 1 mm ST deviation) were frequent: 6 out of 25 patients (24%) showed ST changes prior to 5-FU infusion, escalating to 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P < .002). The incidence of ischemic episodes per patient per hour increased from 0.05  0.02 before 5-FU to 0.13  0.03 during 5-FU (P < .001); the mean duration of ECG changes per patient per hour rose from 0.6  0.3 minutes before 5-FU to 1.9  0.5 minutes during 5-FU (P < .01). Patients with established coronary artery disease exhibited ECG changes more frequently. Two instances of sudden death occurred, both towards the end of the chemotherapy regimen. We conclude that 5-FU infusion correlates with a significant rise in silent ST segment deviation indicative of ischemia, especially in patients with coronary artery disease. The mechanism and clinical implications of these ECG observations require further elucidation.

Prospective Assessment of ST Segment Changes with Ambulatory ECG during Fluorouracil Treatment. Cardiac toxicity linked to fluorouracil (5-FU) treatment has been anecdotally reported but not systematically evaluated. We prospectively conducted continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring on 25 patients receiving 5-FU infusion for solid tumors to assess the incidence of ischemic ST changes. Patients were monitored for an average of 23  4 hours before 5-FU infusion and 98  9 hours during the infusion. Anginal episodes were uncommon, with only one patient experiencing angina during 5-FU infusion. However, asymptomatic ST changes (defined as 1 mm ST deviation) were frequently observed: 6 of 25 patients (24%) exhibited ST changes before 5-FU infusion, compared to 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P < .002). The incidence of ischemic episodes per patient per hour was 0.05  0.02 pre-5-FU infusion versus 0.13  0.03 during 5-FU infusion (P < .001); the duration of ECG changes was 0.6  0.3 minutes per patient per hour before 5-FU versus 1.9  0.5 minutes per patient per hour during 5-FU (P < .01). ECG changes were more pronounced in patients with diagnosed coronary artery disease. Two cases of sudden death occurred, both at the completion of their chemotherapy course. Our conclusion is that 5-FU infusion significantly increases silent ST segment deviation, indicative of ischemia, particularly among individuals with coronary artery disease. The exact mechanism and clinical significance of these observed ECG alterations are yet to be determined.

Cardiovascular Effects of Fluorouracil Therapy: A Prospective Ambulatory ECG Study. Reports of cardiac toxicity associated with fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy are largely anecdotal, lacking systematic investigation. To address this, we prospectively employed continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring in 25 patients undergoing 5-FU infusion for solid tumor treatment, aiming to ascertain the incidence of ischemic ST segment changes. Monitoring extended for 23  4 hours preceding 5-FU infusion and 98  9 hours throughout 5-FU administration. Anginal episodes proved rare, with only a single patient reporting angina during 5-FU infusion. In contrast, asymptomatic ST changes (defined as 1 mm ST deviation) were common: 6 of 25 patients (24%) showed ST changes before 5-FU infusion, increasing to 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P < .002). The incidence of ischemic episodes per patient per hour was 0.05  0.02 prior to 5-FU infusion compared to 0.13  0.03 during 5-FU infusion (P < .001); the average duration of ECG changes per patient per hour was 0.6  0.3 minutes before 5-FU versus 1.9  0.5 minutes during 5-FU (P < .01). ECG abnormalities were observed more frequently in patients with pre-existing coronary artery disease. There were two occurrences of sudden death, both at the conclusion of the chemotherapy course. We conclude that 5-FU infusion is significantly linked to an elevation in silent ST segment deviation suggestive of ischemia, particularly in patients with coronary artery disease. The specific mechanism and clinical relevance of these ECG findings necessitate further study.

The Effect of Administration Timing on monoHER's Cardioprotection Against Doxorubicin-Induced Toxicity in Mice. Doxorubicin (DOX), an effective yet cardiotoxic chemotherapeutic, causes cardiac damage primarily through free radical formation, particularly affecting cardiac myocytes due to their limited antioxidant defenses. Monohydroxyethylrutoside (monoHER), a semisynthetic flavonoid, has demonstrated cardioprotective properties against DOX-induced cardiotoxicity by scavenging radicals and chelating iron. Given monoHER's relatively short terminal half-life (approximately 30 min), the interval between its administration and DOX delivery was hypothesized to influence its protective efficacy. This study aimed to investigate this relationship. Six groups, each comprising 6 BALB/c mice, received either saline, DOX alone, or DOX (4 mg/kg i.v.) preceded by monoHER (500 mg/kg i.p.) at intervals of 10, 30, 60, or 120 min. Following a 6-week treatment and a 2-week observation period, mice were euthanized. Cardiac tissues underwent light microscopy to assess cardiomyocyte damage using the Billingham method (1978). Microscopic analysis revealed that DOX alone significantly increased cardiac damage compared to the saline control group (P<0.001). Specifically, the count of damaged cardiomyocytes was 9.6-fold higher (95% CI 4.4-21.0) in DOX-treated mice than in controls. When monoHER preceded DOX, the ratio of aberrant cardiomyocytes relative to saline-treated mice ranged from 1.6 to 2.8 (mean 2.2, 95% CI 1.2-4.1, P=0.019). Overall, monoHER administration before DOX resulted in a significant 4.4-fold reduction (P<0.001, 95% CI 2.3-8.2) in abnormal cardiomyocytes. Importantly, this cardioprotective effect was independent of the time interval between monoHER and DOX administration (P=0.345). These findings suggest that monoHER can be administered shortly before DOX in a clinical outpatient setting.

Interval Dependence of Monohydroxyethylrutoside's Cardioprotective Efficacy Against Doxorubicin-Induced Damage in Mice. Despite its acknowledged cardiotoxic profile, the anthracycline doxorubicin (DOX) remains a vital and extensively employed chemotherapeutic agent. DOX-induced cardiac impairment is presumed to stem from free radical generation, with reactive oxygen species particularly impacting cardiac myocytes due to their apparently limited antioxidant defense mechanisms. Monohydroxyethylrutoside (monoHER), a semisynthetic flavonoid, has exhibited cardioprotection against DOX-induced cardiotoxicity via its radical scavenging and iron chelating properties. Given monoHER's relatively brief final half-life (approximately 30 minutes), the time separation between monoHER and DOX administrations was hypothesized to modulate its protective action. Therefore, this investigation sought to determine this potential influence. Six groups, each comprising 6 BALB/c mice, were administered either saline, DOX solely, or DOX (4 mg/kg i.v.) following monoHER (500 mg/kg i.p.) at intervals of 10, 30, 60, or 120 minutes. After a 6-week treatment regimen and an additional 2-week observation period, the mice were humanely sacrificed. Their cardiac tissues underwent processing for light microscopy, followed by an assessment of cardiomyocyte damage according to Billingham (1978). Microscopic assessment confirmed that treatment with DOX alone caused significant cardiac injury when contrasted with the saline control group (P<0.001). The quantity of damaged cardiomyocytes was found to be 9.6-fold greater (95% CI 4.4-21.0) in mice receiving only DOX compared to control animals. The proportion of abnormal cardiomyocytes in mice treated with monoHER prior to DOX, relative to those given saline, spanned from 1.6 to 2.8 (mean 2.2, 95% CI 1.2-4.1, P=0.019). The average protective effect achieved by administering monoHER before DOX led to a significant 4.4-fold reduction (P<0.001, 95% CI 2.3-8.2) in aberrant cardiomyocytes. Crucially, this protective efficacy showed no dependency on the time interval separating monoHER and DOX administration (P=0.345). These findings suggest that monoHER could be administered shortly preceding DOX in an outpatient clinical context.

Monohydroxyethylrutoside (monoHER), a semisynthetic flavonoid, has demonstrated effective cardioprotection against DOX-induced cardiotoxicity through its dual actions of radical scavenging and iron chelation. Crucially, this protective benefit exhibited no dependence on the duration of the interval between monoHER and DOX administrations (P=0.345). WT1 gene constitutional mutations in Denys-Drash syndrome patients. Denys-Drash syndrome (DDS) is characterized by a distinctive nephropathy, genitourinary anomalies, and an increased susceptibility to Wilms tumor, leading to eventual end-stage renal failure. The WT1 gene, a candidate Wilms tumor gene situated in the 11p13 chromosomal region, was recently isolated. We conducted DNA sequence analysis on constitutional cells from eight patients, identifying heterozygous mutations in six individuals. Four of these mutations were located in exon 9, all being missense alterations. Specifically, three occurred at nucleotide position 1180, resulting in an arginine to tryptophan amino acid substitution, while the other was at position 1186, converting aspartic acid to asparagine in the predicted protein. One patient presented with a missense mutation in exon 8, changing arginine to histidine. In the final patient, a single base pair insertion at nucleotide position 821 within exon 6 led to the formation of a premature stop codon. Despite comprehensive genomic sequencing of the gene, no mutation was detected in one patient. The remaining patient exhibited a constitutional deletion of the 11p13 region, with no further mutations identified. No clear correlation was observed between the mutation type and the clinical phenotype. These findings further underscore the critical role of the WT1 gene in both renal and genitourinary system development.

Denys-Drash syndrome is defined by a characteristic nephropathy, genital malformations, and an increased propensity for Wilms tumor development, ultimately progressing to end-stage renal failure.
