Novel Manifestation of Hypotension-Associated Cardiotoxicity in Three Patients Receiving Cisplatin and 5-Fluorouracil. Cardiac symptoms, notably hypotension, emerged in three advanced colorectal carcinoma patients undergoing treatment with cisplatin (CDDP) and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). Two of these patients exhibited severe left ventricular dysfunction concurrent with hypotension. All three necessitated treatment cessation. Despite transient electrocardiographic (EKG) alterations, cardiac enzyme levels remained within normal limits. The clinical presentation and comprehensive cardiac assessments (hemodynamic, echocardiographic, and scintigraphic) in these individuals imply previously unrecognised manifestations of 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, potentially modulated by CDDP. Underlying pathophysiologic mechanisms are explored.

Cisplatin and 5-Fluorouracil Treatment: A Case Series on Hypotension as a Cardiotoxic Event. Three patients with advanced colorectal carcinoma developed cardiac symptoms, including a significant drop in blood pressure (hypotension), during therapy with cisplatin (CDDP) and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). In two instances, hypotension was accompanied by profound left ventricular impairment. Discontinuation of treatment was required for all three individuals. Despite the presence of transient electrocardiographic (EKG) abnormalities, cardiac enzyme levels stayed normal. The clinical picture and cardiac diagnostic findings (hemodynamic, echocardiographic, and scintigraphic) in these cases suggest novel forms of 5-FU cardiotoxicity, possibly exacerbated by CDDP. Potential pathophysiologic processes are discussed.

Cardiotoxicity Presenting as Hypotension in Three Patients Exposed to Cisplatin and 5-Fluorouracil. Three patients diagnosed with advanced colorectal carcinoma experienced cardiac manifestations, including hypotension, while receiving a regimen of cisplatin (CDDP) and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). For two of these patients, hypotension was directly linked to severe left ventricular dysfunction. All three patients necessitated the cessation of their therapeutic regimen. Cardiac enzyme tests yielded normal results, notwithstanding concurrent transient electrocardiographic (EKG) changes. The collective presentation and comprehensive cardiac evaluations (hemodynamic, echocardiographic, and scintigraphic) for these patients imply novel forms of 5-FU cardiotoxicity, potentially influenced by the co-administration of CDDP. The prospective pathophysiologic mechanisms are explored in detail.

Unexpected Hypotensive Cardiotoxicity Observed in Three Patients Treated with Cisplatin and 5-Fluorouracil. Cardiac symptoms, specifically hypotension, arose in three patients afflicted with advanced colorectal carcinoma who were undergoing treatment with cisplatin (CDDP) and 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). In two cases, the hypotension coincided with profound left ventricular impairment. All three individuals subsequently required the interruption of their chemotherapy. Despite transient electrocardiographic (EKG) abnormalities, cardiac enzyme levels remained within the normal range. The clinical features and the results from cardiac investigations (hemodynamic, echocardiographic, and scintigraphic) in these patients indicate previously unrecognised manifestations of 5-FU cardiotoxicity, which may be potentiated by CDDP. A discussion of the possible underlying pathophysiologic mechanisms is provided.

Underlying Molecular Mechanism of Chromosome 22q11 Rearrangement Disorders. The 22q11 chromosomal region is vulnerable to rearrangements implicated in congenital anomaly disorders and malignant tumors. Specific congenital conditions, namely cat-eye syndrome, der(22) syndrome, and velo-cardio-facial syndrome/DiGeorge syndrome (VCFS/DGS), are linked to tetrasomy, trisomy, or monosomy, respectively, of a segment of 22q11. VCFS/DGS represents the most prevalent syndrome associated with 22q11 rearrangements. To ascertain whether particular 22q11 regions exhibit rearrangement susceptibility, deletion endpoints were precisely mapped in numerous VCFS/DGS patients via haplotype analysis. A 3 Mb deletion is observed in the majority of VCFS/DGS patients, while some exhibit a nested distal deletion breakpoint resulting in a 1.5 Mb deletion, and a small number of patients possess distinct deletions or translocations. The significant population prevalence and largely sporadic nature of these cases imply that sequences at or near breakpoints confer a predisposition to chromosomal rearrangements. Investigating this, we developed hamster-human somatic hybrid cell lines from VCFS/DGS patients encompassing all three deletion categories. Our findings demonstrate that these breakpoints consistently lie within similar low copy repeats, designated LCR22s. Further reinforcing this concept, we identified a family presenting with an interstitial duplication of the identical 3 Mb region commonly deleted in VCFS/DGS patients. We propose models illustrating how LCR22s can facilitate diverse homologous recombination events, thereby producing the array of rearrangements associated with congenital anomaly disorders. Furthermore, five additional LCR22 copies were identified on 22q11, potentially mediating other disease-causing rearrangements.

Shared Genetic Basis for Chromosome 22q11 Rearrangement-Associated Syndromes. The 22q11 chromosomal region is predisposed to rearrangements connected with congenital malformation syndromes and oncological conditions. Tetrasomy, trisomy, or monosomy of a portion of 22q11 are, respectively, linked to three congenital anomaly disorders: cat-eye syndrome, der(22) syndrome, and velo-cardio-facial syndrome/DiGeorge syndrome (VCFS/DGS). VCFS/DGS is the most frequently occurring syndrome involving 22q11 rearrangements. To determine specific regions within 22q11 prone to rearrangements, haplotype analysis was employed to define deletion endpoints in a substantial cohort of VCFS/DGS patients. The predominant observation in VCFS/DGS patients is a 3 Mb deletion, with some exhibiting a nested distal deletion breakpoint leading to a 1.5 Mb deletion, and rare individuals presenting unique deletions or translocations. The high incidence of the disorder in the population and its largely sporadic occurrence suggest that sequences at or near breakpoints are responsible for susceptibility to chromosomal rearrangements. To explore this, we generated hamster-human somatic hybrid cell lines from VCFS/DGS patients representing all three classes of deletions. Our results reveal that the breakpoints are situated within conserved low copy repeats, termed LCR22s. This notion is further supported by the identification of a family with an interstitial duplication of the same 3 Mb region found deleted in VCFS/DGS patients. We present models explaining how LCR22s facilitate various homologous recombination events, thereby giving rise to numerous rearrangements linked to congenital anomaly disorders. We also located five additional LCR22 copies on 22q11 that may mediate further disease-related rearrangements.

LCR22s as a Unifying Molecular Basis for Chromosome 22q11 Rearrangement Disorders. The chromosome 22q11 region is prone to rearrangements linked to congenital anomaly disorders and malignant tumors. Three congenital anomaly disorderscat-eye syndrome, der(22) syndrome, and velo-cardio-facial syndrome/DiGeorge syndrome (VCFS/DGS)are associated with tetrasomy, trisomy, or monosomy, respectively, for a segment of chromosome 22q11. VCFS/DGS is the most prevalent syndrome related to 22q11 rearrangements. To investigate whether particular regions on 22q11 are susceptible to rearrangements, deletion endpoints were characterized through haplotype analysis in a substantial number of VCFS/DGS patients. The majority of VCFS/DGS patients exhibit a consistent 3 Mb deletion, while some display a nested distal deletion breakpoint resulting in a 1.5 Mb deletion, and a few rare cases involve unique deletions or translocations. The high population prevalence of the condition and its predominantly sporadic nature indicate that sequences located at or near breakpoints confer susceptibility to chromosomal rearrangements. To test this hypothesis, we established hamster-human somatic hybrid cell lines from VCFS/DGS patients representing all three deletion types. Our findings demonstrate that these breakpoints occur within analogous low copy repeats, designated LCR22s. This concept is further substantiated by the identification of a family carrying an interstitial duplication of the identical 3 Mb region that is typically deleted in VCFS/DGS patients. We propose mechanistic models detailing how LCR22s can mediate diverse homologous recombination events, thereby generating the range of rearrangements associated with congenital anomaly disorders. Furthermore, five additional copies of the LCR22 were identified on 22q11, potentially mediating other disease-causing rearrangements.

Elucidating the Molecular Basis of Chromosome 22q11 Rearrangement Disorders. The chromosome 22q11 region demonstrates a propensity for rearrangements, which are implicated in congenital anomaly disorders and malignant tumors. Specifically, cat-eye syndrome, der(22) syndrome, and velo-cardio-facial syndrome/DiGeorge syndrome (VCFS/DGS) are three congenital anomaly disorders linked to tetrasomy, trisomy, or monosomy, respectively, of a segment of chromosome 22q11. VCFS/DGS stands as the most frequent syndrome associated with 22q11 rearrangements. To ascertain the presence of particular regions on 22q11 that are prone to rearrangements, deletion endpoints were precisely determined in numerous VCFS/DGS patients via haplotype analysis. Most VCFS/DGS patients exhibit a consistent 3 Mb deletion, with some displaying a nested distal deletion breakpoint leading to a 1.5 Mb deletion, and a small number of rare patients possessing unique deletions or translocations. The disorder's high prevalence in the population and its largely sporadic occurrence suggest that sequences at or in proximity to the breakpoints confer susceptibility to chromosome rearrangements. To investigate this supposition, we created hamster-human somatic hybrid cell lines from VCFS/DGS patients featuring all three categories of deletions. Our current results indicate that the breakpoints reside within similar low copy repeats, termed LCR22s. To further support this finding, we identified a family that exhibits an interstitial duplication of the identical 3 Mb region typically deleted in VCFS/DGS patients. We present models illustrating how the LCR22s can facilitate various homologous recombination events, thereby producing a spectrum of rearrangements associated with congenital anomaly disorders. Additionally, five other copies of the LCR22 were identified on 22q11, which may mediate further rearrangements contributing to disease.

The utility of brain natriuretic peptide in predicting anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity. Anthracyclines, despite their efficacy as antineoplastic agents, frequently induce dose-dependent cardiotoxicity. This necessitates the identification of highly sensitive methods for predicting cardiac dysfunction. Our investigation aimed to ascertain if plasma brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels could serve as a straightforward diagnostic marker for cardiotoxicity resulting from anthracycline treatment in acute leukemia patients receiving a daunorubicin (DNR)-containing regimen. Thirteen patients diagnosed with acute leukemia underwent a DNR-containing treatment. Radionuclide angiography was employed to assess cardiac functions prior to chemotherapy. Plasma levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and BNP were quantified concurrently with the radionuclide angiography. Following chemotherapy completion, three patients experienced congestive heart failure, and five others were diagnosed with subclinical heart failure. In all patients who developed either clinical or subclinical heart failure, plasma BNP levels rose above the normal threshold of 40 pg/ml before heart failure was detectable via radionuclide angiography. Conversely, BNP levels did not increase in patients who did not develop heart failure, even when administered DNR doses exceeding 700 mg/m. Atrial natriuretic peptide levels did not consistently rise in all patients presenting with clinical and subclinical heart failure. These preliminary findings suggest that BNP may function as an early and sensitive indicator of cardiotoxicity induced by anthracyclines.

Predictive significance of brain natriuretic peptide for anthracycline cardiotoxicity. Anthracycline agents are potent antineoplastic drugs, yet they commonly provoke dose-related cardiotoxicity. The cardiac toxicity associated with conventional anthracycline therapy underscores the critical need for highly sensitive techniques capable of foreseeing cardiac impairment. We evaluated the plasma concentration of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) to determine its potential as a simple diagnostic predictor of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity in patients with acute leukemia undergoing a daunorubicin (DNR)-based regimen. Thirteen acute leukemia patients received a DNR-containing treatment. Cardiac performance was assessed using radionuclide angiography prior to their chemotherapy. Plasma concentrations of both atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and BNP were measured at the time of radionuclide angiography. Post-chemotherapy, three patients developed congestive heart failure, and five patients were identified with subclinical heart failure. For all patients who experienced either clinical or subclinical heart failure, plasma BNP levels elevated beyond the normal limit (40 pg/ml) before radionuclide angiography detected these conditions. In contrast, BNP levels did not increase in patients without heart failure who received DNR, even at doses greater than 700 mg/m. The plasma level of ANP did not consistently increase across all patients manifesting clinical and subclinical heart failure. These initial observations suggest that BNP could be valuable as an early and sensitive marker for cardiotoxicity induced by anthracyclines.

Brain natriuretic peptide as a biomarker for anthracycline-associated cardiac dysfunction. Effective antineoplastic agents, anthracyclines, frequently lead to dose-dependent cardiotoxicity. The prevalence of cardiotoxicity with standard anthracycline treatment necessitates the discovery of highly sensitive methods for anticipating cardiac compromise. Our study aimed to assess the plasma concentration of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) to determine if it could serve as an uncomplicated diagnostic indicator of cardiotoxicity induced by anthracyclines in individuals with acute leukemia receiving a daunorubicin (DNR)-containing treatment. A cohort of thirteen acute leukemia patients was treated with a DNR-containing regimen. Cardiac function was evaluated through radionuclide angiography before the initiation of chemotherapy. Plasma levels of both atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and BNP were quantified concurrently with the radionuclide angiography. Following the completion of chemotherapy, three patients manifested congestive heart failure, and five patients were diagnosed with subclinical heart failure. In all patients exhibiting clinical or subclinical heart failure, plasma BNP levels surpassed the normal threshold of 40 pg/ml prior to the detection of heart failure, clinical or subclinical, by radionuclide angiography. Conversely, BNP levels remained unchanged in patients who did not develop heart failure despite receiving DNR, even at cumulative doses exceeding 700 mg/m. Plasma ANP levels did not invariably rise in all patients with clinical and subclinical heart failure. These preliminary findings indicate that BNP may be a useful, early, and sensitive prognosticator for anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.

An early indicator role for brain natriuretic peptide in anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity. Anthracyclines represent potent antineoplastic medications, yet they are commonly associated with dose-related cardiotoxicity. The cardiac toxicity inherent in conventional anthracycline therapy highlights an urgent need for highly sensitive predictive tools for cardiac dysfunction. We investigated the plasma concentration of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) to establish its potential as a straightforward diagnostic marker for cardiotoxicity caused by anthracyclines in patients with acute leukemia on a daunorubicin (DNR)-containing regimen. Thirteen patients diagnosed with acute leukemia were administered a DNR-containing treatment. Cardiac functions were assessed using radionuclide angiography before their chemotherapies began. Plasma levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and BNP were measured at the same time as the radionuclide angiography. Three patients subsequently developed congestive heart failure, and five patients were diagnosed with subclinical heart failure after their chemotherapy courses were completed. The plasma BNP levels in all patients presenting with either clinical or subclinical heart failure increased above the normal limit (40 pg/ml) before these conditions were identified by radionuclide angiography. In contrast, BNP levels did not elevate in patients who did not experience heart failure following DNR, even at doses greater than 700 mg/m. The plasma level of ANP did not consistently show an increase in all patients experiencing clinical and subclinical heart failure. These initial results suggest that BNP could serve as an effective early and sensitive indicator of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.

A novel case of sorafenib-associated acute myocardial infarction stemming from coronary artery spasm. A 65-year-old male with advanced renal cell carcinoma presented with persistent resting chest pain, two weeks after initiating sorafenib. He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction via laboratory results and electrocardiogram, further supported by subendocardial infarction on enhanced cardiac magnetic resonance imaging. Despite no angiographic evidence of coronary artery stenosis, a provocative test confirmed coronary artery spasm. Discontinuation of sorafenib, along with calcium-channel blocker and nitrate administration, alleviated his symptoms, though a recurrence ensued upon restarting sorafenib. Subsequent incorporation of oral nicorandil mitigated symptoms and maintained stable angina. This represents the initial report of sorafenib-induced coronary artery spasm. Sorafenib, a multikinase inhibitor, targets pathways crucial for cell proliferation and survival. Given the significant role of the Rho/ROCK pathway in coronary artery spasm, this case suggests a potential adverse impact of sorafenib on this pathway.

Sorafenib-associated coronary vasospasm leading to acute myocardial infarction. A 65-year-old male, undergoing treatment for advanced renal cell carcinoma, developed persistent chest pain at rest two weeks after beginning sorafenib therapy. Investigations, including laboratory findings, electrocardiography, and enhanced cardiac magnetic resonance imaging, confirmed non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction with subendocardial involvement. Coronary angiography revealed no significant stenoses, but a provocative test successfully induced coronary artery spasm. The patient's symptoms improved following sorafenib withdrawal and treatment with calcium-channel blockers and nitrates, though they recurred upon reintroduction of the drug. The addition of oral nicorandil subsequently stabilized his angina. This constitutes the first documented instance of acute myocardial infarction attributed to sorafenib-induced coronary artery spasm. Sorafenib functions as a multikinase inhibitor, interfering with essential cellular proliferation and survival pathways. Considering the established role of the Rho/ROCK pathway in coronary artery spasm pathophysiology, this report implies a possible detrimental effect of sorafenib on this mechanism.

Acute myocardial infarction secondary to sorafenib-triggered coronary artery spasm. A 65-year-old man with advanced renal cell carcinoma presented with persistent chest discomfort at rest, commencing two weeks after sorafenib initiation. He received a diagnosis of non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, supported by laboratory markers, electrocardiography, and subendocardial infarction visualized on enhanced cardiac magnetic resonance imaging. Angiography showed no coronary artery stenosis; however, a provocative test confirmed coronary artery spasm. Withdrawal of sorafenib and treatment with calcium channel blockers and nitrates led to symptom improvement, although symptoms reappeared upon re-exposure to sorafenib. Subsequent integration of oral nicorandil diminished his symptoms, achieving a stable angina status. This is the initial report documenting sorafenib as a cause of coronary artery spasm. Sorafenib functions as a multikinase inhibitor, impacting signaling pathways vital for cell proliferation and survival. Given the critical role of the Rho/ROCK pathway in coronary artery spasm pathogenesis, our findings suggest a potential adverse influence of sorafenib on this pathway.

Acute myocardial infarction and coronary artery spasm linked to sorafenib administration. A 65-year-old male with advanced renal cell carcinoma developed ongoing chest pain at rest, two weeks following the initiation of sorafenib. He was diagnosed with a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction based on laboratory results and electrocardiogram findings, corroborated by subendocardial infarction identified on enhanced cardiac magnetic resonance imaging. Despite no evidence of coronary artery stenosis on angiography, a provocative test successfully induced coronary artery spasm. His symptoms improved upon sorafenib discontinuation and treatment with calcium-channel blockers and nitrates, but relapsed when sorafenib was resumed. The subsequent addition of oral nicorandil led to symptom reduction and a stable angina state. This case represents the first report of sorafenib-induced coronary artery spasm. Sorafenib is a multikinase inhibitor, interfering with signaling pathways essential for cellular proliferation and survival. Considering the critical role of the Rho/ROCK pathway in coronary artery spasm pathogenesis, this report suggests a possible adverse effect of sorafenib on this pathway.

Initial Infectious Complications in Kidney, Cardiac, and Hepatic Transplant Recipients Receiving Cyclosporine Immunosuppression. This study monitored infectious complications in 81 renal, 17 cardiac, and 24 hepatic transplant patients. A randomized trial involving 17 renal patients receiving azathioprine (Aza) and prednisone was compared with 21 renal patients treated with cyclosporine and prednisone. All other participants were given cyclosporine and prednisone. The Aza-treated renal patients in the randomized trial experienced a higher incidence of overall infections (P < 0.05) and nonviral infections (P < 0.02) compared to their cyclosporine-treated counterparts. Cardiac and hepatic transplant patients showed more infections than cyclosporine-treated renal patients but fewer than Aza-treated renal patients. No infectious fatalities were observed among renal transplant patients on either cyclosporine or Aza. However, infection was a significant factor in 3 of 6 cardiac transplant deaths and 8 of 9 hepatic transplant deaths. Cyclosporine-treated renal patients presented with the lowest frequency of bacteremias. Analysis of infection sites revealed predominantly abdominal infections in liver recipients, intrathoracic infections in heart recipients, and urinary tract infections in kidney recipients. Pulmonary infections were less prevalent in cyclosporine-treated renal patients than in Aza-treated patients (P < 0.05). Aza patients demonstrated significantly more staphylococcal infections than all other transplant cohorts (P < 0.005), with systemic fungal infections exclusively occurring in the liver transplant group. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) shedding, serological antibody titer increases, or both were detected in 78% of cyclosporine patients and 76% of Aza patients. Of the cyclosporine cohort, 15% developed symptoms associated with CMV infection. Serological evidence for Epstein Barr Virus infection was identified in 20% of 65 cyclosporine patients studied, with three experiencing related symptoms and one progressing to lymphoma.

Post-Transplant Infection Patterns in Kidney, Heart, and Liver Graft Recipients Under Cyclosporine Therapy. A cohort comprising 81 renal, 17 cardiac, and 24 hepatic transplant patients was followed to assess infection incidence. Within a randomized immunosuppression trial, 17 renal patients received azathioprine (Aza) and prednisone, while 21 renal patients were administered cyclosporine and prednisone. All remaining patients received cyclosporine and prednisone. The Aza group in the randomized trial experienced a greater number of total infections (P < 0.05) and nonviral infections (P < 0.02) compared to the cyclosporine group. Heart and liver transplant recipients had more infections than renal patients on cyclosporine, but fewer infections than renal patients on Aza. No infection-related mortalities occurred among renal transplant patients, regardless of whether they received cyclosporine or Aza. However, infection played a major contributory role in 3 out of 6 cardiac transplant deaths and 8 out of 9 liver transplant deaths. Cyclosporine-treated renal patients exhibited the lowest rates of bacteremia. Site-specific infection analysis revealed a predominance of abdominal infections among liver patients, intrathoracic infections in heart patients, and urinary tract infections in renal patients. Pulmonary infections were observed less frequently in cyclosporine-treated renal patients than in Aza-treated patients (P < 0.05). Staphylococcal infections were significantly more common in Aza patients compared to all other transplant groups (P < 0.005). Systemic fungal infections were exclusively confined to the liver transplant cohort. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) shedding or seroconversion (or both) was present in 78% of cyclosporine patients and 76% of Aza patients, with 15% of cyclosporine patients manifesting CMV-related symptoms. Serological evidence of Epstein Barr Virus infection was detected in 20% of 65 cyclosporine patients evaluated; three of these patients presented with symptoms, and one subsequently developed lymphoma.

Infection Epidemiology in Organ Transplant Recipients Receiving Cyclosporine Immunosuppression. The incidence of infection was investigated in 81 renal, 17 cardiac, and 24 hepatic transplant patients. A randomized comparison involved 17 renal patients on azathioprine (Aza) and prednisone versus 21 renal patients on cyclosporine and prednisone. All other patients were treated with cyclosporine and prednisone. Randomized Aza-treated renal patients exhibited a higher frequency of overall infections (P < 0.05) and nonviral infections (P < 0.02) when compared to randomized cyclosporine-treated renal patients. Cardiac and hepatic transplant recipients experienced more infections than cyclosporine-treated renal patients but fewer than Aza-treated renal patients. No infection-associated mortalities were recorded among renal transplant patients, whether on cyclosporine or Aza. However, infection was a principal factor in 3 of 6 cardiac transplant deaths and 8 of 9 liver transplant deaths. Renal patients receiving cyclosporine had the lowest incidence of bacteremia. Site analysis revealed that abdominal infections predominated in liver patients, intrathoracic infections in heart patients, and urinary tract infections in renal patients. Pulmonary infections were less common among cyclosporine-treated renal patients than Aza-treated patients (P < 0.05). Aza patients showed a significantly higher prevalence of staphylococcal infections than all other transplant groups (P < 0.005), and systemic fungal infections were exclusively found in the liver transplant cohort. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) shedding or serological antibody titer elevation, or both, affected 78% of cyclosporine patients and 76% of Aza patients. Fifteen percent of cyclosporine patients manifested CMV-related symptoms. Serological evidence for Epstein Barr Virus infection was identified in 20% of 65 cyclosporine patients examined; three had concurrent symptoms, and one subsequently developed lymphoma.

Initial Post-Transplant Infection Rates and Characteristics Across Kidney, Cardiac, and Hepatic Recipients on Cyclosporine. Infection surveillance was conducted on 81 renal, 17 cardiac, and 24 hepatic transplant patients. A subset of renal patients participated in a randomized immunosuppression trial: 17 received azathioprine (Aza) and prednisone, while 21 received cyclosporine and prednisone. All other patients were on cyclosporine and prednisone. Randomly assigned Aza renal patients experienced a greater burden of overall infections (P < 0.05) and nonviral infections (P < 0.02) compared to randomly assigned cyclosporine renal patients. Cardiac and hepatic patients registered more infections than renal patients receiving cyclosporine but fewer than renal patients on Aza. No infection-related deaths were recorded in renal transplant patients treated with cyclosporine or Aza. However, infection was a major contributor to 3 of 6 cardiac transplant mortalities and 8 of 9 liver transplant mortalities. Renal patients on cyclosporine exhibited the lowest occurrence of bacteremias. Analysis by infection site indicated a prevalence of abdominal infections in liver patients, intrathoracic infections in heart patients, and urinary tract infections in renal patients. Pulmonary infections were less frequent in cyclosporine-treated renal patients than in Aza-treated patients (P < 0.05). Staphylococcal infections were significantly more prevalent in Aza patients than in all other transplant groups (P < 0.005), and systemic fungal infections were observed exclusively in the liver transplant group. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) shedding or seroconversion, or both, was documented in 78% of cyclosporine patients and 76% of Aza patients. Fifteen percent of cyclosporine patients developed symptomatic CMV infection. Serological evidence for Epstein Barr Virus infection was present in 20% of 65 cyclosporine patients evaluated, with three presenting symptoms and one progressing to lymphoma.

Amiodarone-Induced Pulmonary Mass and Novel Membranous Glomerulonephritis in Valvular Heart Disease: A Diagnostic Challenge and Emerging Complication. Amiodarone, an anti-arrhythmic medication for life-threatening tachycardia, is associated with diverse adverse effects. This report details an autopsy case of a patient with valvular heart disease who developed a 1.5 cm diameter lung mass and proteinuria (2.76 g/day) following prolonged amiodarone therapy. Radiologically, the lung mass was strongly suggestive of lung cancer on CT and positron emission tomography; however, histological examination revealed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates within alveolar walls and intra-alveolar foamy macrophages containing characteristic myelinoid bodies, consistent with an amiodarone-related lesion. Furthermore, the lung tissue exhibited uneven hemosiderin deposition, and abnormally tortuous capillaries were observed within the mass and in heavily hemosiderotic areas outside it. Renal findings included glomerular membrane spikes, significant podocyte swelling, and subepithelial deposits, some of which were large and hump-like. No evidence of autoimmune diseases, viral hepatitis, malignant neoplasms, or other conditions known to cause membranous glomerulonephritis was found. This case underscores the significant radiological difficulty in differentiating amiodarone-related pulmonary lesions from neoplasms and suggests that membranous glomerulonephritis may represent another potential complication of amiodarone treatment.

Pulmonary Mass and Unprecedented Membranous Glomerulonephritis Associated with Amiodarone in Valvular Heart Disease: Diagnostic Dilemma and Novel Observations. Amiodarone, an anti-arrhythmic agent utilized for critical tachyarrhythmias, has various documented adverse reactions. We present an autopsy case involving a patient with valvular heart disease who developed a 1.5 cm pulmonary mass and proteinuria (2.76 g/day) after extended amiodarone administration. Initial imaging via CT and PET strongly suggested lung cancer; however, histology demonstrated lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates in alveolar walls and intra-alveolar accumulation of foamy macrophages with characteristic myelinoid bodies, thereby identifying the lesion as amiodarone-related. Additionally, the lung tissue showed heterogeneous hemosiderin accumulation, with unusually tortuous capillaries present within the mass and in hyperpigmented lung regions beyond it. Renal biopsy revealed glomerular membrane spikes, pronounced podocyte swelling, and subepithelial deposits, some large and hump-shaped. Common causes of membranous glomerulonephritis, such as autoimmune diseases, viral hepatitis, or malignancies, were absent. This case emphasizes the potential for significant radiological ambiguity between amiodarone-induced pulmonary lesions and malignancy, and proposes that membranous glomerulonephritis could be a further complication of amiodarone therapy.

Atypical Amiodarone-Associated Pulmonary Mass and Unique Membranous Glomerulonephritis in a Valvular Heart Disease Patient: Diagnostic Complexity and Emerging Manifestations. Amiodarone, an anti-arrhythmic drug for severe tachycardia, is associated with a wide range of reported adverse effects. This report describes an autopsy case of a patient with valvular heart disease who developed a 1.5 cm diameter lung mass and proteinuria measuring 2.76 g/day following long-term amiodarone treatment. While CT and positron emission tomography highly suggested lung cancer, histological analysis confirmed the lesion was amiodarone-related, characterized by lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates within alveolar walls and intra-alveolar foamy macrophages containing distinctive myelinoid bodies. The lung tissue also exhibited patchy hemosiderin deposition and abnormally tortuous capillaries within the mass and in areas of intense hemosiderosis outside it. Kidney examination revealed glomeruli with membrane spikes, significant podocyte edema, and subepithelial deposits, some of which were large and hump-like. Crucially, no underlying autoimmune diseases, viral hepatitis, malignant neoplasms, or other known etiologies of membranous glomerulonephritis were identified. This case highlights the considerable diagnostic challenge radiologically in distinguishing amiodarone-related pulmonary lesions from neoplastic processes, and introduces membranous glomerulonephritis as a potentially newly recognized complication of amiodarone therapy.

Amiodarone-Induced Pulmonary Mass and Distinctive Membranous Glomerulonephritis in Valvular Heart Disease: Pathological Insights and Clinical Relevance. Amiodarone, an effective anti-arrhythmic for life-threatening tachyarrhythmias, is known for its diverse adverse effect profile. Presented is an autopsy case of a patient with valvular heart disease who developed a 1.5 cm lung mass and 2.76 g/day proteinuria following chronic amiodarone administration. The lung mass appeared highly suspicious for malignancy on CT and PET scans; however, histopathological examination revealed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates in the alveolar walls and intra-alveolar accumulation of foamy macrophages containing characteristic myelinoid bodies, thereby confirming an amiodarone-related etiology. Additionally, the pulmonary parenchyma displayed uneven hemosiderin deposits, and unusually tortuous capillaries were evident both within the mass and in adjacent heavily hemosiderotic lung regions. Renal evaluation identified glomeruli with membrane spikes, marked podocyte swelling, and subepithelial deposits, occasionally large and hump-like. Important negative findings included the absence of autoimmune diseases, viral hepatitis, malignant neoplasms, or other established causes of membranous glomerulonephritis. This case report underscores the profound radiological difficulty in distinguishing amiodarone-related pulmonary lesions from neoplastic processes and posits that membranous glomerulonephritis may represent a previously undescribed complication of amiodarone therapy.

P53 Inhibition's Dual Impact on Doxorubicin Cardiotoxicity: Acute Cardioprotection and Delayed Exacerbation. This study investigated the influence of p53 inhibition on both acute and late-stage cardiotoxicity induced by doxorubicin (DOX), a potent anti-cancer agent associated with cardiac damage, particularly in children. Juvenile MHC-CB7 mice, expressing dominant-interfering p53 in cardiomyocytes, and non-transgenic littermates received a cumulative dose of 25 mg/kg DOX over 5 weeks. At 1 week post-treatment (acute phase), MHC-CB7 mice displayed improved cardiac function and reduced cardiomyocyte apoptosis compared to controls. However, by 13 weeks post-treatment (late phase), a progressive decline in cardiac function and elevated rates of cardiomyocyte apoptosis were observed in MHC-CB7 mice relative to non-transgenic counterparts. Mechanistically, p53 inhibition in MHC-CB7 mice prevented transient DOX-induced STAT3 activation, which correlated with increased expression of DNA repair proteins Ku70 and Ku80. Furthermore, mice with cardiomyocyte-specific STAT3 deletion exhibited worsened cardiac function, heightened cardiomyocyte apoptosis, and greater Ku70 and Ku80 induction during the acute stage following DOX administration. These findings propose a model where a p53-dependent, STAT3-mediated cardioprotective pathway alleviates DOX-induced myocardial stress during active drug treatment. Consequently, p53 inhibition may confer cardioprotection during drug delivery but paradoxically amplify cardiotoxicity considerably after treatment cessation.

Differential Temporal Effects of P53 Inhibition on Doxorubicin-Induced Cardiac Dysfunction. Doxorubicin (DOX), an effective oncological therapy, carries a significant risk of cardiotoxicity, both acutely and in the long term, with pediatric patients being particularly vulnerable. This investigation assessed how inhibiting p53 influenced the acute versus late-stage manifestations of DOX-induced cardiotoxicity within a juvenile animal model. Two-week-old MHC-CB7 mice, engineered to express dominant-interfering p53 within their cardiomyocytes, alongside non-transgenic littermates, were administered DOX weekly for a total of 5 weeks, achieving a 25 mg/kg cumulative dose. In the acute phase, occurring one week subsequent to the final DOX dose, MHC-CB7 mice exhibited superior cardiac performance and reduced incidence of cardiomyocyte apoptosis compared to non-transgenic controls. Conversely, during the late phase, observed 13 weeks after the last DOX administration, MHC-CB7 mice demonstrated a progressive deterioration in cardiac function and elevated cardiomyocyte apoptosis rates relative to non-transgenic mice. P53 inhibition was found to abrogate the transient STAT3 activation triggered by DOX in MHC-CB7 mice, a phenomenon associated with an augmented induction of the DNA repair proteins Ku70 and Ku80. Additionally, genetically modified mice with a cardiomyocyte-restricted deletion of STAT3 displayed inferior cardiac function, increased cardiomyocyte apoptosis, and higher levels of Ku70 and Ku80 induction in response to acute-stage DOX treatment when compared with their control counterparts. The presented data support a mechanism where a cardioprotective p53-dependent pathway, operating via STAT3 activation, attenuates myocardial stress caused by DOX during its administration. Furthermore, these findings offer an explanation for the observed paradox where p53 inhibition can provide cardiac protection during drug treatment but exacerbate cardiotoxicity well after treatment discontinuation.

P53 Suppression Exacerbates Long-Term Anthracycline Cardiotoxicity. Doxorubicin (DOX) serves as an effective anticancer therapeutic agent, yet its use is complicated by both immediate and delayed cardiotoxicity, a concern particularly pronounced in pediatric populations who are susceptible to DOX-induced heart failure. The current study investigated the differential effects of p53 inhibition on acute versus late-stage doxorubicin cardiotoxicity in a juvenile mouse model. MHC-CB7 mice, 2 weeks of age, expressing a dominant-interfering p53 variant in cardiomyocytes, along with their non-transgenic littermates, received a total of 25 mg/kg DOX administered weekly over 5 weeks. One week after the final DOX treatment, corresponding to the acute stage, MHC-CB7 mice demonstrated enhanced cardiac function and diminished cardiomyocyte apoptosis rates compared to their non-transgenic controls. Unexpectedly, by 13 weeks post-DOX treatment, designated the late stage, MHC-CB7 mice showed a progressive decline in cardiac function and elevated levels of cardiomyocyte apoptosis when contrasted with non-transgenic mice. Mechanistically, p53 inhibition in MHC-CB7 mice abolished transient DOX-induced STAT3 activation, which was linked to an augmented expression of the DNA repair proteins Ku70 and Ku80. Furthermore, mice with a cardiomyocyte-specific deletion of STAT3 exhibited poorer cardiac function, increased cardiomyocyte apoptosis, and a higher induction of Ku70 and Ku80 in response to acute DOX treatment compared with control animals. These results substantiate a model in which a p53-dependent cardioprotective mechanism, mediated by STAT3 activation, alleviates myocardial stress induced by DOX during drug delivery. The data additionally provide insight into how p53 inhibition might confer cardioprotection during treatment but, paradoxically, intensify cardiotoxicity long after drug cessation.

The Role of P53 Inhibition in Modulating Doxorubicin Cardiotoxicity Progression. Doxorubicin (DOX) is a highly effective antineoplastic agent, yet its utility is constrained by both acute and insidious late-stage cardiotoxicity, with pediatric patients showing particular susceptibility to cardiac failure. This research investigated the influence of p53 inhibition on the development of acute versus late-stage DOX-induced cardiotoxicity in a juvenile animal model. Experiments involved two-week-old MHC-CB7 mice, which express dominant-interfering p53 specifically in cardiomyocytes, and their non-transgenic littermates. All animals received weekly DOX injections over 5 weeks, culminating in a 25 mg/kg cumulative dose. At one week following the final DOX administration (acute phase), MHC-CB7 mice demonstrated improved cardiac performance and reduced cardiomyocyte apoptosis in comparison to non-transgenic mice. However, by 13 weeks post-treatment (late phase), MHC-CB7 mice displayed a progressive decline in cardiac function and higher rates of cardiomyocyte apoptosis when juxtaposed with non-transgenic controls. P53 inhibition in MHC-CB7 mice was observed to block the transient activation of STAT3 induced by DOX, a phenomenon associated with an enhanced induction of the DNA repair proteins Ku70 and Ku80. Additionally, mice with cardiomyocyte-restricted STAT3 deletion exhibited poorer cardiac function, elevated cardiomyocyte apoptosis, and greater induction of Ku70 and Ku80 in response to DOX treatment during the acute stage compared to control animals. These findings support a conceptual framework wherein a p53-dependent cardioprotective pathway, facilitated by STAT3 activation, attenuates DOX-induced myocardial stress during the period of drug administration. Furthermore, these data propose a mechanism explaining how p53 inhibition might lead to cardioprotection during drug treatment, yet paradoxically intensify cardiotoxicity considerably after the cessation of therapy.

The Role of Alpha-Fluoro-Beta-Alanine in 5-Fluorouracil-Induced Cardiotoxicity. Cardiotoxicity represents an infrequent complication during 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy for malignancies. We present the case of a 70-year-old male who developed 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, characterized by an elevated serum concentration of alpha-fluoro-beta-alanine (FBAL). This patient, diagnosed with unresectable liver and lung metastases from colon cancer, had no prior cardiac history when referred for chemotherapy. Following admission, a continuous intravenous infusion of 5-FU (1000 mg/day) was administered, which coincided with the onset of precordial pain and a right bundle branch block, alongside a significantly high serum FBAL level of 1955 ng/ml. Both the chest pain and electrocardiographic abnormalities spontaneously resolved upon cessation of 5-FU. Given that the precordial pain was attributed to 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, 5-FU administration was discontinued. Subsequently, oral S-1, a 5-FU derivative, was initiated at 200 mg/day twice weekly. S-1 is known for its potent inhibitory effect on dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for metabolizing 5-FU into FBAL. Post-S-1 initiation, the serum FBAL concentration declined to 352 ng/ml, mirroring the level observed on the first day of S-1 treatment. No further cardiac symptoms were reported. Six months into S-1 therapy, the patient achieved a partial response. This case, supported by a literature review, indicates a potential link between FBAL and 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, suggesting S-1 as a potentially safe alternative for patients experiencing such adverse effects.

Alpha-Fluoro-Beta-Alanine and 5-Fluorouracil Cardiotoxicity: A Case Report and Therapeutic Implications. Cardiotoxicity is a rare but documented side effect associated with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) treatment for cancer. This report details the case of a 70-year-old man who experienced 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, notably accompanied by a markedly elevated serum level of alpha-fluoro-beta-alanine (FBAL). The patient, presenting with unresectable colon cancer metastasized to the liver and lung and no history of cardiac disease, was referred for chemotherapy. During a continuous intravenous infusion of 5-FU (1000 mg/day) post-admission, he developed precordial pain and a right bundle branch block, concurrent with a high serum FBAL concentration of 1955 ng/ml. Both cardiac symptoms and electrocardiographic changes spontaneously subsided after 5-FU discontinuation. Given the presumed causality of 5-FU in the observed cardiotoxicity, the drug was withdrawn. As an alternative, oral S-1, a 5-FU derivative known to strongly inhibit dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (the enzyme that catabolizes 5-FU to FBAL), was administered at 200 mg/day twice weekly. The patient's serum FBAL concentration subsequently decreased to 352 ng/ml, identical to its level on the initial day of S-1 administration. No subsequent cardiac manifestations were noted, and a partial response was achieved six months after starting S-1 therapy. This case experience, combined with a review of existing literature, implies a relationship between FBAL and 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, and further suggests that S-1 could be safely administered to patients with this complication.

Clinical Evidence for Alpha-Fluoro-Beta-Alanine Involvement in 5-Fluorouracil Cardiotoxicity and S-1 Management. The occurrence of cardiotoxicity during 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) treatment for malignancies is an infrequent adverse event. We present a clinical case involving a 70-year-old male with 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity who exhibited a significantly elevated serum concentration of alpha-fluoro-beta-alanine (FBAL). The patient, with unresectable colon cancer metastases to the liver and lung and no pre-existing cardiac conditions, was admitted for chemotherapy. Following the initiation of a continuous intravenous 5-FU infusion (1000 mg/day), he experienced precordial pain and a right bundle branch block, correlating with a high serum FBAL level of 1955 ng/ml. Both the chest pain and the electrocardiographic abnormalities resolved spontaneously upon cessation of 5-FU. Considering the causal link between 5-FU and the cardiac symptoms, 5-FU administration was halted. Oral S-1, a derivative of 5-FU, was then prescribed at 200 mg/day twice weekly. S-1 effectively inhibits dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for the metabolic degradation of 5-FU into FBAL. Subsequently, the serum FBAL concentration decreased to 352 ng/ml, matching the value recorded on the first day of S-1 treatment. The patient remained free of cardiac symptoms thereafter and achieved a partial response after six months of S-1 treatment. This patient's experience, corroborated by a literature review, proposes a connection between FBAL and 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity and suggests the safe use of S-1 in patients affected by this condition.

Investigating the Link Between Alpha-Fluoro-Beta-Alanine and 5-Fluorouracil Cardiotoxicity. Cardiotoxicity is an uncommon complication observed during the therapeutic administration of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) for various malignancies. This report details the clinical presentation of a 70-year-old man who developed 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, concurrent with a markedly elevated serum level of alpha-fluoro-beta-alanine (FBAL). The patient, without a history of cardiac disease, had unresectable colon cancer with liver and lung metastases and was admitted for chemotherapy. Following the initiation of a continuous intravenous infusion of 5-FU (1000 mg/day), he presented with precordial pain and right bundle branch block, coinciding with a high serum FBAL concentration of 1955 ng/ml. Both the precordial pain and the electrocardiographic changes spontaneously resolved upon discontinuation of 5-FU. As the patient's precordial pain was attributed to 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity, 5-FU treatment was ceased. Subsequently, an alternative regimen of oral S-1 (a 5-FU derivative) was commenced at 200 mg/day twice weekly, chosen for its potent inhibitory effect on dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for the degradation of 5-FU into FBAL. This intervention led to a decrease in serum FBAL concentration to 352 ng/ml, identical to the measurement on the initial day of S-1 administration. No further cardiac symptoms were observed, and the patient achieved a partial response within six months of starting S-1. Based on this case and a review of existing literature, a strong association between FBAL and 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity is implied, suggesting S-1 as a viable and safe therapeutic option for affected individuals.

The Impact of Combined Adriamycin and Whole Body Hyperthermia on Neoplastic and Healthy Tissues. A comparative analysis was conducted in a F344 rat model to assess the thermal potentiation of Adriamycin's antineoplastic efficacy and associated normal tissue adverse effects by whole body hyperthermia. Antitumor effects were evaluated through a tumor growth delay assay. Acute normal tissue toxicities, specifically leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, along with late toxicities such as myocardial and kidney injury, were assessed using functional/physiological and morphological methodologies, respectively. Whole body hyperthermia (120 minutes at 41.5C) augmented both the antineoplastic action of Adriamycin and its deleterious side effects. The thermal enhancement ratio (TER) for antineoplastic activity was determined to be 1.6. TERs for acute hematological alterations were estimated at 1.3, while those for late damage, identified through morphological cardiac and renal lesions, ranged from 2.4 to 4.3. Consequently, although whole body hyperthermia amplifies the Adriamycin-induced antitumor effect, it simultaneously elevates normal tissue toxicity, thereby diminishing the potential therapeutic benefit of this combined treatment approach.

An Evaluation of Adriamycin and Whole Body Hyperthermias Effects on Tumorous and Non-Tumorous Tissues. This study employed a F344 rat model to investigate the thermal augmentation of Adriamycin's antineoplastic activity and its accompanying normal tissue toxicities when combined with whole body hyperthermia. Antitumor activity was quantified via a tumor growth delay assay. Both immediate normal tissue toxicities, specifically leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, and delayed normal tissue toxicities, including myocardial and kidney impairment, were assessed using functional/physiological assays and morphological techniques, respectively. The application of whole body hyperthermia (120 minutes at 41.5C) intensified both the Adriamycin-mediated antitumor effects and its detrimental side effects. The calculated thermal enhancement ratio for antitumor activity stood at 1.6. For acute hematological changes, thermal enhancement ratios were estimated at 1.3, whereas for delayed damage, indicated by morphological cardiac and renal lesions, these ratios ranged from 2.4 to 4.3. The findings indicate that while whole body hyperthermia boosts the Adriamycin-induced antineoplastic effect, it concurrently increases normal tissue damage, consequently eroding the prospective therapeutic advantage of this dual-modality treatment.

Combined Adriamycin and Whole Body Hyperthermia: Effects on Neoplasms and Healthy Organs. The present investigation, utilizing a F344 rat model, examined the thermal potentiation of Adriamycin's antineoplastic efficacy and concomitant normal tissue toxicities by whole body hyperthermia. Assessment of antitumor activity was performed through a tumor growth delay assay. Acute normal tissue adverse effects, namely leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, and late normal tissue injuries, specifically myocardial and kidney damage, were evaluated using functional/physiological and morphological methods, respectively. Whole body hyperthermia (120 minutes at 41.5C) was found to augment both Adriamycin-induced antitumor activity and its undesirable side effects. The thermal enhancement ratio for antitumor efficacy was calculated as 1.6. For acute hematological alterations, thermal enhancement ratios were determined to be 1.3, while for late-onset damage, as evidenced by morphological cardiac and renal lesions, these ratios varied from 2.4 to 4.3. Thus, despite whole body hyperthermia amplifying the Adriamycin-mediated tumoricidal effect, it also exacerbates normal tissue harm, thereby diminishing the potential therapeutic gain achievable with this combined treatment strategy.

Synergistic and Adverse Effects of Adriamycin with Whole Body Hyperthermia on Malignant and Healthy Tissues. The thermal augmentation of Adriamycin's antineoplastic efficacy and its associated normal tissue toxicities by whole body hyperthermia were investigated in a F344 rat model. Antitumor efficacy was assessed using a tumor growth delay assay. Acute normal tissue adverse reactions, specifically leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, along with delayed normal tissue damage, including myocardial and kidney injury, were evaluated via functional/physiological assays and morphological techniques. Whole body hyperthermia, administered for 120 minutes at 41.5C, was observed to enhance both Adriamycin-mediated antitumor activity and its detrimental effects. A thermal enhancement ratio of 1.6 was computed for antitumor activity. Thermal enhancement ratios for acute hematological changes were estimated at 1.3, whereas for late damage, based on morphological cardiac and renal lesions, these ratios ranged from 2.4 to 4.3. Consequently, while whole body hyperthermia intensifies the Adriamycin-induced antineoplastic effect, it simultaneously augments normal tissue toxicity, thereby compromising the prospective therapeutic benefit of the combined modality.

5-Fluorouracil Cardiotoxicity: Coronary Spasm and Calcium Antagonists. This report details a case of spontaneous angina in a patient receiving 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) for colon carcinoma with liver metastasis, experiencing chest pain post-administration. The clinical and electrocardiographic progression mirrored Prinzmetal's angina, with rapid symptom resolution following nifedipine. These observations indicate that 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity may result from coronary spasm, suggesting the potential utility of calcium antagonists for its prevention or management.

Clinical Aspects and Management of 5-Fluorouracil Cardiotoxicity. A case of spontaneous angina following 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) administration is presented, involving a patient with colon carcinoma and liver metastasis who developed chest pain. The clinical and electrocardiographic profile resembled Prinzmetal's angina, and the chest pain was promptly alleviated by nifedipine. This evidence implies that coronary spasm could underlie 5-FU cardiotoxicity, and calcium channel blockers might serve as a viable option for its prevention or treatment.

5-Fluorouracil-Induced Cardiac Toxicity: Etiology and Therapeutic Implications. We describe a case of spontaneous angina where a patient with colon carcinoma and liver metastasis developed chest pain after receiving 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). The clinical and electrocardiographic findings were consistent with Prinzmetal's angina, and the chest pain was effectively and swiftly resolved by nifedipine. These findings propose that 5-FU cardiotoxicity is potentially mediated by coronary spasm, and calcium antagonists could be valuable in preventing or treating this adverse effect.

A Case Study of 5-Fluorouracil-Associated Cardiotoxicity. A patient diagnosed with colon carcinoma and liver metastasis experienced chest pain, consistent with spontaneous angina, following the administration of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). The clinical and electrocardiographic presentation closely resembled Prinzmetal's angina, with nifedipine leading to a rapid cessation of the chest pain. The data from this case suggest that 5-FU-induced cardiotoxicity may stem from coronary spasm, and consequently, calcium antagonists could potentially be employed for its prophylaxis or therapy.

Contrast-Induced Nephropathy Rates in Inpatient Oncology Populations. This study aimed to ascertain the prevalence and associated factors of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) among hospitalized cancer patients. Ninety adult patients were included, excluding those with existing acute renal failure risk factors. Serum creatinine (Cr) levels were measured the day prior to contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) and daily for three subsequent days. CIN was defined by a Cr increase of at least 0.5 mg/dl or a rise of 25% or more from baseline. The investigation revealed CIN in 18 out of 90 (20%) patients. The condition was observed in 25.5% of chemotherapy recipients versus 11% of non-chemotherapy recipients (P = 0.1). A significantly higher incidence of CIN occurred when CT was performed within 45 days of the last chemotherapy session (P = 0.005), which was also identified as an independent risk factor (P = 0.017). Furthermore, CIN was significantly more frequent following bevacizumab/irinotecan treatment (P = 0.021) and in patients with hypertension (P = 0.044). In conclusion, CIN affected 20% of hospitalized oncological patients undergoing CT. Its development was 4.5 times more frequent in cancer patients recently treated with chemotherapy. Hypertension and the bevacizumab/irinotecan regimen appear to be supplementary risk factors for CIN.

Risk Factors and Frequency of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy in Hospitalized Cancer Patients. The objective of this research was to determine the occurrence rate of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) and potential contributing factors in hospitalized patients diagnosed with cancer. A cohort of ninety adult patients was recruited, with individuals exhibiting risk factors for acute renal failure being excluded. Blood samples, specifically for serum creatinine (Cr), were collected on the day preceding contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) and then daily over the subsequent three-day period. CIN was diagnosed if serum Cr increased by 0.5 mg/dl or more, or if it elevated by 25% or more above baseline. An analysis of relationships between CIN and possible risk factors was conducted. Results indicated CIN in 18 of the 90 patients (20%). It developed in 25.5% of patients who received chemotherapy and in 11% of those who did not (P = 0.1). CIN incidence was greater in patients undergoing CT within 45 days after their most recent chemotherapy (P = 0.005), which was also identified as an independent predictor (P = 0.017). A notable increase in CIN was observed in patients treated with bevacizumab/irinotecan (P = 0.021) and in those with hypertension (P = 0.044). The study concluded that CIN affects 20% of hospitalized oncological patients post-CT. It occurred 4.5 times more often in cancer patients who had recently undergone chemotherapy. Hypertension and the combination of bevacizumab/irinotecan represent potential additional risk factors for CIN.

Evaluation of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy Occurrence Among Inpatient Oncology Cases. This study sought to evaluate the frequency and identify possible determinants of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in patients with cancer admitted to the hospital. Ninety adult participants were enrolled, excluding those with established risk factors for acute renal failure. Serum creatinine (Cr) measurements were taken on the day preceding contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) and then consecutively for three days following the procedure. CIN was operationally defined as a serum Cr increase of at least 0.5 mg/dl, or an elevation of Cr by 25% or more above the baseline value. An investigation into the correlations between CIN and potential risk factors was performed. The findings showed that CIN manifested in 18 out of 90 (20%) patients. Among patients receiving chemotherapy, CIN developed in 25.5%, compared to 11% in those who did not (P = 0.1). CIN was observed with significantly higher frequency in patients who underwent CT within 45 days after their final chemotherapy dose (P = 0.005); this factor also emerged as an independent risk determinant (P = 0.017). Furthermore, CIN was markedly more prevalent after bevacizumab/irinotecan therapy (P = 0.021) and in patients suffering from hypertension (P = 0.044). In summary, the incidence of CIN post-CT in hospitalized oncological patients was 20%. CIN developed 4.5 times more often in cancer patients who had recently completed chemotherapy. Hypertension and the bevacizumab/irinotecan regimen may serve as supplementary risk factors for CIN.

Characterizing Contrast-Induced Nephropathy in Hospitalized Oncology Patients. This study's primary aims were to ascertain the frequency of and identify variables associated with contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in hospitalized individuals with cancer. Ninety adult participants were recruited, systematically excluding those with pre-existing risk factors for acute renal failure. Blood samples, specifically for serum creatinine (Cr), were drawn the day before contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) and then daily for three days subsequently. CIN was stipulated as either a serum Cr increase of 0.5 mg/dl or greater, or a Cr elevation of 25% or more above baseline. The potential links between CIN and various risk factors were thoroughly investigated. The findings indicated CIN in 18 of 90 (20%) participants. CIN occurred in 25.5% of patients undergoing chemotherapy versus 11% of those not receiving it (P = 0.1). A higher rate of CIN was observed in patients who had CT within 45 days post-last chemotherapy (P = 0.005), which was also recognized as an independent risk factor (P = 0.017). Furthermore, CIN was significantly more pronounced after bevacizumab/irinotecan treatment (P = 0.021) and in individuals with hypertension (P = 0.044). In conclusion, the prevalence of CIN following CT in hospitalized oncological patients was 20%. CIN developed 4.5 times more frequently in cancer patients who had recently undergone chemotherapy. Hypertension and the bevacizumab/irinotecan combination are potentially additional risk factors for CIN development.

Anemia in Hepatitis C Virus Patients: Characterization and Therapeutic Approaches. Chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is associated with progression to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage liver disease. The gold standard for HCV treatment is combination therapy involving pegylated interferon and ribavirin. This regimen achieves sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in approximately 50% of individuals but can induce a dose-limiting hemolytic anemia. The primary cause of hemoglobin reduction is ribavirin-mediated hemolysis, and this anemia poses significant challenges, particularly for HCV patients with coexisting renal or cardiovascular conditions. Anemia generally elevates the risk of morbidity and mortality, alongside detrimental effects on cognitive function and quality of life. While ribavirin-associated anemia can be mitigated by dose reduction or cessation, such strategies adversely impact treatment outcomes by markedly lowering SVR rates. Although recombinant human erythropoietin has been employed to address ribavirin-induced anemia, it carries other potential drawbacks. Viramidine, a ribavirin prodrug specifically targeting the liver, offers the prospect of maintaining ribavirin's virologic effectiveness while simultaneously decreasing the incidence of hemolytic anemia in chronic hepatitis C patients.

Clinical Significance and Management Strategies for Anemia in Hepatitis C Virus Infection. Hepatitis C virus (HCV) chronic infection can advance to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage hepatic disease. The most effective current treatment for HCV infection utilizes a combination of pegylated interferon and ribavirin. Despite achieving sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in about half of all patients, this regimen may lead to a hemolytic anemia that restricts dosage. Hemoglobin levels primarily decline due to ribavirin-induced hemolysis, and this anemic state is a concern for patients with HCV, particularly those also suffering from renal or cardiovascular comorbidities. Broadly, anemia contributes to an increased risk of morbidity and mortality, and can negatively affect cerebral performance and overall quality of life. Although anemia linked to ribavirin can be reversed through dosage reduction or discontinuation, this approach compromises treatment success by substantially lowering SVR rates. Recombinant human erythropoietin has been used for ribavirin-associated anemia but presents its own disadvantages. Viramidine, a prodrug of ribavirin designed to target the liver, shows potential to sustain the antiviral efficacy of ribavirin while reducing the likelihood of hemolytic anemia in individuals with chronic hepatitis C.

Understanding and Addressing Anemia in Hepatitis C Virus-Infected Individuals. Persistent infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) can progress to severe conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and terminal liver disease. The optimal current therapy for HCV involves co-administration of pegylated interferon and ribavirin. While this dual therapy yields sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in approximately 50% of subjects, it can precipitate a dose-limiting hemolytic anemia. The primary mechanism for reduced hemoglobin concentration is ribavirin-induced hemolysis, and this anemia represents a clinical challenge for HCV-infected patients, especially those with concurrent renal or cardiovascular impairments. Anemia, in general, is associated with heightened risks of morbidity and mortality, and can exert detrimental effects on brain function and patient quality of life. Though ribavirin-related anemia is reversible via dose modification or cessation, this strategy compromises treatment outcomes by significantly diminishing SVR rates. The use of recombinant human erythropoietin to manage ribavirin-associated anemia is an option but possesses other drawbacks. Viramidine, a liver-specific prodrug of ribavirin, offers the potential to preserve ribavirin's virologic efficacy while simultaneously mitigating the risk of hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hepatitis C.

Clinical Aspects and Management of Anemia in Hepatitis C Virus Infection. Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) carries a risk of progression to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage liver disease. The current leading therapeutic approach for HCV infection consists of combination therapy with pegylated interferon and ribavirin. This regimen achieves sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in about half of treated individuals, yet it is frequently linked to a potentially dose-limiting hemolytic anemia. The decline in hemoglobin levels is predominantly a consequence of ribavirin-induced hemolysis, and this anemia can pose substantial difficulties for patients with HCV infection, particularly if they have comorbid renal or cardiovascular conditions. Generally, anemia heightens the potential for morbidity and mortality and can negatively impact cognitive abilities and quality of daily living. While ribavirin-induced anemia can be resolved by reducing or stopping the dose, this tactic undermines favorable outcomes by considerably decreasing SVR rates. Recombinant human erythropoietin has been employed to address ribavirin-related anemia, but it introduces other potential disadvantages. Viramidine, a prodrug of ribavirin designed for hepatic targeting, holds promise for maintaining the virologic effectiveness of ribavirin while simultaneously lowering the incidence of hemolytic anemia in individuals with chronic hepatitis C.

Doxorubicin's Efficacy and Systemic Toxicities in LOU/M/WSL Rats with IgM Solid Immunocytoma. The antitumor activity, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity of doxorubicin were investigated in LOU/M/WSL inbred rats harboring a transplantable solid IgM immunocytoma. Animals bearing tumors, which measured 15.8 +/- 3.3 mm in diameter, received intravenous doxorubicin daily for five days, followed by weekly injections for seven weeks, covering a dose range of 0.015-4.0 mg/kg body weight. Tumor regression was evident at 0.5 mg doxorubicin/kg, with complete tumor eradication achieved at 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg. Histological examination revealed Grade III cardiotoxicity exclusively at the 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg dose. Renal damage, observable via light microscopy, manifested at doses exceeding 0.5 mg doxorubicin/kg, leading to albuminuria and severely reduced serum albumin levels. Specifically, at 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg, serum albumin levels decreased from 33.6 +/- 4.1 to 1.5 +/- 0.5 g/liter. Concurrent observations included ascites and hydrothorax. Parallel experiments in non-tumor-bearing rats showed no significant differences in these toxicities. In conclusion, the antitumor efficacy, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity of doxorubicin were concurrently assessed in the LOU/M/WSL rat model. Renal damage-induced albuminuria, causing profound reductions in serum albumin, suggested that ascites and hydrothorax were not necessarily sequelae of the observed cardiomyopathy.

Evaluation of Doxorubicin's Antineoplastic Action, Cardiac, and Renal Toxicity in the IgM Immunocytoma-Afflicted LOU/M/WSL Rat. This study examined doxorubicin's antineoplastic efficacy, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity in LOU/M/WSL inbred rats, each inoculated with a solid IgM immunocytoma. Tumor-bearing animals, with an average tumor diameter of 15.8 +/- 3.3 mm, underwent intravenous doxorubicin treatment, administered over 5 consecutive days, then weekly for 7 weeks (dose range: 0.015-4.0 mg/kg body wt). A doxorubicin dose of 0.5 mg/kg induced tumor regression, while a 1.0 mg/kg dose resulted in complete tumor disappearance. Histopathologic evidence of cardiotoxicity, graded as III, was exclusively noted at the 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg dose. Light microscopic signs of kidney injury emerged at doxorubicin doses above 0.5 mg/kg, manifesting as albuminuria and markedly low serum albumin concentrations. In the 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg treatment group, serum albumin levels declined from 33.6 +/- 4.1 to 1.5 +/- 0.5 g/liter. Simultaneously, ascites and hydrothorax were observed. Identical experiments conducted on rats without tumors demonstrated no substantial variations in these effects. In summary, doxorubicin's antitumor effects, cardiac, and renal toxicities were concurrently investigated in the LOU/M/WSL rat model. The severe reduction in serum albumin caused by renal damage-induced albuminuria indicated that ascites and hydrothorax were not solely attributable to the observed cardiomyopathy.

Assessment of Doxorubicin's Therapeutic Efficacy and Organ Toxicities in LOU/M/WSL Rats Bearing IgM Solid Immunocytomas. The therapeutic efficacy against tumors, along with cardiotoxicity and nephrotoxicity, induced by doxorubicin, was investigated in LOU/M/WSL inbred rats bearing a transplantable solid IgM immunocytoma. These animals, with an initial tumor diameter of 15.8 +/- 3.3 mm, received doxorubicin via intravenous injections for 5 consecutive days, followed by a weekly injection for 7 weeks, across a dose spectrum of 0.015-4.0 mg/kg body wt. Tumor regression was evident following treatment with 0.5 mg doxorubicin/kg, and complete tumor resolution was achieved with 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg. Grade III cardiotoxicity, confirmed histologically, occurred solely at the 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg dose. Renal damage, identified through light microscopy, became apparent at doxorubicin doses exceeding 0.5 mg/kg, leading to albuminuria and significantly diminished serum albumin levels. For rats administered 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg, serum albumin levels dramatically fell from 33.6 +/- 4.1 to 1.5 +/- 0.5 g/liter. Concurrently, ascites and hydrothorax were noted. Control experiments involving non-tumor-bearing rats showed no major discrepancies in these findings. Overall, the antitumor activity, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity of doxorubicin were simultaneously evaluated in the LOU/M/WSL rat model. The albuminuria resulting from renal damage, causing extremely low serum albumin, indicated that ascites and hydrothorax were not necessarily a direct consequence of the observed cardiomyopathy.

Investigating Doxorubicin's Antitumor, Cardiotoxic, and Nephrotoxic Effects in the LOU/M/WSL Rat Model with IgM Solid Immunocytoma. A study was conducted to ascertain the antitumor activity, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity of doxorubicin in LOU/M/WSL inbred rats, which were all engrafted with a transplantable solid IgM immunocytoma. Animals presenting with tumors (average diameter of 15.8 +/- 3.3 mm) received doxorubicin through intravenous injections, initially for 5 consecutive days, then weekly for 7 weeks, with doses ranging from 0.015 to 4.0 mg/kg body weight. Tumor regression was observed with a doxorubicin dose of 0.5 mg/kg, and complete tumor disappearance was achieved at 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg. Histological signs of cardiotoxicity, graded as III, were exclusively evident at the 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg dose. Light microscopic examination revealed evidence of renal damage at doses above 0.5 mg doxorubicin/kg, culminating in albuminuria and extremely low serum albumin levels. In the cohort treated with 1.0 mg doxorubicin/kg, a reduction in serum albumin levels from 33.6 +/- 4.1 to 1.5 +/- 0.5 g/liter was recorded. Ascites and hydrothorax were concurrently identified. Identical experiments performed on rats without tumors did not reveal significant differences in these adverse effects. The simultaneous study in LOU/M/WSL rats allowed for a comprehensive understanding of doxorubicin's antitumor activity, cardiotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. It was concluded that albuminuria, stemming from renal damage and resulting in profoundly low serum albumin levels, meant that ascites and hydrothorax were not necessarily due to the observed cardiomyopathy.
